title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-Driven Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of AI-driven NLP models in high-stakes applications has raised concerns about their interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable AI-driven NLP. Our HAN model integrates a self-attention mechanism with a hierarchical graph neural network to capture complex contextual relationships in input texts. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results in sentiment analysis and question answering while providing visualizable attention weights that facilitate model interpretability.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-Scale Image Datasets using Deep Embeddings
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in image analysis, but its scalability is limited by the curse of dimensionality. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'DeepHier', which leverages deep embeddings to efficiently cluster large-scale image datasets. We introduce a hierarchical clustering algorithm that iteratively applies a deep neural network to reduce the dimensionality of the data, enabling the clustering of millions of images. Experimental results on the ImageNet dataset demonstrate that DeepHier achieves state-of-the-art clustering performance while reducing computational complexity by up to 90% compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Adaptive Relation Attention for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial component in question answering (QA) systems. However, existing KGE methods often neglect the importance of relation attention in capturing complex semantic relationships. This paper proposes a novel KGE framework, 'ARA-KGE', which adaptively learns relation attention weights based on the question context. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant relations and entities, leading to improved QA performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of ARA-KGE in outperforming state-of-the-art KGE methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive solutions. This paper proposes a novel decentralized approach, 'GNN-TA', that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to allocate tasks to agents in a distributed manner. We model the agent-task interaction as a graph and use GNNs to learn a representation of the agents' capabilities and task requirements. Our approach enables agents to make local decisions while ensuring global optimality, and we demonstrate its effectiveness in simulations of a disaster response scenario.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Optimizing query execution plans is crucial for efficient data retrieval in distributed relational databases. Traditional cost-based optimization techniques often fall short in handling complex query patterns and dynamic workloads. This paper presents RLOpt, a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select optimal plans. RLOpt utilizes a deep Q-network to learn from query execution histories and explores the vast plan space to minimize latency and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database demonstrate that RLOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 35% in terms of query response time.

title: Exploring Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate emotion recognition is crucial in human-computer interaction (HCI) for developing empathetic systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HAT-Emo', for multi-modal emotion recognition. HAT-Emo integrates audio, visual, and textual features using attention mechanisms at multiple levels, capturing both local and global dependencies. Experimental results on the SEMAINE and EmoReact datasets demonstrate that HAT-Emo outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from facial expressions, speech, and text. Our approach enables the development of more effective affective computing systems for HCI applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient resource allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a novel framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to coordinate agents in complex, dynamic environments. We introduce a hierarchical, graph-structured architecture that learns to allocate resources and schedule tasks among agents, while minimizing conflicts and maximizing overall system performance. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing energy costs and improving grid stability compared to traditional optimization methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents in complex environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper introduces a novel approach using hierarchical graph attention networks (HGAT) to learn effective coordination strategies. Our method represents agents and their interactions as a hierarchical graph, which is processed by a stack of graph attention layers to produce a coordinated action policy. Experimental results demonstrate that HGAT outperforms existing approaches in several multi-agent coordination tasks, including robot soccer and traffic management.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging problem due to the complex interplay between data distribution, query patterns, and system resources. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution time. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world graph dataset shows that the RL-based approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) tasks require models to jointly process visual and textual inputs. Existing approaches often concatenate or fuse features using simple concatenation or element-wise multiplication, neglecting the complex relationships between modalities. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on relevant regions in images and words in questions, enabling more effective multi-modal fusion. Our experiments on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 3.2% absolute improvement in accuracy while reducing computational costs by 25%

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We model the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process and develop a deep Q-network-based algorithm to learn an optimal query plan. Our approach takes into account various factors, including data distribution, network latency, and resource availability. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that our approach outperforms traditional rule-based optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Heterogeneous Transfer Learning for Multi-Domain Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a fundamental task in natural language processing, but existing models often struggle to generalize across diverse domains and datasets. This paper proposes a novel heterogeneous transfer learning framework, 'HTL- Sent', which leverages the strengths of multiple pre-trained models and knowledge graphs to adapt to new domains. Our approach combines adversarial domain adaptation with graph-based attention to selectively transfer knowledge from multiple sources. Experimental results on four benchmark datasets demonstrate that HTL-Sent outperforms state-of-the-art models in multi-domain sentiment analysis, achieving an average improvement of 4.5% in accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: As autonomous agents become increasingly prevalent in complex systems, understanding their decision-making processes is crucial. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for explainable multi-agent decision-making. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant environmental cues and agent interactions, generating interpretable rationales for joint action selection. Experimental results on a real-world traffic management scenario demonstrate improved explainability and decision quality compared to existing reinforcement learning methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) has emerged as a powerful framework for coordinating multi-agent systems. However, existing DCOP approaches often rely on centralized coordination or assume uniform communication topologies. This paper presents a novel, decentralized DCOP algorithm, 'Distributed Optimal Assignment' (DOA), which leverages local search and asynchronous communication to efficiently allocate tasks among agents. We demonstrate DOA's scalability and robustness in simulated domains, including disaster response and supply chain management, and provide theoretical guarantees on its convergence properties.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to the lack of global knowledge and communication constraints. This paper proposes a novel approach using reinforcement learning to learn decentralized task allocation policies. We formulate the task allocation problem as a Markov decision process and design a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn from their local interactions. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient and adaptive task allocation compared to traditional optimization-based methods.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has created a pressing need for efficient resource allocation mechanisms. This paper presents a novel decentralized approach based on multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents negotiate and allocate resources in a distributed manner. We propose a hybrid algorithm that combines game-theoretic and machine learning techniques to optimize resource utilization and minimize latency in IoT networks. Experimental results on a simulated IoT testbed demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in adapting to dynamic network conditions and improving overall system performance.

title: Scalable Incremental View Maintenance for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for timely business intelligence. However, maintaining materialized views in the presence of high-volume updates poses significant scalability challenges. This paper presents 'RTView', a novel incremental view maintenance approach that leverages a combination of data striding, partial aggregation, and parallel processing to achieve near real-time view refresh. We demonstrate RTView's effectiveness through extensive experiments on a large-scale data warehousing benchmark, showing orders-of-magnitude performance improvements over conventional view maintenance techniques.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Contextualized Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, aiming to mitigate the vocabulary mismatch between user queries and relevant documents. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepCE', which leverages deep contextualized embeddings to capture semantic relationships between words. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query expansion and relevance ranking, enabling the model to learn context-aware representations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepCE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems often struggle with capturing nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HNRM-QE', which leverages query expansion to improve retrieval accuracy. By incorporating a dense passage retriever and a reranker with a hierarchical attention mechanism, HNRM-QE achieves state-of-the-art results on several benchmark datasets. We demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms existing neural ranking models, especially for complex, open-domain queries.

title: Scalable Deep Retrieval for Dense Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has emerged as a powerful technique for open-domain question answering, but its scalability remains a significant bottleneck. We propose a novel deep retrieval framework, 'DeepScale', which leverages a hierarchical representation of passages to efficiently prune the search space. By combining a sparse retriever with a dense reranker, we achieve a 3x speedup in retrieval time while maintaining state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. We also introduce a new evaluation metric, 'Recall@k', to better capture the efficacy of retrieval models in open-domain question answering.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Thompson Sampling
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the exploration-exploitation dilemma in multi-agent systems, where agents must balance individual learning with collective goal achievement. We propose a novel algorithm, Coordinated Thompson Sampling (CTS), which integrates Thompson sampling with a coordination mechanism that adaptively adjusts exploration rates based on agent interactions. CTS is shown to outperform state-of-the-art methods in simulated robotic search and rescue scenarios, achieving higher cumulative rewards and faster convergence to optimal policies. Theoretical analysis provides insights into the algorithm's performance guarantees and convergence rates.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Dynamic Social Networks
paper_abstract: Dynamic social networks exhibit complex relationships between nodes, making node classification challenging. We propose Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework that captures multi-scale dependencies and temporal dynamics in these networks. HGAT leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and timestamps, enabling accurate classification of nodes. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in node classification, outperforming state-of-the-art graph neural network models.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have revolutionized numerous applications, but their performance heavily relies on careful hyperparameter tuning. Bayesian optimization has emerged as a popular approach for hyperparameter tuning, but its high computational cost limits its applicability. This paper proposes a novel, efficient Bayesian optimization framework, 'HyperBO', which leverages a hierarchical surrogate model to reduce the number of expensive neural network evaluations. We demonstrate HyperBO's effectiveness on various benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results while reducing the tuning time by up to 75% compared to existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained popularity in recent years, but existing methods often rely on simplistic graph structures or ignore complex user-item relationships. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), a novel framework that leverages hierarchical graph attention mechanisms to capture multi-scale user-item interactions. HGAT integrates item-category relationships, user preferences, and item features into a unified graph, enabling Explainable Recommendation Systems (ERS) to provide transparent and accurate recommendations. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and interpretability.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but struggle to scale to large, multi-relational graphs. We propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and relations. Our approach combines node-level attention with hierarchical graph pooling to capture complex dependencies between entities. Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods in terms of link prediction and entity classification, while reducing computational costs by up to 50%

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query processing in DDS remains a challenging problem due to the complex interplay between data distribution, query patterns, and system resources. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query processing in DDS. We design an RL agent that learns to optimize query plans based on feedback from the system, and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving query performance and reducing resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30%.

title: Boosting Retrieval Efficiency with Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems struggle to efficiently retrieve relevant documents from large corpora, particularly when dealing with short queries. This paper introduces HierDoc, a novel document representation technique that leverages hierarchical embeddings to capture both local and global semantic relationships. By encoding documents as hierarchical compositions of sentence and paragraph embeddings, HierDoc enables more effective pruning of irrelevant documents and reduces the number of required similarity computations. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierDoc outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods in terms of mean average precision and query throughput.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a crucial task in human-computer interaction. While deep learning models have achieved high accuracy, they often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. We demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods on the CMU-MOSEI dataset and provide visualizations to illustrate the attention patterns, enabling explainable emotion recognition.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem that requires efficient coordination among agents. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. Our approach, called 'AgentQL', uses a multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to learn a decentralized policy that adapts to changing task requirements and agent capabilities. Experiments on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that AgentQL outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization. We also analyze the robustness of our approach under varying levels of communication noise and agent failures.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Semantic Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promising results in capturing semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, they often struggle with out-of-vocabulary words and limited domain knowledge. This paper proposes a novel query expansion technique, 'SemEx', which leverages pre-trained semantic embeddings to generate contextualized expansion terms. We demonstrate that SemEx can improve the retrieval performance of neural search engines by up to 15% on several benchmark datasets, while reducing the computational overhead by 30% compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation using Distributed Coalition Formation among Heterogeneous Agents
paper_abstract: In this paper, we present a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages distributed coalition formation among heterogeneous agents. Our approach, called AgentCoal, enables agents to form coalitions based on their capabilities, preferences, and task requirements. We propose a novel distributed algorithm that utilizes a combination of graph theory and game-theoretic concepts to facilitate coalition formation and task assignment. Experimental results demonstrate that AgentCoal outperforms traditional centralized approaches in terms of task completion time, agent satisfaction, and system adaptability in dynamic environments.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Multi-Robot Systems
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple autonomous robots to achieve complex tasks is a fundamental challenge in robotics. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HORSE', that enables effective coordination among agents in multi-robot systems. HORSE decomposes the coordination problem into two levels: high-level task allocation and low-level motion planning. We demonstrate that HORSE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in simulations of a warehouse automation scenario, achieving higher task completion rates and reduced collisions. Our approach has significant implications for real-world applications such as search and rescue, warehouse logistics, and environmental monitoring.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in document retrieval, but existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper presents a neural query expansion approach, 'NQE', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to learn query-document representations. NQE combines keyword extraction, semantic role labeling, and contextualized embeddings to generate expanded queries that better capture user intent. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their usability for older adults is limited due to cognitive and physical impairments. This paper presents a novel multimodal interaction framework for designing inclusive voice assistants. Our approach integrates speech, gesture, and gaze recognition to provide intuitive and adaptive interfaces for older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65+ and found significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional voice-only interfaces. Our findings inform the development of accessible and empowered smart home experiences for older adults.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Uncertainty
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents to maximize overall efficiency. However, in real-world scenarios, agents often possess uncertain information about task requirements and capabilities. This paper presents a decentralized coalition formation approach that enables agents to form coalitions and allocate tasks while accounting for uncertainty. Our method leverages Bayesian learning to update agent beliefs and incorporates a novel uncertainty-aware protocol for coalition formation. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task allocation efficiency and robustness under uncertainty.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranking for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in improving the retrieval performance of ad-hoc search systems. This paper proposes a novel neural re-ranking approach, 'NeuQE', which leverages a transformer-based architecture to model the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. We demonstrate that NeuQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, such as Rocchio and RM3, by effectively capturing nuanced context-dependent relationships. Furthermore, we show that NeuQE can be easily integrated into existing retrieval systems, yielding significant improvements in mean average precision and NDCG@10.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Adaptive Relation Attention
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial technique for various AI applications. However, existing KGE methods often suffer from inefficient modeling of complex relations. This paper proposes a novel adaptive relation attention mechanism, 'ARA-KGE', which dynamically adjusts attention weights based on the relational context. We demonstrate that ARA-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods on benchmark datasets, including WN18RR and FB15k-237, with significant improvements in both link prediction and entity disambiguation tasks.

title: Optimizing Join Order Selection for Distributed Database Queries using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Join order selection is a critical optimization problem in distributed database query processing. This paper proposes a novel approach to join order selection using reinforcement learning. We formulate the problem as a Markov Decision Process and employ a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy for join ordering. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional heuristics and state-of-the-art optimization techniques, achieving up to 30% reduction in query execution time.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MAS) is a challenging problem, especially when agents have different capabilities, goals, and communication constraints. This paper proposes a novel framework that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) and graph attention to coordinate MAS. Our approach, called Graph-RL-MAS, represents the agent interactions as a graph and uses attention mechanisms to focus on the most critical agents and their relationships. We evaluate Graph-RL-MAS on a variety of MAS scenarios, including robotic search and rescue, and demonstrate improved coordination and task completion rates compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback onGesture Recognition Accuracy in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition is a crucial aspect of virtual reality (VR) systems, but accuracy can be affected by various factors, including sensory feedback. This study investigates the role of haptic feedback in enhancing gesture recognition accuracy in VR environments. We designed an experiment using a custom-built VR system with integrated haptic feedback and collected data from 30 participants performing a series of gestures. Our results show that the inclusion of haptic feedback significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy, especially for complex gestures. We also identify key factors influencing the effectiveness of haptic feedback, including feedback latency and gesture speed.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used in modern data analytics, but optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed settings. Our method, 'RL-OPT', uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy for selecting efficient query plans based on the database schema, data distribution, and query workload. We evaluate RL-OPT on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and resource utilization compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Icon Design on Mobile App Engagement
paper_abstract: Personalized icon design has gained popularity as a means to enhance user experience in mobile apps. However, its impact on user engagement remains understudied. This paper presents a large-scale study examining the effect of personalized icon design on mobile app engagement metrics, including session duration, interaction frequency, and abandonment rates. We developed a novel icon personalization framework that incorporates user behavior, preferences, and visual aesthetics. Our results show that personalized icon design significantly improves engagement metrics, particularly among users with high novelty-seeking tendencies. We discuss the implications of our findings for HCI practitioners and researchers.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents an empirical study on designing gestural interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of user studies to identify the challenges and opportunities of using gesture-based interfaces with this population. Our findings suggest that gesture recognition accuracy can be improved by incorporating machine learning-based models that adapt to individual motor abilities and cognitive deficits. We propose a novel framework, ' GestureEase', which integrates personalized gesture recognition, error correction, and feedback mechanisms to enhance the user experience. Our results show that GestureEase significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional interface designs.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, particularly in heterogeneous information networks (HINs) where node types and relationships vary. Existing methods often ignore the rich contextual information in HINs, leading to suboptimal query expansion. We propose a novel context-aware query expansion framework, CAQE, which leverages node embeddings and meta-paths to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and entities in the HIN. CAQE adaptively selects the most relevant expansion terms based on the query context, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. Experimental evaluations on real-world HIN datasets demonstrate the superiority of CAQE over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Designing Conversational Interfaces for Inclusive Voice Assistants
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interaction modalities can be inaccessible to individuals with speech or language disabilities. This paper presents a novel framework for designing conversational interfaces that are more inclusive and accommodating of diverse user needs. We propose a set of guidelines for voice assistant designers, focusing on multimodal input support, adaptive difficulty adjustment, and personalized feedback mechanisms. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that our approach improves the usability and satisfaction of voice assistants for users with disabilities, while also enhancing overall system efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in such systems. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using machine learning techniques. We develop a predictive model that learns from historical query execution times and optimizes query plans based on the predicted execution costs. Our approach is demonstrated to achieve significant performance improvements over traditional query optimization methods in a real-world distributed database system.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial task in various AI applications. However, existing methods often neglect the hierarchical structure inherent in many knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel KGE approach, 'HierAtt', which leverages hierarchical attention networks to capture both local and global relationships between entities. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierAtt outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of link prediction and entity classification tasks, while reducing the number of required model parameters.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving relevant documents from a massive, geographically dispersed corpus. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-DSE', which leverages both local and global term statistics to generate context-aware query representations. Our method adaptively selects relevant terms from a hierarchical vocabulary graph, allowing for more effective pruning of irrelevant documents and improved retrieval efficiency. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HQE-DSE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of both retrieval accuracy and query latency.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems through Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence, particularly in scenarios where agents have limited communication and partial observability of the environment. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HiGAT) framework for coordinating multi-agent systems. HiGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn agent representations and hierarchical graph pooling to capture complex dependencies between agents. We evaluate HiGAT on a variety of multi-agent coordination tasks, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and coordination efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to make decisions in complex environments. However, the lack of interpretability in RL models hinders trust and understanding of AV decision-making. This paper proposes a hierarchical explainable RL framework, 'HERO', which integrates attention-based feature importance with hierarchical policy decomposition. HERO enables fine-grained explanations of AV decisions, from high-level goals to low-level control actions. Experiments on a real-world driving dataset show that HERO improves explainability without sacrificing decision-making performance, paving the way for more transparent and trustworthy AV systems.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized, multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for autonomous traffic signal control. We model each traffic signal as an autonomous agent, and utilize a decentralized deep Q-network (DDQN) to learn optimal control policies. Our approach allows agents to adapt to dynamic traffic conditions and communicate with neighboring agents to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. Simulation results on a realistic traffic network demonstrate improved performance compared to traditional, centralized control methods, with a 23% reduction in average travel time and a 17% decrease in congestion.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Range Queries in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and social media has led to an exponential growth in multidimensional data. However, existing query optimization techniques for NoSQL databases are inadequate for efficient processing of range queries. This paper proposes a novel cost-based optimization framework, 'RangeOpt', which leverages statistical correlations and data distribution insights to minimize query latency. Our approach integrates a probabilistic indexing scheme with a machine learning-based query planner to select the most efficient query execution plan. Experimental results on a real-world IoT dataset demonstrate that RangeOpt achieves up to 3x speedup over state-of-the-art optimization techniques for multidimensional range queries.

title: Real-time Query Optimization for IoT Data Streams using Hypergraph Partitioning
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an exponential increase in data streams, making real-time query optimization a pressing challenge. This paper presents 'HyperOpt', a novel approach that leverages hypergraph partitioning to efficiently distribute query processing across a cluster of machines. By representing data streams as hypergraphs, we can identify and optimize critical query patterns, reducing latency by up to 70% compared to existing methods. We evaluate HyperOpt on a large-scale IoT dataset, demonstrating its scalability and effectiveness in handling high-velocity and high-volume data streams.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans in distributed database systems. Our approach, called 'RL-QOpt', uses a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan from a large space of possible plans. We evaluate RL-QOpt on a real-world dataset and show that it achieves an average speedup of 2.5x compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Decomposing Hierarchical Queries for Efficient Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Data warehousing is a crucial component of business intelligence, but processing complex hierarchical queries can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes a novel decomposition strategy, 'HierDecomp', which leverages query rewriting and factorization to optimize query execution. We show that HierDecomp reduces query response time by an average of 30% compared to state-of-the-art approaches, while maintaining query correctness and integrity. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in supporting real-world data analytics workloads.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for multi-modal time series forecasting. HGAT leverages the strengths of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model complex dependencies between time series variables. Our approach involves constructing a hierarchical graph representation of the data, where nodes correspond to variables and edges capture their pairwise correlations. We then apply a stacked attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges at each level of the hierarchy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of forecasting accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Designing Accessible Augmented Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly pervasive, it is essential to ensure that its benefits are accessible to diverse user populations, including older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating AR interfaces that accommodate the needs of this demographic. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with older adults and caregivers, which informed the development of a set of design guidelines and recommendations for accessible AR interaction. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, consistency, and multimodal feedback in AR interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding via Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding has become a crucial task in various AI applications. However, existing methods often fail to capture complex relationships between entities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) to efficiently learn knowledge graph embeddings. Our approach leverages multi-level attention mechanisms to focus on relevant entities and relations, resulting in improved embedding quality. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HAN-based method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in terms of link prediction and triplet classification tasks.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Accessible Gestural Input in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on hand-held controllers or gestures, which can be challenging or impossible for users with mobility impairments. This paper presents 'GazeGuide', a gaze-based interface that enables accessible gestural input in VR. Our approach leverages machine learning-based gaze tracking and gesture recognition to allow users to interact with virtual objects using only their eyes. We evaluate GazeGuide in a user study with participants with and without motor impairments, demonstrating improved accessibility and user experience. The results suggest that gaze-based interfaces can provide a more inclusive and immersive VR experience for users with diverse abilities.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants and chatbots, have become ubiquitous in daily life. However, people with disabilities often face significant barriers when interacting with these systems. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive conversational interfaces that cater to diverse abilities and needs. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with disabilities, identifying key design recommendations for improving accessibility, usability, and user experience. Our findings highlight the importance of multimodal input, adaptive feedback, and personalized accommodation. We demonstrate the feasibility of our approach through a prototype system that integrates these design principles, showcasing improved performance and satisfaction for users with disabilities.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Sparse Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Sparse information retrieval systems, where relevant documents are scarce, pose significant challenges for search engines. This paper presents a novel query-driven document expansion approach, dubbed 'SparseXPand', which leverages contextualized language models to generate synthetic documents that augment the original sparse collection. By incorporating these expanded documents into the retrieval process, SparseXPand improves the recall of relevant documents by up to 25% compared to state-of-the-art sparse retrieval methods. Experimental results on three benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of SparseXPand in enhancing retrieval performance, particularly for rare queries.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, aiming to improve the recall of relevant documents. Traditional methods rely on hand-crafted features and term weighting schemes, which may not capture the nuances of natural language. This paper presents a novel approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn query expansion strategies from large datasets. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes query representation, term importance, and document ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision, while reducing the computational overhead of query expansion.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in Information Retrieval (IR), where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a popular technique to improve retrieval performance, but it is often computationally expensive and may not generalize well to unseen queries. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to query expansion using reinforcement learning, which learns to select the most informative terms to add to the query. Our method, called RLQE, uses a deep Q-network to estimate the expected improvement in retrieval performance for each possible expansion term. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that RLQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel neural architecture that leverages the strengths of both visual and textual modalities. HANs employ a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights feature importance across modalities and spatial regions, enabling efficient sentiment prediction. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HANs over state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach that leverages context-aware embeddings to incorporate semantic and syntactic cues from the query context. Our method, dubbed ConEx, learns to identify and weigh relevant expansion terms based on their contextual similarity to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ConEx significantly outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving an average precision gain of 12.5% at rank 10.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models for document retrieval often struggle with scalability and effectiveness in modern search engines. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HierRank, which leverages the strengths of both lexical and semantic matching techniques. By incorporating a hierarchical attention mechanism, HierRank learns to focus on relevant document segments and capture nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art neural ranking models.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Neural Networks for Retrieval of Short Texts
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, particularly for short texts where query terms may not adequately capture user intent. This paper presents a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'QNLP', which leverages semantic role labeling and contextualized word embeddings to expand queries. QNLP incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to adaptively weight query terms and expansion candidates, leading to improved retrieval effectiveness. Experimental results on several short-text datasets demonstrate significant gains in precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Self-Organizing Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, task allocation among agents is a challenging problem due to the need to adapt to changing conditions and optimize performance. This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework that leverages self-organizing agents to allocate tasks efficiently. We introduce a distributed, auction-based mechanism that enables agents to bid on tasks based on their current workload, capabilities, and environmental factors. Experiments in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and adaptability to changes in the environment.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with diverse capabilities and constraints need to collaborate to accomplish complex tasks. We develop a novel deep reinforcement learning approach that enables agents to learn cooperative strategies and adapt to changing environmental conditions. Our method, called 'HRL-TA', combines a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture with a graph neural network to model agent interactions and task dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion efficiency and robustness compared to traditional optimization-based approaches.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Semantic Search in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs have become a cornerstone of modern information systems, but querying these massive datasets remains a significant challenge. This paper presents HQE, a novel hierarchical query expansion approach that leverages semantic relationships between entities to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of semantic search. By adaptively expanding queries using a combination of entity embeddings and hierarchical clustering, HQE reduces the search space and retrieves more relevant results. Experiments on the YAGO2 and DBpedia datasets demonstrate HQE's superiority over state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, with significant gains in precision and recall.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies in High-Dimensional State Spaces
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex control tasks, but its robustness to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper investigates the vulnerability of DRL policies to perturbations in high-dimensional state spaces, where the curse of dimensionality exacerbates the attack surface. We propose a novel methodology to generate adversarial attacks using a combination of transfer learning and gradient-based methods. Our experiments on several Atari games and robotic control tasks demonstrate that even state-of-the-art DRL algorithms can be significantly compromised by our attacks, highlighting the need for more robust policy architectures and training protocols.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In heterogeneous multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to differences in agent capabilities and task requirements. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt to changing system dynamics. Our approach, called 'HATA', uses a multi-agent Q-network to learn optimal task assignments based on agent capabilities, task priorities, and system constraints. We evaluate HATA on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario and demonstrate improved task completion rates, reduced communication overhead, and enhanced system robustness compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'AgentTA', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to adapt to dynamic environments. Each agent learns to optimize its task selection based on local observations and limited communication with neighboring agents. Our approach incorporates a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a novel reward function that balances task completion with resource utilization. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that AgentTA outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource efficiency.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in domains with complex interactions and dependencies between tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective task allocation strategies. We represent the task allocation problem as a graph, where agents and tasks are nodes, and edges capture their relationships. Our GNN-based model, 'GraphTA', learns to predict the optimal task assignments by aggregating information from neighboring nodes. Experimental results on a range of benchmark problems demonstrate that GraphTA outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved task completion rates and reduced coordination costs.

title: Designing Intuitive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Augmented Reality Environments
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for intuitive and natural interaction mechanisms. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface for AR environments that leverages machine learning-driven gesture recognition. We conducted a user study to evaluate the effectiveness of our approach, which incorporates a combination of hand tracking, skeletal modeling, and gesture classification. The results show significant improvements in user performance and satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. We also discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future AR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, but existing approaches often rely on a single modality, such as speech or text. We propose a hierarchical attention network (HAN) that fuses multimodal inputs from speech, text, and vision to recognize emotions more accurately. Our HAN model consists of two stages: intra-modal attention, which captures local dependencies within each modality, and inter-modal attention, which integrates information across modalities. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art single-modality models and achieves a 15% improvement in emotion recognition accuracy.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Systems
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown immense potential in various domains, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of personalized avatars on user experience and engagement in VR environments. We designed and implemented a novel avatar customization framework, incorporating real-time facial recognition and machine learning-based preference modeling. Our user study involving 100 participants reveals that personalized avatars significantly enhance user engagement, with increased feelings of presence and enjoyment. We discuss the implications of our findings and propose future research directions for personalized VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification in graph-structured data is a fundamental task in many real-world applications. However, the scarcity of labeled data in many domains hinders the performance of traditional graph neural networks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges in the graph. We demonstrate that HGAT can effectively adapt to few-shot learning scenarios, achieving state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we provide theoretical insights into the expressive power of HGAT and its ability to generalize to unseen graph structures.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Natural Language Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in natural language search, where the goal is to reformulate the original query to retrieve more relevant documents. In this paper, we propose a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'NeuroQE', which leverages the semantic relationships between words to generate effective query expansions. NeuroQE consists of a word embeddings layer, a recurrent neural network, and a scoring function to rank potential expansions. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in search performance compared to traditional query expansion techniques, while maintaining efficiency and scalability.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, designing accessible interfaces for older adults with cognitive impairments becomes increasingly important. This paper presents a novel gesture-based interface framework that adapts to individual cognitive abilities and motor skills. We conducted a user study with 30 older adults, using a custom-built gesture recognition system. Our results show that the adaptive interface significantly improved gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional static interfaces. We also present a machine learning-based model that predicts cognitive impairment levels based on gesture patterns, enabling early detection and personalized interface adaptations.

title: Efficient Citation Recommendation using Graph Attention Networks for Scholarly Documents
paper_abstract: Citation recommendation systems play a crucial role in facilitating scholarly communication and advancing research. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) based approach for citation recommendation, which leverages the structural properties of citation graphs to model complex relationships between papers. Our method, GraphCite, incorporates node and edge features from the citation graph, and employs a multi-head attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant neighboring papers. Experimental results on the Cora dataset demonstrate that GraphCite outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of recall and precision, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Ranking-Based Diversification for Personalized Search Result Lists
paper_abstract: Personalized search engines strive to provide users with relevant results, but often compromise on diversity. This paper proposes a novel ranking-based diversification approach, dubbed 'DivRank', which integrates a probabilistic graphical model with a learning-to-rank framework. DivRank incorporates user behavior, query intent, and document semantics to generate diverse search result lists that balance relevance and novelty. Experimental evaluation on a large-scale query log and a commercial search engine dataset demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction, engagement, and diversity metrics compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) systems, where agents interact with each other and their environment. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework, which enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information when making decisions. Our HAN architecture consists of two levels of attention: an intra-agent attention mechanism that models individual agent behaviors, and an inter-agent attention mechanism that captures complex interactions between agents. We evaluate our approach on a variety of MARL benchmarks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalization on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in enhancing learning outcomes, but the role of personalization in these environments remains understudied. This paper investigates the effects of personalized recommendations on user engagement in VR-based learning systems. We designed and deployed a VR platform that incorporates machine learning-based user modeling and adaptive content selection. Our user study with 120 participants reveals that personalized VR experiences lead to significant increases in user engagement, motivation, and knowledge retention compared to non-personalized counterparts. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR-based learning systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular, but they often exclude older adults with motor impairments. This paper presents a novel inclusive design approach, 'EasyGesture', which incorporates compensatory strategies and adaptive feedback mechanisms to facilitate gesture recognition for this user group. We conducted a user study with 20 older adults with motor impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces. Our findings inform the development of more accessible and usable gesture-based systems for older adults.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Autonomous multi-agent systems (AMAS) have been increasingly applied to various domains, such as robotics, traffic management, and smart grids. Task allocation is a critical problem in AMAS, where agents need to be assigned to tasks efficiently and adaptively. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn the complex dependencies between agents and tasks. We design a GNN-based algorithm that enables agents to communicate and negotiate with each other to achieve optimal task assignments. Experimental results on a simulated traffic management scenario demonstrate the scalability and adaptability of our approach in dynamic environments.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent System for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-agent system (MAS) for autonomous traffic management, which leverages decentralized decision-making to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. Our approach, called 'TrafficMAS', consists of a network of autonomous agents that communicate and coordinate with each other to dynamically adjust traffic signal timings and traffic routing. We evaluate TrafficMAS through extensive simulations, demonstrating significant improvements in traffic throughput and reduced travel times compared to traditional centralized traffic management systems. The scalability of our approach is further validated through a real-world case study in the city of San Francisco.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to optimize task assignments in dynamic environments. Our approach, called HRL-TA, uses a two-level hierarchy of agents, where higher-level agents coordinate task assignments and lower-level agents execute tasks. We evaluate HRL-TA in a simulated package delivery scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utility compared to traditional decentralized allocation methods.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing for Sparse Vector Retrieval
paper_abstract: Sparse vector retrieval is a fundamental problem in information retrieval, where the goal is to efficiently search for similar sparse vectors in high-dimensional spaces. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing technique, 'SparseAdapt', which dynamically adjusts the indexing structure based on query patterns and data distribution. By exploiting the sparsity of the vectors, SparseAdapt achieves significant improvements in query performance, reducing the average response time by up to 40% compared to existing state-of-the-art methods. We evaluate SparseAdapt on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in various retrieval scenarios.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of database management systems, especially in distributed settings where data is scattered across multiple nodes. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a Deep Q-Network (DQN) that learns to select optimal query plans based on runtime statistics and system feedback. Experimental results on a TPC-DS dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while ensuring efficient resource utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility features for users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR interfaces that cater to individuals with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with users with disabilities and developed a set of guidelines for accessible VR interaction. Our evaluation shows that the proposed interface significantly improves user experience and task performance for participants with disabilities, paving the way for more inclusive VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation in multi-agent systems, using deep reinforcement learning to optimize the allocation of tasks among agents. We introduce a hierarchical framework that considers both local and global task dependencies, and uses a decentralized decision-making process to allocate tasks to agents. Our approach is evaluated on a variety of scenarios, including disaster response and supply chain management, and shows significant improvements in task completion efficiency and overall system performance compared to traditional allocation methods.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Semantically Similar Documents using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: The proliferation of digital documents has created a pressing need for efficient and effective document retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel framework that leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to capture semantic relationships between documents. By recursively applying graph attention mechanisms, our approach can identify semantically similar documents at multiple abstraction levels. Experimental results on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval techniques, achieving a 23% improvement in mean average precision. We also show that our HGNN-based approach can be seamlessly integrated with existing keyword-based retrieval systems to further enhance their performance.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Few-Shot Learning with Limited Labeled Data
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years due to its ability to adapt to new tasks with limited labeled data. However, existing approaches often rely on complex meta-learning frameworks or expensive data augmentation techniques. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant input features and adapt to new tasks with minimal labeled data. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet, and demonstrates robustness to varying levels of label scarcity.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have shown significant promise in information retrieval tasks, but they often struggle with limited training data and vocabulary mismatch. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to improve the performance of neural retrieval models. Our method, called 'NeuroXPand', uses a neural network to generate expansion terms from a set of pseudo-relevant documents, which are then incorporated into the original query. We evaluate NeuroXPand on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for rare and out-of-vocabulary terms.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) has seen significant progress, but existing approaches often rely on complex, computationally expensive models. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively fuse modalities and recognize emotions. HANs achieve state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while reducing computational overhead by 30%. We attribute this improvement to the hierarchical attention structure, which adaptively weights modalities based on their emotional relevance. Our approach has implications for real-time, low-latency emotion recognition in human-computer interaction and affective computing applications.

title: Eye-Gaze Based Adaptive Interface for Improving User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often struggle to provide an optimal user experience due to the lack of nuanced user input. This paper presents an innovative approach to leveraging eye-gaze tracking to create an adaptive interface that dynamically responds to user attention and intentions. Our system, 'GazeGuide', uses machine learning-driven gaze analysis to infer user goals and adjust the virtual environment accordingly. We conducted a user study demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction when using GazeGuide compared to traditional VR interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable AI-powered Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) is crucial in recommender systems to build trust with users. This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT) for XAI-powered recommenders. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn item relationships and hierarchically aggregates features to provide personalized explanations. We propose a novel attention-based explanation method to highlight influential items and attributes contributing to the recommendation. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate HGAT's superior recommendation performance and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Passage Retrieval using Neural Semantic Models
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial component in many natural language processing applications. While neural semantic models have shown promising results in passage ranking, they often struggle with lexical mismatch between the query and relevant passages. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'SemEx', which leverages the semantic representations generated by neural models to identify relevant terms for expansion. We introduce a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group semantically similar terms and select the most informative ones for expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that SemEx significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural passage retrieval models, especially when combined with a robust ranking framework.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on complex decision-making algorithms, but their lack of transparency hinders trust and accountability. This paper proposes a novel explainable reinforcement learning (ERL) framework for autonomous vehicle decision-making. Our approach integrates graph attention mechanisms to highlight critical road entities influencing the agent's policy. We introduce a novel attention-based explanation method, 'GraphExplain', which provides visual and quantitative insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a simulated driving environment demonstrate that our ERL framework achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art reinforcement learning methods while providing meaningful explanations for the agent's actions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has become increasingly important in various applications, including customer service chatbots and social media analysis. However, existing deep learning models often struggle to provide interpretable results. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates visual, textual, and acoustic features for multimodal sentiment analysis. Our HAN model learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, providing explainable sentiment predictions. Experimental results on the CMU-Multimodal Opinion dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and interpretability.

title: Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing requires efficient query optimization to handle massive data volumes and high query arrival rates. This paper presents 'DeepQOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to dynamically adapt to changing workload patterns. Our approach uses a Deep Q-Network (DQN) to learn an optimal query plan selection policy, taking into account query latency, data freshness, and system resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world data warehousing benchmark show that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of system throughput.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: In IoT networks, efficient task allocation is crucial for optimizing resource utilization and reducing latency. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for distributed task allocation in IoT networks. We propose a decentralized, asynchronous learning approach that enables agents to learn from local observations and adapt to dynamic network conditions. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization. We also analyze the impact of agent communication topology on learning convergence and allocation performance.

title: Meta-Pruning: Adaptive Filter Pruning for Efficient Deep Neural Networks
