paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their computational complexity and memory requirements hinder their deployment on resource-constrained devices. This paper proposes a novel meta-pruning approach, which adaptively prunes filters in DNNs based on their importance, measured by a learnable meta-model. Our method, called Meta-Prune, dynamically adjusts the pruning ratio and filter importance during training, resulting in more efficient models with minimal accuracy loss. Experimental results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that Meta-Prune outperforms existing pruning methods, achieving up to 5.2x compression ratio and 2.3x speedup on mobile devices.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging auction-based mechanisms to efficiently assign tasks to agents. Our approach, called 'AuctionMAS', utilizes a hierarchical auction protocol to facilitate task allocation, ensuring that agents are assigned tasks that maximize their utility while minimizing overall system latency. We present a comprehensive evaluation of AuctionMAS using a variety of task allocation scenarios, demonstrating significant improvements in system throughput and agent utilization compared to existing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperative Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative learning in multi-agent systems is challenging due to the complex interactions between agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) framework that enables agents to learn cooperative strategies in a decentralized manner. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model agent interactions and hierarchical representations to capture complex dependencies. We evaluate HAGNN on a range of cooperative tasks, including multi-agent navigation and resource allocation, and demonstrate improved performance compared to existing methods. The proposed framework has potential applications in autonomous systems, robotics, and smart cities.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Learning using Bayesian Optimization with Transfer Learning
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their hyperparameter tuning remains a time-consuming and computationally expensive task. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian optimization approach that leverages transfer learning to adapt the search space of hyperparameters to the target task. Our method, called 'TransBO', uses a knowledge graph to encode the relationships between hyperparameters and model performance across different tasks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TransBO on several benchmark datasets, achieving faster convergence and better model performance compared to existing Bayesian optimization methods.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph-based Attention Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing use of deep neural networks in safety-critical applications has raised concerns about their vulnerability to adversarial attacks. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks using graph-based attention networks (GATs). Our method, called GAT-Det, leverages the graph structure of neural networks to identify suspicious patterns in the input data. We employ an attention mechanism to focus on the most critical neurons and edges in the network, enabling effective detection of adversarial examples. Experimental results on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate the efficacy of GAT-Det in detecting various types of adversarial attacks, including those crafted using state-of-the-art attack algorithms.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework, 'MA-RL', that leverages reinforcement learning to enable agents to adapt to dynamic environments and learn optimal task assignments. We formulate the task allocation problem as a Markov decision process and propose a novel action-critic algorithm that incorporates both local and global reward functions. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate that MA-RL outperforms traditional auction-based approaches in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Speech Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become ubiquitous, but individuals with speech disabilities, such as apraxia or dysarthria, often struggle to interact with these systems. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive voice-based interfaces that accommodate diverse speech patterns. We introduce a machine learning-based approach that learns to recognize and adapt to individual speech characteristics, enabling more accurate and efficient interactions. Our user study with 20 participants with speech disabilities demonstrates significant improvements in interaction speed and accuracy compared to traditional speech recognition systems.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness against Backdoor Attacks in Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Backdoor attacks pose a significant threat to the reliability of deep neural networks (DNNs) by injecting hidden triggers that mislead the model. Existing defense mechanisms often rely on heuristic methods that fail to generalize. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework, 'BackdoorShield', which leverages the concept of worst-case perturbations to fortify DNNs against backdoor attacks. We devise a systematic approach to generate diverse backdoor patterns, and incorporate them into the training process to enhance the model's robustness. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that BackdoorShield significantly improves the resilience of DNNs against various backdoor attacks, outperforming state-of-the-art defense methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Multi-Modal Retrieval using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-modal retrieval has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches often struggle with the vocabulary mismatch problem. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages deep learning to incorporate visual and textual features. Our approach, dubbed 'MMQE', uses a multi-task learning objective to jointly optimize query representation and expansion. We further introduce a novel attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant terms from the visual modality. Experiments on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that MMQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: A Hybrid Retrieval Model for Multimodal Information Fusion in Web Search
paper_abstract: Traditional web search engines rely on text-based queries, neglecting the richness of multimodal content on the web. This paper proposes a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'Multimodal Fusion Network' (MFN), which integrates visual and textual features to retrieve relevant web pages. MFN employs a deep neural network to learn a shared representation space for both modalities, enabling effective fusion of query and document features. Experimental results on a large-scale web dataset demonstrate that MFN outperforms state-of-the-art text-based retrieval models, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for efficient resource allocation in smart grids. We model the problem as a Markov game, where each agent represents a microgrid and learns to optimize its local resource allocation policy while interacting with neighboring agents. We propose a novel algorithm, 'MARL-DR', which combines deep Q-networks with a graph attention mechanism to capture the complex interactions between agents. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid environment demonstrate that MARL-DR outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods and achieves significant reductions in energy losses and costs.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in human-computer interaction (HCI) involves analyzing diverse modalities of user data, including speech, text, and facial expressions. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates multi-modal features to improve emotion recognition accuracy. Our HAN model employs modality-specific attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features from each modality, and a hierarchical fusion strategy to combine modality representations. Experiment results on a benchmark HCI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, with significant improvements in F1-score and correlation coefficient.

title: Enhancing Agent Coordination with Deep Reinforcement Learning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems have shown promise in various applications, but coordinating agents in dynamic environments remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to improve agent coordination. Our method, called DynaCo, uses a hierarchical architecture that combines a high-level coordination module with low-level action execution modules. We evaluate DynaCo in a simulated urban search and rescue scenario and demonstrate improved coordination and task completion rates compared to existing methods. Our results suggest that DynaCo can be applied to a wide range of dynamic environments, enabling more effective multi-agent systems.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Hearing Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants, are increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility remains a concern for older adults with hearing impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an accessible conversational interface, 'HearMe', tailored to the needs of this population. We conducted a series of semi-structured interviews and co-design workshops with older adults to identify key barriers and preferences. Our findings informed the design of HearMe, which incorporates audio enhancement, visual feedback, and adaptive dialogue management. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in comprehension, satisfaction, and overall experience compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attentional Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems are crucial for building trust with users. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attentional Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) that incorporates both item and user graph structures to generate personalized explanations. HAGNN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges, allowing for interpretable recommendations. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of explanation quality and recommendation accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Multimodal Fusion for Explainable Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Explainable AI has become crucial in various applications, including visual question answering (VQA). This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Multimodal Fusion (HAMF) framework that provides interpretable results in VQA tasks. HAMF integrates visual and textual features using a hierarchical attention mechanism, enabling the model to focus on relevant regions and words when answering questions. Our experimental results on the VQA-X dataset demonstrate that HAMF outperforms state-of-the-art VQA models while providing insightful attention visualizations that reveal the decision-making process.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Neural Networks via Bayesian Neural Architecture Search
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural architecture search (BNAS) approach to improve the adversarial robustness of DNNs. Our method leverages a probabilistic surrogate model to efficiently explore the architecture space and identify robust designs. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in adversarial robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, our analysis reveals that the discovered architectures exhibit unique structural properties that contribute to their robustness.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and cybersecurity. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability, making it challenging to identify the root causes of anomalies. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that detects anomalies while providing explanations for its predictions. Our HAN model consists of a hierarchical encoder that captures both local and global patterns in the time-series data, followed by an attention mechanism that highlights the most relevant features contributing to the anomaly score. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in detecting anomalies while providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Enhanced Cognitive Load Management in Augmented Reality
paper_abstract: As Augmented Reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, it is essential to develop strategies for managing cognitive load in AR-based systems. This paper presents an adaptive visualization framework, 'CogVis', which dynamically adjusts the complexity and content of AR visualizations based on real-time user feedback and cognitive load metrics. Our user study demonstrates that CogVis reduces cognitive load, improves task performance, and enhances user experience in AR-based learning and training applications. We also provide guidelines for incorporating cognitive load management into AR system design.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Older Adults' Perception of Conversational Errors
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational errors can be frustrating and exclusionary, particularly for older adults. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating how older adults perceive and respond to conversational errors in voice assistants. We conducted 20 in-depth interviews and a usability study with 30 participants aged 65-85, using a custom-built voice assistant with controlled error rates. Our findings highlight the importance of error transparency, polite language, and adaptive error recovery strategies to promote trust and inclusivity. We propose a set of design guidelines for more accessible and empathetic voice assistants.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Reinforcement Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) agents often struggle to generalize in partially observable environments, where the state is only partially observable. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAT) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant observations. We demonstrate that HAT enables the agent to learn more interpretable and robust policies in various RL tasks, including robotic control and navigation. Furthermore, we provide a theoretical analysis of the attention mechanisms, showing that they can be used to extract meaningful explanations for the agent's decisions.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in IoT-Generated Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has led to an explosion of time-series data, necessitating efficient query optimization techniques for real-time analytics. This paper presents 'Ripple', a novel distributed query optimization framework that leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to partition and process IoT-generated time-series data in parallel. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that dynamically adjusts the degree of parallelism and data pruning to minimize query latency and maximize resource utilization. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that Ripple achieves up to 5x speedup over traditional query optimization techniques while maintaining high accuracy.

title: Gaze-Based Input for Virtual Reality: A Study on Reducing Eye Movement Errors
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on gaze-based input for user interaction. However, eye movement errors can significantly degrade the user experience. This paper proposes a novel error reduction technique based on machine learning and computer vision. We develop a gaze correction model that leverages pupil center corneal reflection tracking and adaptive filtering to improve the accuracy of gaze-based input. Our user study with 30 participants shows that the proposed method reduces eye movement errors by 35% compared to traditional gaze-based input methods, resulting in improved user performance and satisfaction in VR applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision Making
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) have become increasingly prevalent in real-world applications, but the lack of explainability in their decision-making processes hinders trust and accountability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture, 'ExplainMAS', which learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions to generate interpretable explanations for joint decision-making. We evaluate ExplainMAS on a variety of cooperative and competitive MAS benchmarks, demonstrating significant improvements in explanation quality and decision-making performance compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT) for multi-agent task allocation, a critical problem in decentralized AI systems. HGAT learns to represent agents and tasks as nodes in a hierarchical graph, enabling the model to capture complex relationships between agents, tasks, and their allocations. We demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of allocation efficiency and adaptability to changing task requirements. Experimental results on a large-scale drone surveillance scenario show that HGAT-based allocation policies reduce mission completion time by up to 30% compared to traditional optimization-based approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. Our model, called Query2Vec, learns to represent queries and documents as dense vectors, enabling semantic matching and expansion of the original query. We evaluate Query2Vec on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional methods. Furthermore, we show that Query2Vec can be easily integrated into existing retrieval systems, making it a practical solution for real-world applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems for Real-Time Traffic Flow Optimization
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic flow optimization is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents with varying goals and constraints. This paper presents a novel decentralized coordination framework, 'SmartFlow', which leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize traffic signal control. SmartFlow integrates graph neural networks to model traffic dynamics and attention mechanisms to selectively focus on critical intersections. Our experiments on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate that SmartFlow reduces congestion by 23% and travel times by 17% compared to state-of-the-art traffic management systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: As database-as-a-service (DBaaS) platforms increasingly adopt multi-tenancy to improve resource utilization, query optimization becomes a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'OptiMT', which leverages machine learning-based workload analytics to identify performance-critical queries and applies a suite of optimization techniques, including query rewriting, indexing, and caching. We evaluate OptiMT on a real-world DBaaS platform and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and resource utilization compared to existing optimization methods.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but its inaccessible nature excludes users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences, focusing on auditory and haptic feedback to compensate for visual limitations. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, exploring the effectiveness of our approach in enhancing user engagement and navigation in VR environments. The results demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction, highlighting the need for more accessible VR design practices.

title: Adaptive Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis for Multilingual Product Reviews
paper_abstract: Aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) has become crucial for businesses to understand customer opinions. However, existing ABSA models struggle with multilingual product reviews, where aspects and sentiments vary across languages. This paper proposes a novel adaptive ABSA framework, 'PolyGlot', which leverages transfer learning and language-agnostic aspect extraction. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both aspect-specific and language-invariant sentiment patterns. Experimental results on a large-scale multilingual review dataset demonstrate that PolyGlot outperforms state-of-the-art ABSA models, achieving significant improvements in aspect detection and sentiment classification across six languages.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Swarm Robotics using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for swarm robotics using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'MARLA', enables a team of robots to learn to allocate tasks autonomously in dynamic environments. MARLA combines a decentralized actor-critic architecture with a novel, graph-based communication protocol to facilitate efficient information exchange among robots. We evaluate MARLA on a variety of swarm robotics tasks, including object manipulation and environmental monitoring, and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and robot utilization compared to traditional, centralized allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve a common goal is a longstanding problem in artificial intelligence. Existing methods often rely on centralized controllers or simplistic communication protocols, neglecting the complexity of real-world multi-agent systems. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel architecture that enables agents to selectively focus on relevant teammates and tasks, thereby facilitating more effective cooperation. We demonstrate the explainability of HANs through visualizations of attention weights, providing insights into the decision-making process. Experimental results on a range of cooperative tasks show that HANs outperform state-of-the-art methods while improving interpretability.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to allocate resources efficiently is a challenging problem in various domains, including logistics, finance, and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'AgentDQN', that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize resource allocation in multi-agent systems. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that combines centralized planning with decentralized execution, enabling agents to adapt to changing environments and learn from experience. Experimental results on a simulated resource allocation task demonstrate that AgentDQN outperforms traditional optimization methods and achieves significant improvements in resource utilization and system efficiency.

title: Adaptive Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation strategies play a crucial role in achieving mutually beneficial agreements. However, existing approaches often struggle to adapt to dynamic environments, where agents' preferences and goals may change over time. This paper presents a novel adaptive negotiation framework, 'DynaNeg', which leverages machine learning and opponent modeling to improve negotiation outcomes. DynaNeg employs a hybrid approach, combining case-based reasoning with reinforcement learning, to adapt to changing agent behaviors and preferences. Experimental results in a simulated smart grid scenario demonstrate that DynaNeg outperforms state-of-the-art negotiation strategies in terms of agreement quality and negotiation efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Adversarial Learning for Explainable Computer Vision
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various computer vision tasks, but their lack of transparency and interpretability hinders their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical adversarial learning framework, 'HALO', which generates explainable visual features by leveraging the adversarial relationship between a generator network and a discriminator network. Our approach encourages the generator to produce saliency maps that highlight the most informative regions in an image, leading to improved model interpretability and robustness. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HALO on several benchmark datasets, including ImageNet and COCO.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to learn cooperative policies. Our approach, called 'MASTAR', enables agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing task requirements and environmental conditions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MASTAR in a simulated disaster response scenario, where it outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Real-time Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT using Explainable Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices has heightened the need for efficient anomaly detection systems. This paper introduces 'GraphAnom', a real-time anomaly detection framework that leverages explainable graph convolutional networks (EGCNs) to identify anomalies in IIoT sensor data. GraphAnom exploits the graph structure of IIoT devices to model complex relationships between sensors and captures subtle patterns indicative of anomalies. Our approach provides interpretable explanations for detected anomalies, facilitating timely interventions. Experimental results on a large-scale IIoT dataset demonstrate the superiority of GraphAnom over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and speed.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Workload-Aware Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics workloads. However, query performance remains a significant challenge due to data replication and partitioning. This paper proposes AWAR (Adaptive Workload-Aware Replication), a novel replication strategy that dynamically adjusts data placement based on real-time workload analysis. AWAR leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to group similar queries and allocate replicas accordingly, reducing query latency by up to 30%. Experimental results on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of AWAR in improving query performance and scalability in DDS.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Adaptive Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning. This paper presents a novel deep meta-learning approach that learns to adapt to new tasks with limited data. We introduce a task embedding module that generates adaptive, contextualized embeddings for each task, allowing the model to effectively transfer knowledge across tasks. Our approach, called 'AdapTask', achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including mini-ImageNet and CIFAR-FS, and demonstrates robustness to varying task distributions and difficulties.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Explainability in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is crucial for real-world applications. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant agents and their interactions to improve policy explanations. Our approach extends traditional attention mechanisms to handle complex, multi-agent environments. Experimental results on a range of MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HAN-based agents achieve comparable performance to state-of-the-art methods while providing intuitive, interpretable explanations of their decision-making processes.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Attention-based Anomaly Detectors
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has been increasingly adopted in various applications, but it is vulnerable to adversarial attacks that can manipulate the learning process. This paper proposes a novel attention-based anomaly detector, 'AADRL', to identify malicious attacks in DRL. Our approach leverages the attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most critical state-action pairs, enabling the detection of subtle anomalies. We evaluate AADRL on a range of DRL scenarios and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting adversarial attacks, outperforming existing methods in terms of detection accuracy and robustness.

title: Hierarchical Task Networks for Explainable Planning in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: As autonomous systems become increasingly pervasive, it is essential to develop explainable planning mechanisms that provide transparency into their decision-making processes. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network (HTN) framework, XPlan, which integrates symbolic planning with neural networks to generate interpretable plans for autonomous agents. XPlan leverages a hierarchical representation of tasks to identify relevant sub-goals and generate visual explanations for the planned actions. We evaluate XPlan in a simulated autonomous driving scenario, demonstrating improved explainability and planning efficiency compared to traditional planning approaches.

title: InvisibleButtons: Enhancing Accessibility in Virtual Reality through Tactile Feedback and Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by accessibility limitations. This paper introduces InvisibleButtons, a novel system that enables users with visual impairments to interact with virtual objects more effectively. Our approach combines tactile feedback and gesture recognition to provide an intuitive and accurate way of selecting objects in VR. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, which showed that InvisibleButtons reduces the interaction time by 35% and improves the overall user experience compared to traditional methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases (DGDs) are increasingly used to store and query large-scale graph data. However, query optimization in DGDs is challenging due to the complexity of graph queries and the distributed nature of the data. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages a combination of graph summarization, query rewriting, and cost-based optimization to improve query performance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphOpt on a real-world social network dataset, showing significant improvements in query response times and scalability compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Emotional Intelligence in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: As robots increasingly interact with humans in various settings, understanding human emotions is crucial for effective collaboration. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for emotion recognition in human-robot interaction. Our HAN model utilizes a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant facial features, speech patterns, and context-aware cues. Experimental results on a large-scale emotional intelligence dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing complex emotions, such as empathy and frustration, in real-time human-robot interactions.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often face the challenge of task allocation, where agents must decide which tasks to execute in a distributed manner. This problem becomes even more complex when agents have incomplete information about the environment and other agents' capabilities. We propose a novel decentralized task allocation algorithm, called 'ITA', which utilizes a combination of local observation and communication to achieve near-optimal task assignments. ITA is based on a probabilistic graphical model that captures the uncertainty in agent capabilities and task requirements. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of ITA in achieving high task completion rates and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Modern recommendation systems rely on graph-based models to capture complex user-item relationships. However, these models often struggle with scalability and suffer from over-smoothing issues. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which leverages a hierarchical graph structure to model user and item relationships at multiple scales. By incorporating attention mechanisms and a novel graph pooling strategy, HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while reducing computational complexity. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in a realistic recommendation system and discuss its potential for large-scale industrial applications.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Phrase Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural phrase embeddings to better model query semantics. Our method, termed NPEx, represents queries as dense vectors in a semantic space, enabling more effective expansion of query terms and phrases. Experiments on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate that NPEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Visual Feedback on Motor Skill Learning in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has been increasingly used for motor skill learning, but the impact of personalized visual feedback on learning outcomes remains understudied. This paper presents a user study that investigates the effect of tailored visual feedback on motor skill acquisition in a VR-based golf swing training system. We developed a machine learning model that analyzes user performance and generates customized feedback in real-time. Our results show that participants who received personalized visual feedback demonstrated significant improvements in swing accuracy and consistency compared to those who received standardized feedback. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR-based training systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessibility for users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR experiences, focusing on users with visual and motor impairments. We propose a set of guidelines and tools for designers and developers to create accessible VR interfaces, including adaptive navigation, personalized feedback, and embodied interaction techniques. A user study with 20 participants demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach, highlighting improved user engagement and satisfaction.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: As distributed relational databases become increasingly prevalent, optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach for query optimization, which leverages the structural properties of query plans to identify efficient execution paths. Our method, 'GraphOpt', constructs a weighted graph representation of the query plan and applies a custom-designed graph clustering algorithm to identify optimal join orders and execution strategies. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-structured data, but existing methods often suffer from scalability issues or poor performance on large graphs. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages a hierarchical graph representation to reduce computational complexity. HGAT adaptively selects relevant neighbors at each layer, enabling efficient feature propagation and improved node classification accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT, achieving state-of-the-art performance on large-scale graphs while reducing inference time by up to 70%

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a decentralized reinforcement learning approach, called 'DTRL', that enables agents to learn to allocate tasks without a centralized controller. DTRL uses a novel combination of graph neural networks and multi-agent Q-learning to learn task allocation policies. We evaluate DTRL in a variety of scenarios and show that it outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and agent utility. Our approach has applications in domains such as robotic teams, autonomous vehicles, and smart cities.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Boosting Recommendation Diversity
paper_abstract: Personalized recommendation systems often suffer from a lack of diversity in their suggested items. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) model that tackles this issue by incorporating both item-level and user-level graph attention mechanisms. HGAT adaptively captures complex relationships between users, items, and their associated attributes, leading to improved recommendation diversity and novelty. We conduct extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets, demonstrating the superiority of HGAT over state-of-the-art methods in terms of diversity metrics while maintaining competitive performance in terms of accuracy and ranking metrics.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) has become a popular paradigm for open-domain question answering, but its computational overhead hinders its applicability to large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document expansion technique, 'QADE', which selectively expands relevant documents based on the query context. QADE leverages a learned query-document similarity metric to identify the most informative passages and dynamically adjusts the document representation. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that QADE reduces the computational cost of DPR by up to 40% while maintaining state-of-the-art retrieval performance.

title: Deep Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Natural Language Processing
paper_abstract: The quest for efficient natural language processing (NLP) models has led to the development of various neural architectures. However, manual architecture design is time-consuming and requires significant expertise. This paper proposes a novel deep neural architecture search (NAS) method, 'LinguaNAS', which leverages reinforcement learning to automatically discover efficient NLP models. LinguaNAS uses a hierarchical search space and a novel reward function that balances model accuracy and computational cost. Experiments on several NLP benchmarks demonstrate that LinguaNAS discovers models that outperform manually designed counterparts while reducing inference latency by up to 3x.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval tasks, as it helps to mitigate the vocabulary mismatch problem. In this paper, we propose a novel deep reinforcement learning approach to query expansion, dubbed 'DeepQE'. Our method employs a Markov decision process to model the query expansion process and utilizes a deep neural network to learn the optimal expansion strategy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness, while reducing the computational cost. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the learned expansion strategies, shedding light on the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Dense Passage Retrieval Models
paper_abstract: Dense passage retrieval (DPR) models have shown remarkable performance in information retrieval tasks. However, their computationally expensive nature hinders their deployment in real-world applications. This paper presents a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that significantly reduces the computational overhead of DPR models while maintaining their retrieval effectiveness. HQE leverages a hierarchical clustering of the passage representations to prune the search space and selectively expand the query. Experimental results on the MS MARCO and Natural Questions datasets demonstrate that HQE achieves a 3x speedup over traditional DPR models while sacrificing only 2% in retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks for Semantic Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on manual feature engineering and heuristic-based approaches. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based method for semantic query expansion, dubbed 'DeepQE'. By leveraging pre-trained language models and a neural ranking framework, DeepQE learns to identify relevant terms and phrases in the query context, thereby improving the retrieval effectiveness of search engines. Experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of mean average precision and normalised discounted cumulative gain.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization for Smart City Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinating autonomous agents in smart city traffic management. We propose a distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) framework that enables agents to make decentralized decisions while ensuring global constraints are satisfied. Our approach leverages a novel, anytime algorithm that adaptively adjusts the level of decentralization based on the network's communication topology and constraint dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network show that our approach outperforms existing centralized and decentralized methods in terms of travel time reduction and network throughput.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'GATE', which leverages graph attention networks (GATs) to model agent interactions and task dependencies. GATE enables agents to learn attention weights that reflect the importance of their neighbors' tasks, facilitating coordinated decision-making. We evaluate GATE on a variety of benchmark scenarios, demonstrating improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to state-of-the-art decentralized approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Semantic Search using Graph-Based Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques rely on term co-occurrence or synonyms, which may not capture nuanced semantic relationships. This paper proposes a graph-based approach, 'GraphExpan', that leverages word embeddings to model complex relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. We construct a graph where nodes represent words, and edges denote semantic similarity. Our method efficiently prunes the graph using a novel scoring function, resulting in a more accurate and diverse set of expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and robustness to query ambiguity.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting has numerous applications in finance, healthcare, and energy management. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, their lack of interpretability hinders trust and adoption. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAT) architecture that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant input features and time steps. Our approach provides feature attribution and temporal importance scores, enabling explanations for forecasted values. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate HAT's competitive performance and improved interpretability compared to existing time series forecasting methods.

title: Distributed Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach for distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems using graph neural networks (GNNs). Our approach, called TAGNN, leverages the structural properties of the agent communication graph to learn a distributed task allocation policy. TAGNN consists of two components: a GNN-based task encoder that learns to represent tasks as graph embeddings, and a decentralized allocation algorithm that uses these embeddings to allocate tasks to agents. We evaluate TAGNN on a variety of synthetic and real-world scenarios, demonstrating its effectiveness in achieving efficient and fair task allocation. Our results show that TAGNN outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing system conditions.

title: Query-Adaptive Document Expansion for Improving Retrieval Efficiency in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: In modern search engines, query-dependent document expansion has been shown to improve retrieval efficiency and effectiveness. However, existing methods often rely on simplistic approaches, such as term frequency-based expansion, which may not capture the nuances of the query context. This paper proposes a novel query-adaptive document expansion framework, 'QADE', which leverages graph-based semantic modeling to identify relevant expansion terms. Our approach incorporates a query-dependent attention mechanism to weigh the importance of each expansion term, enabling more accurate and efficient retrieval. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision and a 20% reduction in retrieval time.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A User-Centered Approach to Accessibility
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing inclusive voice assistants, focusing on users with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and usability studies to identify key accessibility requirements. Our findings informed the development of 'AccessibleVox', a novel voice assistant that incorporates adaptive speech recognition, personalized feedback, and multimodal interaction. Evaluation results show significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates for users with disabilities.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic signal control is a complex problem that requires coordination among multiple agents. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'TrafficSync', which leverages graph neural networks to model traffic dynamics and coordination graphs to enable efficient communication among agents. We introduce a hierarchical learning mechanism that decomposes the global reward function into local objectives, allowing agents to learn in parallel and adapt to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a realistic simulation platform demonstrate that TrafficSync reduces congestion by 25% and travel times by 18% compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the complexities of task dependencies, agent capabilities, and communication constraints. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'HeteRAL', which learns to optimize task allocation policies in a decentralized manner. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and task relationships, and incorporates a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to handle task dependencies. Experimental results on a simulated warehouse robotics scenario demonstrate that HeteRAL outperforms traditional optimization methods and achieves near-optimal task allocation efficiency.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: With the proliferation of cloud-based Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms, efficient query optimization has become a critical challenge. This paper presents a novel distributed query optimization framework, 'DQOpt', designed for multi-tenant DBaaS environments. DQOpt leverages a hierarchical, graph-based representation of the query optimization search space, allowing for parallel exploration of alternative query plans. We develop a novel, delay-sensitive cost model that incorporates tenant-specific workload characteristics, enabling more accurate optimization decisions. Experimental results on a real-world DBaaS platform demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing optimization techniques.

title: Designing Accessible Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Voice-Controlled Smart Home Systems
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need to design accessible smart home systems that cater to the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered study on the design of voice-controlled interfaces for smart home systems, focusing on the accessibility requirements of older adults. We conducted a series of usability tests with 20 older adults, identifying key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the development of a set of design guidelines for accessible voice-controlled interfaces, which we evaluate through a prototype implementation. The results demonstrate significant improvements in usability and user satisfaction among older adults.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Learning-based Word Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it aims to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. Our method, called 'EmbedExpan', uses a context-aware embedding model to generate a set of expansion terms that are both semantically similar and contextually relevant to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbedExpan outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, leading to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Adaptive Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel approach using graph attention networks (GATs) to adaptively allocate tasks among agents. Our method, called 'AgentGAT', leverages the structural dependencies between agents and tasks to learn a attention-based allocation policy. Experimental results on various synthetic and real-world scenarios demonstrate that AgentGAT outperforms traditional task allocation methods, such as auction-based approaches, in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As Virtual Reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding user experience is crucial. This paper explores the impact of personalized avatars on user engagement, presence, and perceived realism in VR environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, using a mixed-methods approach to analyze both quantitative and qualitative data. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly enhance user experience, particularly for users with low self-efficacy in VR. We also identify key design factors influencing avatar personalization, including facial features, body type, and clothing. Our findings have implications for the development of more inclusive and effective VR applications.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion via Deep Learning-based Contextualized Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on simplistic term-weighting schemes. This paper proposes a novel QE approach that leverages deep learning-based contextualized embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Our model, 'EmbEx', incorporates a transformer-based architecture to generate dense, contextualized representations of query terms, which are then used to expand the query through a novel attention mechanism. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbEx significantly outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, achieving improved retrieval effectiveness and robustness to query ambiguity.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient and scalable solutions. This paper presents a decentralized approach to task allocation using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). We formulate the task allocation problem as a DCOP and propose a novel algorithm that leverages asynchronous communication and iterative constraint propagation to find near-optimal solutions. Experimental results on a synthetic benchmark dataset show that our approach outperforms existing decentralized methods in terms of solution quality and scalability, making it suitable for large-scale multi-agent systems.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on manually crafted features or word co-occurrence statistics. We propose a neural query expansion approach that leverages dense embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our model, 'NeuQE', incorporates a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query term similarity and relevance feedback. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that NeuQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly for verbose queries and cold-start topics.

title: Embedding Emotional Intelligence in Virtual Assistants using Multimodal Fusion
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have become ubiquitous, yet they often struggle to understand users' emotional states, leading to inadequate responses. This paper presents 'EmoFusion', a novel approach that integrates multimodal cues (speech, text, and facial expressions) to enhance emotional intelligence in virtual assistants. Our system uses a deep neural network to fuse features from each modality, enabling the assistant to recognize and respond empathetically to users' emotional needs. We evaluated EmoFusion in a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in user satisfaction and emotional understanding compared to traditional interfaces.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Augmented Reality Head-Mounted Displays
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) head-mounted displays (HMDs) become increasingly prevalent, ensuring secure user authentication is crucial. This paper explores the feasibility of gaze-based authentication for AR HMDs, leveraging the device's built-in eye-tracking capabilities. We propose a novel approach, 'GazeAuth', which combines machine learning-based gaze pattern analysis with user behavior modeling. Our experiments demonstrate that GazeAuth achieves a high accuracy of 95.2% in distinguishing legitimate users from impostors, while also providing a seamless and non-intrusive authentication experience.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Cognitive Load on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems increasingly rely on gesture recognition to provide an immersive user experience. However, the cognitive load imposed by VR environments can affect the accuracy of gesture recognition systems. This paper presents a comprehensive study on the impact of cognitive load on gesture recognition in VR. We design a novel experimental framework that manipulates cognitive load using a dual-task paradigm and evaluates its effect on gesture recognition performance. Our results show that increased cognitive load leads to a significant decline in gesture recognition accuracy, and that this decline is more pronounced for complex gestures. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of more robust and user-centered VR systems.

title: Efficient Document Indexing with Deep Neural Hashing for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Existing document indexing techniques rely on traditional hashing methods, which suffer from suboptimal performance in high-dimensional spaces. This paper presents a novel deep neural hashing approach, dubbed 'NeuroHash', for efficient document indexing in scalable information retrieval systems. NeuroHash leverages a deep neural network to learn compact binary representations of documents, enabling fast and accurate similarity searches. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroHash outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of search efficiency, document similarity, and query latency.

title: Context-Aware Re-ranking for Session-Based Search using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Session-based search is a crucial component of modern search engines, where the goal is to re-rank documents based on the user's search history. This paper proposes a novel graph neural network (GNN) architecture, 'SessionGNN', that models the complex relationships between queries, documents, and user interactions. We introduce a context-aware re-ranking mechanism that incorporates session-level features, such as query similarity and document co-occurrence, to improve the ranking accuracy. Experimental results on a large-scale search log dataset demonstrate that SessionGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including BERT-based and neural ranking models, in terms of relevance and diversity metrics.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-Driven Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) has become a crucial aspect of sentiment analysis, as it enables transparency into AI-driven decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture, which incorporates both word-level and sentence-level attention mechanisms to capture nuanced sentiment expressions. Our approach leverages a hierarchical fusion of local and global contextual information to provide interpretable sentiment scores. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HAN model outperforms state-of-the-art XAI methods in terms of sentiment accuracy and explanation quality.

title: EmoReact: Affective Gesture Recognition for Emotional Intelligence in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotional intelligence is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, enabling machines to empathize with users' emotional states. This paper presents EmoReact, a novel framework for affective gesture recognition using computer vision and machine learning. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism to extract salient features from hand and facial gestures, which are then classified using a multimodal fusion approach. Our results show that EmoReact achieves state-of-the-art performance on a benchmark dataset, with an average F1-score of 0.92 across six emotions. We discuss the implications of EmoReact for enhancing emotional intelligence in HCI applications, such as virtual assistants and affective computing.

title: Designing Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Upper Limb Impairments
paper_abstract: Upper limb impairments can significantly impact an individual's ability to interact with digital systems. This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that are inclusive of individuals with upper limb impairments. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 participants to identify common challenges and preferences in gesture interaction. Our findings informed the development of 'EasyGest', a gesture recognition system that uses machine learning to adapt to individual differences in motor abilities. A user study with 30 participants demonstrated that EasyGest significantly improves the accuracy and usability of gesture input for individuals with upper limb impairments.

title: Debiasing Neural Networks via Hierarchical Causal Graphs
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks often inherit biases from the training data, perpetuating existing social inequalities. This paper introduces a novel debiasing method, 'CausalDebias', which leverages hierarchical causal graphs to model the relationships between variables. By explicitly representing the causal structure of the data, we can identify and mitigate bias propagation. Our approach is evaluated on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in fairness metrics while maintaining competitive performance on the main task. We further provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method, establishing connections to existing fairness metrics and causal inference techniques.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph Neural Networks for Robust Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommender systems are vulnerable to adversarial attacks that manipulate user ratings to promote or demote items. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks using graph neural networks (GNNs). We model the user-item interaction graph and design a GNN-based detector that learns to identify suspicious patterns. Our approach is robust to various types of attacks and outperforms existing detection methods. We conduct experiments on real-world datasets and demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method in detecting adversarial attacks and improving the overall recommendation quality.

title: Efficient Indexing and Query Optimization for Time-Series Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Time-series data warehouses are increasingly used in various domains, such as IoT, finance, and healthcare. However, efficient indexing and query optimization remain significant challenges. This paper presents a novel indexing scheme, 'TS-Tree', which leverages the temporal and spatial locality of time-series data to reduce storage overhead and improve query performance. We also propose a cost-based query optimizer that takes into account the unique characteristics of time-series data. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing solutions by up to 3x in query response time and 2x in storage efficiency.

title: Designing Emotionally Intelligent Virtual Assistants for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have the potential to improve the daily lives of people with disabilities, but their lack of emotional intelligence can lead to frustration and abandonment. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an emotionally intelligent VA, 'EmpathBot', which incorporates affective computing and adaptive dialogue management to provide personalized support. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with disabilities, showing that EmpathBot significantly outperformed a standard VA in terms of user satisfaction, trust, and perceived empathy. Our results highlight the importance of emotionally intelligent VAs in promoting inclusive and accessible HCI.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) aim to provide transparent and interpretable suggestions to users. While existing ERS methods focus on modeling user-item interactions, they often neglect the complex relationships between items. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that captures both user preferences and item relationships. HAN employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant items and their attributes, generating personalized explanations for each recommendation. Our experiments on a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Adversarial Training with Hierarchical Self-Supervision for Robust Image Classification
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can mislead image classification models. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework that leverages hierarchical self-supervision to improve robustness. Our approach involves training multiple levels of self-supervised tasks, from low-level feature learning to high-level semantic understanding, using a hierarchical curriculum. We demonstrate that this framework leads to more robust image classifiers that are resilient to various types of attacks, including white-box and black-box attacks. Experimental results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 show that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance under different attack scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DaaS) platforms have become increasingly popular, offering scalable and on-demand database resources to multiple tenants. However, optimizing query performance in such multi-tenant environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'QTune', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning-based prediction models to identify optimal query execution plans. QTune incorporates a tenant-aware cost model and a dynamic resource allocation strategy to minimize query latency and maximize resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world DaaS platform demonstrate that QTune achieves an average query performance improvement of 32% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Task Network Planning with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Complex autonomous systems require efficient planning and decision-making capabilities to accomplish tasks in dynamic environments. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task network planning framework that integrates deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize task allocation and execution. Our approach, called HRL-TP, leverages a hierarchical decomposition of tasks to reduce the planning complexity and employs a DRL agent to adaptively adjust the task priorities and resource allocations. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous vehicle scenario demonstrate that HRL-TP significantly outperforms traditional planning methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) require sophisticated control systems to navigate complex, dynamic environments. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'DynaDrive', which integrates high-level decision-making with low-level control policies. DynaDrive leverages a modular architecture to encode domain knowledge and incorporates a novel, graph-based exploration strategy to adapt to changing scenarios. Experimental results on a high-fidelity simulator demonstrate improved safety, efficiency, and adaptability of DynaDrive compared to state-of-the-art baselines in various urban and highway driving scenarios.

title: Adaptive Query Optimization using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face the challenge of optimizing query execution plans in dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel approach to adaptive query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our framework, 'RL-QOpt', learns to select optimal query plans based on feedback from the database system and adapts to changes in data distribution, query patterns, and system workload. Experimental results on a distributed database benchmark demonstrate that RL-QOpt achieves significant performance improvements over traditional optimization techniques, with an average reduction of 30% in query execution time.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance accessibility for users with visual impairments, but existing VR systems often rely on visual cues, excluding these users from immersive experiences. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR experiences that utilize audio and haptic feedback to facilitate navigation and interaction. We conducted a user study with 20 participants with visual impairments, demonstrating that our approach enables them to successfully complete tasks and feel more immersed in the virtual environment. We provide guidelines for VR designers to create more inclusive experiences, promoting equal access to immersive technologies.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a study on designing conversational interfaces that are accessible and usable for older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of user studies with 30 participants to identify the challenges they face when interacting with voice assistants. Our results show that participants struggled with complex dialogue flows, ambiguous intent recognition, and lack of feedback. We propose a set of design guidelines and principles for creating more inclusive conversational interfaces, including the use of simple and consistent language, explicit intent confirmation, and multimodal feedback. Our findings have implications for the development of more accessible and supportive conversational AI systems for older adults.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Efficient Information Retrieval in Short-Text Datasets
paper_abstract: Short-text datasets, such as those found in social media and messaging platforms, pose significant challenges to traditional information retrieval (IR) systems. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages semantic role labeling and entity recognition to better capture the nuances of short-text queries. Our experiments on a large-scale Twitter dataset demonstrate that CAQE improves the retrieval performance of a state-of-the-art IR system by up to 23% in terms of mean average precision, while reducing query latency by an average of 37%. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the impact of contextual features on query expansion and ranking.

title: Hierarchical Task Planning for Autonomous Agents in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in dynamic environments require efficient and adaptive task planning to achieve their objectives. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task planning framework, 'HTP-D', that integrates planning and execution in a unified framework. HTP-D leverages a probabilistic graphical model to represent the environment and agent capabilities, enabling the agent to reason about uncertainty and adapt to changes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HTP-D in a simulated robotic navigation scenario, showcasing improved task completion rates and reduced planning times compared to state-of-the-art planning approaches.

title: Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture nuanced query semantics, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to model complex query relationships. Our approach represents queries as graphs, where nodes correspond to terms and edges capture their semantic dependencies. The HGNN learns to aggregate and propagate information across the graph, generating a set of expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has become a crucial task in various AI applications. However, existing methods suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large-scale graphs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for KGE, which leverages a hierarchical structure to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs and reduce the computational cost. We demonstrate the efficiency and effectiveness of HGAT on several benchmarks, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in terms of both scalability and embedding quality.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents with Hierarchical Task Graphs in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating heterogeneous agents in dynamic environments is a challenging task, particularly when dealing with complex tasks that require cooperation and adaptability. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical task graph (HTG) framework that enables efficient coordination of agents with diverse capabilities and goals. We propose a decentralized planning algorithm that leverages HTGs to generate adaptive plans, which are then executed by the agents in a distributed manner. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, where HTGs improved coordination efficiency by 35% compared to traditional flat task graphs.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As voice-based interfaces become increasingly prevalent, it is essential to ensure their accessibility for older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create an inclusive voice interface, 'EasyVocal', tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops and usability studies to inform the design of EasyVocal, which incorporates features such as simplified language, visual feedback, and error forgiveness.
