Our evaluation results show that EasyVocal significantly improves the user experience and task completion rates for older adults with cognitive impairments, demonstrating the potential for voice interfaces to promote digital inclusion.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query plans for distributed graph databases. Our method, called GraphQLearn, uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan from a set of possible execution plans. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset show that GraphQLearn outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Networks for Interpretable Fake News Detection
paper_abstract: Fake news detection is a critical task in natural language processing, but existing approaches often rely on complex models with limited interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) architecture that leverages graph-based representations of news articles and user interactions. Our model incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to identify relevant features and relations, enabling interpretable explanations for fake news detection. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods while providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR systems often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR experiences for older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with caregivers, healthcare professionals, and older adults to identify key design requirements. Our proposed VR system incorporates cognitive support tools, personalized interfaces, and emotionally engaging content to promote user engagement and accessibility. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach in improving user experience and reducing cognitive load.

title: Automated Feature Engineering for Time-Series Anomaly Detection using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, but manual feature engineering can be time-consuming and suboptimal. This paper introduces 'GrafAnom', a novel framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to automatically extract relevant features from time-series data. We propose a hierarchical graph representation that captures both local and global patterns in the data, and a GNN-based feature learning module that generates a set of discriminative features for anomaly detection. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GrafAnom outperforms state-of-the-art methods while reducing the need for manual feature engineering.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering Using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on effective passage retrieval to retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) approach for ODQA. HDR uses a multi-level hierarchy to represent passages, which enables more accurate and efficient retrieval. We introduce a novel scoring function that leverages both lexical and semantic matching to rank passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset show that HDR outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval methods, achieving a 15% improvement in top-1 passage retrieval accuracy while reducing computational cost by 30%.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Scalable Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in knowledge graph construction, but existing methods suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large-scale datasets. This paper presents a novel indexing framework, 'EDIndex', that enables efficient entity disambiguation by leveraging a combination of graph-based and semantic features. Our approach uses a hierarchical indexing structure to prune the search space, reducing the number of candidate entities to be disambiguated. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EDIndex outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and runtime performance.

title: Unsupervised Representation Learning for Time-Series Anomaly Detection using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. While existing methods often rely on handcrafted features or supervised learning, we propose an unsupervised approach using graph neural networks (GNNs). Our method, GraphAnomaly, learns representations of time-series data by modeling their structural properties as graphs. We introduce a novel graph autoencoder architecture that incorporates temporal convolution and graph attention mechanisms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphAnomaly in detecting anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods by up to 15% in terms of F1-score.

title: Designing Emotion-Aware Virtual Assistants for Older Adults: A Study on Voice-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for virtual assistants that can effectively interact with older adults. This paper presents a study on designing emotion-aware virtual assistants that can recognize and respond to the emotional states of older adults through voice-based interaction. We developed a multimodal framework that integrates speech recognition, natural language processing, and affective computing to detect emotional cues in voice inputs. Our user study with 30 older adults shows that our approach can improve the user experience and reduce frustration with virtual assistants. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more empathetic and supportive virtual assistants for older adults.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for autonomous task allocation, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities and environmental constraints. We introduce a novel decomposition method that separates the task allocation problem into two levels: high-level planning and low-level execution. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario show that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Deep Learning Models Against Multi-Modal Attacks
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have been shown to be vulnerable to various types of attacks, including image-based and audio-based attacks. This paper investigates the robustness of deep learning models against multi-modal attacks, where an attacker manipulates both images and audio inputs to deceive the model. We propose a novel framework, 'MM-Defense', that leverages adversarial training and input pre-processing to improve the robustness of deep learning models against multi-modal attacks. Our experiments demonstrate that MM-Defense achieves significant improvements in robustness against state-of-the-art attacks, while maintaining accuracy on clean data.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for People with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but people with dyslexia often face significant barriers when interacting with these systems. This paper presents 'DyslexiaAware', a novel framework for designing accessible conversational interfaces tailored to the needs of individuals with dyslexia. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving co-design workshops and usability testing to identify key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our results show that DyslexiaAware significantly improves interaction times, accuracy, and user satisfaction for participants with dyslexia, while also providing a more inclusive and user-friendly experience for all users.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, leveraging graph neural networks (GNNs) to model complex agent interactions. Our approach, called 'GNN-TA', utilizes a distributed GNN architecture to learn a task allocation policy that adapts to dynamic agent capabilities and environmental changes. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GNN-TA through extensive simulations, showing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing decentralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Batch Processing for Scalable and Accurate Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have emerged as a powerful tool for graph-structured data analysis. However, their scalability and accuracy are limited by the batch processing mechanism, which can lead to high computational costs and memory usage. This paper proposes a novel batch processing framework, 'BatchGN', which leverages adaptive batch sizing, graph partitioning, and cache-friendly data layout to minimize memory access patterns and optimize computation. Experimental results on large-scale graph benchmarks demonstrate that BatchGN achieves up to 5x speedup and 10% accuracy improvement compared to existing state-of-the-art GNN implementations.

title: Efficient Out-of-Distribution Detection using Hierarchical Gaussian Mixture Models
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to errors when encountering out-of-distribution (OOD) inputs. Existing methods for OOD detection often rely on complex and computationally expensive techniques. This paper proposes a novel approach based on hierarchical Gaussian mixture models (HGMMs) that can efficiently detect OOD samples. Our method leverages the hierarchical structure of HGMMs to model the underlying data distribution and identify anomalies. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting OOD samples while achieving significant speedups over existing methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. While deep learning models have achieved state-of-the-art performance, they often lack interpretability, hindering their adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that not only detects anomalies accurately but also provides explanations for its predictions. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to identify relevant time series segments and features, enabling model interpretability. Experimental results on three real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies and providing actionable insights.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval continues to be a challenging problem in information retrieval. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, called Neural Expansion (NE), uses a graph-based neural network to learn term embeddings that can effectively capture context and synonyms. We evaluate NE on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods. Furthermore, we show that NE can be effectively integrated with existing retrieval models to achieve state-of-the-art performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Semantic Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly improve the recall of relevant documents. However, traditional query expansion methods often rely on manually curated thesauri or expensive machine learning models. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using semantic embeddings, which capture the nuances of word meanings in high-dimensional vector spaces. We introduce a lightweight neural network that learns to predict relevant expansion terms based on the semantic relationships between query words and the document corpus. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision and recall, while requiring significantly fewer computational resources.

title: Efficient Document Indexing for Scalable Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing volume of digital data demands efficient indexing techniques for information retrieval systems. This paper presents a novel document indexing approach, 'HierIndex', which leverages hierarchical clustering and sparse matrix representations to reduce index size and query latency. We evaluate HierIndex on a large-scale document collection and demonstrate significant improvements in indexing time, query performance, and storage efficiency compared to existing methods. Our approach is particularly suitable for real-time search applications and distributed information retrieval systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAT-GNN) approach for effective anomaly detection in time-series data. HAT-GNN leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between time-series data and captures temporal dependencies using hierarchical attention. We evaluate our approach on several real-world datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and false positive rates.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality using Deep Learning-based Eye Tracking
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems require accurate and efficient interaction mechanisms to provide an immersive user experience. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based interaction framework that leverages deep learning-based eye tracking to detect user intentions. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to classify gaze patterns and infer user interactions, achieving an average accuracy of 95.2% on a benchmark dataset. We also present a comprehensive evaluation of our system in a VR gaming scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction latency and user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Column-Oriented Storage
paper_abstract: The increasing scale of big data analytics has led to a surge in the use of column-oriented storage systems. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'COLOPT', which leverages the columnar storage layout to reduce query latency and improve system throughput. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that takes into account the column-wise data distribution and storage layout to generate efficient query plans. Experimental results on a real-world big data analytics workload demonstrate that COLOPT outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explanations for Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of transparency in learned policies hinders trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HAX', which generates explanations for DRL policies. HAX recursively decomposes the policy into attention weights, highlighting the most relevant states, actions, and features contributing to the decision-making process. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAX on several Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing its ability to provide insightful explanations, improve policy interpretation, and facilitate policy improvement through human-in-the-loop feedback.

title: SQLShield: A Novel SQL Injection Detection Framework using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: SQL injection attacks remain a significant threat to database security, with traditional detection methods often relying on rule-based approaches that can be evaded by sophisticated attackers. This paper presents SQLShield, a novel deep learning-based framework for detecting SQL injection attacks in real-time. We propose a hybrid model that combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to analyze SQL query patterns and identify malicious intent. Evaluations on a large dataset of SQL queries demonstrate that SQLShield achieves an accuracy of 97.5% and outperforms existing detection methods, with a significant reduction in false positives and false negatives.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing has become a ubiquitous paradigm for scalable and on-demand computing resources. However, efficient resource allocation remains a significant challenge, particularly in dynamic and heterogeneous environments. This paper presents a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'CloudOpt', which learns to optimize resource allocation policies in cloud data centers. By leveraging a hybrid actor-critic architecture and a carefully designed reward function, CloudOpt achieves significant improvements in resource utilization, response time, and energy efficiency compared to traditional heuristic-based approaches. We evaluate CloudOpt on a realistic cloud simulation platform and demonstrate its scalability and adaptability to diverse workload patterns.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Retrieval of Short Text Documents
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, especially for short text documents where the initial query may not provide sufficient context. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'DeepQE', which learns to expand the query by identifying relevant terms and phrases from the document collection. We employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and document content. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DeepQE outperforms traditional query expansion methods, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained popularity in recent years, leveraging advances in computer vision and machine learning. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which models human skeletons as hierarchical graphs and incorporates attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant joints and sub-graphs. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on popular benchmarks, including NTU-RGB+D and Kinectics, and demonstrates improved robustness to noise and occlusion. We also provide an ablation study to quantify the contributions of each component to the overall performance.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval (IR) often rely on complex feature engineering and exhaustive document matching, leading to high computational costs. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, HNR, which leverages self-attention mechanisms to capture contextualized document representations. HNR employs a two-stage ranking framework, where a coarse-grained ranking module first filters out irrelevant documents, followed by a fine-grained ranking module that refines the scores using hierarchical attention. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate that HNR achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by up to 40% compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Ranking Models using Adaptive Term Weighting
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but they often rely on simple term frequency-based query representations. This paper proposes an adaptive term weighting approach for query expansion, which selectively incorporates relevant terms from the top-ranked documents. Our method leverages a neural network to predict term importance and dynamically adjusts the weights based on the query context. Experimental results on the TREC 2004 dataset demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the retrieval performance of neural ranking models, outperforming existing query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time decision-making to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for efficient control of autonomous vehicles. Our approach leverages a high-level planning module to generate abstract actions, which are then translated into low-level control outputs using a deep deterministic policy gradient algorithm. We introduce a hierarchical exploration strategy that adaptively allocates exploration resources between the planning and control modules, resulting in improved learning efficiency and robustness. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving platform demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving real-time control while outperforming flat RL baselines.

title: Designing Embodied Conversational Agents for Older Adults: A Study on Cognitive Load and User Experience
paper_abstract: This study investigates the design of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) tailored to older adults, focusing on cognitive load and user experience. We developed an ECA system incorporating multimodal interaction (speech, gesture, and facial expressions) and evaluated its effectiveness in a user study with 30 older adults. Results show that our ECA design reduces cognitive load and improves user experience compared to traditional text-based interfaces. We also identify key design factors influencing user engagement and perceived trustworthiness, providing valuable insights for the development of ECAs that cater to the needs of older adults.

title: Efficient Few-Shot Learning with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has emerged as a crucial problem in machine learning, where models must adapt to new classes with limited data. This paper presents Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), a novel architecture that leverages a hierarchical clustering approach to learn robust prototypes. HPN demonstrated state-of-the-art performance on multiple few-shot learning benchmarks, including mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet. We show that HPN's hierarchical structure enables more effective aggregation of prototypes, leading to improved few-shot classification accuracy and reduced overfitting.

title: Efficient Neural Network Pruning for Resource-Constrained Edge Devices
paper_abstract: The proliferation of edge devices has created a pressing need for efficient neural network models that can operate under severe resource constraints. This paper presents a novel pruning method, 'EdgePrune', which leverages a combination of magnitude-based pruning and knowledge distillation to reduce model size and computational complexity. Our approach exploits the inherent redundancy in deep neural networks to achieve significant reductions in memory footprint and energy consumption, while maintaining accuracy. Experimental results on various edge devices demonstrate that EdgePrune outperforms existing pruning methods, enabling real-time inference on resource-constrained devices.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems are crucial for building trust and transparency in AI-driven decision-making. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Network (HAGNN) model that learns to generate interpretable recommendations by capturing complex relationships between users, items, and their attributes. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features and relationships, generating explanations that are both accurate and informative. We evaluate HAGNN on multiple benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and explanation quality compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Long-Tail Classification
paper_abstract: Class imbalance in long-tail datasets hinders the performance of deep learning models. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that selectively focuses on tail classes by leveraging a hierarchical abstraction of the class distribution. Our approach adaptively adjusts the attention weights based on the class frequency, allowing the model to concentrate on the most informative samples. Experimental results on several long-tail benchmarks demonstrate that HAN consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved accuracy and F1-score on tail classes while maintaining competitive performance on head classes.

title: EmoSpark: Affective State Recognition using Electrodermal Activity and Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition has become increasingly important in human-computer interaction (HCI). This paper presents EmoSpark, a novel affective state recognition system that leverages electrodermal activity (EDA) and machine learning techniques. We collect EDA signals from 30 participants while they experience various emotional stimuli, and develop a deep neural network that achieves 87.2% accuracy in classifying four emotions: happiness, sadness, fear, and anger. We demonstrate EmoSpark's applicability in HCI scenarios, such as emotion-aware gaming and mental health monitoring, and discuss its implications for designing more empathetic and personalized interfaces.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems, where agents with limited communication ranges need to collectively accomplish tasks in a dynamic environment. We propose a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a distributed task allocation policy. Our method, called GNN-TA, uses a decentralized GNN architecture to learn a latent representation of the agent-task graph, enabling agents to make allocation decisions based on local information. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that GNN-TA outperforms existing decentralized methods in terms of task completion rate and communication efficiency.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for People with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize experiences for people with visual impairments, but existing VR interfaces are often inaccessible. This paper presents an inclusive VR design framework that incorporates haptic feedback, audio cues, and voice commands to enable visually impaired users to navigate and interact with virtual environments. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, which revealed significant improvements in usability and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. Our framework provides a foundation for developing more accessible VR experiences, promoting equal access to immersive technologies for people with visual impairments.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Structured Representation Learning
paper_abstract: Learning representations from structured data, such as graphs, is a crucial task in machine learning. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and edges at multiple scales. HGAN captures complex patterns and relationships in graph-structured data by iteratively applying attention-based graph pooling and feature refinement. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAN in improving graph classification, node classification, and link prediction tasks.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we tackle the decentralized task allocation problem for heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities and preferences need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning approach, 'MAgent-alloc', which learns to assign tasks to agents based on their characteristics and the task requirements. Our approach utilizes a graph neural network to model the agent-task interactions and a decentralized actor-critic framework to optimize the task allocation policy. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of MAgent-alloc in achieving high task completion rates and efficient resource utilization.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has emerged as a crucial technique for AI applications. However, existing KGE methods struggle to capture complex relationships and hierarchical structures inherent in large-scale knowledge graphs. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) for KGE, which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant entities and relationships. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several benchmarks, achieving state-of-the-art performance on link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Retrieval
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) approach that leverages dense passage embeddings and hierarchical clustering to prune the search space. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDR achieves a 30% increase in retrieval recall at a lower computational cost compared to state-of-the-art sparse retrieval methods. We further analyze the effectiveness of HDR in downstream QA tasks, showing improved answer accuracy and reduced latency.

title: Designing Intelligent Virtual Assistants for Inclusive Accessibility in Smart Homes
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for designing intelligent virtual assistants (IVAs) that cater to the diverse needs of individuals with disabilities in smart home environments. Our approach integrates machine learning-based intent recognition with situated cognition theory to create personalized and adaptive interfaces. We evaluate our IVA prototype through a user study with 30 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction for individuals with visual and motor impairments. Our findings have implications for the development of inclusive and accessible smart home systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults using Embodied Cognition Principles
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their accessibility for older adults remains a concern. This paper presents an embodied cognition-inspired design framework for creating inclusive conversational interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a user study with 30 participants aged 65+, exploring the effects of anthropomorphic agents, spatial memory cues, and multimodal feedback on their engagement and comprehension. Our findings suggest that incorporating embodied cognition principles can significantly improve older adults' interaction experience and reduce cognitive load. We provide design guidelines and implications for future research.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a complex problem, particularly when agents have different capabilities and preferences. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments. Our approach, called HeteroAgent, uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal task allocation policy based on agent characteristics, task requirements, and environmental constraints. Simulation results demonstrate that HeteroAgent outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate, agent satisfaction, and system adaptability.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems are increasingly popular in cloud computing, but optimizing query performance for diverse workloads remains a challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to select optimal query plans based on feedback from the database system. Our approach leverages a combination of exploration strategies and a custom reward function to efficiently explore the vast space of possible query plans. Experiments on a real-world benchmark dataset show that our RL-based optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and throughput.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on effective passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, QDE, which leverages the question's semantic context to expand the initial document set. QDE uses a combination of keyword extraction, semantic role labeling, and graph-based ranking to identify and weight relevant expansion terms. Our experiments on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate that QDE significantly improves passage retrieval accuracy and downstream QA performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, especially for questions with ambiguous or multipart answers.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings and Graph Attention
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial task in data integration and knowledge graph construction. Existing approaches often suffer from scalability issues when dealing with large datasets. This paper proposes a novel entity disambiguation framework, 'EDEmbed', which leverages knowledge graph embeddings and graph attention mechanisms to efficiently disambiguate entities. We introduce a hierarchical attention scheme that captures both local and global context, enabling accurate disambiguation even in the presence of noisy or incomplete data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EDEmbed outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and scalability.

title: Unsupervised Query Expansion using Hierarchical Graph-Based Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal search results. This paper proposes a novel unsupervised query expansion method, Hierarchical Graph-based Embeddings for Retrieval (HGER), which leverages graph neural networks to model complex query-document relationships. HGER represents queries and documents as hierarchical graph structures, allowing for the capture of nuanced contextual information. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGER significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for ambiguous and long-tail queries.

title: Evaluating the Effects of Anthropomorphic Feedback on User Engagement in Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces are increasingly prevalent in modern computing, but their effectiveness relies heavily on user engagement. This study investigates the impact of anthropomorphic feedback on user experience and behavior in conversational systems. We designed and conducted a user study with 120 participants, comparing three types of feedback: human-like, machine-like, and no feedback. Our results show that anthropomorphic feedback significantly improves user engagement, perceived system intelligence, and self-reported enjoyment. Furthermore, we identify specific linguistic features that contribute to these effects. The findings have implications for the design of conversational interfaces in various applications, such as chatbots, voice assistants, and online customer support.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach, called 'AgentTA', enables agents to learn to allocate tasks efficiently in a decentralized manner without requiring a centralized coordinator. We model the task allocation problem as a Markov game and employ a novel variant of the Q-learning algorithm, which incorporates a reward function that encourages cooperation among agents. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that AgentTA outperforms traditional centralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component of ad-hoc search systems, as it can significantly impact retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. Our method, dubbed 'NeuroExpander', leverages a combination of word embeddings and recurrent neural networks to generate high-quality expansion terms. We evaluate NeuroExpander on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion techniques. Furthermore, we analyze the learned representations and provide insights into the effectiveness of our approach.

title: EmoTract: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Framework for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Accurate emotion recognition is crucial for developing empathetic human-computer interfaces. Existing approaches rely on a single modality, such as facial expressions or speech, which can be limiting in real-world scenarios. This paper presents EmoTract, a novel multimodal framework that integrates computer vision, audio processing, and physiological signal analysis to recognize emotions in HCI. EmoTract employs a hierarchical fusion strategy, combining the strengths of individual modalities to improve recognition accuracy. We evaluate EmoTract on a large, diverse dataset and demonstrate its superior performance compared to state-of-the-art unimodal approaches.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Robot navigation in dynamic environments remains a challenging problem due to the complexity of sensorimotor interactions and the need for real-time decision-making. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Nav', which decomposes the navigation task into a series of sub-goals and learns to adapt to changing environmental conditions. We introduce a novel attention-based mechanism that selectively focuses on relevant sensory inputs, reducing the dimensionality of the state space and improving navigation efficiency. Experimental results on a simulated robotic platform demonstrate that HRL-Nav outperforms existing flat RL methods in terms of task completion time and success rate.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehouses require efficient query optimization to support analytics and decision-making. This paper presents 'AdapQO', a novel query optimization framework that combines machine learning and database techniques to adapt to changing workloads and data distributions. AdapQO leverages a neural network to predict query execution times and dynamically adjusts optimization strategies, leading to significant performance improvements. We evaluate AdapQO on a diverse set of real-world datasets, demonstrating its ability to outperform state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Distributed Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, multi-agent systems face the challenge of task allocation, where agents must adapt to changing task demands and resource constraints. We propose a novel distributed task allocation framework that leverages multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to optimize task assignments. Our approach incorporates a decentralized communication protocol and a novel reward function that encourages agents to explore and exploit task opportunities. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our framework outperforms traditional centralized and decentralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rates and agent utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) is a challenging task that requires integrating information from multiple sources, such as text, images, and videos. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for MSA, which learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features at multiple levels. Our approach leverages a multimodal fusion module to combine modalities, followed by a hierarchical attention mechanism that weights the importance of each modality and feature. Experimental results on the MM-IMDb dataset demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art MSA models, achieving an improvement of 3.5% in accuracy and 2.1% in F1-score.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal sentiment analysis (MSA) has become increasingly important in understanding user opinions from diverse data sources. However, existing approaches often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that efficiently fuses and selects relevant features from text, image, and audio modalities. Our approach leverages a multi-level attention mechanism that adaptively weights features based on their sentiment relevance, resulting in improved performance and reduced inference time. Experiments on three benchmark MSA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving state-of-the-art results with significant speedup.

title: End-to-End Neural Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient retrieval of relevant passages from a massive corpus to answer a given question. This paper proposes a novel end-to-end neural retrieval framework, 'NeurRetriever', which replaces traditional pipeline-based approaches. Our model leverages a hierarchical encoder to jointly learn question and passage representations, and a differentiable retrieval mechanism to optimize the retrieval process. Experiments on the Natural Questions benchmark show that NeurRetriever outperforms state-of-the-art pipeline-based models, achieving 5.2% absolute improvement in exact match score while reducing inference time by 30%.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user experience in VR environments. We designed an experiment with 120 participants, using a 3D avatar customization system that incorporates facial recognition, body shape analysis, and personality traits. Our results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, measured through self-reported satisfaction, time spent in VR, and physiological responses. We also identify key factors influencing user preferences for avatar personalization, including age, gender, and personality traits.

title: Enabling Accessible Gesture Recognition with Personalized Machine Learning Models
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but current approaches often struggle with individual variations in gesture patterns. This paper presents a novel framework that leverages machine learning to create personalized gesture recognition models tailored to each user's unique motor abilities and habits. Our approach combines transfer learning with a Bayesian optimization technique to adapt to individual users' gesture datasets, resulting in significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction. We evaluate our system with a diverse user group, demonstrating its effectiveness in enabling accessible interaction for individuals with disabilities.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have revolutionized the way people interact with technology, but their potential benefits are often inaccessible to older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive voice assistants that accommodate the unique needs and abilities of this population. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with older adults and caregivers, identifying key barriers to adoption and informing the development of a prototype voice assistant that incorporates cognitive support features, such as personalized prompts, error forgiveness, and multimodal feedback. Our evaluation results show significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Multi-Armed Bandits
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation strategies to maximize overall performance. This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages multi-armed bandit (MAB) algorithms to adaptively assign tasks to agents. We introduce a novel MAB variant, 'Coop-UCB', which incorporates agent-to-agent communication to share knowledge and reduce exploration-exploitation tradeoffs. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that Coop-UCB achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and overall system efficiency compared to existing decentralized task allocation methods.

title: Entity Disambiguation using Graph Attention Networks for Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various natural language processing and information retrieval applications. However, entity disambiguation remains a significant challenge in these models, particularly when dealing with ambiguous entity mentions. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph attention networks to disambiguate entities in knowledge graph embeddings. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global context, enabling the model to differentiate between entities with similar names. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance in entity disambiguation tasks, outperforming existing methods by a significant margin.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Prototypical Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when models are required to generalize to new classes with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, Hierarchical Prototypical Networks (HPN), which leverages a hierarchical structure to learn robust and transferable representations. HPN consists of a nested prototypical network architecture that captures both local and global patterns in the data, enabling effective adaptation to new classes. We demonstrate the efficacy of HPN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in few-shot image classification tasks.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Real-world Object Detection
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized the design of deep neural networks for various tasks. However, existing NAS methods are computationally expensive and often focus on simplified proxy tasks. This paper proposes a novel, efficient NAS framework, 'RealNAS', specifically tailored for real-world object detection. RealNAS leverages a hierarchical search space and a novel, differentiable neural predictor to reduce the search cost by 3x while achieving state-of-the-art object detection performance on the COCO dataset. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of RealNAS in discovering efficient architectures for object detection in various scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems cater to diverse workloads, leading to complex query optimization challenges. This paper presents a novel Reinforcement Learning (RL) framework, 'QueryOpt', that adapts to dynamic workload patterns and optimizes query execution plans. QueryOpt leverages a Deep Q-Network to learn a policy that balances query performance and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world benchmark demonstrate that QueryOpt achieves up to 30% improvement in query response times and 25% reduction in resource consumption compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but users often struggle with navigation and interaction in immersive environments. This paper investigates the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience in VR. We designed and implemented a novel haptic feedback system, 'HapVR', which provides tactile cues to users through a wearable device. Our user study involving 30 participants shows that HapVR significantly improves user satisfaction, reduces navigation errors, and enhances overall immersion in VR applications. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems and highlight avenues for further research.

title: Enhancing Virtual Reality User Experience through Eye-Tracking based Adaptive Foveated Rendering
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized immersive experiences, but its high computational demands often lead to decreased performance and visual quality. This paper presents a novel eye-tracking based adaptive foveated rendering (EFR) technique that optimizes VR rendering by allocating processing resources to the user's gaze direction. We propose a machine learning model that predicts the user's gaze pattern and dynamically adjusts the rendering resolution, resulting in significant performance improvements and reduced computational overhead. Our user study shows that the proposed EFR technique enhances the overall VR user experience, with participants reporting improved visual quality and reduced fatigue.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the need to integrate heterogeneous data sources. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and time segments to improve emotion recognition performance. Our approach leverages a hierarchical structure to capture both local and global contextual information and incorporates a modality-aware attention mechanism to adaptively weight the contributions of each modality. Experimental results on the multimodal emotion recognition benchmark dataset show that our proposed HAN outperforms state-of-the-art approaches by 12.5% in terms of weighted F1-score.

title: Scalable Anomaly Detection in Time-Series Data using Graph-based Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is crucial for various applications, including IoT monitoring and financial forecasting. However, existing methods struggle with high-dimensional data and limited labeled samples. This paper presents 'GraphCon', a novel approach that leverages graph-based contrastive learning to identify anomalies in time-series data. By constructing a graph from the time-series data and applying contrastive learning, GraphCon learns robust representations that capture complex patterns and relationships. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate GraphCon's superiority over state-of-the-art methods, achieving an average improvement of 15% in F1-score and 20% in AUC-ROC.

title: Hierarchical Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, requiring models to adapt quickly to new classes with limited data. This paper presents a hierarchical meta-learning framework, 'HML-FS', which leverages a novel combination of metric-based and optimization-based meta-learning techniques. HML-FS learns to generate task-specific prototypes and adapt the optimizer's initialization, leading to significant improvements in few-shot classification accuracy on several benchmark datasets. We also provide theoretical insights into the convergence properties of our approach, demonstrating its robustness to varying task distributions.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has garnered significant attention in recent years, but existing approaches struggle to scale to large graphs. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which leverages hierarchical graph representations to efficiently process graphs of varying sizes. HGAT incorporates a novel attention mechanism that adaptively focuses on relevant subgraphs, enabling effective few-shot learning on large graphs. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks to optimize query plans. We model the database schema as a graph and use a graph neural network to learn a representation of the query plan space. Our approach, called 'GQN', uses this representation to efficiently explore the query plan space and identify optimal plans. Experimental results on a real-world benchmark dataset demonstrate that GQN outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query execution time and plan quality.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval (IR) systems often struggle with capturing complex document relationships and semantics. We propose a novel approach, HierGNN-IR, which leverages hierarchical graph neural networks (GNNs) to model document structures and interactions. By representing documents as nodes in a graph, we can capture both local and global dependencies, enabling more accurate retrieval. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, particularly for long-tail queries. We also introduce a new evaluation metric, Graph-based Retrieval Performance (GRP), to better assess IR system performance in graph-based settings.

title: Adversarial Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to adapt to complex driving scenarios. However, RL agents can be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise safety and reliability. This paper introduces a novel framework, 'AdvRL', which integrates adversarial training into the RL process for autonomous vehicle control. We formulate the attack as a minimax game between the RL agent and an adversary, and demonstrate that AdvRL improves the robustness of the agent to targeted attacks. Experimental results on a simulated driving environment show that AdvRL outperforms traditional RL methods in adversarial scenarios, while maintaining comparable performance in nominal conditions.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal sentiment analysis (MSA) involves analyzing sentiment from diverse data sources such as text, images, and videos. While deep learning approaches have shown promising results, they often lack transparency and interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for MSA, which uses attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. We introduce a multi-modal fusion module that adaptively weights the importance of each modality based on the input data. Experimental results on a benchmark MSA dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods while providing interpretable attention weights for sentiment classification.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, dubbed 'GraphExpan', which leverages graph-based embeddings to model semantic relationships between query terms. By incorporating entity disambiguation and contextualized word representations, GraphExpan significantly improves retrieval performance compared to traditional lexical-based methods. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, efficient query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of graph queries and the distributed nature of the data. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages graph structural properties and distributed indexing techniques to reduce query latency and improve throughput. We introduce a cost-based optimization approach that adaptively selects the most efficient query plan based on the underlying data distribution and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query latency and 2x in terms of throughput.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinated task allocation using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Our approach, called 'CATS', learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, preferences, and task dependencies. We employ a decentralized DRL architecture, where each agent learns to make decisions based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. Experimental results on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that CATS outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of solution quality, scalability, and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Improving Search Result Diversity
paper_abstract: Search engines often struggle to provide diverse search results, leading to a lack of novelty and redundancy in the retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel context-aware query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which incorporates user search history and preferences to improve search result diversity. CAQE employs a graph-based method to model the semantic relationships between query terms and expands the query using contextualized embeddings. Experimental results on a large-scale web search dataset show that CAQE significantly improves search result diversity and novelty, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval using Hierarchical Dense Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents containing the answer. We propose a novel approach, HierDPR, which leverages hierarchical dense representations to model document passages at multiple granularities. Our method first represents each passage as a hierarchical structure of dense vectors, capturing local and global semantic cues. Then, we employ a neural retrieval model to compute similarities between the question and passage representations. Experimental results on the Natural Questions and TriviaQA datasets demonstrate that HierDPR significantly outperforms existing passage retrieval methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and downstream QA performance.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of distributed task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have varying capabilities and tasks require different resources. We propose a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'HetroMAL', which trains agents to learn optimal task assignment policies in a decentralized manner. HetroMAL leverages graph neural networks to model agent interactions and task dependencies, and uses a hierarchical actor-critic architecture to balance exploration and exploitation. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HetroMAL outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system efficiency.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) environments, focusing on the role of gesture-based interaction in shaping user experience. We designed a VR system that utilizes hand-tracking technology to enable users to manipulate virtual objects using natural hand gestures. Our study reveals that users who employed gestures to interact with virtual objects exhibited improved cognitive performance and enhanced sense of presence compared to those using traditional controllers. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of more intuitive and immersive VR interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Explainable Reasoning for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) is crucial for trust-worthy decision-making in multi-agent systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention mechanism, 'HierAttn', that enables explainable reasoning in complex, dynamic environments. HierAttn integrates graph attention networks with hierarchical reinforcement learning to reason about agent interactions, goals, and intentions. We evaluate HierAttn on a real-world autonomous vehicle dataset, demonstrating improved explainability and decision-making performance compared to state-of-the-art XAI methods. Our approach has significant implications for human-AI collaboration and trust in safety-critical applications.

title: Uncertainty-Aware Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: Autonomous systems rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to make decisions in complex, dynamic environments. However, the lack of explainability and uncertainty awareness in RL models hinders their deployment in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes 'UAREL', an uncertainty-aware explainable RL framework that integrates Bayesian neural networks with model-based RL. We develop a novel uncertainty quantification method that propagates epistemic uncertainty through the decision-making process, enabling the agent to reason about its own uncertainty. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving scenario demonstrate that UAREL improves decision-making robustness and provides interpretable explanations for its actions.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, query performance remains a significant bottleneck in these systems. This paper proposes an adaptive indexing technique, 'AIQ', which dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distributions. AIQ leverages machine learning algorithms to predict query hotspots and optimize indexing structures accordingly. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that AIQ achieves up to 30% improvement in query response time and 25% reduction in storage overhead compared to traditional indexing techniques.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Individuals with Motor Disabilities
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have transformed human-computer interaction, but individuals with motor disabilities often face challenges using these systems. This paper presents an adaptive gesture recognition framework, 'AdaptGest', which leverages machine learning and computer vision to accommodate varying motor abilities. AdaptGest integrates a novel gesture representation model with a personalized adaptation mechanism, enabling the system to learn from user interactions and adjust its recognition thresholds accordingly. Our user study with 20 participants with motor disabilities demonstrates significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user experience compared to existing gesture recognition systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Few-shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot node classification in graph-structured data is a challenging task, particularly when limited labeled data is available. This paper introduces Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks (HAGNN), a novel architecture that leverages hierarchical graph attention mechanisms to adapt to new classes. HAGNN combines node-level and graph-level attention to capture both local and global structural patterns, enabling effective few-shot learning. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving up to 15% improvement in accuracy on 5-shot node classification tasks.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Neural Ranking Model for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial step in many information retrieval applications, including question answering and text summarization. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based neural ranking model, HANR, which leverages both local and global contextual information to improve passage retrieval accuracy. HANR employs a multi-layered attention mechanism to capture hierarchical relationships between query terms, passage sentences, and passage-level representations. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HANR outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in terms of mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Investigating the Effect of Haptic Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various fields, but current VR systems often lack tactile feedback, leading to a sense of disconnection from the virtual environment. This paper explores the impact of haptic feedback on user experience in VR. We designed and implemented a custom VR system that incorporates vibrotactile feedback, and conducted a user study to evaluate its effects on presence, immersion, and overall user satisfaction. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly enhances user experience, particularly in tasks requiring object manipulation and spatial awareness. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the heterogeneity of modalities. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that effectively integrates and represents multi-modal data. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture intra- and inter-modal relationships, and a hierarchical architecture to model emotion hierarchies. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal data, with improved robustness to noisy or missing modalities.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular, but query optimization remains a challenging problem due to the complex interactions between query plans and data distribution. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. We design a Markov decision process to model the query optimization problem and develop a deep Q-network to learn an optimal policy. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that our approach outperforms traditional rule-based optimizers and achieves an average speedup of 2.5x in query execution time.

title: Scalable and Efficient Query Processing for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have gained popularity due to their ability to efficiently manage and scale resources. However, query processing remains a significant challenge, as it requires balancing performance, isolation, and fairness across tenants. This paper proposes a novel query processing framework, 'QTune', which leverages a combination of query rewriting, indexing, and caching techniques to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. We evaluate QTune on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant performance improvements compared to existing approaches, while ensuring strong isolation and fairness guarantees.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants and chatbots, are increasingly prevalent in daily life. However, people with disabilities often face barriers in using these technologies due to inaccessible design. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for designing inclusive conversational interfaces, incorporating insights from user studies with individuals with visual, hearing, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We introduce a set of accessibility guidelines and a novel evaluation methodology, demonstrating their effectiveness in improving user experience and task completion rates for users with disabilities.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in modern data centers, but optimizing query execution remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to optimize query plans. We design a DRL agent that learns to select efficient query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution times. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Indexing for Temporal Graph Databases
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly important for modeling dynamic relationships in various domains. However, querying these databases efficiently remains a significant challenge. We propose a novel indexing technique, 'TempoGraph', which leverages the temporal locality of graph updates to reduce query latency. TempoGraph utilizes a combination of graph partitioning and temporal clustering to facilitate fast retrieval of temporal graph snapshots. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that TempoGraph outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods by up to 3x in query performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search using Adaptive Density Estimation
paper_abstract: Neural search has shown promise in improving the retrieval performance of information retrieval systems. However, query expansion remains a crucial step in enhancing the search results. This paper introduces a novel query expansion framework that leverages adaptive density estimation to model the underlying document distribution. Our approach, called ADEN, adaptively adjusts the density estimation parameters based on the query complexity and document relevance. We evaluate ADEN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in terms of precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Commonsense Reasoning
paper_abstract: Commonsense reasoning is a crucial aspect of human intelligence, yet it remains a challenging task for AI systems. This paper proposes a novel knowledge graph embedding method, 'HAT-KGE', which leverages hierarchical attention to capture complex relationships between entities and their attributes. By incorporating a graph neural network with attention-based aggregation, HAT-KGE outperforms state-of-the-art models on several benchmarks, including ConceptNet and ATOMIC. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in various commonsense reasoning tasks, such as event prediction and scenario understanding.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex interactions between agents. However, the lack of transparency in these interactions hinders trust and understanding. We introduce Hierarchical Attention Networks (HANs), a novel deep learning approach that learns to explain multi-agent decision-making processes. HANs employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant agent interactions, generating interpretable explanations for the collective decision. Our experiments on a synthetic traffic management scenario demonstrate that HANs outperform state-of-the-art methods in terms of decision accuracy while providing insights into the decision-making process.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Mechanisms for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decentralized negotiation mechanisms are crucial for agents to reach mutually beneficial agreements. This paper proposes a novel negotiation protocol, 'Distributed-ACOPF', which leverages approximation algorithms for solving the Asymmetric Connected Oriented Preferences Framework (ACOPF) problem. We develop a distributed negotiation mechanism that enables agents to iteratively exchange proposals and counter-proposals, converging to a Pareto-optimal agreement. Experimental results on a supply chain management scenario demonstrate that Distributed-ACOPF outperforms existing decentralized negotiation protocols in terms of negotiation efficiency and agreement quality.

title: Distributed Negotiation Protocols for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation protocols enable autonomous agents to reach mutually beneficial agreements. However, real-world scenarios often involve incomplete information, where agents may not have access to the complete state of the environment or the preferences of other agents. This paper proposes a novel distributed negotiation protocol, 'DIP-Negotiate', which extends the traditional alternating offers protocol to accommodate incomplete information. We introduce a probabilistic inference mechanism that enables agents to infer the preferences of other agents based on observed actions and messages. Experimental results on a simulated supply chain management scenario demonstrate that DIP-Negotiate outperforms existing protocols in terms of negotiation efficiency and fairness, even in the presence of incomplete information.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion for Short Text Retrieval using Contextualized Embeddings
paper_abstract: Short text retrieval is a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with queries that lack context.
