This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages contextualized embeddings to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms. We introduce a neural network-based model that fine-tunes pre-trained language models to generate query expansions that are sensitive to the specific context of the query. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, especially for short queries, and outperform traditional query expansion techniques.

title: Improving Query Performance with Neural Ranking Models for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval (IR) rely on hand-crafted features, which can be limited in capturing complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper explores the application of neural ranking models to improve query performance in document retrieval. We propose a novel neural architecture, 'NeuRank', which leverages transformer-based encoders to capture contextualized query-document interactions. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art traditional ranking models.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Learning Models using Explainable AI
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of deep learning models in real-world applications has raised concerns about their vulnerability to adversarial attacks. This paper presents a novel approach to detect such attacks using explainable AI techniques. Our method, 'ExpAd', analyzes the feature importance scores generated by SHAP values to identify anomalous input patterns that are indicative of adversarial attacks. We evaluate ExpAd on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting attacks with high accuracy, outperforming existing detection methods. Our approach has significant implications for the development of robust AI systems in security-critical applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task due to the inherent heterogeneity and complexity of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, enabling efficient and accurate emotion recognition. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods on two benchmark datasets, achieving a 12.5% improvement in weighted F1-score. We also demonstrate the robustness of HAN to varying levels of noise and missing modalities.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Transformers for Efficient Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition is a challenging task that requires integrating and fusing information from diverse modalities such as speech, text, and vision. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based transformer architecture, 'MERTA', that leverages the strengths of each modality to improve emotion recognition accuracy. MERTA employs a modal-agnostic attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of each modality based on the input data. Our experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that MERTA outperforms state-of-the-art methods by 4.2% in terms of weighted F1-score, while reducing computational complexity by 30%.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Hierarchical Entity Embeddings for Knowledge Graph-based Retrieval
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph-based retrieval has gained popularity in recent years, but existing methods often struggle to effectively model complex entity relationships. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages hierarchical entity embeddings to capture nuanced semantic dependencies between entities. Our method, called HierExpan, represents entities as hierarchical vectors that encapsulate their relationships at multiple levels of abstraction. We demonstrate that HierExpan significantly improves retrieval performance on several benchmark datasets, particularly for queries involving entities with ambiguous or polysemous meanings.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Individuals with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and pronunciation, often struggle to interact with these systems. This paper presents the design and evaluation of an inclusive voice assistant, tailored to the needs of individuals with dysarthria. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and interviews with users, caregivers, and speech therapists to inform the development of our system. Our approach incorporates acoustic models trained on dysarthric speech, personalized error correction, and adaptive feedback mechanisms. Results from a usability study demonstrate significant improvements in user engagement, accuracy, and overall satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenancy has become a dominant paradigm in cloud-based database systems, where a single database instance serves multiple tenants. However, this raises significant query optimization challenges due to varying workload patterns and resource constraints. We propose a novel optimization framework, 'MT-QOpt', which leverages machine learning-based workload prediction and adaptive resource allocation to minimize query latency and improve system throughput. Our experimental evaluation using a real-world e-commerce dataset demonstrates that MT-QOpt outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques by up to 35% in terms of query response time.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Graph Neural Networks for Skeleton-based Action Recognition
paper_abstract: Skeleton-based action recognition has gained significant attention in recent years due to its potential applications in human-computer interaction and healthcare. However, existing methods often struggle to model the complex spatial and temporal relationships between joints. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) that leverages both node-level and graph-level attention mechanisms to capture nuanced patterns in skeleton data. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the NTU RGB-D and Kinetics datasets, outperforming existing methods by a significant margin. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the attention weights, revealing insights into the importance of different joints and their interactions.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of life, but individuals with visual impairments are often excluded from these experiences. This paper presents a novel VR interface design framework, 'AccessibleVR', which incorporates multisensory cues and audio-based navigation to enhance usability for visually impaired users. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that AccessibleVR significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. Our findings provide valuable insights for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to diverse user needs.

title: Accelerating Query Processing with Learned Index Structures for Main-Memory Databases
paper_abstract: As main-memory databases become increasingly prevalent, query processing efficiency remains a major bottleneck. This paper explores the application of learned index structures to accelerate query execution in main-memory databases. We propose a novel neural network-based indexing approach, 'NeuroIX', which learns to predict the optimal query plan based on workload patterns and data distributions. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that NeuroIX achieves significant speedups over traditional indexing techniques, reducing query latency by up to 3.5x while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent task allocation is a fundamental problem in distributed artificial intelligence, where agents must efficiently allocate tasks to maximize overall system performance. This paper introduces a novel approach, Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT), that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex agent interactions and task dependencies. HGAT is designed to scale to large numbers of agents and tasks, outperforming existing methods in terms of allocation efficiency and adaptability to dynamic environments. We evaluate HGAT on a series of simulated logistics scenarios, demonstrating its effectiveness in real-world applications.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, but existing methods often struggle with handling long-range dependencies and high-dimensional data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages self-attention mechanisms at multiple scales to capture complex temporal patterns. Our approach integrates a pyramidal structure to efficiently process long-range dependencies, and a feature importance module to adaptively select relevant inputs. Experiments on four real-world datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of prediction accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Improved Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, where the goal is to reformulate the original query to better capture the user's information need. Traditional methods rely on heuristics or manual feature engineering, which often lead to suboptimal performance. We propose a novel approach that formulates query expansion as a sequential decision-making problem and employs reinforcement learning to optimize the expansion process. Our method, 'RL-EXPAND', learns to select the most effective expansion terms by maximizing a reward function that balances retrieval effectiveness and query coherence. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Column Stores using Machine Learning-based Index Selection
paper_abstract: Modern column stores have revolutionized analytical workloads, but optimizing queries remains a challenging task. This paper presents 'ColSel', a novel framework that leverages machine learning to select the most effective indexes for a given query. By training a neural network on a dataset of query patterns and index statistics, ColSel can predict the optimal index configuration for a query, reducing the overhead of index creation and maintenance. Experiments on a real-world dataset show that ColSel outperforms existing rule-based index selection methods by up to 3x, while also providing insights into the underlying query patterns.

title: Designing Adaptive Haptic Feedback for Enhanced Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often lack nuanced haptic feedback, reducing immersion and user satisfaction. We present 'HapAxis', a novel framework that adaptively generates haptic effects based on real-time user behavior, environment, and task requirements. Our approach combines machine learning-driven prediction models with psychophysical analysis to optimize haptic feedback for diverse VR applications. A user study demonstrates that HapAxis significantly improves user engagement, task performance, and overall VR experience quality.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Q-Networks
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of coordinated exploration in multi-agent systems, where agents must balance individual learning and collaboration to achieve a common goal. We propose a novel approach using deep Q-networks (DQN) to learn cooperative policies in partially observable environments. Our method, called Coordinated Exploration with DQN (CEDQN), incorporates a decentralized exploration strategy that adaptively adjusts the exploration rate based on the agents' observations and rewards. We evaluate CEDQN in a decentralized sensor network scenario, demonstrating improved convergence and robustness compared to existing decentralized reinforcement learning methods.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Voice-Controlled Smart Home Systems
paper_abstract: As voice-controlled smart home systems become increasingly prevalent, it is essential to ensure their accessibility for older adults. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop conversational interfaces that cater to the needs of this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, exploring their experiences with voice-controlled systems and identifying key design recommendations. Our findings highlight the importance of clear and simple voice prompts, intuitive error handling, and personalized feedback mechanisms. We also propose a set of accessibility guidelines for designers and developers of voice-controlled systems, aiming to promote independent living and social inclusion for older adults.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Agents using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems require efficient task allocation to achieve common goals. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent interactions and task dependencies. Our approach, called GraphAgent, represents agents as nodes in a graph and uses GNNs to learn a task allocation policy that maximizes overall system utility. We demonstrate the efficacy of GraphAgent in a simulated disaster response scenario, showing improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Eye Movement-Based Authentication for Augmented Reality Devices
paper_abstract: As augmented reality (AR) technology becomes increasingly pervasive, the need for secure and convenient authentication methods grows. This paper presents a novel eye movement-based authentication approach tailored to AR devices. We leverage the high-resolution eye tracking capabilities of modern AR head-mounted displays to capture unique saccadic patterns, which are then used to verify user identities. Our proposed system, 'EyeGuard', achieves an equal error rate of 2.1% on a dataset of 100 participants, outperforming existing authentication methods in AR scenarios. We also conduct a comprehensive security analysis, demonstrating the robustness of EyeGuard against various spoofing attacks.

title: Adaptive Trust Models for Multi-Agent Systems with Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust models play a crucial role in facilitating cooperation and decision-making. However, existing approaches often rely on simplistic trust metrics that fail to account for uncertainty in the environment. This paper proposes a novel adaptive trust model, 'ATM-U', which integrates probabilistic reasoning and machine learning techniques to estimate trust values in uncertain environments. We evaluate ATM-U in a simulated environment and demonstrate its ability to adapt to changing conditions, outperforming traditional trust models in terms of cooperation success rates and resilience to manipulative agents.

title: Efficient Hyperparameter Tuning for Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Optimization with Gaussian Processes
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various machine learning tasks, but their success heavily relies on the careful tuning of hyperparameters. Bayesian optimization with Gaussian processes has emerged as a popular approach for hyperparameter tuning, but it can be computationally expensive. This paper proposes an efficient Bayesian optimization method that leverages a novel acquisition function, 'GP-UCB-EI', which balances exploration and exploitation. We conduct experiments on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of both computational efficiency and model performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval using Graph-Based Keyword Embeddings
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a challenging problem in information retrieval due to the limited context and ambiguity of query terms. This paper presents a novel query expansion method that leverages graph-based keyword embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our approach constructs a graph of co-occurring keywords and uses graph convolutional networks to learn dense representations of query terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our method significantly improves retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, particularly for short queries with fewer than five terms.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) technology becomes increasingly prevalent, designing intuitive and engaging interfaces is crucial. This study investigates the role of haptic feedback in enhancing user experience and engagement in VR. We developed a custom VR platform with varying levels of haptic feedback and conducted a user study with 30 participants. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves user engagement, reduces cognitive load, and enhances overall satisfaction. We also identify specific design recommendations for incorporating haptic feedback in VR interfaces, highlighting the importance of synchronization and tactile cues.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition using Hierarchical Temporal Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to personalized gesture recognition using hierarchical temporal convolutional networks (HTCNs). Our method leverages the strengths of both convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs) to model the complex temporal dependencies in gesture data. We propose a hierarchical architecture that captures local and global patterns in gestures, allowing for robust recognition of personalized gestures. Experimental results on the popular Gesture Phase Segmentation dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Few-Shot Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various node classification tasks. However, they often require large amounts of labeled data, which can be scarce in real-world scenarios. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention-based GNN framework, HAGNN, that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs for few-shot node classification. We introduce a novel meta-learning objective that adapts the attention weights to the target task, enabling the model to generalize to unseen graphs and classes. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN in few-shot node classification scenarios.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on reinforcement learning (RL) to make decisions in complex scenarios. However, the lack of explainability in RL models hinders trust and understanding of their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel XRL framework, 'CARMA', which integrates saliency mapping and attention mechanisms to provide interpretable representations of the RL agent's decision-making process. Evaluations on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate that CARMA improves model transparency without compromising decision-making performance. Our approach has significant implications for the development of trustworthy autonomous systems.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Learned Index Structures
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are widely used in modern data centers, but optimizing query performance remains a major challenge. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages learned index structures (LIS) to improve query efficiency in DDS. We propose a framework, 'LIS-Distributed', that integrates LIS with traditional indexing techniques to reduce query latency and improve resource utilization. Our experiments on a real-world dataset demonstrate that LIS-Distributed achieves up to 3x improvement in query performance compared to state-of-the-art indexing methods, while maintaining scalability and fault tolerance.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Learning Models using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Deep learning models are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can lead to misclassification and security breaches. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT). HGAT integrates both local and global feature representations to identify subtle patterns indicative of adversarial attacks. We evaluate our approach on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting various types of attacks, including white-box, black-box, and gray-box attacks. Our results show that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in detecting adversarial attacks, achieving an average detection rate of 95.2%.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Time-Series Databases using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Time-series databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large amounts of temporal data. However, optimizing query performance for these databases remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for time-series databases. Our approach, dubbed 'TSRLE', uses a Markov decision process to model the query optimization problem and learns to optimize query plans using a deep Q-network. Experimental results on a real-world time-series dataset demonstrate that TSRLE outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Graph Convolutional Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, where the goal is to enrich the original query with relevant terms to improve retrieval performance. In this paper, we propose a novel approach that leverages the power of deep graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model the complex relationships between query terms and their expansions. Our model, dubbed 'GraphQE', learns to represent queries and their expansions as graph-structured data, and uses GCNs to capture higher-order dependencies between terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Representations
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) requires efficient passage retrieval from a large corpus to answer user queries. Existing dense passage retrieval (DPR) models suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. We propose Hierarchical DPR (HDPR), a novel approach that leverages hierarchical representations to reduce the dimensionality of passage embeddings. Our method employs a coarse-grained retriever to select top-k passages and a fine-grained reranker to re-score the retrieved passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDPR achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by 75% compared to standard DPR models.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforced Neural Query Translation for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'RNeQT', which leverages reinforced neural query translation to generate high-quality query expansions. Our method uses a deep reinforcement learning framework to learn a policy for query translation, allowing the system to adapt to the nuances of natural language queries. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for timely business decision-making. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'ColOpt', which leverages column-store indexing to accelerate query execution. We introduce a cost-based optimization strategy that considers both storage and processing costs, and demonstrate improved performance compared to traditional row-store indexing. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset show that ColOpt reduces query latency by up to 75% while maintaining data freshness.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Multi-Relational Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in multi-relational graphs is a fundamental task in various applications, such as social network analysis and recommender systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages the complex relationships between nodes and edges in these graphs. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and edge types, enabling more accurate node representations. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the attention weights, revealing insightful patterns and relationships in the graph structures.

title: Adaptive Re-ranking for Diverse Query Intent Identification in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query intent identification is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it significantly impacts the relevance and diversity of search results. Existing approaches often rely on fixed ranking models, which can lead to suboptimal performances for queries with diverse intents. This paper proposes a novel adaptive re-ranking framework, 'AdaptIR', which dynamically adjusts the ranking function based on the query context and user behavior. Our approach leverages a graph-based neural network to model the relationships between queries, documents, and user interactions, and incorporates a reinforcement learning mechanism to optimize the ranking policy. Experiments on a large-scale search engine dataset demonstrate that AdaptIR improves both relevance and diversity metrics compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Relational Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used to handle large-scale data processing. However, optimizing query performance in such systems remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to tune query execution plans in real-time. We design a deep Q-network that learns to optimize query performance by interacting with the database system and receiving rewards based on query latency. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning in Partially Observable Environments
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) in partially observable environments is a challenging problem, as agents must learn to cooperate and communicate effectively despite limited information. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture, which integrates attention mechanisms at both the intra-agent and inter-agent levels. Our approach enables agents to selectively focus on relevant information from their observations and coordinate with others to achieve common goals. Experimental results in a series of cooperative navigation tasks demonstrate that HAN outperforms existing MARL methods, improving both individual and team rewards in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Time-series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, but the lack of interpretability in existing methods hinders their adoption. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that detects anomalies while providing explainable insights into the decision-making process. Our approach leverages self-attention to model temporal dependencies and hierarchical attention to capture local and global patterns. We evaluate HAN on three real-world datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and interpretability.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: An Exploratory Study on User Experience for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become increasingly prevalent in smart homes, but their usability for older adults remains largely unexplored. This study investigates the experiences of older adults (65+ years) interacting with voice assistants, identifying pain points and areas for improvement. Through a mixed-methods approach combining surveys, interviews, and usability testing, we uncover significant barriers to adoption, including difficulties with voice recognition, navigation, and understanding system feedback. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating more inclusive voice assistants, emphasizing clear and simple language, personalized feedback, and tailored functionality for older adults.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Retrieval Effectiveness in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to incomplete or imperfect query representations. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, QEDEX, which leverages contextualized embeddings to enrich the query and document representations. QEDEX adaptively selects the most informative terms from the top-ranked documents to augment the original query, thereby improving the retrieval effectiveness. Our experiments on the TREC-COVID dataset demonstrate that QEDEX outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The proliferation of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on urban roads necessitates efficient coordination mechanisms to optimize traffic flow and safety. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoAV', which enables AVs to learn cooperative strategies in real-time. We employ a graph neural network to model AV interactions and develop a novel attention-based approach to handle partial observability. Simulation results in a realistic urban setting demonstrate that CoAV reduces congestion by 23% and collision rates by 41% compared to traditional rule-based AV controllers.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve collective goals. This paper presents a decentralized approach to task allocation using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). Our algorithm, called DCA-MA, leverages local constraint propagation and asynchronous communication to allocate tasks in a distributed manner. We prove that DCA-MA converges to a near-optimal solution with probabilistic guarantees and evaluate its performance using a real-world disaster response scenario. Experimental results show that DCA-MA outperforms centralized approaches in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for adaptive traffic signal control. We propose a novel framework, 'TrafficMAgent', which enables individual agents to learn and adapt to dynamic traffic patterns in real-time. By leveraging a distributed architecture and asynchronous communication, TrafficMAgent can scale to large networks and respond to changing traffic conditions more effectively than traditional centralized approaches. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulation platform demonstrate significant improvements in traffic flow and reduced congestion.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic signal control can significantly reduce traffic congestion and emissions. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework, 'TrafficSync', which coordinates traffic signals to optimize traffic flow. We introduce a decentralized, graph-based learning approach that enables agents to learn from local observations and communicate with neighboring agents to achieve global coordination. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulator demonstrate that TrafficSync outperforms traditional decentralized control methods, reducing average travel time by 23.5% and emissions by 17.2%.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient coordination to achieve optimal performance. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to dynamically allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. We design a hierarchical framework where agents learn to estimate task rewards and costs, and a coordinator agent makes allocation decisions based on these estimates. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization, and is robust to changes in task arrival rates and agent availability.

title: EARL: Efficient Adaptive Layout Recommendation for Accessible Web Interfaces
paper_abstract: Web accessibility is a growing concern, with many websites failing to provide usable interfaces for users with disabilities. This paper presents EARL, a novel layout recommendation system that leverages machine learning and crowd-sourced user feedback to generate accessible web interfaces. EARL employs a hierarchical Bayesian model to adapt to user preferences and adaptively refines its recommendations based on user interactions. We evaluate EARL on a large-scale dataset of web pages and demonstrate significant improvements in accessibility metrics, including navigation efficiency and screen reader compatibility.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, autonomous agents must adapt to changing task requirements and allocate resources efficiently. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-ATA', that enables agents to coordinate and allocate tasks in real-time. HRL-ATA combines a high-level planning module with a low-level execution module, allowing agents to balance exploration and exploitation in complex task spaces. Our experiments demonstrate that HRL-ATA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in dynamic task allocation scenarios, such as disaster response and autonomous warehouse management.

title: Incremental Query Rewriting for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Engines
paper_abstract: Distributed search engines are crucial for efficient information retrieval in large-scale document collections. However, query rewriting remains a bottleneck due to the overhead of re-indexing and re-ranking. This paper proposes an incremental query rewriting approach, 'IQREW', which leverages query logs and document similarity to rewrite queries in real-time. IQREW reduces the number of re-indexed documents by 30% and improves retrieval efficiency by 25% compared to state-of-the-art methods. We evaluate IQREW on the TREC-8 dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in reducing query latency while maintaining retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking Models
paper_abstract: Traditional learning-to-rank approaches in information retrieval (IR) suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which integrates a coarse-grained document filtering stage with a fine-grained ranking stage. We employ a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant document regions and reduce the dimensionality of the input space. Experimental results on the TREC Deep Learning Track dataset demonstrate that HierRank achieves state-of-the-art retrieval performance while reducing computational costs by up to 60% compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Specialized Domains
paper_abstract: Existing query expansion techniques often struggle to effectively capture domain-specific terminology, leading to suboptimal document retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-SD', which leverages a combination of lexical and semantic features to identify relevant expansion terms. Our method incorporates a domain-specific ontology to disambiguate polysemous terms and contextualize query concepts. Experimental results on a collection of specialized-domain datasets demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis on Social Media
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis on social media requires handling diverse inputs such as images, text, and audio. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of both visual and textual features to improve sentiment prediction. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules that adaptively weight the importance of each input modality, followed by a multimodal fusion layer that integrates the outputs. Experiments on a large-scale social media dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and robustness, especially in scenarios with noisy or incomplete data.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Cloud Computing
paper_abstract: Cloud computing providers face the challenge of efficiently allocating resources to meet dynamic workload demands while minimizing costs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Cloud', which learns to optimize resource allocation in a decentralized manner. We introduce a hierarchical policy that balances exploration and exploitation across multiple timescales, facilitating adaptation to changing workload patterns. Experiments on a real-world cloud dataset demonstrate that HRL-Cloud outperforms traditional rule-based allocation methods, achieving an average of 23% cost savings while maintaining 99.99% SLA compliance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Relation Prediction in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph (KG) relation prediction has become a crucial task in various applications, including question answering and recommendation systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) model for relation prediction in KGs. HGAT leverages multi-hop neighborhood information and hierarchical attention mechanisms to capture complex relational patterns. We evaluate HGAT on three benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of Hits@1 and MRR metrics. Furthermore, we provide an in-depth analysis of the learned attention weights, revealing the importance of hierarchical information in KG relation prediction.

title: Exploiting Query Reformulation Patterns for Enhanced Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on users to formulate effective queries, but this can be a challenging task, especially for complex information needs. This paper presents a novel approach to leveraging query reformulation patterns to improve retrieval performance. We propose a graph-based model that captures the relationships between query reformulations and their corresponding search results. Our approach incorporates both syntactic and semantic features to identify effective reformulations and rerank the search results accordingly. Experimental results on the TREC ad-hoc search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for difficult queries.

title: Deep Relevance Matching for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Hierarchical Query Reconstruction
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging problem in information retrieval, especially when dealing with complex, multi-faceted queries. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, Hierarchical Relevance Matcher (HRM), which leverages a hierarchical query reconstruction mechanism to better capture the semantic relationships between query components. Our approach uses a deep relevance matching scheme that adaptively weighs the importance of different query aspects based on their contextual relevance. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art models, with HRM achieving a 12.4% increase in NDCG@10.

title: Optimizing Query Performance through Learned Index Structures for High-Dimensional Data
paper_abstract: Traditional indexing methods struggle to efficiently query high-dimensional data, leading to poor performance in various applications. This paper proposes a learned index structure, 'HDIndex', which leverages deep neural networks to approximate the underlying data distribution. By learning a compact representation of the data, HDIndex enables fast and accurate query execution. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate that HDIndex outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving up to 5x improvement in query response time and 3x reduction in storage requirements.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, the design of neural architectures for MER remains largely manual and time-consuming. This paper proposes a novel neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'MERA', which leverages a hierarchical search space and a surrogate-assisted evolutionary algorithm to efficiently discover high-performing architectures for MER. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MERA on two benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance while reducing the search time by an order of magnitude compared to existing NAS methods.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodiment in Virtual Reality-Based Gesture Recognition Systems
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has seen significant advancements, but gesture recognition systems remain limited in their ability to accurately detect user intentions. This paper explores the concept of embodiment in VR-based gesture recognition, where the user's sense of body ownership and agency is leveraged to improve system performance. We design and evaluate a novel VR-based gesture recognition system that incorporates visual, auditory, and haptic feedback to enhance embodiment. Our results show that the proposed system achieves significant improvements in gesture recognition accuracy and user experience compared to traditional computer vision-based approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but the lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that incorporates both spatial and temporal attention mechanisms to provide insights into the decision-making process. We evaluate our approach on a suite of Atari games and demonstrate improved interpretability without compromising performance. Furthermore, we introduce a novel explainability metric, 'attention flow,' which quantifies the contribution of each attention module to the final policy.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Queries
paper_abstract: Multi-modal queries, comprising both text and images, have become increasingly prevalent in modern information retrieval systems. However, existing document retrieval models struggle to effectively fuse and weigh the relevance of different modalities. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that learns to selectively focus on relevant regions of the query image and corresponding text fragments. Our experiments on the WikiImage dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness, particularly for queries with ambiguous or abstract semantics. We also explore the interpretability of our HAN model, visualizing attention patterns to provide insights into the decision-making process.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Agent Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, understanding how humans interact with agents in these environments is crucial. This study investigates the effect of embodiment on human-agent collaboration in VR, focusing on the role of anthropomorphic agents. We conducted a within-subjects experiment with 30 participants, analyzing their behavior and performance when working with embodied and non-embodied agents. Our results show that embodied agents lead to increased trust, communication, and task success, but also higher cognitive load. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of future human-agent collaboration systems in VR.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep learning-based embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms. Our method, dubbed 'EmbedExpan', uses a combination of word2vec and transformer-based architectures to generate contextualized embeddings for query terms. These embeddings are then used to expand the original query, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of EmbedExpan, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Impaired Dexterity
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have revolutionized human-computer interaction, but their adoption among older adults with impaired dexterity is hindered by inaccessible interfaces. This study investigates the design of inclusive voice assistants that accommodate the needs of this demographic. We conducted a participatory design process with 15 older adults, revealing key challenges and opportunities for improvement. Our proposed design, 'EasyVoice', incorporates adaptive speech recognition, personalized command sets, and multimodal feedback. A user study with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. Our findings provide actionable guidelines for designers and developers of voice assistants to create more inclusive and supportive systems for older adults.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces are increasingly prevalent, but their design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create inclusive voice-based interfaces for this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify their needs, preferences, and pain points when interacting with voice-based systems. Our results highlight the importance of considering age-related cognitive and physical changes in interface design. We propose a set of design guidelines and recommendations for creating more accessible and usable voice-based interfaces for older adults.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, where multiple tenants share the same database instance. However, optimizing queries for multiple tenants poses significant challenges due to varying workload patterns and resource constraints. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'MultiOpt', which leverages machine learning techniques to predict query performance and adaptively allocate resources. We propose a hierarchical optimization approach that considers both tenant-level and system-level constraints, resulting in improved query throughput and reduced latency. Experiments on a real-world multi-tenant database system demonstrate the effectiveness of MultiOpt in achieving scalable query optimization.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Adaptive Font Sizes on Reading Comprehension for Visually Impaired Users
paper_abstract: This study investigates the effectiveness of adaptive font sizes in enhancing reading comprehension for visually impaired users. We developed a novel font adaptation algorithm that dynamically adjusts font sizes based on user preferences, reading speed, and content complexity. Our user study with 30 visually impaired participants reveals that adaptive font sizes significantly improve reading comprehension and reduce eye strain compared to fixed font sizes. We also analyze the impact of font adaptation on reading speed, accuracy, and user satisfaction, providing insights for designing more accessible digital interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification in Large-Scale Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in large-scale graphs is a fundamental task in graph-based machine learning. However, existing methods suffer from high computational complexity and memory requirements. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages a hierarchical graph representation to reduce the complexity of node classification. HGAN uses a bottom-up approach to aggregate node features and attention weights, enabling efficient processing of large graphs. We evaluate HGAN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in classification accuracy and computational efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hybrid Agent-Based Framework for Real-Time Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid agent-based framework for real-time traffic management, integrating both centralized and decentralized approaches. The framework leverages multi-agent systems to model and simulate dynamic traffic scenarios, while incorporating machine learning algorithms to optimize traffic signal control. We evaluate the framework using a real-world traffic dataset and demonstrate improved traffic flow and reduced congestion compared to traditional traffic management systems. The proposed framework has the potential to revolutionize traffic management in smart cities, enabling real-time adaptation to changing traffic conditions.

title: Exploring Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperation in Complex Environments
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperative behavior is crucial for achieving complex goals. However, current approaches often rely on hand-crafted rules or simplistic communication models. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework, which enables agents to learn cooperative strategies from raw sensor data. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model relationships between agents and their environment, while a hierarchical architecture facilitates the learning of abstract, high-level policies. Experimental results in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that HGAT agents outperform state-of-the-art baselines in terms of cooperation efficiency and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Improving Search Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems face challenges in scaling query processing while maintaining search efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE', which leverages semantic relationships between query terms to reduce the search space. HQE adaptively selects relevant expansion terms based on the query context and document collection statistics. Experimental results on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms existing query expansion techniques in terms of search efficiency, precision, and recall, while reducing the average query processing time by 35%.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection for Time-Series Data using Graph-Based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: As AI-powered systems increasingly rely on time-series data, the risk of adversarial attacks grows. This paper proposes a novel approach for detecting such attacks using graph-based anomaly detection. Our method, 'TS-GAD', represents time-series data as graphs and leverages graph neural networks to identify patterns indicative of malicious behavior. We evaluate TS-GAD on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting real-world attacks, achieving an F1-score of 0.95 compared to state-of-the-art methods. Our approach has significant implications for securing AI systems in applications such as healthcare, finance, and cybersecurity.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Deep Neural Network-based Retrieval Models in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Recent advancements in neural ranking models have significantly improved the performance of information retrieval systems. However, the computational cost of these models can be prohibitively expensive, hindering their adoption in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages the inherent structural properties of deep neural networks to reduce the computational overhead of inference. We introduce a hierarchical pruning strategy that selectively eliminates redundant computations, resulting in a 3x speedup in query processing time while maintaining retrieval accuracy. Experiments on a large-scale dataset demonstrate the efficacy of our approach in facilitating efficient query optimization for neural ranking models.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering over knowledge graphs (KGs) has gained significant attention in recent years. However, existing methods often suffer from the curse of dimensionality and inadequate modeling of complex relationships. This paper proposes a novel KG embedding approach, 'HieraQA', which leverages hierarchical attention to selectively focus on relevant entities and relations. We develop a multi-level attention mechanism that captures both local and global dependencies in the KG. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HieraQA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of answer accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to autonomous task allocation in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, called TARL, leverages a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn task assignment policies that maximize global rewards while respecting agent capabilities and constraints. Experimental results on a range of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that TARL outperforms state-of-the-art heuristics in terms of task completion rate, latency, and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Towards Efficient Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in multi-agent systems, where agents with different capabilities need to be assigned to tasks to achieve global objectives. Existing approaches often rely on handcrafted heuristics or traditional optimization methods, which can be computationally expensive and suboptimal. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework for task allocation in multi-agent systems. Our approach leverages a graph neural network to learn a representation of the agent-task graph and a deep Q-network to optimize task assignments. Experimental results on a realistic disaster response scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Efficient task allocation in multi-agent systems is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to enable autonomous task allocation among agents. We introduce a decentralized framework, 'MARL-TA', that utilizes a combination of deep Q-networks and graph neural networks to learn optimal task assignments. Our approach considers agent capabilities, task dependencies, and environmental constraints, leading to improved system performance and adaptability. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of MARL-TA in various scenarios, including search and rescue operations and warehouse automation.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Design on User Trust in Conversational Interfaces
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but designing them to evoke trust in users remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of anthropomorphic design elements on user trust in conversational agents. We conducted a mixed-methods experiment involving 120 participants, exposing them to three different chatbot designs: minimalist, anthropomorphic, and hybrid. Our results show that anthropomorphic design elements, such as facial expressions and gestures, can increase user trust, but only when accompanied by transparent and consistent language processing. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of trustworthy conversational interfaces and outline avenues for future research.

title: Efficient Attention Mechanisms for Multi-Modal Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems often struggle to effectively integrate and process multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and visual cues. This paper presents a novel attention mechanism, 'HybridFocus', which adaptively weights and combines attention weights from different modalities. We demonstrate that HybridFocus significantly outperforms existing approaches in both utterance-level and dialogue-level evaluation metrics. Furthermore, we show that our proposed mechanism can be efficiently implemented using a combination of parallel computing and knowledge distillation, making it suitable for real-world deployment.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Multimodal Interaction Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interaction design often neglects the needs of older adults. This paper presents a multimodal interaction study that explores the challenges and opportunities of designing inclusive voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 older adults, using a combination of surveys, interviews, and usability testing. Our results highlight the importance of incorporating visual and tactile cues, simplifying language processing, and providing contextual support to facilitate independent use. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating more accessible and user-centered voice assistants that can empower older adults in their daily lives.

title: Enhancing Query Performance with Deep Neural Ranking Models for E-commerce Search Engines
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines face the challenge of efficiently retrieving and ranking relevant products from vast catalogs. This paper proposes a novel deep neural ranking model, 'DNR-EC', which leverages the strengths of both lexical and semantic matchings. We incorporate a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex query-product relationships and a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize ranking and retrieval tasks. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that DNR-EC outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of precision, recall, and query latency, making it a promising solution for real-world e-commerce search engines.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Dynamic IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of IoT networks necessitates efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper proposes a decentralized, agent-based approach that leverages reinforcement learning to allocate resources in dynamic IoT environments. Our framework, 'DARA', utilizes a network of autonomous agents that learn to optimize resource allocation based on local observations and communication with neighboring agents. We evaluate DARA on a simulated IoT network and demonstrate improved resource utilization, reduced latency, and enhanced adaptability to network changes compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Explainable AI in Medical Imaging
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) is crucial in medical imaging to build trust in AI-driven diagnosis. However, existing XAI methods often incur significant computational overhead. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that efficiently generates interpretable explanations for medical image analysis tasks. HAN leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions and features, reducing the computational cost of explanation generation. We evaluate HAN on a large-scale medical imaging dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving model interpretability while maintaining state-of-the-art performance.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of personalized avatars on user experience in VR environments. We designed and implemented a novel avatar generation system that incorporates user preferences and personality traits. Our user study results show that personalized avatars significantly increase user engagement, sense of presence, and overall satisfaction. Furthermore, we identify key factors influencing user preferences and discuss implications for VR system design.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of deep neural networks in real-world applications has made them vulnerable to adversarial attacks. Existing detection methods are limited by their inability to capture complex relationships between input features. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that models input data as a graph and leverages attention mechanisms to identify suspicious patterns. Our approach outperforms state-of-the-art detectors on benchmark datasets and demonstrates robustness against various attack types, including white-box and black-box attacks.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Decentralized Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a complex problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized reinforcement learning framework for hierarchical task allocation, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their capabilities and the system's overall objectives. Our approach uses a graph neural network to model agent interactions and a decentralized Q-learning algorithm to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized methods in terms of task completion rate and system adaptability.

title: Multi-Modal Emotional Intelligence for Human-Robot Interaction using Graph-Based Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Effective human-robot interaction (HRI) requires robots to understand and respond to human emotions. We propose a novel multi-modal emotional intelligence framework, EmoGraph, which leverages graph-based attention networks to fuse facial expression, speech, and physiological signals. EmoGraph outperforms state-of-the-art methods on the RECOLA dataset, achieving a 15% improvement in emotion recognition accuracy. We demonstrate the framework's efficacy in a real-world HRI scenario, where robots adapt their behavior to comfort users experiencing emotional distress.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for coordinating autonomous vehicles in complex urban scenarios. Our approach, called HiMAC, consists of two levels: a high-level planner that assigns tasks to individual vehicles, and a low-level controller that executes the tasks using deep reinforcement learning. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HiMAC in a simulated environment, where it outperforms traditional distributed control methods in terms of traffic flow, safety, and fuel efficiency. Our results have implications for the development of large-scale autonomous transportation systems.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed the way we interact with digital information, but the impact of embodiment on social presence in VR remains understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining how different embodiment styles (e.g., full-body avatars, hand-tracking, or controller-based interactions) influence users' sense of social presence in VR. Our results show that full-body avatars significantly enhance social presence, while hand-tracking and controller-based interactions have a neutral effect. We discuss the implications of these findings for VR system design and future research on embodiment in HCI.

title: Scalable Query Expansion using Hierarchical Neural Network Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial component in modern information retrieval systems, as it enhances the retrieval performance by incorporating relevant terms into the original query. However, existing QE methods suffer from scalability issues, particularly when dealing with large datasets and complex queries. This paper proposes a novel approach, Hierarchical Neural Network Embeddings (HNNE), which leverages the strengths of both neural networks and hierarchical clustering to generate effective query expansions. Our method models the semantic relationships between terms using a hierarchical neural network, allowing for efficient and effective query expansion. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HNNE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods in terms of retrieval performance and computational efficiency.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents are increasingly being used in various applications, such as search and rescue, surveillance, and smart cities. Task allocation is a critical component of these systems, as it directly affects the overall performance and efficiency. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation approach using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) for autonomous agents. Our approach leverages the DCOP framework to model task allocation as a constraint satisfaction problem, which is then solved using a distributed algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized methods in terms of solution quality, scalability, and communication overhead.

title: Query Expansion using Knowledge Graph Embeddings for Improving Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (IR) systems struggle to capture the nuances of complex medical queries, leading to inadequate search results. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to enhance the retrieval performance. We integrate domain-specific knowledge graphs, such as the Unified Medical Language System (UMLS), with word embeddings to create a hybrid representation of medical concepts. Our experiments on a benchmark medical IR dataset demonstrate significant improvements in precision and recall compared to traditional query expansion techniques, showcasing the potential of knowledge graph-based methods for medical IR.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have different capabilities and tasks have varying requirements. We propose a graph neural network (GNN) based framework that learns to represent agents and tasks as nodes in a graph, and allocates tasks by predicting the optimal assignment of agents to tasks. Our approach leverages the strengths of both model-based and learning-based methods, and is scalable to large systems. Experimental results on a variety of scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving system performance and robustness.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems require efficient query optimization to minimize response times and resource utilization. Traditional query optimization techniques rely on rule-based approaches or statistical models, which may not capture complex relationships between query patterns and system dynamics. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to learn query execution plans. Our approach represents the database schema and query workload as a graph, which is fed into a GNN to predict optimal execution plans. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant barriers when interacting with modern computing devices. This paper presents a novel, adaptive gesture-based interface designed to accommodate users with varying levels of motor ability. Our approach leverages machine learning to dynamically adjust gesture recognition thresholds, enabling users to accurately interact with devices despite physical limitations. A user study involving 20 participants with motor impairments demonstrates significant improvements in interface usability and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture-based interfaces.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, especially in dynamic and uncertain environments. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn coordinated task allocation strategies. We design a decentralized, multi-agent framework that utilizes graph neural networks to model agent interactions and a hierarchical reinforcement learning architecture to optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving overall system performance and adapting to changing environmental conditions.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing query execution plans remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively learn the optimal join orders and indexing strategies for a given query workload. Our approach, called 'RL-QOpt', uses a deep Q-network to predict the optimal plan based on query features and database statistics. Experimental results on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that RL-QOpt outperforms traditional rule-based optimizers and achieves up to 3x improvement in query execution time.

title: Investigating the Role of Embodiment in Virtual Reality-Based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but accurate gesture recognition remains a challenge. This paper explores the concept of embodiment in VR and its impact on gesture recognition. We designed an experiment to investigate how users' sense of embodiment influences their gesture patterns and recognition accuracy. Our results show that users with a higher sense of embodiment exhibit more natural and consistent gestures, leading to improved recognition accuracy. We propose a novel embodiment-based gesture recognition framework that incorporates user embodiment metrics, achieving an average accuracy of 92.5% on a benchmark dataset.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Information Networks
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often struggle with heterogeneous information networks, where documents exhibit diverse structural and semantic properties. We propose an adaptive query expansion framework, 'AQE-HIN', which leverages graph neural networks to capture complex relationships between documents and queries. AQE-HIN dynamically adjusts the expansion strategy based on the query's semantic context, resulting in improved retrieval performance and reduced computational overhead. Our experiments on a large-scale heterogeneous dataset demonstrate significant gains in precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Optimizing Query Execution on Multi-Core Architectures for Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Column-store databases have gained popularity in recent years due to their ability to efficiently process analytical queries. However, modern multi-core architectures pose significant challenges in optimizing query execution. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'CORE', which leverages a combination of dynamic reordering, parallel execution, and cache-aware optimization techniques. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that CORE achieves significant performance improvements, up to 3.5x, compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers on multi-core systems.

title: Distributed Task Allocation via Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: We propose a novel framework for distributed task allocation in multi-agent systems, leveraging reinforcement learning with graph attention mechanisms. Our approach, dubbed 'DAGMA', enables agents to learn cooperative strategies for task assignment and execution, while adapting to dynamic network topologies and task dependencies. Experimental results on a range of benchmark scenarios demonstrate that DAGMA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion efficiency, communication overhead, and robustness to agent failures.

title: ElasticRank: Adaptive Document Ranking for Efficient Information Retrieval in Dynamic Collections
paper_abstract: The ever-growing scale and dynamics of modern document collections pose significant challenges to traditional information retrieval (IR) systems. This paper introduces ElasticRank, a novel ranking framework that adapts to changing document collections by leveraging incremental learning and hierarchical clustering. We propose a robust and efficient ranking model that incorporates document similarity, query context, and relevance feedback to improve retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC Dynamic Domain Benchmark demonstrate that ElasticRank outperforms state-of-the-art IR methods in terms of precision, recall, and computational efficiency.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on public roads necessitates the development of efficient coordination strategies to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex interactions between AVs and their environment. Our approach enables AVs to learn coordinated behaviors, such as lane changing and merging, in a decentralized manner. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that our method outperforms traditional rule-based approaches and achieves significant improvements in traffic throughput and safety.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
