paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular due to their ability to handle large-scale data and high traffic. However, optimizing query execution in DDS remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph-based reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in DDS. Our approach models the query optimization problem as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to navigate the search space of possible query plans to minimize execution time. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Emotional State Inference from Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Understanding users' emotional states is crucial for designing empathetic and personalized human-computer interaction systems. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion framework that integrates facial expression, speech, and physiological signals to infer users' emotional states in real-time. Our approach leverages a deep neural network to learn a shared representation across modalities, and a probabilistic graphical model to reason about the uncertainty of emotional state inference. Experimental results on a large-scale HCI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving the accuracy and robustness of emotional state inference, compared to traditional unimodal and early fusion approaches.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving complex goals. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework for task allocation, which integrates a high-level, graph-based task allocator with low-level, agent-centric controllers. Our approach leverages the strengths of both planning and learning methods, enabling effective task assignment and adaptive execution. We evaluate our framework in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and agent utilization compared to traditional, flat RL approaches.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has seen significant advancements in recent years, but the lack of personalized avatars hinders user immersion. This study investigates the effect of tailoring avatars to individual users' physical characteristics, preferences, and behavioral traits on their VR experience. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, employing a mixed-methods approach to assess user engagement, presence, and satisfaction. The results show that personalized avatars lead to a significant increase in user satisfaction and presence, while also reducing feelings of discomfort and anxiety. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of VR systems and highlight avenues for future research.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction Model for Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual input devices, limiting the sense of immersion. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction model, 'GazeVR', which leverages eye-tracking technology to enable intuitive user interactions in VR environments. We develop a machine learning-based algorithm that infers user intent from gaze patterns, and demonstrate its effectiveness in a range of VR applications, including object selection, navigation, and manipulation. Our user study shows that GazeVR significantly improves user experience and reduces cognitive load compared to traditional input methods.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve cognitive training and therapy for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing VR interfaces often present barriers to adoption and usage. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop accessible VR interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a series of usability studies and workshops with 30 participants, resulting in the identification of key design principles and guidelines for accessible VR interaction. Our findings inform the development of more inclusive and effective VR-based cognitive interventions.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to gesture recognition systems that adapt to the abilities and needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. Our system, called 'Easy Gesture', uses a machine learning-based framework to recognize and interpret gestures from a range of input devices, including cameras, sensors, and wearable devices. We conducted a user study with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments and found that Easy Gesture significantly improved gesture recognition accuracy and reduced user frustration compared to existing systems. Our results have implications for the design of accessible and inclusive human-computer interfaces for older adults.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Vibrotactile Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but users often struggle with spatial awareness and presence in virtual environments. This paper investigates the effect of vibrotactile feedback on user experience in VR. We designed a series of experiments using a custom-built VR platform that incorporates vibrotactile actuators in the controllers. Our results show that vibrotactile feedback significantly improves users' sense of presence and reduces spatial disorientation. We also found that the type and frequency of vibrations affect user performance in VR tasks. Our findings have implications for the design of more immersive and effective VR systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, enabling systems to respond empathetically and enhance user experience. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture for multi-modal emotion recognition, incorporating facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and regions, improving recognition accuracy and robustness. Experimental results on a large, diverse dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in recognizing emotions across various contexts and user populations.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph-structured data. However, optimizing query execution in these systems remains a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our proposed framework, 'GraphRL', learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution time. We evaluate GraphRL on a popular distributed graph database and demonstrate significant improvements in query performance compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Specialized Search Engines
paper_abstract: Specialized search engines, such as those for academic or biomedical queries, often struggle with low query clarity and sparse relevance feedback. We propose a novel hierarchical query expansion (HQE) approach that leverages both word embeddings and domain-specific ontologies to enhance retrieval performance. Our method iteratively expands the original query using a top-down strategy, incorporating semantic relationships and term importance weights. Experimental results on a dataset of biomedical queries demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain compared to state-of-the-art expansion techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Human-AI Collaboration
paper_abstract: Human-AI collaboration has become increasingly important in various domains, but understanding AI decision-making processes remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) framework that enables explainable human-AI collaboration. HGAT captures complex relationships between human and AI agents by learning hierarchical graph representations. We introduce a novel attention mechanism that adaptively weighs the importance of human and AI inputs, facilitating transparent and interpretable decision-making. Experimental results on a real-world healthcare dataset demonstrate that HGAT improves collaboration outcomes while providing insightful explanations for AI-driven decisions.

title: Efficient Indexing Techniques for Real-Time Data Warehousing
paper_abstract: Data warehousing has become a crucial component of business intelligence, but traditional indexing techniques struggle to keep pace with real-time data ingestion. This paper proposes a novel indexing framework, 'RTIndex', which leverages a combination of column-store indexing, delta encoding, and incremental clustering to facilitate efficient query processing in real-time data warehousing environments. We evaluate RTIndex using the TPC-H benchmark and demonstrate significant performance improvements over existing indexing techniques, achieving query response times under 100ms for complex analytics workloads.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their usefulness is severely limited for individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by difficulty articulating words. This paper presents a novel framework for designing accessible voice assistants that can better understand and respond to users with dysarthria. We develop a speaker-dependent acoustic model that leverages transfer learning from a large corpus of healthy speech data and fine-tunes on a small dataset of dysarthric speech. Our evaluation shows that the proposed system significantly improves transaction success rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants. We also provide design recommendations for voice assistant interfaces to facilitate more effective communication with users with dysarthria.

title: Query Expansion using Contextualized Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages contextualized embeddings to better capture the semantic relationships between query terms. Our approach, called ConEx, uses a pre-trained language model to generate contextualized embeddings for query terms, which are then used to expand the original query with relevant terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ConEx significantly outperforms existing query expansion techniques, particularly for queries with ambiguous or rare terms.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Pathfinding with Dynamic Graph Partitioning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to multi-agent pathfinding, a crucial problem in autonomous systems, video games, and robotic navigation. We introduce 'DynaPart', a scalable algorithm that leverages dynamic graph partitioning to efficiently compute collision-free paths for hundreds of agents in complex environments. DynaPart combines a hierarchical graph decomposition with a distributed auction-based method to allocate paths, achieving a significant reduction in computation time and memory usage compared to existing state-of-the-art methods. Experimental results on various benchmark scenarios demonstrate the efficacy and robustness of our approach.

title: Hierarchical Document Representation for Efficient Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle with document representation, leading to suboptimal query performance. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical document representation (HDR) approach that captures both local and global semantic relationships within documents. Our method represents documents as a nested hierarchy of semantic clusters, allowing for efficient pruning of irrelevant documents during query processing. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HDR achieves significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art dense passage retrieval methods.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture-Based Interfaces for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that adapt to the abilities of individuals with motor impairments. We propose a machine learning-based framework that utilizes a combination of computer vision and sensor data to recognize and classify gestures. Our approach enables users to customize the interface to their individual needs, allowing for more accurate and efficient interaction. We evaluate our approach through a user study with participants with varying levels of motor impairment, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user satisfaction.

title: Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Improved Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it can significantly impact the quality of retrieved documents. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using neural semantic embeddings, which capture the nuances of word meanings and relationships. We present a deep learning model that learns to generate expanded queries by projecting user queries into a high-dimensional semantic space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in precision and recall.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Effective task allocation is crucial in multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and constraints need to coordinate to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to autonomously allocate tasks in such systems. Our method, called 'ATA-MAS', employs a decentralized, asynchronous framework that adapts to dynamic environment changes and agent failures. We evaluate ATA-MAS on a range of simulated scenarios, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, centralized allocation strategies.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Decision-Making
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, decision-making often relies on complex interactions between agents. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HiGAT) framework to model these interactions and provide explainable decision-making. HiGAT combines graph attention mechanisms with hierarchical clustering to capture both local and global dependencies between agents. Experimental results on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate that HiGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of decision accuracy and interpretability, while also providing insights into agent interactions and decision influences.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Neural Ranking Models in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have become increasingly popular in information retrieval due to their ability to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, their computational overhead can lead to significant latency and resource consumption. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'NeuroOpt', which leverages pruning and quantization techniques to reduce the computational cost of neural ranking models. We evaluate NeuroOpt on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant speedups while maintaining retrieval effectiveness.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant performance challenges due to data replication and consistency maintenance. This paper presents a novel approach, 'AdaptRep', which dynamically adjusts replication factors based on real-time query patterns and data access frequencies. Our experiments on a large-scale distributed database testbed demonstrate that AdaptRep reduces query response times by up to 35% and improves system throughput by 21%, compared to traditional fixed-replication strategies. We also develop a theoretical model to guide replication factor adaptation, which is validated through extensive simulations.

title: Latent Semantic Analysis with Attention-based Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional latent semantic analysis (LSA) techniques rely on bag-of-words representations, overlooking the semantic relationships between words. This paper presents a novel neural LSA approach, ATTN-LSA, which incorporates attention mechanisms to model word contexts. Our method learns to weight words based on their importance in the document, allowing for more accurate topic modeling. Experimental results on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to traditional LSA and deep learning-based methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Column-Oriented NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: Column-oriented NoSQL databases have gained popularity in big data analytics due to their high storage efficiency and query performance. However, supporting multi-dimensional range queries (MDRQs) on these databases remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'CORI', which leverages the columnar storage layout to efficiently process MDRQs. CORI uses a combination of tree-based indexing and bitvector compression to reduce the query response time and storage overhead. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that CORI outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in query performance while maintaining a comparable storage footprint.

title: Personalized Gesture Recognition using Hierarchical Bayesian Networks for Inclusive HCI
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems often struggle to accommodate users with diverse abilities and preferences. This paper presents a novel, probabilistic approach to personalized gesture recognition, leveraging hierarchical Bayesian networks (HBNs) to model user-specific gesture patterns. Our framework, 'GESTURE+', incorporates domain knowledge and user feedback to adapt the recognition model, ensuring improved accuracy and inclusivity for users with disabilities. Experiments with a heterogeneous user group demonstrate significant performance gains over traditional machine learning approaches, highlighting the potential of HBN-based methods for enhancing accessibility in HCI.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Smart Home Environments
paper_abstract: As smart home technology becomes increasingly prevalent, there is a growing need for intuitive and efficient human-computer interaction methods. This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system that adapts to individual users' preferences and habits in real-time. Our approach combines machine learning-based gesture classification with user feedback and contextual information from smart home sensors. We evaluate our system through a user study, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to traditional gesture recognition systems. Furthermore, we provide a thorough analysis of the impact of environmental factors on system performance.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems Using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In heterogeneous multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn effective allocation strategies. We model the agent-task interaction as a graph and use GNNs to learn a latent representation of the agents' capabilities and task requirements. Our approach enables agents to make local decisions while considering global constraints, resulting in improved task allocation efficiency and adaptability to changing system dynamics. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on IoT Sensor Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices has generated vast amounts of sensor data, posing significant challenges for real-time analytics. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'IoTBoost', designed to accelerate query processing on IoT sensor data. IoTBoost leverages a combination of data partitioning, indexing, and caching techniques to minimize latency and maximize throughput. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT dataset demonstrate that IoTBoost outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization approaches by up to 3x, while ensuring low latency and high throughput for real-time analytics.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multimodal data (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a challenging task due to the inherent heterogeneity of modalities. This paper introduces a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that leverages the strengths of each modality to improve emotion recognition. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention modules that learn to fuse relevant features from each modality, followed by a hierarchical fusion layer that combines the outputs from each modality. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal fusion techniques, achieving an F1-score of 0.83 for emotion classification.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts system performance and throughput. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using deep reinforcement learning. We propose an agent-based framework, 'QLearn', that leverages a hybrid neural network architecture to learn optimal query plans for complex queries. Our experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that QLearn outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of execution time, while also adapting to changing workload patterns.

title: EmoTract: A Multimodal Affective State Tracker for Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper presents EmoTract, a novel multimodal affective state tracking system for human-computer interaction. EmoTract leverages computer vision, speech recognition, and physiological signal processing to detect and recognize users' emotions in real-time. Our approach employs a hybrid deep learning architecture, combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for facial expression analysis with recurrent neural networks (RNNs) for speech and physiological signal processing. We evaluate EmoTract on a dataset of 100 users, demonstrating high accuracy in recognizing six basic emotions (happiness, sadness, anger, fear, surprise, and disgust) with an average F1-score of 0.92.

title: Improving Query Efficiency in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems using Hierarchical Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval (DIR) systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale search queries. However, the communication overhead between nodes can significantly impact query efficiency. This paper presents a novel hierarchical indexing approach, HI-DIR, which leverages a two-level indexing structure to reduce the number of node interactions during query processing. Experimental results on a large-scale text corpus demonstrate that HI-DIR achieves an average query response time reduction of 37% compared to state-of-the-art DIR systems while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) systems, as it can significantly improve the retrieval performance. However, existing query expansion techniques often rely on manual feature engineering and may not generalize well to diverse query types. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework that leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of queries and documents. Our approach uses a multi-level attention mechanism to selectively expand queries based on their contextual importance. Experimental results on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Passage Retrieval
paper_abstract: Passage retrieval is a crucial step in open-domain question answering systems, requiring accurate ranking of relevant passages. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of queries and passages. Our model incorporates a multi-head self-attention mechanism to capture complex contextual relationships between query terms and passage content. Experimental results on the TREC CAR dataset demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 12% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Towards Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of big data has led to the widespread adoption of distributed relational databases. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'DistributedQueryOptimizer', that leverages machine learning and graph-based techniques to improve query efficiency. Our approach involves learning a query performance model from historical query executions and using it to guide the optimization process. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our framework outperforms existing query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Efficient traffic management is crucial for reducing congestion and improving safety in urban areas. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'TrafficMaster', which enables autonomous agents to learn decentralized traffic control policies in real-time. We introduce a hierarchical graph neural network architecture that captures complex traffic patterns and adapts to changing traffic conditions. Experimental results on a large-scale traffic simulation dataset demonstrate that TrafficMaster outperforms traditional optimization methods in terms of reduced travel times and increased network throughput.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to scalable multi-agent task allocation using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP). We propose a hierarchical DCOP framework, where agents are organized into clusters and allocate tasks within their respective clusters using a decentralized constraint optimization algorithm. The proposed approach is evaluated on a realistic logistics scenario, where multiple agents need to be assigned to transport tasks with varying constraints. Experimental results demonstrate a significant reduction in computation time and improved solution quality compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Emotive Avatars for Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing avatar designs often neglect the emotional and social needs of users. This paper presents 'Empatho', a novel framework for creating emotive avatars that facilitate empathetic connections in VR. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, which revealed that our avatars' emotional expressions and gestures significantly improved user engagement and social presence. We also developed a set of guidelines for inclusive avatar design, emphasizing the importance of cultural sensitivity and diversity representation.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion with Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion framework that leverages context-aware embeddings to better model query semantics. We introduce a two-stage approach, wherein the initial query is first expanded using a graph-based method, and then further refined using a contextualized embedding model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Deep Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require real-time decision-making capabilities to navigate complex environments. This paper presents 'RT-RL', a novel deep reinforcement learning framework optimized for real-time autonomous driving. We introduce a hierarchical policy architecture that leverages model-based and model-free learning to balance exploration and exploitation. Our approach incorporates a customized reward function that prioritizes safety, efficiency, and smoothness. Experimental results on a high-fidelity driving simulator demonstrate that RT-RL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of response time, fuel efficiency, and overall driving quality.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to improve the quality of search results by incorporating relevant terms. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network-based approach, 'QNExpand', which leverages semantic relationships between query terms and candidate expansion terms. QNExpand utilizes a dual-encoder architecture, where the query and candidate terms are separately embedded, followed by a attention-based interaction mechanism to predict the relevance of expansion terms. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that QNExpand outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, yielding significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) is a popular technique for achieving high concurrency in distributed databases. However, it can lead to complex query optimization challenges due to the presence of multiple versions of data. This paper presents a novel query optimization algorithm, 'MVCC-Opt', that leverages a combination of static and dynamic analysis to minimize the number of version checks and reduce query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a distributed database benchmark shows that MVCC-Opt outperforms existing approaches by up to 30% in terms of query throughput and 25% in terms of latency.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on distributed column-stores is crucial for various applications, including IoT and financial services. However, query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper presents 'RIO', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning-based cost modeling and dynamic reordering of join operations. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world column-store system demonstrates that RIO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3.5x in terms of query latency and 2.2x in terms of resource utilization. We also provide a theoretical analysis of RIO's performance guarantees under varying data distributions and query workloads.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column-Store Indexes
paper_abstract: With the increasing demand for real-time business intelligence, traditional row-store databases struggle to provide efficient query performance in data warehousing applications. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework that leverages column-store indexes to accelerate query execution. Our approach exploits the sparse nature of column-store data to reduce storage costs and improve query performance. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our framework achieves up to 5x query speedup compared to traditional row-store databases, making it suitable for real-time data warehousing applications.

title: Designing Adaptive Haptic Feedback for Multimodal Virtual Reality Experiences
paper_abstract: This paper explores the design of adaptive haptic feedback systems for multimodal virtual reality (VR) experiences. We propose a novel framework, 'HapSense', which integrates machine learning-based user modeling, haptic rendering, and real-time physiological signal processing. Our approach enables personalized and context-aware haptic feedback that enhances user immersion and engagement in VR applications. A user study involving 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in presence, spatial awareness, and overall user experience when using HapSense compared to traditional haptic feedback methods.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Database Systems with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems with heterogeneous storage configurations have become increasingly prevalent in modern data centers. However, optimizing query performance in such environments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'HeteroOpt', which leverages machine learning-based cost modeling and dynamic plan refinement to adapt to diverse storage characteristics. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database system show that HeteroOpt achieves significant improvements in query response time and throughput compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Deep Relevance Ranking for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Hierarchical Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with long documents and nuanced queries. This paper presents a novel deep learning approach, Hierarchical Relevance Embeddings (HRE), which captures both local and global semantic relationships within documents to improve relevance ranking. HRE employs a hierarchical document encoder that generates embeddings at multiple granularities, which are then used to compute relevance scores with respect to the query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate that HRE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including BERT-based models, and achieves significant improvements in terms of nDCG and ERR metrics.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and real-time analytics has led to an increased demand for efficient query optimization in data warehouses. This paper presents 'AdaOpt', a novel adaptive query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and statistical models to optimize query plans in real-time. AdaOpt dynamically adjusts to changing data distributions, query patterns, and system workloads, ensuring optimal performance and minimizing latency. Our experiments on a realistic dataset demonstrate that AdaOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize agent utility and minimize communication overhead. Our approach, called 'RL-TA', uses a distributed Q-network to learn task allocation policies for each agent, taking into account local observations and partial knowledge of the environment. We evaluate RL-TA in a simulated search-and-rescue scenario and demonstrate significant improvements in task completion time and agent satisfaction compared to traditional auction-based methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Decomposition for Multi-Agent Planning in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task decomposition framework for multi-agent planning in dynamic environments. Our approach, called HTD-MA, leverages a two-layered abstraction to efficiently reason about complex tasks and adapt to changing environmental conditions. The top layer represents high-level goals and subgoals, while the bottom layer focuses on low-level action planning. We introduce a probabilistic reasoning mechanism to handle uncertainty and a hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm to optimize task execution. Experimental results demonstrate that HTD-MA outperforms state-of-the-art multi-agent planning methods in terms of task completion rate, adaptability, and communication efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Graph-Based Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial technique for improving the effectiveness of information retrieval systems. However, traditional methods based on term co-occurrence and frequency analysis often suffer from limited contextual understanding. This paper proposes a novel approach, GraphQE, which leverages graph-based embeddings to capture semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our method represents the query and document graphs as dense vectors, enabling efficient similarity computation and query expansion. Experimental results on standard benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and robustness over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Conversational Search with Intent-Aware Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems aim to provide more natural and interactive search experiences. However, existing retrieval models often struggle to capture the nuances of conversational queries. This paper presents a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'IntentEx', which integrates a traditional keyword-based approach with a neural intent-aware query expansion component. IntentEx leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to identify relevant intent cues in the conversation history and generates expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on a large-scale conversational search dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and user satisfaction.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments, but current VR interfaces often exclude this population due to accessibility barriers. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'CARE-VR', a novel VR interface tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a user-centered design process involving 20 participants with mild cognitive impairment, resulting in a set of design guidelines and recommendations for inclusive VR interaction. Our evaluation study shows that CARE-VR significantly improves user engagement, task performance, and user experience compared to standard VR interfaces.

title: Self-Supervised Representation Learning for Time-Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time-series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and manufacturing. This paper proposes a novel self-supervised representation learning approach, 'TS-Rep', which leverages the inherent temporal dependencies in time-series data to learn effective anomaly detectors. TS-Rep uses a contrastive loss function to learn a robust representation space, where anomalies are distinguished from normal patterns. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that TS-Rep outperforms state-of-the-art anomaly detection methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in terms of F1-score.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDBS) are increasingly used in modern applications, but optimizing query performance remains a challenging problem. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query performance in DDBS. We propose a novel RL framework, 'QueryOpt', which learns to optimize query plans based on feedback from the database system. QueryOpt uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan for a given query and database state. Our experiments on a real-world DDBS dataset show that QueryOpt outperforms traditional query optimization techniques, achieving an average query performance improvement of 30%. We also demonstrate the adaptability of QueryOpt to changing database workloads and query patterns.

title: Scalable and Efficient Data Replication for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems face significant challenges in maintaining data consistency and availability in the presence of node failures and network partitions. This paper proposes a novel data replication strategy, 'Replex', which leverages a combination of quorum-based replication and asynchronous logging to achieve high availability and fault tolerance. We demonstrate the performance and scalability of Replex through extensive experiments on a large-scale distributed database testbed, showcasing significant improvements over existing replication strategies in terms of write throughput and latency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing approaches focus on either visual or textual explanations. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that integrates multi-modal information from user reviews, item images, and contextual data to generate personalized explanations for recommendations. Our HAN model learns to selectively attend to relevant features across modalities, producing more accurate and informative explanations. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art ERS methods in terms of both recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents through Hierarchical Task Decomposition and Reward Shaping
paper_abstract: Coordinating autonomous agents in complex, dynamic environments remains a significant challenge in multi-agent systems. This paper presents a novel framework for hierarchical task decomposition and reward shaping, enabling agents to reason about high-level goals and adapt to changing task requirements. We introduce a graph-based representation of tasks and subtasks, allowing agents to recursively decompose complex tasks into manageable sub-problems. Additionally, we propose a reward shaping mechanism that incorporates domain knowledge and incentives for cooperative behavior. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving agent coordination and task completion rates.

title: earableSense: A Context-Aware Wearable System for Real-Time Emotional State Detection
paper_abstract: earableSense is a novel wearable system that leverages machine learning and multimodal sensing to detect emotional states in real-time. Our system combines physiological signals from electrodermal activity, heart rate, and facial expressions to recognize emotional patterns. We introduce a context-aware framework that incorporates environmental and social factors, enhancing the system's accuracy and robustness. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that earableSense achieves an average F1-score of 0.92 in detecting four primary emotions, outperforming state-of-the-art approaches. Our system has significant implications for mental health monitoring, personalized recommendation systems, and human-computer interaction.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Elderly Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the quality of life for elderly individuals with motor impairments. However, existing systems often struggle to accurately recognize gestures performed by users with limited mobility or coordination. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive gesture recognition, which incorporates machine learning models that learn to recognize gestures from a small set of user-specific examples. We evaluate our approach using a custom-built dataset of gestures performed by elderly users with motor impairments and demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy compared to traditional, one-size-fits-all approaches.

title: Learning to Rank with Graph-based Relevance Propagation for Structured Queries
paper_abstract: Existing learning-to-rank (LTR) models for structured queries often rely on explicit feature engineering, ignoring the rich relational context within the query graph. We propose GraphRP, a novel LTR framework that infuses relevance propagation into the graph-based query representation. By modeling the query as a heterogeneous graph, GraphRP captures both syntactic and semantic relationships between entities, and learns to propagate relevance signals across the graph. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of complex queries demonstrate that GraphRP outperforms state-of-the-art LTR models, achieving significant improvements in ranking accuracy and relevance metrics.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, where the goal is to reformulate the user's query to better match the relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using reinforcement learning. We frame the query expansion problem as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select the most informative terms to add to the query. Our agent is trained using a reward function that balances the trade-off between precision and recall. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that our approach outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and reciprocal rank.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Search Engines using Graph-Based Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion techniques often rely on term co-occurrence or frequency-based methods, which may not capture the nuanced relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a graph-based approach, 'GraphEx', which leverages graph convolutional networks to learn context-aware embeddings for queries and documents. By modeling the query-document relationships as a graph, GraphEx can effectively capture semantic and syntactic dependencies, leading to improved retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of GraphEx in enhancing the search engine's ranking quality and retrieval accuracy.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Multi-Cloud Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: As data warehouses increasingly span multiple cloud providers, optimizing queries across distributed, heterogeneous systems becomes crucial. This paper presents 'CloudQ', a novel distributed query optimization framework that leverages machine learning to predict query execution times and adaptively schedules sub-queries across cloud regions. We introduce a novel cost model that incorporates data locality, network latency, and resource availability, and demonstrate that CloudQ outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in reducing query latency and improving resource utilization.

title: Entity Disambiguation for Knowledge Graph Construction using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph construction is a crucial task in information retrieval, but entity disambiguation remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph attention networks to disambiguate entities in knowledge graphs. Our method, called GAT-ED, learns to focus on relevant neighboring entities and contextual information to accurately resolve entity ambiguities. We evaluate GAT-ED on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving knowledge graph quality and reducing ambiguity. Our results show that GAT-ED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in entity disambiguation, especially in scenarios with limited training data.

title: Investigating the Effects of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: This study explores the impact of personalized avatars on user engagement in virtual reality-based learning environments. We designed an experiment where 120 participants interacted with a virtual reality platform using either a generic or personalized avatar. Our results show that participants using personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, as measured by time spent in the virtual environment and self-reported enjoyment. Furthermore, we found that personalized avatars increased users' sense of presence and embodiment, leading to improved learning outcomes. The implications of these findings for the design of virtual reality-based educational systems are discussed.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Passage Retrieval in Conversational Search
paper_abstract: Conversational search systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to provide accurate answers to user queries. This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, 'ConvRank', which leverages pre-trained language models and incorporates conversational context to improve passage ranking. We propose a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes passage relevance, semantic similarity, and conversation coherence. Experimental results on the TREC Conversational Assistance Track dataset demonstrate that ConvRank outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of mean average precision and response quality.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Hierarchical Neural Networks for Query-Document Matching
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for information retrieval often rely on complex, resource-intensive architectures. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural network (HNN) architecture that leverages both local and global contextual information to improve query-document matching. Our approach hierarchically integrates multiple encoding layers, enabling the model to capture nuanced semantic relationships between queries and documents. Experimental results on the TREC-2004 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in ranking accuracy and computational efficiency compared to existing neural ranking models.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can mislead them to make incorrect predictions. To address this issue, we propose a novel defense mechanism based on hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). Our approach, called 'AdvHR', consists of two stages: (1) a low-level policy that generates perturbations to the input data, and (2) a high-level policy that selects the most effective perturbations to robustify the network. We evaluate AdvHR on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving the robustness of deep neural networks against various types of adversarial attacks.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Agent Coordination for Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized coordination framework for autonomous agents in smart grids, enabling efficient resource allocation and adaptive decision-making. Our approach leverages distributed constraint optimization and multi-agent reinforcement learning to optimize energy distribution, reduce peak demand, and improve grid resilience. We evaluate our framework using a realistic simulation environment and demonstrate significant improvements in resource efficiency, response time, and scalability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in medical information retrieval, where the goal is to retrieve relevant documents from large biomedical databases. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion framework, 'MedExpan', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of medical concepts. We introduce a multi-task learning approach that jointly optimizes query expansion and document ranking, resulting in significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on the TREC-CDS dataset demonstrate that MedExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly for complex clinical queries.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents have varying capabilities and tasks have diverse requirements. We propose a decentralized approach using distributed constraint optimization (DCOP) to allocate tasks efficiently. Our method, called HeteroAlloc, models the task allocation problem as a DCOP and employs a novel algorithm that leverages agent negotiation and asynchronous constraint propagation. Experimental results on a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario demonstrate that HeteroAlloc outperforms centralized optimization methods in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Systems for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent system for autonomous traffic management, where agents representing individual vehicles or traffic signals cooperate to optimize traffic flow. We introduce a novel negotiation protocol that enables agents to dynamically adjust their behavior in response to changing traffic conditions, while respecting constraints imposed by traffic infrastructure and safety regulations. Our approach is evaluated using real-world traffic data and simulations, demonstrating improved traffic throughput and reduced congestion compared to traditional centralized traffic management systems.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Heuristics and Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial component of distributed database systems, as it directly impacts system performance and scalability. Existing approaches often rely on hand-crafted heuristics or exhaustive search, leading to suboptimal query plans. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages reinforcement learning to learn effective optimization strategies. We design a reward function that balances query execution time, resource utilization, and data consistency, and employ a deep Q-network to learn an optimal query plan generation policy. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate significant improvements in query performance and scalability compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems require efficient query optimization to ensure scalability and responsiveness. This paper presents a novel approach, Adaptive Indexing (AIx), which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query workload and data distribution. AIx leverages online learning to predict query patterns and adaptively creates or drops indexes to minimize query latency. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world dataset demonstrates that AIx outperforms traditional indexing techniques by up to 30% in query response time, while reducing storage overhead by 25%. We also explore the trade-offs between query performance and indexing overhead in distributed database systems.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach that leverages hierarchical task embeddings to adapt to new classes with limited labeled examples. We introduce a hierarchical task encoder that captures both global and local task relationships, enabling more effective knowledge transfer across tasks. Our method, 'Meta-HTE', achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets, including mini-ImageNet and CIFAR-FS. We also provide insights into the importance of task embeddings and their hierarchical structure in few-shot learning scenarios.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Temporal Logic Specifications
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems by synthesizing controllers that satisfy temporal logic specifications. We introduce a hierarchical planning framework that decomposes the global specification into local tasks, which are then allocated to individual agents using a distributed constraint satisfaction algorithm. Our approach is evaluated in a simulated robotics scenario, where a team of robots must cooperate to achieve a common goal while avoiding collisions and respecting safety constraints. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in generating correct-by-construction controllers that satisfy the desired specifications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their interfaces often neglect the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create more inclusive and accessible voice assistants for this demographic. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key pain points and areas for improvement. Our findings informed the development of 'ElderVoice', a novel voice assistant that incorporates age-related accommodations, such as simplified language, increased response time, and personalized feedback. A usability study with 30 older adults demonstrated significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly prevalent in modern data-intensive applications. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge in DDS due to the complexity of data distribution and communication overhead. This paper presents a novel graph-based indexing approach, called GraphIX, which leverages the structural properties of data graphs to optimize query performance. GraphIX constructs a hierarchical index that captures the underlying graph structure, enabling efficient query routing and reducing communication overhead. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that GraphIX achieves up to 3x improvement in query response time compared to existing indexing techniques.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its accessibility for users with visual impairments remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel VR interface design framework that incorporates auditory and haptic feedback to facilitate navigation and interaction for visually impaired users. We conducted a user study to evaluate the usability and accessibility of our proposed framework, which resulted in significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. Our findings have important implications for the development of inclusive VR applications that can benefit a broader user population.

title: Query Optimization Using Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data analytics. However, query optimization remains a challenging task due to the complexity of distributed systems. This paper proposes a novel query optimization approach using reinforcement learning, which learns to select the most efficient execution plan for a given query. Our approach, called QRL, uses a deep Q-network to model the query optimization problem and learns to adapt to different database configurations and workloads. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system show that QRL achieves significant performance improvements compared to traditional query optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Re-Ranking for Neural Search Engines using Query-Aware Document Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity due to their ability to capture semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, they often suffer from inefficient re-ranking mechanisms that fail to effectively leverage query context. This paper proposes a novel query-aware document embedding approach, 'QADE', which learns to incorporate query semantics into document representations. We demonstrate that QADE can be seamlessly integrated with existing neural ranking models, leading to significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and computational efficiency. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that QADE outperforms state-of-the-art re-ranking methods, achieving a 15% relative gain in NDCG@10.

title: Coordinated Exploration of Multi-Agent Systems using Graph-based Policy Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems exhibit complex behavior, making policy learning challenging. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach, 'GraphMA', which enables coordinated exploration among agents. By modeling agent interactions as a graph, we develop a policy learning framework that incorporates graph convolutional networks and attention mechanisms. GraphMA adaptively adjusts exploration strategies based on the graph structure, leading to improved coordination and overall system performance. Experimental results on a suite of multi-agent benchmark tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphMA in achieving better coordination and scalability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Retrieval Models using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but often suffer from limited query representation capacity. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'KG-Expan', which leverages knowledge graph embeddings to enrich query representations. We incorporate entity disambiguation and relation inference to generate high-quality expansion terms, and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we show that KG-Expan can be seamlessly integrated with existing neural retrieval models, making it a versatile and practical solution for real-world IR applications.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems have numerous applications in robotics, smart cities, and autonomous vehicles. Effective task allocation is crucial for achieving efficient collaboration. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using deep reinforcement learning, enabling agents to adapt to changing environments and learn from experience. We introduce a novel attention-based neural network architecture that incorporates communication constraints and partial observability, outperforming traditional heuristic-based approaches in simulated experiments.

title: EARL: Emotion-Aware Recommendation for Learning Disabilities in Online Education
paper_abstract: Students with learning disabilities (LD) often face emotional challenges in online educational environments. This paper introduces EARL, a novel affective computing framework that integrates multimodal emotion recognition with personalized learning recommendations. Our approach leverages facial expression analysis, sentiment analysis of chat logs, and learning behavior modeling to detect early signs of frustration or anxiety. EARL then adapts the learning content, pace, and feedback to promote emotional regulation and engagement. A user study with 50 LD students shows that EARL improves learning outcomes, reduces anxiety, and enhances overall user experience.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Decentralized Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper proposes a decentralized reinforcement learning framework for multi-agent systems, where each agent learns to make decisions based on local observations and communicates with neighboring agents to achieve global optimality. We introduce a novel graph-based attention mechanism that enables agents to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and adapt to changing traffic patterns. Experimental results on a simulated traffic network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized optimization methods and achieves significant reductions in travel time and congestion.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education, but limited research has explored the role of personalized avatars in enhancing user engagement. This study investigates the effect of customized avatars on user experience, motivation, and learning outcomes in VR-based learning environments. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, randomly assigned to either a personalized avatar or a default avatar condition. Results show that participants with personalized avatars reported higher levels of engagement, enjoyment, and self-efficacy, and achieved better learning outcomes compared to those with default avatars. Our findings have implications for the design of VR-based learning systems and highlight the importance of personalized avatars in promoting user engagement.

title: Optimizing Query Performance with Adaptive Indexing in Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems (MMDBs) offer high performance, but indexing strategies remain crucial for query optimization. We propose an adaptive indexing approach, ADI, which dynamically adjusts index structures based on query patterns and data distribution. ADI leverages a novel cost model that considers both query frequency and index maintenance overhead. Our experimental evaluation on a real-world MMDB system demonstrates that ADI achieves significant query performance improvements, up to 3.2x, compared to traditional static indexing techniques, while minimizing index maintenance costs.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database-as-a-Service Platforms
paper_abstract: Database-as-a-Service (DBaaS) platforms have become increasingly popular for deploying multi-tenant databases. However, query optimization in such platforms remains a significant challenge due to the complexities of shared resource allocation and varying workload patterns. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MultiOpt', which leverages machine learning-based predictive modeling to identify optimal query execution plans for each tenant. We evaluate MultiOpt on a real-world DBaaS platform and demonstrate substantial improvements in query performance and resource utilization compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Task Allocation using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent task allocation framework using deep reinforcement learning. We formulate the task allocation problem as a decentralized Markov decision process and utilize a multi-agent deep Q-network to learn the optimal task assignment policy. Our approach enables agents to adapt to dynamic task requirements and learn from their own experiences, without relying on a centralized controller. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient task allocation and improved system performance.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the lives of older adults, but existing systems often neglect their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a participatory design study that involved 20 older adults in the co-design of an inclusive voice assistant. We identified four key themes: simplicity, flexibility, trust, and social connection. Our findings inform the development of a prototype that incorporates these themes, including a simplified interface, flexible input methods, and trust-building features. Our study demonstrates the importance of involving older adults in the design process to create voice assistants that are accessible and usable for this growing population.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Task Network Planning
paper_abstract: Coordinating multiple agents to achieve complex tasks is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems. This paper presents a novel approach based on hierarchical task network (HTN) planning, which allows agents to reason about abstract tasks and their decomposition into primitive actions. We introduce a decentralized HTN planning algorithm that enables agents to coordinate their plans while minimizing communication overhead. Experimental results on a logistics domain demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of plan quality and execution time.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to predict sentiment from heterogeneous data sources (e.g., text, images, audio). Existing deep learning approaches often rely on complex models, making it challenging to interpret the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) for MSA, which integrates graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant multimodal features. We introduce a hierarchical feature fusion strategy, enabling the model to capture both local and global dependencies across modalities. Our experiments on three datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing explainable insights into the sentiment formation process.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Motion Planning
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient motion planning to navigate complex environments. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning approach, 'HiRLMP', which decomposes the motion planning problem into a hierarchy of tasks and sub-tasks. HiRLMP utilizes a high-level planner to generate a coarse trajectory and a low-level planner to refine the trajectory using a reinforcement learning policy. Our experiments demonstrate that HiRLMP outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of safety, efficiency, and adaptability to dynamic environments.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: As virtual reality (VR) becomes increasingly prevalent, it is essential to understand how embodiment ‚Äì the sense of owning a virtual body ‚Äì affects human-robot collaboration in these environments. This paper presents a user study (N=30) examining the effects of embodiment on trust, fluency, and overall collaboration performance in a VR-based assembly task. We find that participants in the embodied condition exhibit higher trust and fluency in their robotic partners, leading to improved task completion times and reduced errors. Our results have significant implications for the design of VR-based collaborative systems and highlight the importance of considering embodiment in human-robot interaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Interpretable Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time series forecasting is a crucial task in many applications, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture that leverages graph-based representations to model complex temporal dependencies. HGAT uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to identify relevant time series components and their interactions, providing interpretable insights into forecasting decisions. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of forecasting accuracy while offering improved model interpretability.

title: Adaptive Context-Aware Query Expansion for Short-Text Retrieval
paper_abstract: Short-text retrieval is a fundamental task in modern search engines, where queries often lack sufficient context. This paper introduces a novel adaptive context-aware query expansion framework, 'ACE', which leverages semantic embeddings and attention mechanisms to incorporate relevant contextual information. ACE adaptively adjusts the weight of expansion terms based on the query's ambiguity and the user's search intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ACE achieves significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and relevance compared to state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has seen significant advancements, but interaction methods remain limited. This paper presents an in-depth study on gaze-based interaction for VR, focusing on user experience and performance. We design and implement a custom VR system incorporating a gaze-tracking camera and evaluate its usability through a user study. Our results show that gaze-based interaction significantly reduces task completion time and improves user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based methods. We also identify key factors influencing user performance, including gaze accuracy, visual attention, and cognitive load.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have the potential to improve the lives of older adults with cognitive impairments, but current designs often fail to account for their unique needs. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to creating inclusive conversational interfaces for this population. We conducted interviews and usability studies with 20 older adults with cognitive impairments to identify key challenges and design recommendations. Our findings highlight the importance of simplicity, clarity, and cognitive support in conversational interface design. We propose a set of design guidelines and a prototype system that incorporates these principles, demonstrating improved usability and user experience for older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular due to the growing volume and complexity of data. However, query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using graph convolutional networks (GCNs). We represent the database schema as a graph and leverage GCNs to learn a latent representation of the query plan space. Our method, called QOGCN, uses this representation to predict optimal query plans, resulting in significant performance improvements over traditional optimization techniques. Experimental results on a real-world benchmark demonstrate that QOGCN outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query latency and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Query Expansion with Deep Neural Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity and nuance of patent language. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural embeddings to improve retrieval accuracy. We propose a two-stage framework, where a neural query expansion model generates semantically related terms and a learning-to-rank model re-ranks the expanded query to optimize retrieval performance. Experimental results on the PatentIR dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision. The proposed framework is scalable and can be easily integrated into existing patent retrieval systems.

title: Efficient Multi-Task Learning with Hierarchical Attention for Medical Image Analysis
paper_abstract: Medical image analysis often involves multiple tasks, such as lesion detection, segmentation, and classification. We propose a novel multi-task learning framework, 'HierAtt', which leverages hierarchical attention to share knowledge across tasks and modalities.
