Our approach learns to selectively focus on relevant regions and features, reducing the need for task-specific annotations and improving overall performance. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of brain MRIs demonstrate that HierAtt outperforms state-of-the-art methods in various tasks, while reducing computational costs and requiring fewer labeled samples.

title: Robustness Analysis of Deep Learning Models against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep learning models have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can significantly impact their performance. This paper proposes a novel approach to analyze the robustness of deep learning models against such attacks using Bayesian neural networks. We develop a framework that leverages Bayesian inference to quantify the uncertainty of the model's predictions and identify the most vulnerable inputs. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach can effectively detect and mitigate adversarial attacks, providing a robustness score that can guide model development and deployment.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Natural Language Processing Tasks with Hierarchical Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot natural language processing (NLP) tasks pose significant challenges due to the limited availability of labeled training data. This paper presents a novel meta-learning approach that leverages hierarchical task embeddings to adapt to new NLP tasks with only a few examples. Our method, called HiTE, learns to encode tasks in a hierarchical structure, capturing both task-specific and task-agnostic knowledge. We evaluate HiTE on a range of few-shot NLP tasks, including text classification, sentiment analysis, and question answering, and demonstrate state-of-the-art performance. Our results show that HiTE can effectively generalize to new tasks and outperforms existing few-shot NLP approaches.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Distributed Relational Databases using Adaptive Join Ordering
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases are increasingly used to support large-scale applications, but query processing remains a bottleneck. This paper proposes an adaptive join ordering technique, 'AJO', which dynamically adjusts the join order based on runtime statistics and data distribution. AJO integrates a machine learning-based cost model with a probabilistic optimization framework to minimize query execution time. Our experiments on the TPC-DS benchmark demonstrate that AJO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers in terms of query execution time and scalability, especially for complex queries with multiple joins.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Time Series Data
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in time series data is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. While existing methods often rely on hand-crafted features or supervised learning, we propose a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) for unsupervised anomaly detection. Our approach leverages the graph structure of time series data to capture complex patterns and relationships. The hierarchical architecture enables the model to learn both local and global features, improving detection performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAN in identifying anomalies, outperforming state-of-the-art methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of coordinating autonomous vehicles in urban traffic networks. We propose a decentralized multi-agent system, 'TrafficHub', which enables real-time decision-making and adaptive routing. TrafficHub utilizes a combination of model-based and model-free reinforcement learning to optimize traffic flow and minimize congestion. Experimental results using a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that TrafficHub outperforms traditional traffic management systems, reducing travel times by up to 30% and decreasing congestion by 25%

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis with Uncertainty Estimation
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has drawn increasing attention in recent years, but most existing approaches neglect the uncertainty inherent in model predictions. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) that jointly learns sentiment representations from text, image, and acoustic modalities. We propose a Bayesian extension to HAN, which enables uncertainty estimation for sentiment predictions. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal sentiment analysis models, while providing calibrated uncertainty estimates that can facilitate more informed decision-making in real-world applications.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Speech Patterns of Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern homes, but their usability and accessibility for older adults are often overlooked. This paper presents a mixed-methods study investigating the speech patterns of older adults interacting with voice assistants. We conducted interviews and usability testing with 30 participants aged 65+, analyzing their speech characteristics, error rates, and user experience. Our findings highlight the need for more inclusive design, suggesting that voice assistants should accommodate slower speech rates, varied pronunciation, and implicit command structures. We propose a set of design recommendations for improving the accessibility of voice assistants for older adults, promoting more equitable interaction experiences.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex systems, coordinating autonomous agents to achieve efficient resource allocation is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to train agents to adapt to changing environments and coordinate with each other. We develop a decentralized framework, 'AdaptCoord', which enables agents to learn from their experiences and adjust their resource allocation strategies in real-time. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid system demonstrate that AdaptCoord outperforms traditional optimization methods, achieving up to 25% reduction in resource waste and 30% improvement in system efficiency.

title: Evaluating the Efficacy of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: As the population ages, there is a growing need for accessible and effective interfaces for older adults. Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have shown promise in reducing cognitive load, but their efficacy in this context is understudied. This paper presents a mixed-methods study examining the impact of ECAs on cognitive load and user experience in older adults. Our results show that ECAs can significantly reduce cognitive load compared to traditional graphical user interfaces, particularly for tasks requiring working memory and attention. We also identify key design factors influencing user experience and provide guidelines for ECA development in this domain.

title: Query Optimization for Scalable Real-time Analytics on Temporal Graphs
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics on temporal graphs has become increasingly important in various domains, such as social network analysis and IoT data processing. However, existing query optimization techniques are limited by their inability to handle the unique properties of temporal graphs. This paper presents 'ChronoOpt', a novel query optimization framework that leverages the temporal and structural characteristics of graphs to minimize query latency and improve system scalability. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that incorporates graph summarization and temporal indexing to reduce the search space and accelerate query execution. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate ChronoOpt's effectiveness in reducing query latency by up to 5x compared to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, cooperative behavior often relies on complex interactions and relationships between agents. However, existing approaches to multi-agent cooperation lack interpretability, making it difficult to understand the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) architecture that enables explainable multi-agent cooperation. HGAN integrates graph attention mechanisms to capture agent relationships at multiple scales, allowing for transparent and interpretable cooperation policies. We evaluate HGAN on a range of cooperative tasks, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph Neural Networks for Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a crucial step in knowledge graph construction, but it becomes increasingly challenging as the graph size grows. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn representations of entities and their context, enabling accurate disambiguation at scale. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures both local and global dependencies in the graph, and demonstrate its effectiveness on several real-world knowledge graphs. Our experiments show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency, making it a viable solution for large-scale knowledge graph construction.

title: Designing Adaptive Keyboard Layouts for Enhanced Gesture-Based Text Entry on Touchscreens
paper_abstract: Gesture-based text entry on touchscreens is becoming increasingly popular, but traditional keyboard layouts are not optimized for this input modality. This paper presents a novel approach to designing adaptive keyboard layouts that dynamically adjust to an individual's gesture patterns and typing habits. We propose a machine learning model that leverages user data to optimize key placement, size, and spacing, resulting in improved typing accuracy and speed. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that our adaptive layout outperforms traditional QWERTY and alphabetical layouts by 15% and 25%, respectively, in terms of typing speed and accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems (ERS) have gained significant attention in recent years. However, most existing ERS methods focus on modeling user-item interactions and neglect the rich structural information present in the data. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) model that integrates graph attention and hierarchical representation learning to capture complex relationships between users, items, and their attributes. Our approach provides personalized explanations for recommendations, improving transparency and trust in AI-driven systems. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HGAT in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Entity Disambiguation in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation in knowledge graphs (KGs) often relies on query expansion techniques to capture contextual information. However, existing methods suffer from high computational costs and limited semantic understanding. We propose a novel query expansion framework, 'KG-Expand', which leverages graph attention mechanisms and lexical semantic analysis to selectively incorporate relevant entities and relationships. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets, such as YAGO and DBpedia, with significant reductions in computational time. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of KG-Expand in improving entity disambiguation accuracy for downstream applications, such as question answering and text classification.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Adaptive Trust for Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, the presence of untrusted or Byzantine agents can compromise system performance. This paper introduces a novel decentralized task allocation framework, 'ATA', which incorporates adaptive trust mechanisms to mitigate the impact of malicious agents. ATA uses a Bayesian approach to update trust values based on agent behavior, and employs a distributed auction protocol to allocate tasks. Experimental results demonstrate that ATA outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion rate and robustness to agent failures.

title: Deep Graph Multi-Task Learning for Node Classification and Graph Reconstruction
paper_abstract: Graph-structured data is ubiquitous in many real-world applications, including social networks, molecular biology, and recommender systems. This paper proposes a novel deep graph multi-task learning framework, 'GraphMTL', which jointly learns node classification and graph reconstruction tasks. GraphMTL leverages a hierarchical graph attention mechanism to capture node and graph-level representations, and incorporates a reinforcement learning-based optimization strategy to adaptively weigh task losses. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in node classification accuracy and graph reconstruction quality compared to state-of-the-art single-task models.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Contrastive Regularization
paper_abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved remarkable success in various domains, but the lack of interpretability hinders its applicability in high-stakes decision-making scenarios. This paper proposes a novel approach to explainable RL by incorporating contrastive regularization into the policy optimization process. Our method, Contrastive-RL, encourages the agent to learn a compact and meaningful representation of the state space, enabling the identification of key factors driving its decision-making. We demonstrate the effectiveness of Contrastive-RL on a range of Atari games and a real-world robotics task, showcasing improved transparency and performance.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Relational Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial task in relational databases, but existing methods often rely on hand-crafted heuristics or expensive search procedures. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn query optimization strategies. We represent query plans as graphs and train a GNN model to predict the optimal execution plan. Our experiments on a suite of benchmark queries demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers in terms of query execution time and plan quality. We also explore the interpretability of our model, providing insights into the decision-making process of the optimizer.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, but current approaches rely heavily on manual feature engineering and fail to capture the complexities of human emotions. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates multimodal data from speech, text, and facial expressions. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on salient features and hierarchically fuse information from different modalities. Experimental results on a large-scale multimodal dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions and achieves improved robustness to noisy or missing data.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis has gained significant attention in recent years, as it enables the analysis of opinions expressed through different modalities, such as text, images, and audio. However, existing approaches often treat each modality independently, overlooking the complex interactions between them. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that jointly learns to extract and fuse features from multiple modalities. Our HAN model consists of modality-specific attention layers that learn to weigh the importance of each modality, followed by a hierarchical fusion layer that captures the interactions between modalities. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art multimodal sentiment analysis models, particularly in scenarios with noisy or incomplete data.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Norm-Based Social Influence
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, social influence can significantly impact the emergence of global behavior. This paper introduces a novel framework for coordinating agents using norm-based social influence. We propose a probabilistic model that captures the dynamics of social influence, and develop a decentralized algorithm for agents to adapt to changing norms. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a series of simulations, showcasing its ability to promote cooperation and achieve system-level goals in complex, dynamic environments.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems have gained popularity due to their ability to provide high performance and low latency. However, optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning-based cost estimation and a dynamic reordering approach. Our framework, called 'MemOpt', considers the unique characteristics of main-memory systems, such as the absence of disk I/O and the limited availability of CPU resources. Experimental results demonstrate that MemOpt outperforms traditional query optimizers in terms of query execution time and reduces the number of CPU cycles required.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance in critical applications. This paper proposes a novel approach to robustify DNNs against such attacks using Bayesian neural networks (BNNs). We leverage the probabilistic nature of BNNs to model uncertainty and develop a new defense mechanism that adapts to the variability of input data. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves the robustness of DNNs against various types of adversarial attacks, including white-box and black-box attacks.

title: Efficient Reinforcement Learning with Hierarchical Graph Attention for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient decision-making in complex environments. We propose a novel reinforcement learning framework that leverages hierarchical graph attention to model the relationships between road entities. Our approach, 'GRAVITAS', enables the agent to focus on critical regions of the graph, reducing computational overhead and improving navigation performance. Experimental results on a simulated urban driving scenario demonstrate that GRAVITAS outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in terms of task completion rate and safety metrics.

title: SQL-Opt: A Query Optimization Framework for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular, but optimizing query performance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents SQL-Opt, a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and graph-based models to minimize query latency and improve resource utilization. SQL-Opt integrates with existing database management systems and can be easily extended to support various data distributions and query patterns. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that SQL-Opt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system designed specifically for older adults with motor impairments. Our system, called 'EasyGest', uses a combination of machine learning algorithms and wearable sensor data to adapt to individual users' abilities and preferences. We conducted a user study with 20 participants and found that EasyGest achieved an accuracy of 92.1% in recognizing gestures, outperforming existing systems. Our results suggest that adaptive gesture recognition systems can improve the accessibility and usability of technology for older adults with motor impairments.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but users with dysarthria, a speech disorder affecting articulation and pronunciation, often struggle to interact with these systems effectively. This paper presents the design and evaluation of 'EasyVoice', a novel voice-based interface tailored to the needs of users with dysarthria. EasyVoice incorporates a range of accessibility features, including personalized speech recognition models, dynamic prompt adjustment, and multimodal feedback. A user study with 20 participants with dysarthria demonstrates significant improvements in interaction accuracy, fluency, and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph-based Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in various applications, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks raises significant concerns. In this paper, we propose a novel graph-based anomaly detection method, called GraphAAD, to detect adversarial attacks in DRL environments. GraphAAD leverages the structural relationships between states and actions to identify abnormal patterns in the agent's behavior. Our experiments on several DRL benchmarks demonstrate that GraphAAD significantly outperforms existing detection methods, achieving an average detection accuracy of 92.5%. We also provide theoretical analysis to guarantee the robustness of our approach.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Control
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the challenging problem of coordinating multi-agent systems in urban traffic control. We propose a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework that integrates both macro- and micro-level control strategies. The upper level optimizes traffic signal control policies using a graph attention network, while the lower level adapts agent behavior to local traffic conditions using deep Q-networks. Our approach is validated through simulations on a real-world traffic network, demonstrating significant reductions in travel time and congestion compared to traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning with Graph Attention
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for coordinating multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning with graph attention. We introduce a new architecture that incorporates graph attention mechanisms to learn agent relationships and coordination strategies. Our approach is evaluated on a series of benchmarks, including traffic control and robotic swarm coordination tasks. The results show significant improvements in coordination efficiency and task completion rates compared to existing methods. We also provide theoretical guarantees for the convergence of our algorithm in decentralized settings.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Social Media
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis on social media platforms is challenging due to the multimodal nature of user-generated content. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that jointly learns from visual, textual, and acoustic features. Our HAN model employs a nested attention mechanism to capture local and global contextual relationships between modalities, enabling more accurate sentiment predictions. Experimental results on a large-scale, multimodal dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, outperforming state-of-the-art multimodal fusion techniques by 3.5% in F1-score.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Multimodal emotion recognition (MER) involves analyzing human emotions from various modalities such as speech, text, and vision. Existing MER approaches often rely on early fusion or late fusion strategies, which may not effectively capture complex relationships between modalities. This paper proposes a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to model multimodal interactions. Our HGAT framework consists of a modality-specific encoder, a graph attention module, and a fusion layer. Experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art MER models, achieving an average F1-score of 83.2% for emotion classification.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have the potential to improve the lives of older adults, but existing systems often neglect their unique needs and abilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for creating accessible conversational interfaces tailored to older adults. We conducted a series of focus groups and co-design workshops with older adults to identify key design recommendations, including the use of simple and consistent language, visual cues, and error forgiveness. We implemented these recommendations in a prototype conversational agent and evaluated its usability with 30 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Feature Fusion in Visual Question Answering
paper_abstract: Visual question answering (VQA) requires the integration of visual and linguistic features to accurately answer questions about images. This paper proposes a hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that leverages multi-modal feature fusion to improve VQA performance. Our approach uses graph attention to model relationships between visual regions, objects, and question words, and hierarchically aggregates features to capture complex contextual information. Experimental results on the VQA 2.0 dataset demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models, achieving a 4.5% absolute improvement in accuracy.

title: Decoupling Gestural Input from Motor Control in Virtual Reality using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on precise motor control to interpret user gestures, leading to fatigue and decreased immersion. We propose a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to decouple gestural input from motor control, enabling users to interact with virtual objects using subtle, intuitive movements. Our method, GestureRL, employs a hierarchical policy architecture that learns to recognize gestures from vision-based input and translates them into precise motor commands. Experimental results show that GestureRL achieves a 35% reduction in user fatigue while maintaining high accuracy in gesture recognition, paving the way for more accessible and engaging VR experiences.

title: Coordinated Exploration in Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, effective exploration is crucial for efficient task allocation and resource utilization. We propose a novel approach, Graph Attention-based Coordinated Exploration (GACE), which leverages graph attention networks to model agent interactions and coordination. GACE enables agents to share knowledge and adjust their exploration strategies based on the graph structure, leading to improved coverage and reduced redundancy. Our experiments on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that GACE outperforms traditional decentralized exploration methods, achieving higher task completion rates and shorter exploration times.

title: EmoTract: Affective State Inference from Multimodal Interaction Traces for Enhanced Human-Computer Collaboration
paper_abstract: Effective human-computer collaboration relies on the system's ability to understand users' emotional states. This paper introduces EmoTract, a multimodal framework that infers users' affective states from interaction traces, including facial expressions, speech patterns, and keyboard/mouse dynamics. We propose a novel fusion approach that combines the strengths of machine learning and psychological models to improve inference accuracy. Evaluation on a real-world dataset shows that EmoTract outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotional states, enabling more empathetic and personalized human-computer interactions.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation for autonomous agents using deep reinforcement learning. We propose a decentralized framework, 'AgentDRL', which enables agents to learn efficient task allocation strategies through interactions with their environment and other agents. Our approach leverages a multi-agent deep Q-network to model the complex relationships between agents and tasks, and we demonstrate its effectiveness in a simulated warehouse management scenario. Experimental results show that AgentDRL outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion time and agent utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current VR interfaces often exclude users with visual impairments. This paper presents a novel framework for designing inclusive VR interfaces that accommodate users with varying levels of visual impairment. We conducted a participatory design study with 15 participants, resulting in the development of four key design principles: audio-centric navigation, tactile feedback, personalized audio cues, and adaptable font sizes. We implemented these principles in a VR game and evaluated its usability with 10 visually impaired participants, demonstrating significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of autonomous vehicles on public roads necessitates the development of efficient coordination mechanisms to ensure safe and efficient traffic flow. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'AV-Coor', which enables autonomous vehicles to learn cooperative behaviors in complex traffic scenarios. AV-Coor utilizes a decentralized, graph-structured neural network to model the interactions among vehicles and the environment, and demonstrates improved traffic throughput and reduced congestion compared to traditional rule-based approaches in simulated experiments.

title: Diversifying Search Results using Reinforcement Learning-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Information retrieval systems often suffer from the problem of result homogeneity, where users are presented with overly similar documents. To address this, we propose a novel query expansion approach based on reinforcement learning. Our method, dubbed 'RL-QE', learns to select expansion terms that maximize a diversified set of relevant documents. We formulate the query expansion task as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that RL-QE significantly improves the diversity of search results while maintaining retrieval effectiveness.

title: Towards Explainable Adversarial Attacks on Deep Neural Networks using Attention-based Attribution
paper_abstract: Despite their impressive performance, deep neural networks remain vulnerable to adversarial attacks. In this paper, we propose an attention-based attribution method to generate explainable adversarial attacks. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to identify the most critical input features contributing to the model's predictions. By perturbing these features, we craft targeted attacks that are more interpretable and effective. Experimental results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate the efficacy of our method in generating visually meaningful attacks while maintaining a high attack success rate. Our work provides new insights into the adversarial vulnerability of deep models and paves the way for developing more robust and transparent AI systems.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Control
paper_abstract: Real-time traffic control is a complex problem that requires the coordination of multiple agents to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating multi-agent systems in traffic control. Our approach consists of a high-level controller that learns to allocate resources and set goals for individual agents, which in turn learn to optimize their local control policies. We evaluate our approach using a realistic traffic simulator and demonstrate improved performance compared to traditional reinforcement learning methods. We also analyze the scalability and robustness of our approach in various traffic scenarios.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly prevalent in modern data management systems. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning to optimize query execution plans. We develop a learning-based cost model that accurately predicts query execution times and a reinforcement learning-based optimizer that adapts to changing database workloads. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query latency and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where multiple agents need to coordinate to accomplish complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'CATAR', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task allocation in cooperative multi-agent systems. CATAR learns a decentralized policy that considers both local and global rewards, enabling agents to adapt to changing task requirements and environmental dynamics. Experimental results demonstrate that CATAR outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion time, resource utilization, and system scalability.

title: Gaze-Informed Adaptive User Interfaces for Individuals with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with visual impairments face significant challenges when interacting with graphical user interfaces. This paper presents 'GAZE', a novel adaptive UI framework that leverages gaze tracking and machine learning to dynamically adjust UI elements for improved accessibility. We integrate a deep learning-based gaze estimation model with a user behavior analysis module to infer users' intentions and adapt the UI in real-time. Our user study with 20 visually impaired participants demonstrates that GAZE significantly reduces interaction time and improves overall user experience compared to traditional assistive technologies.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-time Data Warehousing using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing requires optimizing complex queries to minimize latency and ensure freshness of data. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepQOpt', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn optimal query plans from historical query logs and system metadata. We design a hierarchical DQN architecture that incorporates domain knowledge from database optimization and explores the vast space of possible query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DeepQOpt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time and 2x in terms of system resource utilization.

title: Real-time Emotion Recognition using Multimodal Fusion and Attention-based Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction, with applications in fields such as mental health, customer service, and entertainment. This paper presents a novel multimodal approach that leverages audio, video, and text inputs to recognize emotions in real-time. Our proposed architecture, called 'EmoFusion', employs attention-based deep neural networks to selectively focus on relevant features from each modality, leading to improved recognition accuracy and robustness. Experimental results on a large, publicly available dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of EmoFusion in recognizing emotions in diverse contexts, outperforming state-of-the-art unimodal and multimodal approaches.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of haptic feedback on user experience and learning outcomes in VR-based learning environments. We designed a VR system that incorporates tactile feedback and conducted a controlled experiment with 120 participants. Results show that haptic feedback significantly enhances user engagement, presence, and learning transfer, particularly for complex tasks. Our findings have implications for the design of VR-based educational systems and highlight the importance of incorporating multimodal feedback to enhance user experience.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Vehicles using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous vehicles using multi-agent reinforcement learning. We propose a novel algorithm, 'MARL-TA', that enables vehicles to learn and adapt to dynamic environments and tasks in real-time. MARL-TA uses a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (DEC-POMDP) to model the task allocation problem, and employs a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic scenario demonstrate that MARL-TA achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and reduces overall travel time compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Attention-based Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has emerged as a crucial technique for representing complex relationships in large-scale graphs. However, existing methods struggle to capture nuanced dependencies between entities and relationships. We propose 'AttentionKG', a novel KGE framework that integrates attention-based graph neural networks to selectively focus on relevant subgraphs during training. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmark datasets, including WN18RR and FB15K-237, and demonstrates improved interpretability through attention visualizations.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Heterogeneous Capabilities
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that involves assigning tasks to agents with varying capabilities. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'HeteroAssign', which leverages graph neural networks to model agent capabilities and task requirements. HeteroAssign uses a consensus-based optimization approach to allocate tasks in a decentralized manner, ensuring that agents with suitable capabilities are assigned tasks that maximize system efficiency. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that HeteroAssign outperforms existing centralized and decentralized methods in terms of task completion rate and system adaptability.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Cooperation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent cooperation, understanding the decision-making process is crucial for trust and accountability. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) framework that enables explainable cooperation among agents. HAN learning agents attend to relevant information from both local observations and communication with other agents, allowing for interpretable decision-making. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in a variety of cooperative tasks, including joint navigation and resource allocation, and show that it outperforms existing methods in terms of both performance and explainability.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Optimization for Multi-Robot System Coordination
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized optimization framework for coordinating multi-robot systems using agent-based methods. Our approach leverages a distributed optimization algorithm, which enables each robot to make decisions based on local information and communicate with its neighbors to achieve a global objective. We evaluate the performance of our framework using a simulated search-and-rescue scenario, demonstrating improved convergence rates and robustness compared to traditional centralized optimization methods. The proposed framework has potential applications in various domains, including disaster response, environmental monitoring, and surveillance.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Internet of Things Networks
paper_abstract: In Internet of Things (IoT) networks, efficient task allocation is crucial for optimizing resource utilization and minimizing latency. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'DTRL', for distributed task allocation in IoT networks. DTRL employs a decentralized architecture, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communicates with neighboring agents to achieve global optimality. We evaluate DTRL on a simulated IoT network and demonstrate significant improvements in task allocation efficiency and adaptability compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Individuals with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but individuals with visual impairments often face significant barriers to accessing these experiences. This paper presents a novel, inclusive VR interface design framework that leverages multimodal sensory substitution and audio-based navigation to enable visually impaired users to engage with VR environments. We evaluate the effectiveness of our approach through a user study with 20 visually impaired participants, demonstrating improved navigation performance and user satisfaction compared to traditional visual-based interfaces.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize learning experiences, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user participation and motivation in VR-based educational settings. We designed an experiment involving 120 participants, who interacted with either a generic or personalized avatar in a VR learning environment. Our results show that users who interacted with personalized avatars reported higher levels of engagement, enjoyment, and self-efficacy compared to those with generic avatars. We also found that the personalization effect was more pronounced for users with lower prior experience in VR. The findings have implications for the design of inclusive and effective VR-based learning systems.

title: Designing Inclusive Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Study
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces, such as voice assistants, have become ubiquitous in modern life. However, older adults often face difficulties using these systems, citing issues with understanding, trust, and usability. This paper presents a participatory design study with 20 older adults, co-designing and evaluating a conversational interface tailored to their needs. Our findings highlight the importance of speech recognition accuracy, clear and concise language, and personalized feedback. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating inclusive conversational interfaces that support older adults' autonomy and digital literacy. Our study contributes to the development of more accessible and user-centered conversational systems.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Relational Link Prediction
paper_abstract: Link prediction in knowledge graphs is a fundamental task in various AI applications. While existing methods focus on flat graph structures, real-world graphs often exhibit hierarchical relationships. We propose a novel knowledge graph embedding framework, 'HATKE', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to capture multi-relational semantics. Our approach learns entity and relation embeddings that adapt to the hierarchical structure, improving link prediction performance. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HATKE outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly in scenarios with complex relational patterns.

title: Query Optimization for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As distributed databases increasingly support multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) for improved transactional throughput, query optimization becomes a critical challenge. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCCO', which leverages a combination of static analysis, runtime profiling, and machine learning-based prediction to identify optimal query execution plans for MVCC-enabled databases. Our experimental evaluation on a benchmark dataset demonstrates that MVCCO reduces average query latency by up to 35% compared to existing optimization techniques, while maintaining strong consistency and correctness guarantees.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Medical Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Medical information retrieval (IR) systems struggle to handle complex queries, leading to poor retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'MedEx', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic representations of medical concepts. We develop a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture relationships between query terms and medical entities, enabling effective expansion of queries. Experimental results on a benchmark medical dataset demonstrate that MedEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a significant improvement in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Neural Topic Modeling for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent from short, ambiguous queries. We propose a novel query expansion approach that leverages neural topic models to identify latent topics in the query and generate semantically relevant expansion terms. Our method, called NeuroTE, uses a variational autoencoder to learn a compact representation of the query, which is then used to generate expansion terms via a topic-based language model. Experimental results on several standard IR benchmarks demonstrate that NeuroTE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Visual Feedback on User Experience in Virtual Reality-Based Gesture Recognition
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has enabled the development of gesture recognition systems that can be used in various applications. However, the lack of tactile feedback can lead to user frustration and decreased performance. This study investigates the effect of visual feedback on user experience in VR-based gesture recognition. We designed a VR system that provides users with real-time visual cues about their gesture accuracy and compared it to a system without feedback. Our results show that visual feedback significantly improves user performance, reduces error rates, and enhances overall user experience. We also found that users with prior VR experience benefited more from visual feedback than novice users.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Hybrid Relational-NoSQL Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of NoSQL databases in modern data management has led to the development of hybrid relational-NoSQL systems. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'HybridOpt', which leverages the strengths of both relational and NoSQL paradigms. HybridOpt introduces a cost-based optimization approach that considers the underlying data storage and query patterns to generate efficient query plans. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HybridOpt outperforms existing optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Deep Ranking Models for Diverse Query Intent Discovery
paper_abstract: Query intent discovery is a crucial task in information retrieval (IR), as it enables search engines to return more relevant results. This paper proposes a novel deep ranking model, 'DiverseIntent', which leverages a combination of semantic and intent-based features to improve query intent discovery. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that captures diverse intent aspects, such as entity, attribute, and action, and demonstrate its effectiveness in identifying underlying query intents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that DiverseIntent outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of intent discovery accuracy and relevance ranking quality.

title: Adaptive Document Ranking with Neural Query Graphs for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval (IR) often rely on handcrafted features and static query representations, limiting their adaptability to diverse query types and document collections. This paper introduces Neural Query Graphs (NQG), a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks to model query-document interactions. NQG learns to adaptively represent queries as graphs, capturing complex semantic relationships between query terms and entities. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art ranking models.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Graph-Based Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has revolutionized deep learning model design. However, existing methods suffer from high computational costs and limited exploration of the vast search space. This paper introduces GraphNAS, a novel NAS framework that leverages graph-based reinforcement learning to efficiently explore the architecture space. By representing architectures as graphs, we enable effective exploration-exploitation trade-offs and reduce the number of required evaluations. Experimental results on popular benchmarks demonstrate that GraphNAS achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing search time by an order of magnitude.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning techniques to improve query optimization. We develop a neural network-based model that predicts optimal query plans based on historical query patterns and system workload. Our experimental results show that the proposed approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Enhanced Cognitive Load Management in Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) interfaces have the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but they also introduce significant cognitive load challenges. This paper presents a novel design framework for adaptive visualizations that dynamically adjust to the user's cognitive state. We propose a real-time cognitive load assessment model that combines eye-tracking, EEG, and performance metrics. Our approach is evaluated through a user study, demonstrating improved task performance and reduced mental fatigue in a VR-based problem-solving scenario. The results have implications for the design of more inclusive and user-centered VR interfaces.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Anthropomorphic Design on User Trust in Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) are increasingly integrated into daily life, but their anthropomorphic design can influence user trust. This study investigates how VA design features, such as facial expressions and tone of voice, affect user trust and perceived reliability. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 120 participants, who interacted with a VA in a controlled environment. Results show that VAs with more human-like features were perceived as more trustworthy, but this effect was mitigated when the VA made mistakes. Our findings have implications for the design of VAs in high-stakes applications, such as healthcare and finance.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Semantic Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval systems rely heavily on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. However, existing methods often suffer from limited context awareness and vocabulary mismatch. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'SemExpan', which leverages deep semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. We integrate BERT-based embeddings with a graph-based expansion approach, enabling the incorporation of domain knowledge and semantic constraints. Experimental results on a large patent dataset demonstrate that SemExpan outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision and a 20% increase in recall.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Emotional Intelligence in Human-Computer Interaction Using Multimodal Fusion
paper_abstract: Emotional intelligence (EI) has become a critical aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), as it enables systems to better understand and respond to users' emotional states. This paper presents a novel multimodal fusion approach for evaluating EI in HCI, combining facial expression analysis, speech patterns, and physiological signals. We conducted a user study with 50 participants, analyzing their interactions with an affective chatbot. Our results show that our approach significantly outperforms single-modality EI evaluation methods, achieving an accuracy of 87.2% in detecting users' emotional states. We discuss the implications of our findings for designing more empathetic and human-centered interfaces.

title: Designing Accessible Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Error Recovery Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice-based interfaces have become increasingly popular, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by difficulties in error recovery. This paper presents a study on designing accessible voice-based interfaces for older adults, focusing on error recovery strategies. We conducted a series of user studies with 30 older adults, investigating the effectiveness of four error recovery strategies: explicit error messages, implicit error correction, proactive error prevention, and adaptive error recovery. Our results show that a combination of explicit error messages and adaptive error recovery leads to significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of voice-based interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Virtual Reality Using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has seen widespread adoption, but securing user authentication in immersive environments remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel gaze-based authentication system, 'GazeAuth', which leverages deep learning to identify users based on their gaze patterns while navigating VR scenes. We collect a dataset of gaze trajectories from 100 participants and train a convolutional neural network (CNN) to extract discriminative features. Experimental results demonstrate that GazeAuth achieves an accuracy of 95.6% and outperforms state-of-the-art authentication methods in VR settings.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for Large-Scale Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based applications. However, their computation is often hindered by the large scale of real-world graphs. This paper introduces 'HierGNN', a novel hierarchical clustering framework that efficiently processes large graphs by recursively aggregating node representations. Our approach leverages a density-based clustering algorithm to group nodes into hierarchical communities, reducing the computational complexity of GNNs. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate that HierGNN achieves significant speedups while maintaining competitive performance with existing GNN models.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Relational Databases using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Optimizing complex queries in distributed relational databases is a challenging task, especially in scenarios with large amounts of data and diverse query patterns. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn query optimization strategies. Our method, called QOpt-GNN, represents the database schema and query patterns as graphs and trains a GNN to predict optimal query plans. Experimental results on the TPC-H benchmark demonstrate that QOpt-GNN outperforms traditional rule-based and cost-based query optimizers, achieving an average speedup of 2.5x in query execution time.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Older Adults
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to improve gesture-based interaction for older adults. We designed a VR system that incorporates bodily gestural cues to facilitate intuitive interaction with virtual objects. Our user study with 30 older adults (ages 65-85) demonstrates a significant reduction in interaction time and error rate compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. Furthermore, our analysis of EEG and behavioral data reveals increased cognitive engagement and reduced cognitive load when using the gesture-based system. Our findings have implications for the design of accessible and inclusive VR interfaces for older adults.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time analytics has become a crucial aspect of modern data-driven applications, requiring efficient processing of complex queries over distributed databases. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'Raptor', that leverages machine learning and statistical modeling to predict query execution costs and optimize join orders. We introduce a novel cost model that incorporates data skew, correlation, and query concurrency, and demonstrate significant performance improvements over state-of-the-art optimizers on a range of real-world benchmarks.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Graph-Based Term Embeddings for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, but traditional methods often rely on manual input or simplistic term co-occurrence analysis. This paper proposes a novel neural graph-based approach, 'TermGraph', which learns dense term embeddings from a large-scale knowledge graph. By incorporating graph attention mechanisms, TermGraph captures complex semantic relationships between terms and enables more effective query expansion. Experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance and efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Drone Navigation in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous drones require efficient navigation in uncertain environments, which is challenging due to the complexities of real-world scenarios. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'DroneHRL', which integrates high-level mission planning with low-level control policies. We propose a novel abstraction mechanism that enables the agent to reason about the environment at different levels of granularity, allowing for more effective navigation in uncertain scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that DroneHRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of navigation efficiency and robustness to environmental uncertainty.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art results in node classification tasks, but their computational complexity increases rapidly with graph size. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes and subgraphs. By recursively applying attention at multiple scales, HGAN reduces the number of node embeddings to be computed, resulting in significant speedups. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAN achieves competitive accuracy to state-of-the-art GNNs while being up to 5x faster.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Experiences for People with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to enhance the quality of life for people with disabilities, but existing VR systems often neglect the needs of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive VR experiences for individuals with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive disabilities. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with individuals with disabilities and developed a set of guidelines and tools for designers to create accessible VR applications. Our evaluation study with 20 participants with disabilities demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach in improving their VR experience and enhancing their sense of presence and engagement.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation in dynamic environments is a challenging problem that requires efficient decision-making and adaptability. This paper proposes a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CoopStar', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies for task allocation in uncertain and changing environments. We introduce a decentralized Q-network architecture that incorporates communication and trust mechanisms, allowing agents to share knowledge and adapt to new situations. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that CoopStar outperforms traditional centralized approaches and achieves significant improvements in task completion rates and response times.

title: Enhancing Document Retrieval with Aspect-Aware Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in document retrieval, but traditional methods often fail to capture the nuances of user intent. This paper proposes Aspect-Aware Query Expansion (AAQE), a novel framework that incorporates aspect-based sentiment analysis to disambiguate query terms. We leverage a deep learning model to identify relevant aspects in the query and then expand the query with aspect-specific terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, improving mean average precision by up to 15%.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Adaptive Auction Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using adaptive auction mechanisms, which enables agents to dynamically adjust their bidding strategies based on real-time feedback. We introduce a novel auction protocol that incorporates a reinforcement learning component to optimize task allocation and minimize communication overhead. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and system efficiency, while maintaining scalability and robustness in dynamic environments.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity in recent years, but their performance is often limited by the quality of the query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize the selection of expansion terms. Our approach, dubbed 'ReinforceQE', uses a neural agent to learn a policy for selecting expansion terms based on their expected impact on retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that ReinforceQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, leading to significant improvements in search accuracy and efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Decision-Making
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require efficient decision-making strategies to navigate complex scenarios. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) framework, 'Automa', which integrates task decomposition and option learning to improve decision-making in autonomous vehicles. Automa decomposes the driving task into a hierarchy of sub-tasks, each with its own option policy. We demonstrate that Automa achieves superior performance and adaptability compared to flat reinforcement learning methods in various simulated driving scenarios, including lane merging and pedestrian interaction.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval using Deep Neural Ranking Models with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Deep neural ranking models have shown promising results in document retrieval tasks, but their performance can be limited by the quality of the input queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages semantic relationships between query terms to generate more informative and context-aware queries. Our approach uses a combination of word embeddings and graph-based methods to identify relevant expansion terms, which are then incorporated into a neural ranking model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly improves the retrieval performance of state-of-the-art neural ranking models, especially for ambiguous and underspecified queries.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Efficient Query Expansion in Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in ad-hoc search, but existing methods often sacrifice retrieval efficiency for improved effectiveness. This paper introduces a hybrid retrieval model, 'HybEx', which combines the strengths of lexical and semantic expansion techniques. HybEx leverages a neural network-based query intent detector to selectively apply expansion strategies, reducing the number of redundant terms and improving query latency. Our experiments on the TREC ad-hoc search dataset demonstrate that HybEx achieves state-of-the-art effectiveness while reducing query processing time by up to 30% compared to existing methods.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality-Based Gesture Recognition Systems
paper_abstract: This study explores the role of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR)-based gesture recognition systems. We designed an experimental framework that utilizes VR to simulate real-world scenarios, while participants performed gestures with varying levels of embodiment. Our results show that embodied cognition significantly enhances gesture recognition accuracy, particularly in scenarios requiring fine-grained motor control. We also observed a positive correlation between embodiment and user engagement. These findings have implications for the design of more effective and engaging gesture-based interfaces in VR applications.

title: Bayesian Neural Architecture Search for Real-time Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on accurate and efficient object detection to ensure safety. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian neural architecture search (NAS) approach, 'AutoDetect', to optimize real-time object detection models for autonomous vehicles. We introduce a hierarchical Bayesian optimization framework that incorporates domain knowledge and performance metrics to search for the optimal neural architecture. Experiments on the KITTI dataset show that AutoDetect achieves state-of-the-art detection accuracy while reducing inference latency by up to 30% compared to manually designed models.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: Traffic signal control is a complex problem that requires real-time decision-making to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. This paper proposes a hierarchical multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'HMA-RL', that coordinates traffic signals across a network of intersections. HMA-RL consists of a top-level controller that learns to allocate green light times to different intersections and a set of low-level agents that adjust their signal phases based on local traffic conditions. We evaluate HMA-RL on a real-world traffic dataset and show that it outperforms traditional fixed-time and actuated signal control methods in terms of average travel time and queue length.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embeddings have become a crucial component in various AI applications, but their interpretability remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for learning explainable knowledge graph embeddings. HGAT leverages multi-hop relationships to capture both local and global graph structures, while attention mechanisms facilitate the identification of relevant entities and relations. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance on knowledge graph completion and link prediction tasks, while providing insights into the learned embeddings through attribution analysis.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Graph Neural Networks for Node Classification
paper_abstract: Node classification is a fundamental task in graph-based learning, but existing methods often struggle to capture complex relationships between nodes. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention-based graph neural network (HAGNN) architecture, which leverages multi-scale node representations and attention weights to selectively focus on relevant neighbors. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAGNN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks. Moreover, we provide empirical evidence of the benefits of hierarchical attention in capturing long-range dependencies and improving robustness to noisy graph structures.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Entity disambiguation is a fundamental task in knowledge graph construction, but traditional methods suffer from scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'KGEmbedD', which leverages knowledge graph embeddings to efficiently disambiguate entities. We learn vector representations of entities and their contexts, enabling fast similarity calculations and accurate disambiguation. Experiments on large-scale datasets demonstrate that KGEmbedD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, making it suitable for real-world applications.

title: Scalable Multi-Task Learning with Hierarchical Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning has emerged as a powerful paradigm for simultaneously learning multiple related tasks. However, existing approaches often suffer from scalability issues and require careful task selection. This paper presents a novel hierarchical task embedding framework, dubbed 'HTE', which enables efficient and effective multi-task learning at scale. By representing tasks as hierarchical clusters of embedded vectors, HTE can capture complex task relationships and adapt to new tasks with minimal additional computation. Our experiments on a suite of benchmark datasets demonstrate that HTE achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple tasks while requiring significantly fewer parameters and training iterations compared to existing methods.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Gamification in Enhancing User Engagement with Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants (VAs) have become ubiquitous in modern life, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study investigates the application of gamification techniques to improve user interaction with VAs. We designed and developed a gamified VA prototype, incorporating features such as point systems, leaderboards, and personalized challenges. A user study with 120 participants demonstrated a significant increase in user engagement, with participants exhibiting higher motivation and enjoyment when interacting with the gamified VA compared to a standard VA. Our findings provide insights into the potential of gamification to enhance the user experience with VAs.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Embodied cognition theories suggest that the mind is grounded in sensorimotor experiences, which can be leveraged to improve learning outcomes. This paper investigates the effectiveness of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR)-based learning environments. We designed a VR-based learning system that incorporates gestural interactions, spatial awareness, and haptic feedback to promote deeper understanding of complex scientific concepts. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates that the embodied cognition approach leads to significant improvements in knowledge retention, transfer, and application compared to traditional desktop-based learning environments. Our findings have implications for the design of immersive learning systems that can enhance educational outcomes.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global goals. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework, 'DRL-TA', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments in real-time. Each agent learns to select tasks based on its local observations, and a decentralized communication protocol enables information sharing and coordination among agents. We evaluate DRL-TA on a simulated search and rescue scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional auction-based methods.

title: Hybrid Retrieval Model for Efficient Short-Text Search in E-Commerce Platforms
paper_abstract: E-commerce platforms face the challenge of efficiently searching and ranking short-text product descriptions to provide users with relevant results. This paper proposes a novel hybrid retrieval model, 'HybridRank', which combines the strengths of term-based and semantic-based retrieval approaches. HybridRank incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and product descriptions, while leveraging sparse term-frequency representations to reduce computational overhead. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate that HybridRank achieves a 25% increase in recall and a 30% reduction in latency compared to state-of-the-art retrieval models.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Multimodal Retrieval in E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines struggle to effectively retrieve relevant items when users submit queries with limited context. We propose a context-aware query expansion framework that leverages multimodal information from product images, videos, and user reviews. Our approach incorporates a graph-based attention mechanism to identify salient context features and generate expanded queries that better capture user intent. Experimental results on a large e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of voice-based interfaces has transformed human-computer interaction, but individuals with cognitive impairments, such as older adults, often struggle to effectively utilize these systems.
