This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create inclusive voice-based interfaces tailored to the needs of older adults with cognitive impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants, resulting in the development of a novel interface framework that incorporates cognitive support, error tolerance, and personalized feedback. Our evaluation demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to existing voice-based interfaces.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Autonomous Driving
paper_abstract: Real-time autonomous driving requires rapid decision-making and adaptability to dynamic environments. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-AD', which leverages a combination of high-level planning and low-level control to improve navigation efficiency and safety. Our approach decomposes the driving task into a hierarchical structure, where a high-level policy optimizes long-term goals, and a low-level policy executes short-term actions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HRL-AD in various real-world driving scenarios, achieving significant improvements in task completion rate and reduced latency compared to flat reinforcement learning methods.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodied Cognition on Human-Computer Interaction in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper explores the role of embodied cognition in shaping human-computer interaction (HCI) in virtual reality (VR) environments. We designed an immersive VR experiment to investigate how users' bodily experiences influence their problem-solving strategies and performance in a spatial reasoning task. Our results show that participants who underwent a brief embodied cognition induction exhibited improved task performance and reduced cognitive load compared to a control group. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of more intuitive and effective VR-based interfaces, and highlight the potential for embodied cognition to inform the development of more human-centered HCI systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Temporal Graph Forecasting
paper_abstract: Temporal graph forecasting is a crucial task in many real-world applications, such as traffic prediction and disease spread modeling. However, existing methods often lack interpretability, making it challenging to understand the underlying dynamics. We propose Hierarchical Attention Networks (HAN-Forecast), a novel framework that incorporates hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes, edges, and timestamps. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on several benchmark datasets while providing explainable predictions through attention visualization. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN-Forecast in a case study on traffic flow prediction, showcasing its potential for real-world deployment.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, vision) is crucial for human-computer interaction. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture to tackle this problem. HAN leverages attention mechanisms at multiple scales to selectively focus on relevant modalities, features, and temporal segments. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on three benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs. Our analysis reveals that HAN's hierarchical attention structure enables it to capture complex cross-modal interactions and contextual dependencies.

title: Optimizing Join Order Enumeration using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed database systems, join order enumeration significantly impacts query performance. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics or exhaustive search, leading to suboptimal solutions. We propose 'JoinRL', a novel deep reinforcement learning framework that learns to optimize join order enumeration. JoinRL leverages a graph neural network to represent query graphs and a policy network to generate join orders. Experimental results on various TPC-H benchmarks demonstrate that JoinRL outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, achieving up to 3x improvement in query execution time.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Dataspaces with Heterogeneous Data Sources
paper_abstract: Distributed dataspaces have emerged as a promising architecture for integrating heterogeneous data sources. However, optimizing queries in such environments remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution and varying source capabilities. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'DQM', which leverages a combination of statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to efficiently identify optimal query plans. We demonstrate the efficacy of DQM through extensive experiments on a real-world distributed dataspace, showcasing significant performance improvements over existing optimization methods.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: Investigating Gestural Input for Multimodal Interaction
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has transformed human-computer interaction, but existing interfaces often neglect the role of embodiment in cognition. This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in VR, where users' gestures and body language influence their mental representations. We design and evaluate a multimodal interaction system, 'EMERGE', which leverages machine learning-based gesture recognition, gaze tracking, and physiological signals to create a more immersive and intuitive user experience. Our user study demonstrates that EMERGE enhances cognitive processing, reduces mental workload, and increases user engagement in VR environments.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-time Query Expansion in Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in search engines, but its computational overhead can significantly impact query response times. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'QEIndex', that facilitates efficient query expansion for real-time search applications. By leveraging a combination of term co-occurrence analysis and clustering-based document representation, QEIndex reduces the number of candidate expansion terms while preserving retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate a 3x reduction in query expansion latency compared to state-of-the-art techniques, making QEIndex a promising solution for modern search engines.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Mitigating Cognitive Biases
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interactions can perpetuate and even amplify cognitive biases. This paper presents a novel multimodal framework for designing inclusive voice assistants that mitigate biases in human-computer interaction. Our approach combines natural language processing, affective computing, and cognitive modeling to detect and adapt to users' emotional and cognitive states. A user study with 120 participants demonstrates that our approach reduces bias in decision-making tasks and improves user satisfaction. We discuss implications for designing more inclusive and empathetic voice assistants.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the problem of task allocation in heterogeneous multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and resources need to accomplish complex tasks. We propose a decentralized auction-based mechanism that enables agents to bid for tasks based on their estimated costs and capabilities. Our approach leverages a novel auction protocol that ensures truthfulness, individual rationality, and Pareto optimality. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in achieving efficient task allocation and improved system performance compared to centralized and heuristic-based methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention-based Knowledge Graph Embedding for Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention-based knowledge graph embedding (HAKGE) method for multi-label classification tasks. Our approach leverages the structural information in knowledge graphs to learn entity and relation embeddings, which are then integrated with a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex semantic dependencies between entities. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HAKGE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multi-label classification, particularly in scenarios with limited training data. Our approach has potential applications in natural language processing, question answering, and recommender systems.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval faces challenges in capturing the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a neural query expansion framework, 'NQE-PRF', that leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to refine query representations. Our approach combines a neural query encoder with a relevance-based feedback mechanism, allowing the model to adapt to the retrieval scenario. Experimental results on several TREC datasets demonstrate that NQE-PRF outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Dialogue Management
paper_abstract: Dialogue management in multi-agent systems remains a challenging task, particularly when agents have diverse goals and communication styles. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that models agent interactions and dialogue flows. Our HAN learns to selectively focus on relevant dialogue contexts and agent intentions, enabling more effective and efficient dialogue management. Experimental results on a large-scale multi-agent dialogue dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of dialogue coherence, agent goal achievement, and overall system performance.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, leveraging graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn effective allocation strategies. Our approach, dubbed 'GraphAgent', represents the agent-task graph as a sparse, heterogeneous network and applies GCNs to learn node representations that capture task dependencies and agent capabilities. Experimental results on a variety of agent-task scenarios demonstrate that GraphAgent outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of allocation efficiency, scalability, and robustness to agent failures.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to improve the effectiveness of ad-hoc retrieval systems. We formulate query expansion as a Markov decision process, where the agent learns to select a subset of expansion terms that maximize the expected relevance of the retrieved documents. Our DRL model, called QERL, uses a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to capture the semantic relationships between query terms and expansion candidates. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QERL outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall.

title: Efficient Query-Document Similarity Measurement using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional query-document similarity measurement methods in Information Retrieval (IR) rely on handcrafted features and shallow learning techniques, which may not capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel deep neural network architecture, 'DeepSim', which learns hierarchical representations of queries and documents from large-scale clickthrough data. We demonstrate that DeepSim outperforms state-of-the-art IR models on several benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency. Furthermore, we analyze the learned representations and provide insights into the semantic patterns captured by DeepSim.

title: Adaptive Task Assignment for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to task assignment in multi-agent systems using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, called Adaptive Task Assignment (ATA), learns to allocate tasks to agents based on their capabilities, availability, and the dynamic environment. ATA uses a decentralized, multi-agent Q-network to optimize task assignments and minimize overall system latency. We evaluate ATA in a simulated robotic search and rescue scenario, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and agent utilization compared to traditional, rule-based assignment methods.

title: Enriching Query Representations with Hierarchical Attention for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of complex queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query representation model, Hierarchical Attention-based Query Encoder (HAQE), which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant aspects of the query. By recursively applying attention at the word, phrase, and sentence levels, HAQE generates enriched query representations that better capture the query intent. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval benchmark demonstrate that HAQE outperforms state-of-the-art query encoding methods, achieving significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Navigation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles (AVs) operating in dynamic environments require real-time decision-making and adaptability to navigate safely and efficiently. This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for AV navigation, where each agent represents a distinct vehicle or traffic entity. We introduce a hierarchical graph-based architecture that integrates local and global state representations, enabling agents to learn cooperative behaviors and respond to changing environmental conditions. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic scenario demonstrate improved navigation performance and reduced collision rates compared to traditional single-agent approaches.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the independence and quality of life for older adults with cognitive impairments. However, existing systems often fall short in accommodating the unique needs of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to developing an accessible voice assistant, 'EasyVoice', tailored to the cognitive and linguistic abilities of older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops and usability studies, resulting in a novel conversation flow and visualization framework that reduces cognitive load and promotes successful task completion. Our evaluation with 25 older adults with cognitive impairments demonstrates significant improvements in task accuracy and user satisfaction compared to commercial voice assistants.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalization on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by user experience (UX) issues. This study explores the effect of personalization on UX in VR, focusing on user preferences, cognitive load, and emotional response. We designed a user study involving 30 participants, who interacted with a VR system that adapted to their individual preferences, cognitive abilities, and emotional states. Our results show that personalized VR experiences lead to improved user satisfaction, reduced cognitive load, and enhanced emotional engagement. We also identify key factors influencing personalization in VR and provide guidelines for designers and developers.

title: Scalable Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Hashing
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is a crucial component in various applications, including similarity search and data mining. Existing indexing methods, such as ball trees and locality-sensitive hashing, suffer from scalability issues and high computational costs. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical hashing approach, dubbed 'HashTree', which leverages a recursive partitioning strategy to efficiently index high-dimensional data. Our approach achieves a significant reduction in query time and memory usage compared to state-of-the-art methods, making it suitable for large-scale datasets. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HashTree in various applications, including nearest neighbor search and clustering.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query representations. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQERL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn an optimal policy for selecting expansion terms. We model the query expansion process as a Markov decision process and employ a deep Q-network to learn the value function. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQERL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving an average improvement of 15.2% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Efficient Zero-Shot Learning for Open-World Object Detection using Graph-Based Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Object detection in open-world scenarios poses significant challenges, particularly when encountering unseen classes. This paper presents a novel zero-shot learning approach, 'GraphZSL', which leverages graph-based knowledge graph embeddings to learn a universal detector. By modeling relationships between classes as a graph, we can efficiently propagate knowledge from seen to unseen classes. Our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on multiple benchmarks, demonstrating improved detection accuracy and robustness in open-world settings.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing User Anxiety in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown immense potential in various fields, but user anxiety remains a significant barrier to its widespread adoption. This study investigates the effectiveness of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) in reducing user anxiety in VR environments. We designed and implemented an ECA-based system that utilizes multimodal cues to provide emotional support and guidance to users. Our user study involving 40 participants reveals that the ECA system significantly reduces user anxiety and improves overall VR experience. We also identify key design factors that influence the anxiety-reducing effect of ECAs, providing valuable insights for the development of anxiety-mitigating VR systems.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Object Transport
paper_abstract: Cooperative object transport tasks, where multiple agents work together to transport large objects, are challenging due to the need for coordination and communication. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'CAT', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies without explicit communication. We introduce a novel graph-based representation that captures the agents' spatial relationships and a reward function that promotes cooperation. Experimental results on a simulated object transport domain demonstrate that CAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and success rate.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy sources in smart grids necessitates the development of advanced control strategies. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for coordinating autonomous agents in smart grids. We design a two-level architecture, where a high-level agent learns to optimize the overall grid performance, while low-level agents focus on local voltage control. Our approach enables agents to adapt to dynamic grid conditions, reduce energy losses, and improve voltage stability. Simulation results on a realistic grid model demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in reducing energy losses by up to 12% compared to traditional rule-based control methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for multi-agent dialogue systems, enabling explainable decision-making and improved dialogue coherence. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant agents, utterances, and context, thereby facilitating more accurate and interpretable dialogue state tracking. We evaluate our model on a large-scale, multi-agent dialogue dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in dialogue success rate and human evaluation metrics compared to state-of-the-art baselines. Our architecture provides a promising step towards developing more transparent and trustworthy AI-powered dialogue systems.

title: Adaptive Buffer Management for Efficient Query Processing in Multi-Core Database Systems
paper_abstract: Multi-core database systems have become increasingly prevalent, but efficient query processing remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel adaptive buffer management strategy, called 'ABMS', which dynamically allocates buffer space to optimize query performance. ABMS leverages a machine learning model to predict query access patterns and adapts to changing workloads. Our extensive experimental evaluation on a real-world database benchmark demonstrates that ABMS achieves significant improvements in query response time and throughput compared to state-of-the-art buffer management approaches.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Multimodal Approach to Enhance Accessibility for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their adoption by older adults is hindered by accessibility barriers. This paper presents a multimodal approach to enhance the inclusivity of voice assistants for older adults, incorporating both speech and gesture-based input. We propose a novel framework, 'AccessibleVA', which leverages machine learning and computer vision to recognize and interpret gestures, and integrates them with speech recognition to improve overall system accuracy. Our user study with 30 older adults demonstrates that AccessibleVA significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional speech-only interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition has become a crucial aspect of human-computer interaction (HCI), enabling more empathetic and personalized systems. However, existing approaches often rely on complex, black-box models that struggle to provide transparent and interpretable results. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) for multi-modal emotion recognition, integrating facial expressions, speech, and physiological signals. Our HAN architecture leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant features and modalities, providing real-time explanations for emotion predictions. Experimental results on the SEMAINE database demonstrate improved recognition accuracy and robustness compared to state-of-the-art methods, while our visual attention heatmaps offer valuable insights into the emotional cues driving our model's decisions.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Modern Search Engines
paper_abstract: The increasing volume of web data has made efficient document retrieval a critical component of modern search engines. This paper proposes a novel neural query expansion approach that leverages deep learning models to effectively capture query semantics and expand user queries. Our approach, dubbed 'NQE', incorporates a dual-encoder architecture that jointly learns query and document representations, allowing for efficient query expansion and document ranking. Experimental results on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness and efficiency compared to traditional query expansion methods.

title: Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks for Cold-Start Recommendation
paper_abstract: Cold-start recommendation, where user or item interactions are scarce, remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel heterogeneous graph neural network (HGNN) framework, 'HetRec', which leverages multiple types of relationships between users, items, and attributes. We design a meta-learning based approach to adapt the HGNN to new, unseen items, and demonstrate its effectiveness in cold-start scenarios. Experimental results on real-world datasets show that HetRec outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly in scenarios with extreme sparsity.

title: Hierarchical Multi-Task Learning for Explainable Recommender Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommender systems have gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing approaches focus on either model-based or model-agnostic explanations. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical multi-task learning framework, 'ExplainHTL', which integrates both types of explanations. Our approach leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to capture complex user-item relationships and a multi-task objective to jointly optimize rating prediction and explanation generation. We conduct extensive experiments on three real-world datasets and demonstrate that ExplainHTL outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of recommendation accuracy and explanation quality.

title: EyeGazeType: A Machine Learning Approach to Predictive Text Entry for Individuals with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often rely on alternative text entry methods, which can be slow and error-prone. This paper presents EyeGazeType, a machine learning-based system that leverages eye gaze and keystroke patterns to predict and complete words in real-time. Our approach combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) for gaze pattern recognition with a recurrent neural network (RNN) for language modeling. Evaluation with 20 participants with motor impairments shows that EyeGazeType significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of text entry speed and accuracy, enabling more efficient communication for individuals with disabilities.

title: Adaptive Regularization for Deep Neural Network Pruning in Resource-Constrained Environments
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are increasingly deployed on resource-constrained devices, where model size and computational complexity are critical concerns. This paper presents a novel regularization technique, 'AdaReg', which adaptively adjusts the pruning rate of DNNs based on the availability of computational resources. Our approach leverages a reinforcement learning framework to optimize the trade-off between model accuracy and compression ratio. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaReg outperforms existing pruning methods in terms of model size reduction while preserving accuracy, making it suitable for real-world applications with varying resource constraints.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have gained popularity due to their ability to capture complex query-document relationships. However, they often struggle to generalize to out-of-vocabulary queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method, 'ConQE', which leverages contrastive learning to learn robust query representations. By training a contrastive model to distinguish between relevant and non-relevant documents, ConQE generates effective expansion terms that improve the retrieval performance of neural search engines. Experimental results on the TREC CAR dataset demonstrate that ConQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines Using Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have revolutionized information retrieval, but their effectiveness is often hindered by limited query representation. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'ContrastiveQE', which leverages contrastive learning to generate high-quality expansion terms. By training a neural network to differentiate between relevant and non-relevant documents, ContrastiveQE learns to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and expanded terms. Our experiments on the TREC-8 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion methods by up to 12% in terms of MAP.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with ambiguous or under-specified queries. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep reinforcement learning. Our method, dubbed 'RL-Expan', learns to iteratively expand the query by selecting relevant terms from a large vocabulary, guided by a reward function that balances retrieval effectiveness and query coherence. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RL-Expan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis is a challenging task that requires modeling complex relationships between visual, textual, and acoustic features. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that captures both local and global dependencies across modalities. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to learn modality-specific and multimodal representations, which are then fused using a hierarchical pooling strategy. Experimental results on the MMIMDB and CMU-MOSEI datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multimodal sentiment analysis tasks, achieving significant improvements in accuracy and F1-score.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Entities through Dynamic Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that affects the overall performance and efficiency of the system. This paper presents a novel approach to dynamic task allocation, where autonomous entities adapt to changing environmental conditions and task requirements. Our approach, called 'DyTAMA', uses a decentralized, auction-based mechanism to allocate tasks in real-time, taking into account the capabilities, preferences, and constraints of individual agents. Experimental results demonstrate that DyTAMA outperforms existing task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and system adaptability.

title: Hierarchical Neural Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional ranking models in information retrieval often suffer from high computational complexity, limiting their applicability to large-scale document collections. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking model, 'HierRank', which leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant document segments. By exploiting the document structure, HierRank reduces the computational overhead while maintaining state-of-the-art retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our approach, particularly in scenarios with limited computational resources.

title: EyeCare: A Gaze-Based Interface for Individuals with Severe Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with severe motor impairments face significant challenges interacting with digital systems. This paper presents EyeCare, a novel gaze-based interface that enables users to interact with graphical user interfaces using only their eye movements. EyeCare employs a machine learning-based gaze estimation model that leverages deep learning techniques to accurately detect and interpret user intentions. A user study with 15 participants demonstrates that EyeCare achieves an average accuracy of 92.5% in selecting UI elements, significantly outperforming existing state-of-the-art systems. EyeCare has the potential to greatly improve the quality of life for individuals with severe motor impairments.

title: Optimizing Query Processing for Multi-Version Concurrency Control in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As distributed databases continue to scale, multi-version concurrency control (MVCC) has emerged as a crucial technique for ensuring transactional consistency. However, MVCC introduces additional overheads in query processing, particularly in distributed settings. In this paper, we propose a novel query optimization framework, 'MVCC-Opt', which leverages statistical models to predict query execution times and dynamically adjusts the MVCC protocol to minimize latency. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MVCC-Opt using a comprehensive experimental evaluation on a distributed database benchmark, showing improvements of up to 30% in query throughput and 25% in latency reduction compared to existing MVCC approaches.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Elderly Users
paper_abstract: This study investigates the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) to alleviate cognitive load in elderly individuals. We designed an ECA system, 'ElderCare', which utilizes multimodal inputs (speech, gesture, and facial expression) to provide personalized assistance. Our user study involved 30 elderly participants who interacted with ElderCare to complete various tasks. Results show that ElderCare significantly reduced cognitive load, as measured by pupil dilation and self-reported metrics, compared to traditional text-based interfaces. Our findings have implications for the development of accessible and user-centered HCI systems for aging populations.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: In complex multi-agent systems, coordinating autonomous agents to achieve efficient resource allocation is a challenging problem. This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-CAA', that enables agents to learn coordination strategies in a decentralized manner. Our approach integrates a high-level planning module with a low-level execution module, allowing agents to adapt to changing environments and optimize resource allocation. We evaluate HRL-CAA in a simulated smart grid scenario, demonstrating improved resource allocation efficiency and reduced energy waste compared to traditional decentralized control methods.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Semantic Embeddings for E-commerce Search
paper_abstract: E-commerce search engines rely heavily on query expansion techniques to improve retrieval accuracy. However, traditional methods often fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships between query terms and products. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'SemExpan', which integrates semantic embeddings into the query expansion process. By leveraging pre-trained language models and product knowledge graphs, SemExpan generates context-aware expansion terms that better align with user intent. Experimental results on a large-scale e-commerce dataset demonstrate significant improvements in search relevance and user satisfaction compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Deep Semantic Hashing for Efficient Image Retrieval in Large-Scale Databases
paper_abstract: The rapid growth of visual data has made image retrieval a challenging task, particularly in large-scale databases. This paper proposes a novel deep semantic hashing (DSH) approach that learns compact binary codes for efficient image retrieval. Our method leverages a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes image representation, semantic embedding, and hash code generation. Experimental results on popular benchmarks demonstrate that our DSH approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval accuracy, while reducing storage requirements and improving query efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Column Stores using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: With the increasing adoption of distributed column stores, query optimization has become a critical challenge. Traditional optimization techniques rely on heuristics and rule-based approaches, often leading to suboptimal query plans. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RL-Opt', that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans. We design a custom reward function that balances query latency and resource utilization, and demonstrate that RL-Opt significantly outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques on a range of benchmark queries. Our experiments on a distributed column store prototype show that RL-Opt reduces query latency by up to 3x and improves resource utilization by up to 2x.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults Using Embodied Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become increasingly prevalent, but their usability for older adults remains a concern. This paper presents an embodied agent-based approach to designing accessible conversational interfaces for this demographic. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 older adults, exploring their perceptions of embodied agents and their role in facilitating conversational engagement. Our findings highlight the importance of agent embodiment, multimodal feedback, and context-aware dialogue management in promoting accessibility and trust. We propose a set of design guidelines for creating inclusive conversational interfaces and discuss their implications for older adult care and social interaction.

title: Query Optimization for Temporal Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Temporal graph databases have become increasingly popular for modeling complex relationships between entities over time. However, query optimization for such databases remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query execution plans for temporal graph databases. Our method, called TemporalGraphRL, uses a graph neural network to learn a policy for selecting the most efficient query plan based on the graph structure, query patterns, and data distributions. Experimental results on real-world temporal graph datasets demonstrate that TemporalGraphRL outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Autonomous agents operating in complex environments require efficient task allocation strategies to achieve their goals. This paper proposes a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework for distributed task allocation among autonomous agents. Our approach leverages a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to allocate tasks based on local observations and communicates with neighboring agents to achieve global optimality. We evaluate our approach on a simulated warehouse management scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to centralized task allocation methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Online Reviews
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis in online reviews is a crucial task for businesses, but existing techniques struggle to capture the nuances of multimodal data. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that integrates visual and textual features to analyze sentiment in online reviews. Our approach employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant regions of the image and corresponding textual descriptions. Experimental results on a large-scale dataset of online reviews demonstrate that our HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of sentiment classification accuracy and aspect-level sentiment analysis.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Scalable Graph Database Systems
paper_abstract: As graph databases continue to grow in size and complexity, optimizing query performance becomes increasingly critical. This paper presents a novel distributed query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', designed for scalable graph database systems. GraphOpt leverages a hierarchical decomposition of the graph structure to identify and prune redundant subqueries, reducing the communication overhead between nodes. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that adaptively adjusts the query plan based on runtime statistics and node availability. Experimental results on a large-scale graph dataset demonstrate that GraphOpt achieves up to 3x speedup compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: A Scalable and Efficient Query Optimization Framework for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing. However, query optimization remains a significant challenge due to the complexity of data distribution and system heterogeneity. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'OptiDist', which leverages machine learning and graph-based techniques to efficiently optimize queries in DDS. We propose a hierarchical query representation model that captures data distribution and system constraints, and develop a reinforcement learning-based optimizer that adaptively selects the best query plan. Experimental results on a real-world DDS setup demonstrate that OptiDist achieves up to 3x improvement in query performance and 2x reduction in optimization time compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in many applications, but existing methods often lack interpretability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture for explainable time-series forecasting. Our approach leverages self-attention mechanisms to identify relevant patterns at multiple scales, and then combines them using a hierarchical fusion strategy. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN on several benchmark datasets, showcasing improved forecasting accuracy and interpretable feature importance. Ablation studies and visualizations provide insights into the learned attention patterns, enabling better understanding of the underlying time-series dynamics.

title: Efficient Join Order Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Join order optimization is a crucial step in query optimization for distributed database systems. Traditional approaches rely on heuristics and rule-based systems, which can lead to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel approach using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to learn join order optimization. We model the query graph as a neural network and train it on a large dataset of queries. Our experiments demonstrate that the GNN-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of query execution time and plan quality. We also explore the scalability of our approach on large-scale distributed database systems.

title: Robustness Evaluation of Deep Learning Models against Adversarial Attacks using Bayesian Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have demonstrated remarkable performance in various machine learning tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to evaluate the robustness of deep learning models against adversarial attacks using Bayesian neural networks (BNNs). We leverage the probabilistic nature of BNNs to quantify the uncertainty in the model's predictions, enabling the detection of adversarial examples with high accuracy. Our experiments on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in identifying and mitigating the impact of adversarial attacks on model performance.

title: Distributed Decision-Making in Multi-Agent Systems using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, distributed decision-making is a crucial task that requires efficient communication and coordination among agents. This paper proposes a novel approach using hierarchical graph neural networks (HGNNs) to learn distributed decision-making policies. Our method utilizes a hierarchical graph structure to model agent interactions and incorporates attention mechanisms to focus on relevant agents and their relationships. Experimental results on a series of benchmark problems demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of decision-making accuracy and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Inductive Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has garnered significant attention in recent years, but most existing approaches rely on transductive settings or require extensive retraining for new tasks. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) that enables inductive few-shot learning. HGAT leverages task-agnostic graph representations and attention mechanisms to adapt to novel tasks with limited labeled data. Our experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both few-shot and zero-shot settings, while requiring minimal additional training data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Big Data Analytics
paper_abstract: The exponential growth of big data has rendered traditional query optimization techniques ineffective. This paper presents a novel approach to optimize queries for multidimensional big data analytics, focusing on reducing the computational overhead and improving response times. We propose a hierarchical query decomposition framework that leverages statistical correlation analysis and dimensionality reduction to prune unnecessary data access. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate significant performance gains over existing approaches, with an average query execution time reduction of 43.7%.

title: Indexed Query Expansion for Efficient Retrieval in Dynamic Document Collections
paper_abstract: In today's information-intensive world, efficient retrieval of relevant documents from dynamic collections is crucial. This paper proposes a novel indexed query expansion (IQE) approach that leverages the strengths of both keyword-based and semantic-based retrieval methods. IQE constructs a compact index of document semantics and utilizes a probabilistic query expansion strategy to adapt to changing document collections. Experimental results on the TREC dataset demonstrate that IQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency, making it a promising solution for real-world information retrieval applications.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Deep Semantic Search using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Deep semantic search has emerged as a promising approach for retrieving relevant documents in information retrieval systems. However, existing techniques often struggle to effectively expand user queries to capture nuanced semantic relationships. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'GraphExp', which leverages graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to model complex relationships between query terms and their semantic neighbors. Our approach incorporates a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on the most informative nodes in the graph, leading to significant improvements in retrieval performance. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate the efficacy of GraphExp in retrieving relevant documents, outperforming state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Dense Representations for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on efficient passage retrieval to identify relevant documents for answer extraction. This paper presents a novel approach to passage retrieval, Hierarchical Dense Representations (HDR), which learns dense embeddings for passages at multiple granularities. We introduce a hierarchical attention mechanism that selectively aggregates embeddings from sentence-level to document-level, enabling more accurate relevance scoring. Experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDR improves retrieval quality by 12.5% compared to state-of-the-art dense retrieval models, while reducing computational overhead by 30%.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Explainable Reinforcement Learning Policies
paper_abstract: Explainable reinforcement learning (XRL) has gained popularity in recent years, enabling model transparency and accountability in high-stakes decision-making domains. However, the vulnerability of XRL policies to adversarial attacks remains understudied. This paper investigates the susceptibility of popular XRL algorithms to perturbation-based attacks, which can manipulate policy explanations to alter agent behavior. We propose a novel attack framework, 'XRL-Attack', that leverages gradient-based optimization to craft perturbations targeting specific policy features. Experimental results on several Atari games demonstrate that XRL-Attack can significantly degrade policy performance and compromise explanation quality, highlighting the need for robustness measures in XRL.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Reinforcement Learning using Graph Convolutional Networks
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) models have shown promising results in various applications, but they are vulnerable to adversarial attacks. Existing detection methods focus on supervised learning-based approaches, which require labeled data and are computationally expensive. This paper proposes an unsupervised graph-based approach, 'GADRL', to detect adversarial attacks in DRL models. We leverage graph convolutional networks (GCNs) to learn a representation of the state-action graph and identify anomalies indicative of adversarial attacks. Experimental results on a range of DRL environments demonstrate the effectiveness of GADRL in detecting various types of attacks with high accuracy and low false positives.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A User-Centered Approach
paper_abstract: As voice assistants become increasingly prevalent in smart homes, older adults face unique challenges in using these systems. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to develop an accessible voice assistant tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants, aged 65-85, to identify pain points and design preferences. Our findings highlight the importance of intuitive voice commands, personalized feedback, and visual cues to support cognitive impairments. We propose a novel architecture integrating these features and evaluate its usability and accessibility using the W3C's Web Content Accessibility Guidelines.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs, such as speech, text, and vision, has numerous applications in human-computer interaction and affective computing. However, existing models often lack interpretability, making it difficult to understand the decision-making process. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that incorporates attention mechanisms at multiple levels to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate improved emotion recognition accuracy and provide insights into the attention patterns, enabling explainable AI for real-world applications.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems are critical for modern data-intensive applications, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'AdaOpt', which leverages machine learning and statistical models to adapt to changing workloads and data distributions. AdaOpt incorporates a scalable, hierarchical clustering algorithm to identify optimal query plans, and a reinforcement learning module to continuously refine the optimization process. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that AdaOpt achieves up to 3x performance improvement compared to state-of-the-art query optimizers.

title: Optimizing Query Performance in Distributed Databases using Adaptive Workload-Aware Replication
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used in modern data-intensive applications, but their performance is often bottlenecked by inefficient query execution. This paper presents AWAR, an adaptive workload-aware replication strategy that dynamically adjusts data placement and replica selection to minimize query latency. AWAR leverages machine learning-based workload prediction and proactive rebalancing to ensure that hotspots are effectively mitigated. Our experimental evaluation using the TPC-C benchmark demonstrates that AWAR achieves up to 40% improvement in query throughput and 25% reduction in latency compared to state-of-the-art replication schemes.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Cross-Lingual Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Cross-lingual information retrieval (CLIR) is a crucial task in modern search engines, where users query in one language and expect relevant results in another. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep neural networks, which leverages bilingual word embeddings and sentence encoders to generate context-aware expansions. Our experiments on the bilingual English-Spanish CLIR dataset show that our method significantly outperforms traditional translation-based approaches, achieving a 25% improvement in mean average precision. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in handling out-of-vocabulary words and named entities.

title: Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexity of patent documents and the ambiguity of search queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that leverages deep neural networks to improve patent retrieval performance. Our method, called DeepQE, uses a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to learn a dense representation of patent documents and expand search queries with relevant terms. Experiments on a large patent dataset show that DeepQE significantly outperforms traditional query expansion methods, achieving a 25% increase in recall and a 15% increase in precision.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Cooperation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Coordinating the actions of multiple agents in dynamic environments is a challenging problem in artificial intelligence. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture that enables effective cooperation among agents by learning to represent and reason about their interactions. Our approach leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between agents and their environment, and hierarchical representations to capture both local and global dependencies. Experimental results on a suite of multi-agent scenarios demonstrate the superior performance of HGAT compared to existing methods, highlighting its potential for real-world applications such as autonomous vehicles and smart cities.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable RDF Query Processing on Distributed Graph Databases
paper_abstract: The increasing popularity of knowledge graphs has led to a surge in RDF data storage and querying. Existing solutions for scalable RDF query processing often rely on centralized indexing, which becomes a bottleneck in distributed graph databases. This paper presents a novel distributed indexing approach, 'RDFix', that leverages graph partitioning and parallelization to accelerate query execution. RDFix utilizes a hierarchical indexing structure that adaptively adjusts to the query workload, reducing the communication overhead between nodes. Experimental results on real-world RDF datasets demonstrate that RDFix outperforms state-of-the-art indexing techniques by up to 3x in terms of query response time and scalability.

title: Efficient Knowledge Graph Embedding with Hyperbolic Geometry for Question Answering
paper_abstract: Question answering over knowledge graphs (KGs) has become increasingly important in natural language processing. However, existing embedding methods struggle to capture the complex structural relationships in large KGs. This paper proposes a novel hyperbolic geometry-based embedding approach, HyperQA, which leverages the ability of hyperbolic spaces to model hierarchical structures. We demonstrate that HyperQA outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both link prediction and question answering tasks on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, our approach is more computationally efficient and scalable to large KGs.

title: Deep Generative Models for Tabular Data Imputation with Hierarchical Dependencies
paper_abstract: Missing data is a pervasive problem in many real-world datasets, particularly in tabular data. Existing imputation methods often fail to capture complex hierarchical dependencies between variables. This paper presents a novel deep generative model, 'HiGen', which learns to impute missing values in tabular data by modeling hierarchical relationships between variables. HiGen employs a multi-level variational autoencoder to capture both local and global dependencies, and is trained using a novel objective function that balances reconstruction and regularization terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiGen outperforms state-of-the-art imputation methods, particularly in settings with complex hierarchical structures.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Personalized Avatars in Virtual Reality-Based Stroke Rehabilitation
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in stroke rehabilitation, but the impact of personalized avatars on user engagement and motor skill recovery is not well understood. This study explores the effectiveness of customizable, anthropomorphic avatars in a VR-based stroke rehabilitation system. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, randomly assigning them to either a personalized avatar or a generic avatar condition. Results show that participants in the personalized avatar group demonstrated significant improvements in arm mobility and cognitive function compared to the generic avatar group. Additionally, users with personalized avatars reported higher levels of motivation and enjoyment during the rehabilitation process.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing environments, but they pose significant query optimization challenges. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach to efficiently optimize queries in multi-tenant settings. We model the database schema as a graph and leverage graph convolutional networks to predict the optimal query plan. Our approach reduces the query optimization time by up to 50% compared to traditional cost-based optimization methods, while maintaining comparable query performance. We evaluate our approach on a real-world dataset and demonstrate its effectiveness in improving the overall system throughput.

title: Efficient Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicles using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely on efficient decision-making to navigate complex scenarios. This paper presents a novel reinforcement learning approach, 'GNRL', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a compact representation of the environment. By incorporating graph-based state abstraction, GNRL reduces the action space and accelerates policy learning. We demonstrate the effectiveness of GNRL on a suite of simulated driving tasks, showcasing improved performance and reduced training time compared to traditional reinforcement learning methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot Task Planning in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: Robot task planning in uncertain environments is a challenging problem due to the complexity of handling multiple tasks and uncertain outcomes. This paper presents a hierarchical reinforcement learning framework, 'HRL-Uncertainty', which integrates task planning and motion planning to achieve efficient and adaptive robot behavior. Our approach utilizes a high-level task planner to generate task sequences and a low-level motion planner to execute the tasks, while incorporating uncertainty estimation and risk-aware decision-making. Experimental results on a robotic arm platform demonstrate that HRL-Uncertainty outperforms existing methods in terms of task completion time and success rate in uncertain environments.

title: Scalable and Adaptive Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data Streams
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and sensors has led to an exponential growth in time-series data streams. However, existing indexing techniques struggle to handle the high velocity and volume of such data. This paper presents 'TSI-Adapt', a novel indexing framework that dynamically adapts to changing data distributions and velocity. TSI-Adapt leverages a hierarchical indexing structure and a feedback-based optimization mechanism to ensure efficient query processing and minimal memory overhead. We evaluate TSI-Adapt on real-world datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art indexing techniques in terms of query performance and adaptability.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Short-Text Search using Word Embeddings and Graph-Based Methods
paper_abstract: Short-text search queries often lack sufficient context, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach that combines word embeddings with graph-based methods to capture nuanced semantic relationships. We introduce a graph-based framework that leverages word co-occurrence patterns to identify relevant expansion terms, which are then re-weighted using contextualized embeddings. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in precision and recall.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, but existing methods often rely on superficial term co-occurrences, neglecting deeper semantic relationships. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'SemExpan', which leverages deep semantic embeddings to capture nuanced associations between query terms and relevant documents. By integrating a graph-based neural network with traditional retrieval models, SemExpan significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, especially for short and ambiguous queries. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of SemExpan over state-of-the-art expansion techniques.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Hierarchical Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging task in machine learning, requiring models to generalize from scarce data. This paper presents a novel meta-learning approach that leverages hierarchical attention networks (HANs) to adapt to new classes with limited examples. Our method, dubbed 'MetaHAN', employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant features and filter out noise. We evaluate MetaHAN on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating its ability to outperform state-of-the-art few-shot classification methods, especially when dealing with low-data regimes.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Urban traffic management is a complex problem that requires coordinating multiple autonomous agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to train agents to cooperate and make decisions in real-time. We introduce a multi-agent deep Q-network (MA-DQN) that learns to optimize traffic signal control, lane usage, and routing for multiple agents. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate significant reductions in travel time, congestion, and emissions compared to traditional traffic management systems.

title: Co-Designing Voice Assistants with People with Disabilities: An Exploration of Multimodal Input Strategies
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in smart homes, but their accessibility for people with disabilities remains limited. This paper presents a co-design approach to develop inclusive voice assistants, focusing on multimodal input strategies. We conducted a series of workshops with individuals with disabilities, identifying pain points and opportunities for improvement. Our findings inform the design of an adaptable voice assistant that incorporates gestures, eye-tracking, and lip-reading input modalities. A usability study with 20 participants demonstrates significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction. Our work contributes to the development of more accessible and inclusive voice assistants, enhancing the quality of life for people with disabilities.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks, but their scalability is limited by the computation and memory requirements of attention mechanisms. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) that leverages a hierarchical representation of the graph to reduce the attention complexity. HGAN incorporates a node clustering step to group similar nodes, followed by a hierarchical attention mechanism that learns to focus on relevant clusters and nodes. Experimental results on large-scale graph datasets demonstrate that HGAN achieves comparable accuracy to state-of-the-art GNNs while reducing the computational cost by up to 75%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention for Scalable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as text, audio, and vision, is a challenging task due to the complexity of modeling relationships between modalities. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention framework, 'HGA-EMO', which leverages graph neural networks to capture both local and global dependencies across modalities. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HGA-EMO outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal data, with improved scalability and interpretability.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Adaptive Sampling
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular in recent years, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Existing optimization techniques often rely on simplistic cost models or exhaustive enumeration, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper presents a novel adaptive sampling approach, 'AdaSample', which leverages machine learning to estimate query costs and dynamically adjusts sampling rates to minimize optimization overhead. Our experiments on a real-world distributed database benchmark demonstrate that AdaSample outperforms state-of-the-art optimization techniques, achieving up to 30% improvement in query response time and 25% reduction in optimization overhead.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases using Heuristics
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, optimizing query performance in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper presents a novel query optimization approach that leverages heuristics to reduce the search space of possible query plans. Our method, called HEO, integrates a cost-based optimizer with a set of graph-specific heuristics that capture the structural properties of the data. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset demonstrate that HEO outperforms existing query optimization techniques, achieving an average speedup of 3.2x in query execution time.

title: Hierarchical Temporal Convolutional Networks for Efficient Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Multivariate time series forecasting is crucial in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and energy management. However, existing methods often suffer from high computational complexity and poor scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical temporal convolutional network (HTCN) architecture that leverages both local and global temporal dependencies in multivariate time series data. Our approach reduces the computational cost by 30% compared to state-of-the-art methods while achieving competitive forecasting accuracy on several benchmark datasets.

title: Context-Aware Query Expansion for Neural Search Engines
paper_abstract: Neural search engines have shown promise in capturing semantic relationships between queries and documents. However, they often struggle with ambiguous or underspecified queries. This paper presents a context-aware query expansion framework that leverages both local and global contextual cues to disambiguate user queries. Our approach combines a graph-based query representation with a neural ranking model, allowing it to adapt to diverse search scenarios. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, especially for complex, open-domain queries.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction with Public Displays Using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Public displays are becoming increasingly prevalent in urban spaces, but interacting with them remains a challenge. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interface for public displays using deep neural networks. We propose a convolutional neural network (CNN) that detects and tracks users' gazes in real-time, enabling intuitive and hands-free interaction. Our approach leverages a combination of computer vision and machine learning techniques to overcome the limitations of traditional gaze-tracking systems. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of our method, achieving an average accuracy of 92.5% in gaze-based selection tasks.

title: PROXIMAL: A Proximity-Aware Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval
paper_abstract: State-of-the-art neural ranking models for document retrieval often rely on complex, compute-intensive architectures that struggle to scale to large document collections. This paper proposes PROXIMAL, a novel ranking model that leverages proximity-aware features to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. By incorporating proximity signals into a simple, yet effective, neural architecture, PROXIMAL achieves significant improvements in retrieval efficiency while maintaining comparable accuracy to more complex models. Extensive experiments on several TREC datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of PROXIMAL in real-world retrieval scenarios.

title: Semantic Query Expansion via Hierarchical Embeddings for Improved Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion techniques play a crucial role in enhancing the performance of information retrieval systems. However, existing methods often rely on simplistic term-weighting schemes, neglecting the nuanced relationships between query terms. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'HIER', which leverages hierarchical embeddings to capture semantic dependencies between query terms. By representing queries as dense, hierarchical vectors, HIER enables more effective expansion of query terms, leading to improved retrieval accuracy. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of HIER over state-of-the-art query expansion methods.

title: Deep Hierarchical Fusion for Multimodal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition in conversational agents is a challenging task due to the complexity of human emotions and the variability of multimodal cues. This paper introduces a novel deep hierarchical fusion framework, 'MultiEmo', which leverages the strengths of vision, speech, and language modalities to recognize emotions in conversations. Our approach uses a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant modalities and fuse their representations at multiple levels. Experimental results on the IEMOCAP dataset demonstrate that MultiEmo outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multimodal inputs, achieving a significant improvement in F1-score and correlation coefficient.

title: Efficient Join Ordering for Distributed Query Optimization in Cloud-Based Data Warehouses
paper_abstract: Cloud-based data warehouses have become increasingly popular for storing and processing large datasets. However, optimizing query execution plans in these systems remains a challenging task. This paper addresses the problem of efficient join ordering for distributed query optimization in cloud-based data warehouses. We propose a novel approach, 'Distributed Join Optimizer' (DJO), which leverages a combination of statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to identify the most efficient join ordering. DJO is designed to adapt to dynamic changes in data distributions and query workloads, thereby improving query performance and reducing resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DJO outperforms existing optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Gaze-Based Error Detection in Multimodal Human-Computer Interaction
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to error detection in multimodal human-computer interaction using gaze-based metrics. We develop a machine learning model that leverages eye-tracking data to identify instances of user frustration and confusion, enabling proactive system interventions to prevent errors. Our approach is evaluated on a dataset of users performing a range of tasks on a multimodal interface, demonstrating a significant reduction in error rates and user frustration compared to traditional interaction methods. The proposed method has implications for the design of more intuitive and user-friendly interfaces in various domains.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, aiming to bridge the vocabulary gap between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel context-aware embedding-based approach, dubbed CAQE, which leverages semantic relationships between query terms and their co-occurring context words. Our method adapts a transformer-based architecture to learn dense vector representations that capture nuanced query-term dependencies. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that CAQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Decentralized Coordination of Autonomous Agents using Blockchain-based Incentive Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, coordinating autonomous agents to achieve a common goal is a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel blockchain-based approach to incentivize agents to cooperate and make decisions that benefit the overall system. We design a decentralized coordination mechanism that leverages smart contracts to facilitate the exchange of rewards and penalties between agents. Our approach ensures that agents are motivated to behave honestly and contribute to the system's overall utility. Experimental results demonstrate that our mechanism outperforms traditional centralized coordination methods in terms of efficiency and fairness.

title: Distributed Query Optimization for Heterogeneous Database Systems
paper_abstract: With the increasing prevalence of big data and cloud computing, heterogeneous database systems have become a norm. However, query optimization in such systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel distributed query optimization framework, 'HeteroOpt', which leverages machine learning and graph-based models to optimize query plans across disparate database systems. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HeteroOpt through extensive experiments on a real-world dataset, showcasing improvements in query response time and resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Robust Feature Learning via Adaptive Margin-Based Contrastive Loss for Image Classification
paper_abstract: Contrastive learning has emerged as a powerful approach for self-supervised representation learning.
