However, existing methods often struggle with noisy or ambiguous data, leading to suboptimal feature learning. This paper proposes a novel adaptive margin-based contrastive loss function, 'AdaMargin', which dynamically adjusts the margin based on the similarity distribution of positive and negative samples. We demonstrate that AdaMargin improves the robustness of feature learning to noisy data and outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark image classification datasets, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Graph Databases Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying large-scale graph data. However, query optimization in these systems remains a challenging task due to the complexity of graph queries and the need to balance query performance with data distribution and communication costs. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning. Our method, GraphRL, learns to optimize query plans by interacting with the database and receiving rewards based on query execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world social network dataset demonstrate that GraphRL outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and reduces resource utilization by up to 40%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification with Limited Labels
paper_abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have shown great potential in node classification tasks. However, in many real-world scenarios, labeled data is scarce and expensive to obtain. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages both local and global graph structures to improve node classification performance with limited labels. HGAT employs a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant nodes and layers to aggregate features. Our experiments on four benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art GNNs and attention-based models in low-label settings, with significant improvements in accuracy and F1-score.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Time-Series Forecasting Models using Attention-based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: As AI-driven time-series forecasting models become increasingly prevalent, it is essential to develop techniques that provide insights into their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel attention-based explainability framework, 'AttExplainer', which generates interpretable explanations for complex forecasting models. AttExplainer leverages self-attention mechanisms to identify key input features and their relationships, enabling the identification of influential factors driving forecasting errors. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that AttExplainer outperforms existing explainability methods in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency, paving the way for more trustworthy AI-driven forecasting applications.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion using Reinforcement Learning for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to accurately capture user intent, leading to suboptimal query formulations. We propose a hierarchical query expansion framework, RLEXPAND, that leverages reinforcement learning to optimize query refinement. RLEXPAND models the query expansion process as a Markov decision process, learning to iteratively refine queries by selecting relevant terms and phrases from a hierarchical representation of the document collection. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for challenging, ambiguity-prone queries.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning: A Hierarchical Attention Framework
paper_abstract: Explainability is crucial for real-world adoption of reinforcement learning (RL) agents. Existing methods often focus on post-hoc explanation or rely on simplified, linear models. We propose a novel hierarchical attention framework, HAT, which integrates explainability into the RL process. HAT uses a hierarchical policy network with attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant state features, providing insights into the decision-making process. Our experiments on Atari games and a real-world robotics task demonstrate that HAT achieves competitive performance while providing meaningful explanations of the agent's policy.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval (IR) that aims to enrich the original query to improve retrieval performance. Traditional approaches rely on term co-occurrence and statistical methods, which may not capture complex semantic relationships. This paper proposes a deep neural network-based approach, dubbed 'NeuroQE', that learns to generate effective expanded queries from large-scale IR datasets. NeuroQE leverages a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively incorporate relevant terms from the document collection, outperforming state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets.

title: Accelerating Query Optimization with Deep Reinforcement Learning in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component in distributed databases, as it directly affects the performance and scalability of the system. Traditional query optimization methods rely on rule-based or cost-based approaches, which may not adapt well to complex and dynamic database environments. This paper explores the application of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to query optimization in distributed databases. We propose a novel DRL framework, 'QOptRL', which learns to optimize queries by interacting with the database environment and receiving feedback in the form of execution time and resource utilization. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database show that QOptRL outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time and 25% in terms of resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Graph-based Coalition Formation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel decentralized task allocation framework for autonomous agents, enabling them to dynamically form coalitions and allocate tasks in complex, dynamic environments. We leverage graph theory to model agent relationships and propose a distributed algorithm, 'GraphCoalition', which enables agents to negotiate and form coalitions based on their capabilities and task requirements. Experimental results demonstrate that GraphCoalition outperforms traditional centralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and agent utility, while maintaining scalability and robustness in the presence of agent failures.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Distributed Constraint Optimization
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require coordinated task allocation to achieve efficient and effective collaboration. This paper proposes a novel distributed constraint optimization approach, referred to as D-COORD, to tackle this problem. D-COORD leverages a combination of local search and message-passing algorithms to find near-optimal task assignments that satisfy constraints and minimize conflicts. Experiments on a simulated logistics domain demonstrate that D-COORD outperforms existing centralized and decentralized approaches in terms of solution quality, communication overhead, and scalability. Our approach enables the development of more efficient and flexible multi-agent systems in real-world applications.

title: Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval using Word Embeddings
paper_abstract: Traditional query expansion methods for document retrieval rely on term co-occurrence statistics, which can be limited by the quality of the underlying document collection. We propose a novel approach that leverages pre-trained word embeddings to capture semantic relationships between terms. Our method, called EmbedEx, uses a combination of term similarity and document frequency to select expansion terms that are both semantically relevant and discriminative. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that EmbedEx outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed databases have become increasingly popular in modern data-intensive applications, but optimizing queries across multiple nodes remains a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to navigate the vast space of possible query plans and identifies near-optimal solutions. Our approach leverages a domain-specific reward function that balances query latency, resource utilization, and data freshness. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database system demonstrate that our RL-based optimizer outperforms traditional rule-based approaches by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Investigating the Impact of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Industrial Settings
paper_abstract: As robots become increasingly prevalent in industrial environments, effective human-robot collaboration is crucial for productivity and safety. This study explores the role of embodiment in shaping human trust and behavior in human-robot teams. We conducted a series of experiments using a robotic arm and a virtual reality platform, manipulating the level of embodiment and task complexity. Our results show that increased embodiment leads to higher trust and more efficient collaboration, but only in simple tasks. In complex tasks, the benefits of embodiment are diminished. We discuss the implications of these findings for the design of human-robot collaboration systems and future research directions.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Distributed databases are increasingly used to store large amounts of multi-dimensional data. However, efficient indexing techniques for range queries in such systems remain a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel indexing approach, 'DIMRI', which leverages a combination of hierarchical clustering and compact bit-vector representations to accelerate range query processing. We demonstrate the efficacy of DIMRI through a comprehensive experimental evaluation on real-world datasets, showcasing significant performance improvements over existing state-of-the-art indexing techniques.

title: Real-time Object Detection with Efficient Attention Mechanism for Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Accurate and efficient object detection is crucial for autonomous vehicles to navigate safely. This paper proposes a novel real-time object detection framework, 'RTD-Attention', which leverages an efficient attention mechanism to reduce computational complexity. RTD-Attention uses a lightweight attention module to selectively focus on relevant regions of the input image, thereby improving detection accuracy and reducing inference time. We evaluate RTD-Attention on the KITTI dataset and demonstrate a 25% reduction in inference time while maintaining state-of-the-art detection accuracy.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: As the scale of distributed document collections grows, query processing efficiency becomes a critical concern. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-Dist', which leverages the structural properties of distributed index organizations to reduce the number of query iterations. HQE-Dist adaptively selects a subset of promising terms from the initial query results, expands the query using a hierarchical clustering scheme, and prunes irrelevant documents using a probabilistic relevance model. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed IR benchmark demonstrate that HQE-Dist achieves a 30% reduction in query latency and a 25% improvement in retrieval precision compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Robot-Assisted Warehouse Navigation
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical reinforcement learning approach to optimize robot navigation in warehouse environments. Our method, called HierRL, combines a high-level task planner with a low-level motion controller to efficiently navigate robots through densely packed shelves. We demonstrate that HierRL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of navigation time and success rate, while also adapting to changes in warehouse layouts and inventory. Experimental results using a simulated warehouse environment show that HierRL reduces navigation time by up to 30% compared to flat reinforcement learning methods.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Graph Neural Networks with Hierarchical Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various graph-based tasks, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework to improve the robustness of GNNs against adversarial attacks. Our approach leverages contrastive learning to learn hierarchical representations of graph structures, which enables the detection of adversarial patterns. We further develop a white-box attack algorithm to evaluate the robustness of our proposed framework. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms existing defense methods in terms of both accuracy and robustness.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Autonomous Agents using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to distributed task allocation for autonomous agents using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our method, called 'META', enables agents to learn decentralized policies that optimize task assignment in dynamic environments. We formulate the problem as a decentralized partially observable Markov decision process (Dec-POMDP) and employ a variant of deep Q-networks to learn effective allocation strategies. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that META outperforms traditional methods in terms of task completion efficiency and adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Robotics
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in robotics, but the lack of transparency in decision-making processes hinders its adoption in safety-critical applications. This paper proposes a novel model-agnostic explanation framework, 'RL-Explain', which generates interpretable explanations for DRL policies in robotics. We introduce a gradient-based attribution method that identifies the most relevant state features and action components contributing to the agent's decisions. Our experiments on robotic grasping and manipulation tasks demonstrate that RL-Explain provides accurate and informative explanations, improving the trustworthiness and accountability of DRL systems.

title: Gaze-Based Intention Detection for Proactive Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants have become ubiquitous, but their reactive nature often leads to frustration and inefficiency. This paper presents a novel approach to proactive virtual assistance by detecting users' intentions through gaze patterns. We develop a machine learning model that leverages eye-tracking data to predict user goals and desires, allowing the virtual assistant to take preemptive actions. Our user study reveals that our gaze-based intention detection system achieves an accuracy of 87.3% and improves overall user satisfaction by 35.2%. The system's applicability is demonstrated in a smart home scenario, where it enables more efficient and personalized automation.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Decentralized Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems (MAS) often face challenges in coordinating actions to achieve common goals, particularly in resource-constrained environments. This paper presents a decentralized reinforcement learning (DRL) framework for coordinating MAS in resource allocation tasks. Our approach, called 'DRL-MA', enables agents to learn cooperative policies through localized interactions and asynchronous updates. We evaluate DRL-MA in a simulated grid-world environment and demonstrate its ability to adapt to changing resource availability and agent behaviors, outperforming traditional centralized and heuristic-based approaches.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation with Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: In IoT networks, task allocation is a crucial problem that requires efficient assignment of tasks to agents with varying capabilities. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework using multi-agent reinforcement learning, where agents learn to allocate tasks based on their local observations and rewards. We introduce a novel algorithm, 'Distributed Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning' (DTARL), which leverages the concept of graph convolutional networks to model agent interactions and optimize task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that DTARL outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Agent Coordination Using Blockchain-based Reputation Systems
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, coordination and trust remain significant challenges. This paper proposes a blockchain-based reputation system, 'RepuChain', which enables agents to evaluate and reward reliable behavior in their peers. RepuChain leverages smart contracts to maintain a tamper-proof reputation ledger, ensuring that agents are incentivized to act cooperatively. We demonstrate the effectiveness of RepuChain in a simulated supply chain management scenario, showing improved collaboration and reduced malicious behavior compared to traditional reputation systems. Our approach has implications for decentralized autonomy in various domains, including IoT and edge computing.

title: Efficient Exploration of Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning with Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) has shown promise in solving complex tasks, but exploring large state spaces remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'Graph-HRL', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to efficiently explore hierarchical representations of state spaces. By learning to encode subgoals as graph nodes, our method enables the agent to reason about abstract states and focus exploration on promising regions. Experimental results on a range of benchmark tasks demonstrate that Graph-HRL outperforms state-of-the-art HRL methods in terms of exploration efficiency and overall performance.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper introduces Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks (HGAT) for explainable multi-agent reinforcement learning. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex agent interactions and hierarchical relationships in multi-agent systems. We propose a novel attention-based credit assignment algorithm that enables agents to learn from each other's experiences and provide interpretable explanations for their decision-making processes. Experimental results on a range of multi-agent domains demonstrate the effectiveness of HGAT in improving collaboration and coordination among agents while providing transparent and actionable insights into their behavior.

title: Deep Relevance Matching for Ad-hoc Retrieval with Multi-Modal Query Embeddings
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively handle complex, multi-modal queries. This paper proposes a novel deep relevance matching framework, 'MultiMatch', which leverages query embeddings to jointly model textual, visual, and semantic features. Our approach extends the transformer architecture to incorporate multi-modal attention mechanisms, enabling the capture of nuanced relationships between query elements. Experimental results on the TREC-VID dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance, particularly for queries with multiple media types. We also show that our method generalizes well to unseen query types, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in zero-shot retrieval scenarios.

title: Designing Adaptive Feedback Mechanisms for Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, but its adoption is hindered by the lack of accessible and usable interfaces for diverse user populations. This paper presents a novel framework for designing adaptive feedback mechanisms in VR systems, focusing on users with disabilities. Our approach leverages machine learning-based user modeling and real-time adaptation to provide personalized feedback, ensuring an inclusive and engaging VR experience. We evaluate our framework through a user study with participants with visual impairments, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Gaze-Based Interface for Enhancing Cognitive Load Management in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize education and training, but high cognitive loads can lead to user fatigue and decreased performance. This paper presents 'GazeCue', a novel gaze-based interface that detects and adapts to users' cognitive load in real-time. By leveraging machine learning models and eye-tracking technology, GazeCue provides personalized feedback and guidance to reduce cognitive overload, improving overall user experience and task performance. Our user study demonstrates significant reductions in cognitive load and error rates, highlighting the potential of GazeCue to enhance VR-based learning and training applications.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Cooperation for Distributed Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: Distributed resource allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where agents must cooperate to achieve a common goal. This paper proposes a novel decentralized algorithm, 'MACRO', which enables scalable cooperation among agents with heterogeneous resources and objectives. MACRO utilizes a hierarchical clustering approach to group agents with similar resource profiles, followed by a distributed optimization procedure to allocate resources. Experimental results on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that MACRO achieves near-optimal allocation efficiency while reducing communication overhead by up to 70% compared to existing methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Neural Ranking Models using Pseudo-Relevance Feedback
paper_abstract: Neural ranking models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in information retrieval tasks, but they often suffer from limited query representation and shallow relevance feedback. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'PRF-NE', which leverages pseudo-relevance feedback to generate high-quality expansion terms. We introduce a neural pseudo-relevance feedback module that iteratively refines the query representation by incorporating relevance signals from top-ranked documents. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset demonstrate that PRF-NE outperforms existing query expansion methods, achieving a 15% improvement in NDCG@10.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Decentralized task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem due to the lack of centralized control and limited communication between agents. This paper proposes a graph reinforcement learning framework that enables agents to learn to allocate tasks in a decentralized manner. We model the task allocation problem as a graph, where agents and tasks are represented as nodes, and edges represent the availability of agents for tasks. Our approach uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture, where each agent learns to optimize a local objective function that takes into account the global system's performance. Experiments on a variety of task allocation scenarios demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional decentralized task allocation methods in terms of system efficiency and fairness.

title: Self-Optimizing Index Structures for Multi-Core Database Systems
paper_abstract: Modern multi-core database systems often struggle with suboptimal index structures, leading to poor query performance. This paper proposes a novel self-optimizing index framework, 'AutoIndex', which adaptively reconfigures index structures based on runtime query patterns and system resource utilization. Our approach leverages machine learning-based prediction models to forecast query workloads and optimize index layouts for improved query efficiency. Experimental results on a real-world database benchmark demonstrate that AutoIndex achieves up to 3x query performance improvement compared to traditional static indexing techniques.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning approach for real-time traffic signal control in large-scale urban networks. Our method, dubbed 'MARLIN', leverages a hierarchical architecture to coordinate the actions of multiple agents, each responsible for controlling a single intersection. We propose a novel communication mechanism that enables agents to share local observations and adapt to dynamic traffic patterns. Experimental results on a realistic traffic simulator demonstrate that MARLIN outperforms traditional signals timing plans, reducing average travel times by 23% and increasing network throughput by 17%.

title: Hierarchical Few-Shot Learning with Meta-Learned Adaptive Distance Metrics
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle with adapting to novel classes and distances. This paper proposes a hierarchical few-shot learning framework, 'HiFSL', which leverages meta-learning to adaptively learn distance metrics at multiple levels of abstraction. By learning to weigh and combine different distance metrics, HiFSL outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets, including mini-ImageNet and tiered-ImageNet. We provide theoretical analysis and empirical evidence to demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in handling unseen classes and increasing robustness to noisy data.

title: Efficient Few-Shot Learning with Adaptive Margin-Based Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing meta-learning methods often struggle with limited training data. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'AdaptiveMargin', which adaptively adjusts the margin of the classifier based on the complexity of the task. We introduce a meta-learning objective that incorporates a margin-based regularization term, allowing the model to learn more effective task representations. Experimental results on benchmark few-shot datasets demonstrate that AdaptiveMargin outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving improved accuracy and robustness in low-data regimes.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Semantic Search using Knowledge Graph Embeddings
paper_abstract: Semantic search has become increasingly important in modern information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel query expansion method that leverages knowledge graph embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between entities. Our approach, called KGQE, uses a graph attention mechanism to select the most relevant entities and expand the query with contextual keywords. We evaluate KGQE on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance compared to traditional query expansion methods. Furthermore, we show that KGQE can be efficiently integrated into existing search systems without requiring significant computational overhead.

title: Efficient Indexing for Proximity Search in High-Dimensional Spaces
paper_abstract: Proximity search is a fundamental operation in many information retrieval applications, but its performance degrades significantly in high-dimensional spaces. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'HD-Prox', which leverages a combination of hierarchical clustering and compact binary codes to efficiently search for nearest neighbors. Our approach reduces the number of distance computations by up to 90% compared to state-of-the-art methods, while maintaining a high recall rate. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the efficacy of HD-Prox in various IR applications, including image and text retrieval.

title: Efficient Gradient-Based Optimization for Deep Neural Networks using Stochastic Weight Averaging
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have become increasingly prevalent in various machine learning applications. However, their training process is often computationally expensive and time-consuming. This paper proposes a novel optimization method, 'Stochastic Weight Averaging with Momentum' (SWAM), which leverages stochastic weight averaging and momentum-based gradient descent to accelerate the training process. We theoretically analyze the convergence properties of SWAM and demonstrate its empirical effectiveness on several benchmark datasets. Experimental results show that SWAM achieves faster convergence rates and improved generalization performance compared to state-of-the-art optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize task assignments among agents. Our approach, called HTRL, learns to allocate tasks based on agent capabilities, task dependencies, and environmental constraints. We evaluate HTRL in a simulated warehouse management scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional decentralized methods. The proposed framework can be applied to various real-world domains, such as search and rescue, disaster response, and autonomous transportation systems.

title: Rethinking Query Optimization: A Graph-Based Approach for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly prevalent, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a novel graph-based approach, dubbed 'DistributedQuery', which reformulates the query optimization problem as a graph partitioning task. By modeling the database as a graph and queries as subgraphs, we develop an efficient algorithm that minimizes communication overhead and reduces query latency. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DistributedQuery outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of execution time.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Improving Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it helps to overcome the vocabulary mismatch between users' queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel neural embedding-based approach for query expansion, which leverages the semantic relationships between words to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method uses a graph convolutional network to learn dense vector representations of words, which are then used to compute the similarity between the original query terms and candidate expansion terms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving significant improvements in retrieval performance.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Systems for Autonomous Resource Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: We present a novel decentralized multi-agent system (MAS) framework for autonomous resource allocation in smart grids. The proposed approach leverages a hybrid of reinforcement learning and auctions to enable self-organizing agents to negotiate and allocate resources in real-time. Our simulation results demonstrate improved efficiency, scalability, and adaptability compared to traditional centralized approaches. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the system's convergence properties and explore the impact of agent heterogeneity on overall system performance.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalization for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interfaces often neglect the needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create personalized voice assistants that cater to users with visual, auditory, motor, and cognitive impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 30 participants with diverse disabilities, resulting in a set of design principles and guidelines for inclusive voice interaction. Our findings highlight the importance of adaptable dialogue management, multimodal feedback, and customizable accessibility features. We demonstrate the feasibility of our approach through a prototype voice assistant, which significantly improves user satisfaction and task completion rates for users with disabilities.

title: Efficient Graph Neural Networks for NodeAttribution in Explainable AI
paper_abstract: Explainable AI (XAI) is crucial for trustworthy AI decision-making. Node attribution in graph-structured data is a key challenge in XAI. This paper presents a novel graph neural network (GNN) architecture, 'AttributionNet', which efficiently computes node attributions for explainable graph classification. We propose a sparse attention mechanism that adaptively selects relevant nodes for attribution, reducing computational complexity. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that AttributionNet outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both attribution accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Resource Allocation in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: In distributed systems, efficient resource allocation is crucial for optimal performance. This paper introduces a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'MARLA', which enables autonomous agents to adaptively allocate resources in response to changing system demands. MARLA leverages a decentralized Markov decision process to model the complex interactions between agents and their environment. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MARLA in a simulated cloud computing environment, showing significant improvements in resource utilization and system throughput compared to traditional static allocation methods.

title: Neural Retrieval Models for Cold-Start Problem in Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Cold-start problem, where there is limited user-item interaction data, is a fundamental challenge in recommendation systems. This paper proposes a novel neural retrieval model, 'NR-Cold', which leverages the strengths of both collaborative filtering and content-based filtering. NR-Cold uses a dual-encoder architecture to learn vector representations of users and items, and then employs a neural retrieval mechanism to generate personalized recommendations for cold-start users. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that NR-Cold outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving significant improvements in recommendation accuracy and diversity.

title: Decentralized Agent-Based Resource Allocation for Autonomous IoT Networks
paper_abstract: The increasing complexity of IoT networks necessitates efficient resource allocation strategies. This paper presents a decentralized agent-based approach, where autonomous agents are deployed on IoT devices to negotiate and allocate resources in a peer-to-peer manner. We propose a novel auction-based mechanism that incorporates device-centric utility functions and real-time resource pricing, enabling adaptability to dynamic network conditions. Experimental results on a large-scale IoT testbed demonstrate improved resource utilization and reduced latency compared to traditional centralized approaches.

title: Scalable Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data processing tasks. However, optimizing query execution plans in such systems remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize query plans in distributed database systems. Our approach, called 'RL-Optimizer', uses a deep Q-network to learn the optimal query plan based on the system's current state and workload. We evaluate RL-Optimizer on a real-world dataset and demonstrate significant improvements in query execution time and system throughput compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Label Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label classification is a fundamental problem in many applications, but existing methods often struggle with scalability and accuracy. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages the power of graph neural networks and attention mechanisms to efficiently handle large-scale multi-label data. HGAT learns to represent each label as a graph node and applies hierarchical attention to capture complex label relationships. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both accuracy and computational efficiency, making it a promising solution for real-world applications.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks and Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating multi-agent systems using hierarchical task networks (HTNs) and deep reinforcement learning (DRL). We introduce a hierarchical framework that decomposes complex tasks into smaller sub-tasks, enabling agents to reason about their actions at multiple levels of abstraction. Our DRL algorithm, 'HTN-Q', learns to select optimal sub-tasks and allocate resources efficiently, while adapting to dynamic environments. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving task completion rates and reducing communication overhead.

title: Optimizing Join Order in Distributed Query Processing using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed query processing is a crucial component of modern data analytics, but optimizing join order remains a challenging problem. This paper explores the application of reinforcement learning (RL) to dynamically determine the optimal join order in distributed query processing. We propose a novel RL-based approach, 'Distributed Join Optimizer' (DJO), which learns to adapt to changing data distributions and query patterns. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that DJO outperforms traditional join order optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time, while achieving comparable accuracy.

title: Coordinated Multi-Agent Planning with Incomplete Information using Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: In real-world multi-agent systems, agents often have incomplete information about their environment and other agents' intentions. This paper proposes a novel approach to coordinated multi-agent planning that leverages graph attention networks to model agent relationships and infer missing information. Our method, called GAPLan, integrates a graph neural network with a planning framework to generate high-quality plans that account for uncertainty. We evaluate GAPLan in a complex rescue scenario and demonstrate improved planning performance compared to existing methods that rely on complete information.

title: Latent Semantic Analysis for Enhanced Query Expansion in Search Engines
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) techniques are crucial for improving the effectiveness of search engines. This paper proposes a novel latent semantic analysis (LSA) approach for QE, which leverages the semantic relationships between terms in a query to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method, called LSA-QE, incorporates a deep neural network to learn the latent semantic representations of terms and queries. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that LSA-QE outperforms state-of-the-art QE methods, leading to significant improvements in search engine performance. We also demonstrate the robustness of LSA-QE against query ambiguity and polysemy.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Dialogue Systems
paper_abstract: Dialogue systems have made significant progress in generating coherent and informative responses. However, the lack of transparency and interpretability in these systems hinders their widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that incorporates explicit attention mechanisms to facilitate explainable dialogue generation. Our approach integrates a utterance-level attention module to model the conversation context and a token-level attention module to focus on salient input tokens. Experimental results on the DSTC7 benchmark dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models in both response generation and explainability metrics.

title: Designing Embodied Avatars for Enhanced Social Presence in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: This paper presents a study on the design of embodied avatars in virtual reality (VR) to enhance social presence and user engagement. We investigate the effects of avatar customizability, gesture recognition, and facial expression mirroring on users' sense of embodiment and social connection. Our results show that avatars with dynamic facial expressions and gestures lead to higher levels of social presence and user satisfaction compared to static avatars. We also find that customizability features, such as skin tone and clothing options, increase users' sense of ownership and agency. The findings have implications for the design of social VR experiences, virtual events, and remote collaboration platforms.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Conversational Strategies for Users with Disabilities
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their conversational interfaces often exclude users with disabilities. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create more inclusive voice assistants. We conducted a mixed-methods study with 30 participants with visual, hearing, motor, or cognitive disabilities to identify challenges and opportunities in conversational interactions. Our findings inform the development of adaptive conversational strategies, such as personalized feedback, explicit error handling, and multimodal input support. We evaluate these strategies through a prototype voice assistant and demonstrate significant improvements in user experience and task completion rates.

title: Exploring Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality for Enhancing Spatial Awareness
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize the way we learn and interact with spatial information. However, the cognitive processes underlying spatial awareness in VR remain poorly understood. This paper presents an embodied cognition framework for enhancing spatial awareness in VR. We designed a VR environment that leverages gesture-based interactions and haptic feedback to facilitate spatial understanding. Our user study with 30 participants shows that our approach improves spatial accuracy and reduces cognitive load compared to traditional mouse-based interfaces. The results have implications for the design of VR-based training systems and spatial cognition research.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management is a complex task that requires coordinating multiple agents with conflicting goals. We propose a novel approach that leverages deep reinforcement learning to optimize the behavior of traffic lights and autonomous vehicles in a multi-agent setting. Our method, called 'TrafficMA', uses a decentralized actor-critic architecture to learn coordinated policies that minimize congestion and reduce travel times. We evaluate TrafficMA in a simulated urban environment and demonstrate significant improvements over traditional traffic signal control methods.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Neural Query Graphs
paper_abstract: Traditional information retrieval systems rely on exact keyword matching, which often fails to capture complex semantic relationships between queries and documents. This paper proposes a novel neural ranking model, 'NQG-Rank', which leverages graph neural networks to encode query-document interactions. By representing queries as graphs and documents as nodes, our model can effectively capture contextual and relational information, leading to improved ranking performance. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the superiority of NQG-Rank over state-of-the-art neural ranking models, particularly in handling complex, multi-entity queries.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Semantic Hashing for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complex and technical nature of patent documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach using deep semantic hashing (DSH) to improve the retrieval performance. Our method embeds patent queries and documents into a compact binary space, enabling efficient similarity search and query expansion. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on a large-scale patent dataset, achieving significant improvements in mean average precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art query expansion techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Indexing
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing queries in these systems remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel graph-based indexing approach that leverages the structural properties of query graphs to efficiently prune unnecessary joins and reduce query execution time. Our approach is designed to work with various query optimization techniques and is adaptable to different data distribution scenarios. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art query optimization methods by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Designing Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to provide immersive experiences for users with motor impairments. However, current VR interfaces often rely on precise hand or finger movements, limiting accessibility for individuals with mobility impairments. This paper presents a novel VR interface design that utilizes alternative input modalities, including gaze-based and voice-controlled interactions. Our user study with 20 participants with motor impairments shows that our designed interface significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to traditional VR interfaces. We also provide a set of design guidelines for creating accessible VR experiences.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Context-Aware Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with ambiguous or underspecified queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'CAQE', which leverages context-aware neural embeddings to capture nuanced query semantics. By incorporating a dual-encoder architecture that jointly models query and document representations, CAQE outperforms state-of-the-art expansion techniques on several benchmark datasets. Furthermore, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method in improving retrieval performance for diverse query types, including entity-based and event-based queries.

title: EyeGazeAnalytics: A Machine Learning Framework for Inferring User Intent from Eye Movements in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has revolutionized human-computer interaction, but understanding user intent remains a significant challenge. This paper presents EyeGazeAnalytics, a novel machine learning framework that leverages eye movement data to infer user goals in VR environments. Our approach combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with graph-based models to analyze eye gaze patterns and identify relevant objects of interest. We evaluate EyeGazeAnalytics on a large-scale dataset of VR user interactions and demonstrate significant improvements in intent recognition accuracy compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Deep Graph Attention Networks for Node Classification in Attributed Graphs
paper_abstract: Node classification in attributed graphs is a fundamental task in many real-world applications, such as social network analysis and recommender systems. This paper proposes a novel deep learning framework, 'DeepGAT+', which leverages graph attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant node features and neighbors. We introduce a hierarchical attention architecture that adaptively weighs node attributes and graph structure, leading to improved performance on node classification tasks. Experimental results on several benchmarks demonstrate the effectiveness of DeepGAT+ in achieving state-of-the-art performance.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Retrieval-based Question Answering
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in retrieval-based question answering systems, as it enables the retrieval of relevant passages that may not contain the exact keywords. However, traditional query expansion methods rely on hand-crafted rules or statistical models, which may not capture the nuances of natural language. This paper proposes a novel approach to query expansion using deep neural networks. We leverage a pre-trained language model to generate a set of expansion terms that capture the semantic intent of the original query. Our experimental results on the SQuAD dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and answer accuracy compared to traditional methods.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning with Attention-based State Abstraction
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved impressive successes in complex domains, but its lack of interpretability hinders its adoption in high-stakes applications. This paper presents a novel approach, 'Attend2State', which integrates attention mechanisms into state abstraction to provide Explainable RL (XRL). By learning to focus on relevant state features, our method enables the identification of key factors influencing the agent's decision-making process. We evaluate Attend2State on several Atari games and a real-world autonomous driving scenario, demonstrating improved performance and interpretability compared to traditional DRL methods.

title: Elasticity-Aware Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: As data volumes continue to grow, real-time analytics in distributed databases demands efficient query optimization strategies. This paper presents 'ElaOpt', a novel elasticity-aware query optimization framework that dynamically adjusts to changing workload patterns and resource availability. ElaOpt leverages a hybrid cost model that integrates both data and resource heterogeneity, enabling up to 3x improvement in query response times compared to state-of-the-art optimizers. We evaluate ElaOpt on a large-scale distributed database and demonstrate its effectiveness in supporting real-time analytics workloads.

title: Investigating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in enhancing learning outcomes, but user engagement remains a significant challenge. This study explores the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR-based learning environments. We designed and implemented a VR system that generates avatars tailored to individual users' preferences and characteristics. Our user study involving 120 participants reveals that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, self-efficacy, and learning satisfaction. We also identify key design factors influencing avatar personalization and provide recommendations for future VR-based learning systems.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interfaces for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of embodied cognition principles in virtual reality (VR) to design more intuitive and engaging user interfaces. We present a gesture-based interface framework that leverages the cognitive benefits of bodily interactions to improve user experience in VR. Our user study involving 30 participants shows that embodied interfaces lead to enhanced spatial awareness, reduced cognitive load, and increased user satisfaction compared to traditional controller-based interfaces. We discuss the implications of our findings for the design of future VR systems and highlight avenues for further research.

title: Elastic Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: As data scales, distributed database systems require efficient query optimization to ensure performance and scalability. This paper presents an elastic query optimization framework, 'ElasticQuery', which dynamically adapts to changing workload and data distributions. We propose a novel cost model that incorporates both data locality and CPU utilizations, enabling the optimizer to make informed decisions on query execution strategies. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database demonstrate that ElasticQuery achieves up to 3.2x query performance improvement and 2.5x reduction in resource utilization compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Time-Series Anomaly Detection in Industrial IoT
paper_abstract: Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices generate vast amounts of time-series data, making anomaly detection crucial for ensuring system reliability and efficiency. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that captures complex temporal patterns and relationships in IIoT data. Our approach leverages multi-scale attention mechanisms to focus on relevant features and time intervals, improving detection accuracy and reducing false positives. Experimental results on a real-world IIoT dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in detecting anomalies in industrial equipment and outperforming state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Scalable and Efficient Indexing for Main-Memory Column-Store Databases
paper_abstract: Main-memory column-store databases have become increasingly popular for analytical workloads, but their indexing mechanisms often struggle to keep pace with growing dataset sizes. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'CMIX', which leverages a hybrid combination of tree-based and hash-based indexing to achieve efficient query performance. CMIX incorporates a probabilistic data structure to minimize memory overhead and uses a cost-based optimization framework to dynamically adapt to changing workload patterns. Experimental results on a variety of real-world datasets demonstrate that CMIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods in terms of query latency and memory efficiency.

title: Designing Adaptive Visualizations for Inclusive Gesture-Based Interfaces
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have become increasingly popular in various domains, including gaming, education, and healthcare. However, existing interfaces often neglect the diverse needs of users with disabilities. This paper presents an adaptive visualization framework, ' GestureVue', that dynamically adjusts visual feedback to accommodate individual users' abilities and preferences. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, including those with visual and motor impairments, to evaluate the effectiveness of GestureVue in improving interaction accuracy and user satisfaction. Our results show a significant reduction in errors and increased user confidence when using GestureVue, highlighting its potential for promoting inclusive interaction design.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Multimodal Neural Networks using Graph-Based Contrastive Learning
paper_abstract: Multimodal neural networks have achieved state-of-the-art performance in various applications, but their vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in multimodal neural networks using graph-based contrastive learning. We construct a graph representation of the input data and learn a contrastive loss function that captures the relationships between different modalities. Our approach can detect adversarial attacks with high accuracy and outperforms existing methods on several benchmark datasets. We also provide theoretical insights into the robustness of our approach against various types of attacks.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Real-Time Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper explores the application of multi-agent reinforcement learning to real-time traffic signal control. We propose a decentralized framework, 'TrafficMA', where each agent represents a traffic signal controller that learns to optimize traffic flow by interacting with neighboring agents. TrafficMA employs a novel, graph-based state representation that captures the spatial and temporal dependencies of traffic patterns. Through simulation experiments, we demonstrate that TrafficMA outperforms traditional, centralized optimization methods and adapts effectively to changing traffic conditions.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for massive-scale Graph Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Modern graph databases are increasingly used to store massive amounts of interconnected data, posing significant challenges for query optimization. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based approach, GraphQLearn, which leverages graph neural networks to predict optimal query execution plans. We introduce a graph embedding technique that captures structural and statistical properties of the graph, enabling the learning model to generalize across diverse query workloads. Experimental results on a real-world graph database show that GraphQLearn outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query response time and resource utilization.

title: Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Accessibility in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize accessibility, but current gesture recognition systems often struggle with users who have motor impairments. This paper presents 'AdaptaGest', a machine learning-based framework that adapts to individual users' abilities and preferences in real-time. Our approach leverages a novel combination of computer vision, machine learning, and HCI principles to recognize gestures from a diverse range of users, including those with disabilities. Results from a user study show that AdaptaGest significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user experience for participants with motor impairments, enabling more inclusive and accessible VR interactions.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for People with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face difficulties interacting with gesture-based systems. This paper presents an adaptive gesture recognition framework, 'EaseRecognize', which leverages machine learning and human-computer interaction principles to accommodate diverse motor abilities. Our approach involves real-time adaptation of gesture models based on user performance, incorporating feedback from wearable sensors and eye-tracking data. We conducted a user study with 20 participants, demonstrating significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user experience for individuals with motor impairments. The results have implications for the design of more inclusive and accessible human-computer interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) has emerged as a crucial paradigm for tackling complex, real-world problems. However, the curse of dimensionality and partial observability in MARL domains hinder the scalability and efficiency of existing methods. We propose a novel hierarchical attention network (HAT) architecture that addresses these challenges by selectively focusing on relevant agents, observations, and actions. HAT enables more effective exploration, improves coordination, and reduces communication overhead among agents. Our experiments on several MARL benchmarks demonstrate that HAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of learning speed, convergence, and overall performance.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems with Dynamic Resource Constraints
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. However, dynamic resource constraints and agent heterogeneity often lead to suboptimal allocations. This paper presents a novel decentralized algorithm, 'DynaCAT', which leverages graph-based modeling and distributed constraint optimization to allocate tasks in real-time. DynaCAT adaptively adjusts to changes in resource availability and agent capabilities, ensuring efficient and flexible task assignments. Experiments on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate significant improvements in task completion rates and resource utilization compared to existing approaches.

title: Hierarchical Attention for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal inputs (e.g., speech, text, and vision) is a challenging task, particularly when explaining the decision-making process. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HierAttnEmo', which leverages the strengths of both transformer-based architectures and graph neural networks. HierAttnEmo learns to focus on relevant modalities and features, providing interpretable emotion recognition results. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance while offering insights into the emotional cues used by the model.

title: Scalable and Interpretable Attention-Based Neural Networks for Real-Time HumanActivity Recognition
paper_abstract: Real-time human activity recognition is crucial in various applications, including healthcare, surveillance, and human-computer interaction. This paper presents a novel attention-based neural network architecture, 'ActAttn', which leverages hierarchical attention mechanisms to focus on relevant spatio-temporal features in sensor data. We propose a scalable and interpretable approach to model complex activity patterns, achieving state-of-the-art performance on three benchmark datasets. Our approach is computationally efficient, allowing for real-time processing on edge devices, and provides insights into the decision-making process through attention visualization.

title: Autonomous Agent-Based Task Allocation for Dynamic Manufacturing Systems
paper_abstract: In modern manufacturing systems, task allocation is a crucial problem that affects production efficiency and adaptability. This paper presents a novel approach to task allocation using autonomous agents, which can dynamically adjust to changes in the production environment. Our proposed framework, 'AgentMAP', leverages a decentralized multi-agent system to allocate tasks based on real-time resource availability and production constraints. We evaluate AgentMAP using a simulation-based case study of a flexible manufacturing system and demonstrate improved production throughput and adaptability compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Efficient Indexing for High-Dimensional Data using Hierarchical Grids
paper_abstract: High-dimensional data indexing is crucial for efficient query processing in various applications. Existing indexing techniques, such as k-d trees and ball trees, often suffer from the curse of dimensionality. This paper introduces a novel indexing approach, 'HierGrid', which leverages hierarchical grids to partition the data space. By adaptively adjusting the grid resolution and pruning irrelevant regions, HierGrid significantly reduces the indexing time and improves query performance. Experimental results on real-world datasets demonstrate that HierGrid outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, particularly in high-dimensional spaces.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection using Graph Attention Networks for Time-Series Data
paper_abstract: Time-series data is increasingly susceptible to adversarial attacks, which can have devastating consequences in applications like finance and healthcare. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect such attacks using Graph Attention Networks (GATs). We model time-series data as a graph, where each node represents a timestamp, and edges capture temporal dependencies. Our GAT-based detector learns to identify anomalous patterns indicative of attacks, achieving state-of-the-art performance on a benchmark dataset. We further demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in real-world scenarios, including stock market and ECG signal analysis.

title: Adaptive Query Expansion for Efficient Document Retrieval in Heterogeneous Collections
paper_abstract: The proliferation of heterogeneous document collections poses significant challenges to traditional information retrieval (IR) systems. This paper presents a novel adaptive query expansion (AQE) framework that leverages both local and global context to improve retrieval efficiency. Our approach incorporates a deep learning-based query representation model that captures semantic relationships between terms and documents. Experimental results on a large-scale heterogeneous collection demonstrate that AQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision, recall, and mean average precision, while reducing computational overhead.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering using Hierarchical Dense Embeddings
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) involves retrieving relevant passages from a large corpus and then extracting the answer. However, the passage retrieval step is computationally expensive and often bottlenecks the overall pipeline. This paper proposes a novel approach, HierDPR, which leverages hierarchical dense embeddings to efficiently retrieve top-k passages. We introduce a multi-level hierarchical clustering method that reduces the number of passage embeddings to be computed, resulting in significant speedup. Our experiments on several ODQA benchmarks demonstrate that HierDPR achieves comparable or better retrieval performance than state-of-the-art methods while reducing computational cost by up to 75%.

title: Efficient Document Retrieval with Hierarchical Neural Ranking
paper_abstract: Traditional learning-to-rank models for document retrieval often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical neural ranking approach, 'HierRank', which leverages a two-stage architecture to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. The first stage employs a lightweight neural network to filter out irrelevant documents, while the second stage fine-tunes ranking using a more expressive, but computationally expensive, neural model. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierRank achieves state-of-the-art performance while reducing computational costs by an order of magnitude.

title: Coordinating Heterogeneous Agents through Decentralized Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Traffic Management
paper_abstract: Autonomous traffic management systems require coordinating multiple heterogeneous agents to optimize traffic flow and reduce congestion. In this paper, we propose a decentralized reinforcement learning framework, 'HATR', that enables agents to learn from their local observations and make coordinated decisions without relying on a centralized controller. HATR uses a novel, graph-based state representation that captures the complex relationships between agents and their environment. We evaluate HATR on a realistic traffic simulation platform and demonstrate significant improvements in traffic throughput and reduced congestion compared to traditional, centralized control methods.

title: Embodied Cognition in Virtual Reality: A Study on Gesture-Based Interaction for Enhanced User Experience
paper_abstract: This paper explores the concept of embodied cognition in virtual reality (VR) and its implications on user experience. We designed a gesture-based interaction system that leverages the cognitive benefits of bodily engagement to enhance user immersion and overall satisfaction. Our user study involving 30 participants demonstrates that the proposed system significantly improves task performance, reduces cognitive load, and increases user enjoyment compared to traditional controller-based interaction. The findings have implications for the design of more intuitive and engaging VR interfaces.

title: Aspect-Based Sentiment Analysis with Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Domain Reviews
paper_abstract: Aspect-based sentiment analysis (ABSA) is a crucial task in natural language processing, enabling businesses to gain insights from customer reviews. However, existing ABSA models struggle to generalize across multiple domains and datasets. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) architecture, 'AspectGAT', which leverages the graph structure of review documents to capture complex relationships between aspects, sentiments, and contextual information. Our experiments on a multi-domain review dataset demonstrate that AspectGAT outperforms state-of-the-art ABSA models, achieving improved aspect extraction and sentiment prediction accuracy.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In decentralized multi-agent systems, task allocation is a challenging problem due to the lack of a central authority and limited communication between agents. This paper proposes a novel approach using deep reinforcement learning to learn task allocation policies for each agent. Our method, called Dec-TAR, uses a decentralized actor-critic framework to learn both individual and joint policies for task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated robotic swarm scenario demonstrate that Dec-TAR outperforms existing decentralized task allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Learning-based Query Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval is a fundamental task in Information Retrieval (IR) that aims to retrieve relevant documents for a given query. Query expansion is a popular technique used to improve retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. In this paper, we propose a novel deep learning-based approach to query expansion, dubbed 'QE-DL'. QE-DL leverages a neural network to learn dense query embeddings that capture semantic relationships between query terms and the document collection. Our experiments on several standard IR datasets demonstrate that QE-DL significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of retrieval effectiveness and efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Distributed Database Systems using Graph-Based Models
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a critical component of distributed database systems, but traditional approaches struggle to handle complex query patterns and large-scale data sets. This paper proposes a novel graph-based query optimization framework, 'GraphOpt', which leverages graph neural networks to model query patterns and optimize query plans. We develop a scalable graph-based query representation and a efficient optimization algorithm that exploits the structural properties of the graph. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database benchmark show that GraphOpt achieves up to 3x speedup compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable AI-powered Clinical Decision Support Systems
paper_abstract: Clinical decision support systems (CDSSs) can significantly improve healthcare outcomes, but their opacity hinders trust and adoption. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that enables explainable AI-powered CDSSs. Our approach integrates domain-specific knowledge graphs with attention mechanisms to generate transparent and interpretable recommendations. We evaluate HAN on a large-scale electronic health records dataset, demonstrating improved predictive performance and enhanced explainability compared to state-of-the-art CDSS models.

title: Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Documents using Hierarchical Neural Embeddings
paper_abstract: With the increasing prevalence of multi-modal documents, such as those containing images, videos, and text, traditional information retrieval systems are struggling to efficiently retrieve relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages hierarchical neural embeddings to jointly model the semantic relationships between different modalities. Our method, called Hierarchical Multi-Modal Retrieval (HMMR), learns a hierarchical representation of documents by recursively applying a neural embedding module to each modality. Experiments on a large-scale dataset show that HMMR outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of retrieval efficiency and effectiveness, while also providing interpretable results.

title: Bayesian Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years. This paper introduces a novel Bayesian graph attention network (BGAT) that leverages both graph structures and attention mechanisms to provide interpretable recommendations. BGAT models user behavior as a probabilistic graph, where attention weights are learned to identify influential items and users. We propose a Bayesian inference approach to capture uncertainty in attention weights, enabling the model to provide personalized explanations for recommended items. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of BGAT in improving recommendation performance and providing meaningful explanations.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Reinforced Neural Ranking Models for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, as it can significantly improve the retrieval performance. In this paper, we propose a novel reinforced neural ranking model, 'RNN-Ranker', which learns to expand queries by generating context-aware and semantically relevant keywords. Our approach leverages a deep reinforcement learning framework to optimize the ranking model, allowing it to adapt to the complex query-document relationships. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that RNN-Ranker outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving substantial improvements in precision and recall.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture Recognition Systems for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to enhance the quality of life for older adults, but existing systems often neglect the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach for developing accessible gesture recognition systems tailored to older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify key challenges and opportunities for gesture-based interaction. Our findings inform the development of a novel gesture recognition algorithm that adapts to age-related motor skill declines and cognitive impairments. We evaluate our system through a usability study, demonstrating improved recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing systems.

title: Enhancing Retrieval Effectiveness with Hybrid Neural Ranking Models for Multimodal Search
paper_abstract: Multimodal search systems, which simultaneously process text and visual features, have become increasingly popular. However, existing neural ranking models struggle to effectively integrate both modalities. This paper proposes a novel hybrid neural ranking framework, 'MM-Rank', which combines the strengths of transformer-based language models and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for visual feature extraction. MM-Rank employs a shared semantic space to align text and image representations, enabling more accurate ranking and retrieval. Experimental results on the Flickr30k dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness over state-of-the-art baselines, particularly for multimodal queries.

title: Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a critical problem in multi-agent systems, especially in dynamic environments where agent capabilities and task requirements change over time. This paper presents a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning to adapt task allocation policies in real-time. Our method, 'MATA-RL', uses a decentralized, multi-agent Q-learning algorithm to optimize task assignments based on agent expertise, task urgency, and environmental constraints.
