We demonstrate the effectiveness of MATA-RL in a simulated disaster response scenario, showcasing improved response times, reduced task failures, and enhanced overall system resilience.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize various aspects of our lives, including education, entertainment, and social interaction. However, user engagement remains a significant challenge in VR environments. This paper investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, who were randomly assigned to either a personalized avatar group or a default avatar group. Our results show that users with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, including increased time spent in the VR environment and improved task performance. We also analyzed the impact of avatar personalization on user experience and identified key design factors that influence user engagement.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Unsupervised Time Series Anomaly Detection
paper_abstract: Unsupervised time series anomaly detection is a challenging problem due to the lack of labeled data. Contrastive learning has shown promise in this domain, but existing methods often suffer from mode collapse and limited scalability. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical contrastive learning framework, 'HiCAD', which leverages a multi-scale representation of time series data to identify anomalies. HiCAD uses a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group similar time series segments, and then applies contrastive learning to learn a discriminative representation of each cluster. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HiCAD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of both detection accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Efficient Query Expansion Using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems struggle to effectively capture user intent from short queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. This paper proposes a novel query expansion framework, 'NeuroQE', which leverages neural semantic embeddings to enrich query representations. By jointly learning query and document embeddings, NeuroQE captures nuanced semantic relationships between terms and identifies informative expansion candidates. Experiments on standard benchmarks demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval effectiveness, particularly for short and ambiguous queries, showcasing the potential of neural embeddings in query expansion for ad-hoc retrieval.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehousing using Column Store Indexes
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehousing has become increasingly important for businesses to make timely decisions. However, query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper presents a novel approach to query optimization using column store indexes, which leverages the benefits of both column-store and row-store indexing techniques. We propose a cost-based optimization algorithm that dynamically selects the most efficient indexing strategy based on query patterns and data distribution. Our experiments on a real-world dataset show that our approach achieves an average query performance improvement of 3.5x compared to traditional row-store indexing, while reducing storage costs by 30%.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Human-Robot Interaction
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition is a crucial aspect of human-robot interaction, enabling robots to respond empathetically to users. However, existing approaches struggle to effectively fuse and interpret multi-modal cues from speech, text, and vision. This paper presents a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that learns to selectively focus on salient modalities and contextual features. Our HAN architecture comprises a feature extraction module, modality-aware attention, and a hierarchical fusion mechanism. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in recognizing emotions from multi-modal inputs, with improved robustness to noisy or missing data.

title: Autonomous Negotiation Strategies for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Negotiation is a crucial aspect of multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents must reach mutually beneficial agreements in complex, dynamic environments. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework, 'AgentNegotiator', which enables agents to learn effective negotiation strategies through self-play. We introduce a hierarchical architecture that integrates game-theoretic models with deep neural networks, allowing agents to adapt to changing opponent behaviors and negotiate in a more human-like manner. Experimental results on a real-world supply chain management scenario demonstrate that AgentNegotiator outperforms traditional negotiation protocols in terms of agreement quality, negotiation speed, and robustness to opponent strategies.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in Uncertain Environments
paper_abstract: In complex, dynamic environments, task allocation among multiple agents is a challenging problem. This paper presents MADARA, a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that learns to allocate tasks adaptively based on environmental uncertainty. MADARA integrates a hierarchical task representation with a probabilistic graphical model to reason about uncertain task dependencies. Experimental results in a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that MADARA outperforms traditional, rule-based allocation methods in terms of task completion rate and agent utilization.

title: Designing Inclusive Gestural Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing gestural interfaces that cater to older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants with Parkinson's disease, stroke, or arthritis, and analyzed their motor abilities, gesture preferences, and feedback. Our findings inform the development of 'EasyGest', a novel gestural interface that incorporates adaptable gesture recognition, personalized feedback, and error tolerance. A usability evaluation with 15 participants demonstrates that EasyGest significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing interfaces.

title: Efficient Query Processing for Large-Scale Graph Databases using Parallelized Subgraph Matching
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between entities. However, as graph sizes continue to grow, query processing efficiency becomes a major bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel parallelized subgraph matching algorithm, 'ParaMatch', which exploits the inherent parallelism in modern processors to accelerate query execution. We develop a dynamic task scheduling strategy that adaptively assigns subgraph matching tasks to available processing units, minimizing idle time and maximizing throughput. Experimental results on real-world graph datasets demonstrate that ParaMatch achieves up to 5x speedup over state-of-the-art sequential algorithms, making it an attractive solution for large-scale graph query processing.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Effective Retrieval in Short-Text Collections
paper_abstract: Short-text collections, such as tweets and product reviews, pose unique challenges for information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical query expansion approach, 'HQE-ST', that leverages the semantic relationships between query terms and their variants to improve retrieval effectiveness. HQE-ST integrates a word-embedding-based semantic similarity measure with a hierarchical clustering algorithm to generate a set of expanded queries that better capture the user's information need. Experimental results on several short-text datasets demonstrate that HQE-ST outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, particularly for short queries with limited context.

title: Query Optimization Techniques for Distributed Databases with Heterogeneous Storage
paper_abstract: Distributed databases with heterogeneous storage systems are increasingly common, but optimizing queries in such environments remains a significant challenge. This paper proposes a novel cost-based query optimization framework, 'HeteCost', which takes into account the diverse storage characteristics and access patterns of different devices. We develop a probabilistic modeling approach to estimate the cost of query execution plans, and introduce a dynamic reordering strategy to minimize data transfer and processing overhead. Experimental results on a real-world distributed database setup demonstrate that HeteCost achieves up to 3x improvement in query response time compared to existing optimization techniques.

title: Robustifying Deep Neural Networks against Adversarial Attacks via Meta-Learning
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can mislead them into making incorrect predictions. This paper presents a novel approach to robustifying deep neural networks against such attacks using meta-learning. Our method, called 'MetaShield', learns to generate adversarial examples that are used to train a network to be robust against a wide range of attacks. We demonstrate the effectiveness of MetaShield on several benchmark datasets, including ImageNet and CIFAR-10, and show that it outperforms state-of-the-art defenses in terms of robustness and accuracy.

title: Efficient Indexing for Real-Time Time-Series Data in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: The proliferation of IoT devices and real-time data streaming has created a pressing need for efficient indexing and querying of time-series data in distributed databases. This paper introduces 'TSIRIS', a novel indexing framework that leverages a combination of in-memory caching, hierarchical clustering, and distributed query optimization to achieve low-latency query performance for time-series data. Experimental results on a 100-node distributed cluster demonstrate that TSIRIS outperforms state-of-the-art indexing schemes by up to 5x in terms of query latency and 3x in terms of storage efficiency.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-based Embeddings for Knowledge Graph Construction
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph construction relies on accurate entity disambiguation, which becomes increasingly challenging with large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphED', that leverages graph-based embeddings to disambiguate entities in a scalable manner. We design a graph neural network that jointly learns entity and context representations, enabling effective disambiguation even in the presence of limited training data. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that GraphED outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency, particularly for entities with few occurrences.

title: Scalable Deep Learning for Multimodal Time Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Multimodal time series forecasting is a crucial task in various applications, including healthcare, finance, and climate modeling. However, existing deep learning methods suffer from scalability issues and struggle to handle the complexity of multimodal data. This paper presents a novel architecture, 'Multimodal Transformer Ensemble' (MTE), which leverages the strengths of transformer models and ensemble learning to achieve state-of-the-art performance on large-scale multimodal datasets. We propose a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively weights the importance of different modalities and a parallel ensemble strategy that reduces computational overhead. Experiments on a large-scale healthcare dataset demonstrate the scalability and effectiveness of MTE in multimodal time series forecasting.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Relational Databases using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed relational databases (DRDBs) have become increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and processing. However, optimizing query performance in DRDBs remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages machine learning (ML) techniques to predict optimal query execution plans for DRDBs. We develop a query optimizer that uses a graph neural network (GNN) to learn the query patterns and database statistics. Our experimental results on a real-world dataset show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Exploring Hierarchical Attention for Multi-Modal Dialogue State Tracking
paper_abstract: Dialogue state tracking (DST) is a crucial component in task-oriented dialogue systems, requiring the ability to accurately track user goals and preferences across multiple turns. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention framework, 'HAT-DST', which leverages multi-modal inputs (text, speech, and vision) to improve DST performance. Our approach employs a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant context and modalities, while incorporating contextualized embeddings to capture nuanced user intentions. Experimental results on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in DST accuracy and robustness, especially in scenarios with noisy or ambiguous user input.

title: Hierarchical Neural Document Ranking with Hyperbolic Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Traditional neural ranking models for information retrieval (IR) often suffer from high computational costs and limited scalability. This paper presents a novel hierarchical neural document ranking framework that leverages hyperbolic embeddings to efficiently model complex document relationships. Our approach, called HyDR, learns a hierarchical representation of documents in hyperbolic space, enabling fast and accurate retrieval of relevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HyDR outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models while reducing computational costs by up to 40%.

title: Efficient Indexing for In-Memory Column Stores using Hierarchical Bloom Filters
paper_abstract: In-memory column stores have become increasingly popular for analytical workloads due to their high performance and low latency. However, indexing schemes in these systems often suffer from high memory overhead and poor update performance. This paper introduces Hierarchical Bloom Filters (HBF), a novel indexing technique that leverages the hierarchical structure of Bloom filters to reduce memory consumption and improve query performance. We demonstrate the effectiveness of HBF on a range of benchmarks, showing up to 30% reduction in memory usage and 25% improvement in query throughput compared to state-of-the-art indexing schemes.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve complex goals. This paper presents a novel approach to distributed task allocation using reinforcement learning. Our method, 'MA-RL', enables agents to learn from their interactions with the environment and other agents, adapting to changing task requirements and agent capabilities. We evaluate MA-RL in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional centralized allocation methods.

title: Deep Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in many domains, but the need for efficient models that can handle high-dimensional data has become increasingly important. This paper proposes a novel deep neural architecture search (NAS) framework, 'TS-NAS', which automatically designs compact and accurate time-series forecasting models. TS-NAS leverages a hierarchical search space and a differentiable NAS algorithm to jointly optimize the model architecture and hyperparameters. We demonstrate the effectiveness of TS-NAS on several real-world datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results with significant reductions in model size and inference time.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Gesture-based interfaces have the potential to improve the accessibility of technology for older adults with motor impairments. However, existing gesture recognition systems often fail to account for the unique needs and abilities of this population. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to developing accessible gesture-based interfaces for older adults with motor impairments. We conducted a series of participatory design workshops with older adults and healthcare professionals to identify key design requirements and preferences. Our results show that incorporating personalized gesture recognition, adaptive feedback, and multimodal input can significantly improve the usability and accessibility of gesture-based interfaces for this population.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Dementia
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible interfaces that can be used by older adults with dementia. This paper presents a gesture-based interface designed specifically for this demographic. We conducted a user study with 20 participants to identify key design principles and gesture patterns that are intuitive and easy to use. Our results show that a simplified, icon-based gesture set with auditory feedback can significantly improve task completion rates and user satisfaction. We also discuss the implications of our findings for future research in accessible HCI design.

title: Designing Personalized Avatars for Enhanced User Engagement in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has the potential to revolutionize human-computer interaction, but existing avatar designs often fail to engage users. This paper presents a novel framework for generating personalized avatars that incorporate users' personality traits, preferences, and behavior. We conducted a user study with 120 participants, using a mixed-methods approach to evaluate the impact of our avatar design on user experience. Results show that personalized avatars lead to increased user engagement, improved self-representation, and enhanced emotional expression in VR environments.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on User Experience in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technology has made tremendous progress in recent years, but the impact of embodiment on user experience remains understudied. This paper presents a systematic investigation of how different levels of embodiment (from simple controllers to full-body tracking) affect users' sense of presence, engagement, and cognitive load in VR environments. Our study involves 120 participants and employs a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative metrics with qualitative feedback. Results show that higher levels of embodiment lead to increased presence and engagement, but also introduce significant cognitive load. We discuss implications for VR system design and highlight areas for future research.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Embodied Conversational Agents in Reducing Cognitive Load for Older Adults
paper_abstract: This study investigates the potential of embodied conversational agents (ECAs) to alleviate cognitive load in older adults when interacting with digital systems. We designed an ECA-based interface for a medication reminder system and conducted a within-subjects experiment with 30 older adults. Our results show that participants experienced significantly reduced cognitive load when interacting with the ECA-based interface compared to a traditional text-based interface. Furthermore, we observed improved task completion time and reduced errors. Our findings have implications for the design of accessible and inclusive digital systems for older adults, and highlight the potential of ECAs as a means to support healthy aging.

title: Deep Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Task-Aware Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning. While meta-learning has shown promise, existing methods often rely on simplistic task embeddings that fail to capture the nuances of novel tasks. This paper proposes a deep meta-learning framework that learns task-aware embeddings through a novel graph neural network architecture. Our approach leverages self-supervised learning to adapt to new tasks and demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on popular few-shot benchmarks. We also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method, revealing its connections to existing meta-learning techniques.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Improving Ad-hoc Retrieval Performance
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to effectively retrieve relevant documents, especially for short or ambiguous queries. This paper proposes a novel query-driven document expansion approach, which selects and integrates relevant contextual information into the original document representation. Our method, dubbed 'QueryExpan', leverages a combination of semantic role labeling and dependency parsing to identify salient entities and relationships within documents. Experimental results on the TREC-8 ad-hoc retrieval dataset demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain compared to state-of-the-art retrieval models.

title: Efficient Reinforcement Learning for Real-World Autonomous Driving using Graph-Based State Representation
paper_abstract: Autonomous driving has seen significant progress in recent years, but real-world deployment remains challenging due to the complexity and variability of real-world scenarios. This paper introduces a novel graph-based state representation for reinforcement learning in autonomous driving, which captures the structural relationships between various road elements and agents. Our approach, 'GraphDrive', leverages graph neural networks to learn a compact and expressive state representation, improving the sample efficiency and scalability of reinforcement learning algorithms. Experimental results on a large-scale autonomous driving dataset demonstrate that GraphDrive outperforms existing methods in terms of driving safety and efficiency.

title: Efficient Document Filtering using Hierarchical Graph Neural Networks for Scalable Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: The exponential growth of online data has made efficient document filtering a critical component of modern information retrieval systems. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph neural network (HGNN) framework for scalable document filtering. Our approach leverages the graph structure of document collections to learn hierarchical representations of documents, enabling efficient filtering of irrelevant documents. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our HGNN-based approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of filtering accuracy and computational efficiency, making it a promising solution for large-scale information retrieval applications.

title: Efficient Explainability Techniques for Deep Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: As autonomous systems increasingly rely on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) for decision-making, transparency and accountability become crucial. This paper proposes 'TreeX', a novel model-agnostic explainability framework for DRL. TreeX leverages hierarchical feature importance and sparse attention mechanisms to provide interpretable explanations for agent decisions. We evaluate TreeX on a suite of benchmarks, demonstrating improved explainability without compromising policy performance. Furthermore, we provide theoretical guarantees for the fidelity of TreeX explanations, facilitating trustworthiness in high-stakes applications.

title: Distributed Task Allocation using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for IoT Networks
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a crucial problem in IoT networks, where multiple agents must coordinate to achieve efficient resource utilization. This paper proposes a novel distributed task allocation framework using multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). We design a communication-efficient algorithm that enables agents to learn cooperative policies and adapt to dynamic network conditions. Experimental results on a simulated IoT network demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion rate and energy efficiency.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults with Cognitive Impairments
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, it is essential to design interfaces that are accessible and usable for older adults with cognitive impairments. This paper presents a gesture-based interface designed specifically for this population, with a focus on reducing cognitive load and improving usability. We conducted a user-centered design process, involving co-design workshops and usability testing with older adults, to develop a novel gesture set and interface layout. Our evaluation results show that the proposed interface significantly improves task completion time and reduces errors compared to traditional touchscreen interfaces, demonstrating the potential of gesture-based interfaces to enhance accessibility for older adults with cognitive impairments.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Environments using Deep Learning
paper_abstract: With the growing adoption of virtual reality (VR) technology, there is a need for more intuitive and natural interaction mechanisms. This paper presents a novel gaze-based interaction system that leverages deep learning to accurately track and interpret user gazes in VR environments. Our approach uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) to analyze eye movement data from VR headsets and generates a probabilistic gaze map, which is then used to infer user intent. We evaluate our system through a user study, demonstrating significant improvements in interaction accuracy and user experience compared to traditional controller-based interfaces.

title: Multi-Task Deep Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles require the ability to perform multiple tasks simultaneously, such as lane following, obstacle avoidance, and speed control. This paper presents a novel multi-task deep reinforcement learning framework, 'MTDRL', which enables a single neural network to learn multiple tasks in a shared environment. We introduce a task-conditioned policy gradient method that adapts to changing task priorities and demonstrate improved performance on a realistic autonomous driving simulator. Experimental results show that MTDRL outperforms single-task and multi-agent baselines in complex urban scenarios.

title: Efficient Approximate Nearest Neighbor Search using Hierarchical Graph Indexing
paper_abstract: Nearest neighbor search (NNS) is a fundamental problem in many applications, including computer vision, natural language processing, and recommender systems. However, exact NNS algorithms are often computationally expensive, especially for large-scale datasets. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph indexing approach, called 'HGI-ANN', which accelerates approximate NNS queries by exploiting the structural properties of the data graph. Our method leverages a balanced binary tree to partition the data space and a graph-based indexing scheme to prune the search space. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGI-ANN achieves significant speedup over state-of-the-art approximate NNS algorithms while maintaining comparable accuracy.

title: Elderly-Friendly Gesture Recognition Using Transfer Learning and Depth Sensors
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gesture recognition system designed for elderly individuals, leveraging transfer learning and depth sensors to improve accuracy and accessibility. Our approach fine-tunes a pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN) on a dataset of elderly-specific gestures, and incorporates depth information from a low-cost sensor to enhance robustness to varying lighting and environmental conditions. Experimental results show that our system achieves an average recognition accuracy of 92.5%, outperforming state-of-the-art methods in this domain. We discuss the implications of our work for promoting independent living and healthcare for older adults.

title: Query Optimization for Distributed Blockchain-Based Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of blockchain technology has led to the development of distributed database systems that leverage blockchain's immutability and transparency. However, query optimization in these systems remains a significant challenge due to the decentralized nature of the data. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'BlockchainAware', that exploits the blockchain's underlying structure to improve query performance. We introduce a cost-based optimization approach that considers factors such as block height, transaction latency, and smart contract overhead. Experimental evaluation on a real-world blockchain-based database system demonstrates that BlockchainAware achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional optimization techniques.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, learning effective communication and cooperation strategies is crucial for achieving common goals. This paper presents a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) framework for multi-agent reinforcement learning. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex agent interactions and hierarchically aggregates agent representations to capture both local and global dependencies. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark environments and demonstrate significant improvements in task performance and convergence speed compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Gradient-Based Optimization for Deep Neural Networks using Adaptive Momentum
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks have become increasingly complex, making optimization a crucial aspect of their training. This paper proposes an adaptive momentum-based optimization algorithm, 'AdaMom', which dynamically adjusts the momentum factor based on the gradient norm. AdaMom converges faster and achieves better generalization performance compared to existing gradient-based optimizers, including SGD with momentum and Adam. We provide theoretical convergence guarantees and validate our approach on various benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10 and ImageNet.

title: Adversarial Attacks on Deep Reinforcement Learning Policies in Autonomous Vehicles
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved state-of-the-art performance in autonomous vehicle control tasks. However, recent studies have shown that DRL policies are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise safety and reliability. This paper investigates the robustness of DRL policies in autonomous vehicles against targeted attacks on sensor inputs. We propose a novel attack framework, 'AV-Attack', which leverages generative models to craft perturbations that deceive the DRL policy into making unsafe decisions. Our experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of AV-Attack on various DRL algorithms, highlighting the need for robustness evaluation and adversarial training in autonomous vehicle development.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Query Processing in Distributed Information Retrieval Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed information retrieval systems require efficient query processing to facilitate fast response times. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing approach that combines the benefits of inverted indexing and term-partitioned indexing. Our approach, dubbed 'HybridIX', leverages a two-layer indexing structure to reduce query latency and improve throughput. Experiments on a large-scale document collection demonstrate that HybridIX outperforms state-of-the-art indexing methods, achieving an average query response time reduction of 35% and a 25% increase in query throughput.

title: Graph Attention Networks for Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series
paper_abstract: Multivariate time series anomaly detection is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper presents a novel graph attention network (GAT) approach, dubbed 'TS-GAT', which leverages the inherent relationships between variables in multivariate time series data. TS-GAT adaptively learns attention weights for each variable, enabling effective feature extraction and anomaly detection. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate the superiority of TS-GAT over state-of-the-art methods, including traditional statistical approaches and deep learning-based methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Explainable Recommendation
paper_abstract: Explainable recommendation systems have gained significant attention in recent years. However, most existing methods suffer from high computational complexity, making them unsuitable for large-scale industrial applications. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that leverages both user and item embeddings to generate personalized explanations for recommended items. Our approach reduces the computational complexity of explanation generation by 3x compared to state-of-the-art methods while achieving comparable recommendation accuracy on benchmark datasets. We also demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in real-world scenarios using a large-scale e-commerce dataset.

title: Explainable Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) involves predicting sentiment from diverse input modalities such as text, images, and audio. Existing deep learning methods often rely on complex black-box models, making it challenging to understand their decision-making processes. This paper proposes a novel explainable hierarchical attention network (EHAN) for MSA, which integrates both local and global attention mechanisms to capture multimodal interactions. Our approach enables the identification of salient input features and modalities contributing to the predicted sentiment, thereby providing transparency and interpretability. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate EHAN's superior performance and explainability compared to state-of-the-art MSA models.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems rely on query expansion to improve retrieval performance. Traditional methods employ hand-crafted rules and thesauri, which can be brittle and domain-specific. This paper proposes a novel neural embedding-based approach, 'NeuroQE', which learns to expand queries by capturing semantic relationships between terms. We leverage a large-scale corpus to train a neural network that maps terms to dense vectors, and then use these vectors to generate expansion terms. Experiments on the ClueWeb09 dataset demonstrate that NeuroQE outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of MAP and NDCG, while requiring minimal domain knowledge and tuning.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems have become ubiquitous in modern e-commerce, but their opacity hinders user trust and understanding. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework for explainable recommendation systems. Our approach leverages multi-level attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant user and item features, generating interpretable explanations for recommended items. We evaluate our HAN model on three real-world datasets, demonstrating improved recommendation accuracy and explanatory power compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Coordinated Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Deep Graph Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Coordinating task allocation in multi-agent systems is a challenging problem, particularly in dynamic and uncertain environments. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines graph neural networks and deep reinforcement learning to learn effective task allocation policies. Our method, called GraphMA, represents the agent-task graph as a dynamic relational structure and uses a hierarchical graph reinforcement learning framework to optimize task allocation. We evaluate GraphMA on a variety of task allocation benchmarks and demonstrate significant improvements over state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion rate, agent utilization, and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Gaze-Based Authentication for Virtual Reality Head-Mounted Displays
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) head-mounted displays (HMDs) have become increasingly popular, but their security remains a concern. This paper presents a novel gaze-based authentication mechanism for VR HMDs, leveraging the high-resolution eye-tracking capabilities of modern devices. Our approach, 'GazeAuth', uses machine learning to classify user gaze patterns and detect authentication attempts. We conducted a user study with 30 participants and achieved an accuracy of 95.6% in distinguishing between genuine and impostor attempts. GazeAuth offers a convenient, non-intrusive, and highly secure authentication solution for VR HMDs, ensuring a safe and immersive user experience.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Personalized Avatars on User Engagement in Virtual Reality-Based Learning Environments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has shown promise in enhancing learning experiences, but user engagement remains a crucial factor in its adoption. This study investigates the effect of personalized avatars on user engagement in VR-based learning environments. We designed an experiment where participants were randomly assigned to either a generic avatar or a personalized avatar that reflected their physical appearance and personality traits. Our results indicate that users with personalized avatars exhibited higher levels of engagement, measured through self-reported surveys and behavioral metrics, compared to those with generic avatars. Furthermore, we found that the impact of personalized avatars varied across different learning tasks and user demographics.

title: Ranking-Based Neural Model for Document Retrieval with Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Traditional document retrieval methods often struggle to effectively incorporate semantic query expansion, leading to suboptimal ranking performance. In this paper, we propose a novel ranking-based neural model, 'QRex', which integrates query expansion into a unified neural ranking framework. QRex leverages a multi-task learning objective, combining ranking loss with a query expansion reconstruction loss. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that QRex outperforms state-of-the-art retrieval models, achieving significant improvements in NDCG@10 and MAP metrics.

title: Efficient Indexing for Scalable Main-Memory Database Systems
paper_abstract: Main-memory database systems have gained popularity due to their ability to provide high performance and low latency. However, as data sizes continue to grow, indexing mechanisms play a crucial role in ensuring query efficiency. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'AdaptiveHash', which leverages the properties of main-memory storage to provide superior query performance and scalability. Our approach dynamically adapts the index structure based on query patterns and data distribution, resulting in a significant reduction in query latency and memory usage. Experimental evaluations on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of AdaptiveHash in comparison to existing indexing techniques.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Dimensional Indexing in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: With the increasing scale of modern database systems, query optimization has become a critical component for achieving efficient data retrieval. This paper focuses on optimizing query performance in distributed database systems that employ multi-dimensional indexing. We propose a novel approach, 'DMIndex', which leverages a combination of clustering and caching techniques to reduce the number of disk I/O operations and minimize query latency. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database demonstrate that DMIndex outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 30% in terms of query response time.

title: Adversarial Training of Graph Convolutional Networks for Robust Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) have achieved state-of-the-art performance in node classification tasks. However, their vulnerability to adversarial attacks hinders their deployment in real-world applications. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework for GCNs, which incorporates a learnable perturbation generator to simulate attacks on the graph structure and node features. We demonstrate that our approach, 'AdvGCN', significantly improves the robustness of GCNs against various types of attacks, including node addition, deletion, and feature manipulation. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that AdvGCN outperforms existing defense methods, achieving an average improvement of 12.5% in classification accuracy under attack.

title: Distributed Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Swarm Intelligence
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel distributed task allocation framework for multi-agent systems, inspired by swarm intelligence principles. Our approach, called 'SwarmAllocator', leverages the collective behavior of agents to allocate tasks efficiently and adapt to dynamic environment changes. We employ a decentralized, self-organized mechanism that enables agents to share information and negotiate task assignments based on their capabilities and availability. Experimental results on a large-scale logistics scenario demonstrate that SwarmAllocator outperforms traditional centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Query-Driven Document Expansion for Enhanced Retrieval in Ad-Hoc Search
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc search systems often struggle to retrieve relevant documents due to the limited query context. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'QueryDX', which leverages query-driven document expansion to enrich the query representation. Our method incorporates a neural query encoder and a document expansion module, which generates additional query terms based on the semantic context of the original query. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that QueryDX improves retrieval performance by 15% compared to state-of-the-art models, particularly for short and ambiguous queries.

title: Designing Accessible Gesture-Based Interfaces for Older Adults Using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible interfaces that can accommodate the physical and cognitive changes associated with aging. This paper presents a machine learning-driven approach to designing gesture-based interfaces that are intuitive and usable for older adults. We collect a dataset of gestures from a diverse group of older adults and use machine learning algorithms to identify patterns and preferences. Our results show that the proposed approach can improve gesture recognition accuracy by up to 25% compared to traditional methods, and user studies demonstrate significant improvements in user experience and satisfaction.

title: Gaze-Based Emotional State Inference for Personalized Virtual Assistants
paper_abstract: Virtual assistants are increasingly prevalent, but their inability to recognize users' emotional states limits their effectiveness. This paper presents a novel gaze-based approach to infer emotional states using a wearable eye-tracking device. We propose a machine learning model that leverages gaze patterns, pupil dilation, and facial feature extraction to recognize six primary emotions. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates that our system achieves an accuracy of 85.6% in classifying emotional states, outperforming existing audio-based methods. We discuss the implications of our approach for creating more empathetic and personalized virtual assistants.

title: Hierarchical Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Graph Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems have become increasingly popular in various real-world applications, such as autonomous vehicles and smart homes. However, task allocation remains a challenging problem, particularly when dealing with complex dependencies between tasks and agents. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task allocation framework that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to model agent capabilities, task relationships, and environmental constraints. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through extensive simulations, showing significant improvements in task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing methods.

title: Causal Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Counterfactual Reasoning
paper_abstract: Counterfactual reasoning is a fundamental aspect of human decision-making, but existing AI systems lack the ability to provide interpretable explanations for their predictions. This paper introduces Causal Graph Attention Networks (CGANs), a novel framework that integrates graph attention mechanisms with causal inference to generate explainable counterfactuals. We demonstrate the effectiveness of CGANs on a real-world healthcare dataset, showing that they outperform state-of-the-art methods in terms of both prediction accuracy and explanation quality. Our approach has significant implications for building trustworthy AI systems that can provide actionable insights for decision-makers.

title: Hierarchical Attention Neural Networks for Multi-Label Image Classification
paper_abstract: Multi-label image classification is a fundamental task in computer vision, where an image can be associated with multiple labels. Existing methods often suffer from label dependencies and lack of attention to relevant regions. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention neural network (HAN) that leverages label correlations and spatial attention to improve performance. Our HAN model consists of a label-aware attention module that selectively focuses on relevant labels and a spatial attention module that adapts to the image context. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN in achieving state-of-the-art performance and robustness to label noise.

title: Hierarchical Contrastive Learning for Efficient Visual Representation
paper_abstract: Contrastive learning has emerged as a powerful method for self-supervised representation learning in computer vision. However, existing approaches often rely on computationally expensive and memory-intensive techniques, limiting their applicability to large-scale datasets. This paper introduces Hierarchical Contrastive Learning (HCL), a novel framework that leverages a hierarchical representation of images to efficiently learn visual features. HCL employs a pyramidal architecture to capture multi-scale context and a momentum-based approach to maintain consistency across different scales. Our experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that HCL outperforms state-of-the-art contrastive learning methods while reducing computational costs by up to 30%.

title: Goal-Oriented Task Allocation for Hybrid Agent Teams in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: We present a novel task allocation framework for hybrid agent teams, comprising both autonomous and human agents, operating in dynamic environments. Our approach leverages goal-oriented reasoning to maximize team performance and adapt to changing environmental conditions. We introduce a hierarchical planning framework that integrates task decomposition, role assignment, and resource allocation to optimize team behavior. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in simulated search-and-rescue scenarios, outperforming existing task allocation methods in terms of task completion time and team utility.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Older Adults: A Study on Cognitive Load Reduction
paper_abstract: As the global population ages, there is a growing need for accessible conversational interfaces that cater to the needs of older adults. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to reduce cognitive load in conversational systems for older adults. We conducted a mixed-method study involving 30 participants aged 65-85, exploring the effects of simplifying dialogue structures, using clear and concise language, and incorporating visual cues on cognitive load reduction. Our results show that the designed conversational interface reduced cognitive load by 35% compared to standard conversational interfaces, improving overall user experience and satisfaction.

title: Cooperative Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems via Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent systems often require efficient task allocation to achieve complex goals. This paper proposes a novel deep reinforcement learning framework for cooperative task allocation, dubbed 'CATARINA'. By leveraging graph neural networks and attention mechanisms, CATARINA enables agents to learn effective task assignments and coordination strategies in dynamic environments. We evaluate CATARINA in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Hierarchical Query Expansion for Session-based Search Tasks
paper_abstract: Session-based search tasks, where users interact with a search engine through multiple queries, pose significant challenges for traditional retrieval models. In this paper, we propose a novel hierarchical query expansion framework, 'HQE', that leverages both short-term and long-term dependencies within a search session. Our approach integrates topic modeling and word embeddings to generate contextualized expansion terms, which are then weighted using a session-aware relevance scoring function. Experimental results on the TREC Session Track dataset demonstrate that HQE outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving significant improvements in session-level retrieval metrics.

title: Efficient Object Detection in Autonomous Vehicles using Hierarchical Attention-based YOLO
paper_abstract: Real-time object detection is a critical component of autonomous vehicle systems. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based YOLO (HAT-YOLO) framework that improves detection accuracy and efficiency in complex scenes. Our approach integrates a hierarchical attention mechanism that adaptively focuses on regions of interest, reducing computational overhead and improving robustness to occlusions and varying lighting conditions. Experimental results on the KITTI and Cityscapes datasets demonstrate that HAT-YOLO outperforms state-of-the-art detectors, achieving an average precision of 92.1% at 30 FPS on a single NVIDIA GPU.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Multi-Agent Systems using Auction-Based Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving global objectives. This paper proposes a decentralized auction-based mechanism, 'DAMA', which allocates tasks to agents based on their capabilities, availability, and communication costs. DAMA introduces a novel bidding strategy that incorporates graph-based task dependencies and agent expertise, ensuring efficient and adaptive allocation in dynamic environments. We evaluate DAMA on a real-world disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to existing centralized approaches.

title: Towards Explainable Reinforcement Learning: A Hierarchical Attention-Based Framework
paper_abstract: Explainability is a crucial aspect of trustworthy AI systems, particularly in reinforcement learning (RL) where agents make sequential decisions. We propose a novel hierarchical attention-based framework, 'HATRL', that provides interpretable explanations for RL policies. Our approach incorporates both spatial and temporal attention mechanisms to identify relevant state features and action influences. We evaluate HATRL on several benchmark environments, demonstrating improved transparency and fidelity of explanations compared to existing methods. Furthermore, we show that HATRL enables more effective human-AI collaboration and policy adaptation in complex decision-making scenarios.

title: Meta-Learning for Few-Shot Image Classification with Adaptive Task Embeddings
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when faced with novel tasks and limited data. This paper proposes a novel meta-learning approach, 'AdaptiveTaskEmbed', which leverages task embeddings to capture the underlying relationships between tasks. Our approach adaptively updates task embeddings based on the support set, allowing the model to better generalize to unseen tasks. We evaluate our method on several benchmark datasets, demonstrating significant improvements over state-of-the-art few-shot learning methods.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Dynamic Environments
paper_abstract: Cooperative task allocation in dynamic environments is a challenging problem that requires agents to adapt to changing circumstances while coordinating with each other. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning framework, 'DMARL-CTA', which enables agents to learn cooperative policies in a distributed manner. We introduce a novel communication protocol that facilitates information exchange between agents, and a modular neural network architecture that allows agents to update their policies independently. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario demonstrate that DMARL-CTA outperforms existing centralized and decentralized approaches in terms of task completion rate and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Decentralized Autonomous Systems for Real-time Traffic Management using Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel decentralized autonomous system for real-time traffic management using multi-agent reinforcement learning. Our approach leverages a hierarchical architecture, where local agents learn to optimize traffic signal control in response to real-time traffic conditions, while a central coordinator agent ensures global optimality through periodic interventions. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in a simulated urban traffic network, achieving a 23.4% reduction in average travel time and a 17.1% decrease in congestion duration compared to traditional traffic management systems.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Efficient Multi-Agent Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, task allocation is a critical problem that requires efficient and adaptive decision-making. This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) architecture that learns to allocate tasks to agents in a decentralized manner. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to model complex dependencies between agents and tasks, and hierarchically structures the attention weights to capture both local and global task relationships. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate that our HAN-based approach outperforms traditional optimization-based methods in terms of task completion time and overall system efficiency.

title: Designing Accessible Conversational Interfaces for Users with Dyslexia
paper_abstract: Conversational interfaces have become ubiquitous, but their design often neglects the needs of users with dyslexia. This paper presents a user-centered approach to designing accessible conversational interfaces that accommodate the unique challenges faced by users with dyslexia. We conducted a comprehensive study involving 30 participants with dyslexia, identifying three key areas of difficulty: text comprehension, speech recognition errors, and navigation complexity. Our proposed design framework, 'DyslexiaAware', incorporates multimodal input, personalized feedback, and simplified dialogue flows to improve user experience and task completion rates. A usability evaluation with 20 participants demonstrated significant improvements in user satisfaction and task efficiency compared to existing conversational interfaces.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Time Series Analysis
paper_abstract: Multi-modal time series data, which combines different sensor readings or data sources, is increasingly prevalent in various domains. This paper introduces a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture for effectively modeling complex dependencies in multi-modal time series data. HGAT employs a hierarchical graph structure to capture both local and global patterns, while attention mechanisms selectively focus on relevant modalities and time steps. Experimental results on several real-world datasets demonstrate HGAT's superiority in forecasting and anomaly detection tasks compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Deep Transfer Learning for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis in Low-Resource Domains
paper_abstract: Multimodal sentiment analysis is a challenging task, particularly in low-resource domains where annotated data is scarce. This paper proposes a novel deep transfer learning approach, 'ModaTL', which leverages pre-trained multimodal encoders and fine-tunes them on a small set of target domain data. We introduce a domain adaptation module that aligns the feature distributions of the source and target domains, enabling effective knowledge transfer. Experimental results on three low-resource datasets demonstrate that ModaTL outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 12% in terms of overall sentiment accuracy, while requiring significantly less target domain data.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Big Data Analytics using Machine Learning
paper_abstract: Query optimization is a crucial step in big data analytics, as it directly impacts query performance and system resource utilization. Traditional query optimization techniques rely on rule-based and cost-based approaches, which can be inefficient and inaccurate for complex queries. This paper proposes a novel machine learning-based query optimization framework, 'ML-QO', which leverages query execution plans and runtime statistics to predict optimal query plans. We develop a deep learning model that incorporates both syntactic and semantic features of queries, and demonstrate its effectiveness on a range of big data benchmarks. Experimental results show that ML-QO outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 3x in terms of query execution time and resource utilization.

title: Hierarchical Attention-Based Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel hierarchical attention-based multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for autonomous vehicle control. We propose a decentralized approach where each vehicle learns to communicate with its neighbors and negotiate control decisions based on its local observations. Our method utilizes attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant neighbors and filter out noisy information. Experimental results on a simulated autonomous driving environment demonstrate improved navigation efficiency, safety, and scalability compared to existing centralized and decentralized control methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Few-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Few-shot learning has gained significant attention in recent years, but most existing methods focus on single-label classification. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) for multi-label few-shot learning. HGAT leverages graph neural networks to model label relationships and attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant labels. We introduce a hierarchical label embedding strategy that captures label semantics at multiple granularities, enabling effective knowledge transfer between labels. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in multi-label few-shot learning scenarios.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Bayesian HyperNetworks
paper_abstract: Neural Architecture Search (NAS) has emerged as a promising paradigm for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing NAS methods often rely on computationally expensive reinforcement learning or evolutionary algorithms. This paper proposes a novel Bayesian HyperNetwork (BHN) approach that efficiently searches for high-performing architectures in a probabilistic manner. Our BHN framework learns to predict the performance of candidate architectures using a surrogate model, which is trained on a small set of evaluated architectures. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art NAS performance while reducing the computational cost by an order of magnitude.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Improving Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely heavily on effective passage retrieval to identify relevant information. We propose a novel query expansion approach, 'QE-Pro', which leverages a combination of semantic role labeling and contextualized embeddings to generate high-quality expansion terms. Our method outperforms existing query expansion techniques on the SQuAD and Natural Questions datasets, achieving significant improvements in passage retrieval accuracy and downstream QA performance. We also provide an in-depth analysis of the benefits and limitations of QE-Pro, highlighting its robustness to out-of-vocabulary terms and domain shift.

title: Coordinating Multi-Agent Systems with Hierarchical Task Networks
paper_abstract: Coordinating multi-agent systems (MAS) to achieve complex tasks is a challenging problem. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical task network (HTN) approach to coordinate MAS. We introduce a graph-based representation of the task hierarchy, which enables agents to reason about task dependencies and allocate resources efficiently. Our approach is evaluated on a real-world disaster response scenario, where multiple agents must collaborate to rescue people and extinguish fires. Experimental results show that our HTN-based approach outperforms traditional planning-based methods in terms of task completion time and resource utilization.

title: Neural Re-ranking with Attention-based Query Document Interaction for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in information retrieval, particularly when dealing with complex queries and long documents. This paper proposes a novel neural re-ranking approach that leverages attention-based query document interaction to capture fine-grained semantic relationships between queries and documents. Our model, called QR-AttRank, utilizes a hierarchical attention mechanism to selectively focus on relevant query terms and document segments, and then integrates these interactions to produce a more accurate ranking. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that QR-AttRank significantly outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving a 15% improvement in terms of NDCG@10.

title: Designing Accessible Voice Assistants for Older Adults: A Participatory Design Approach
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have the potential to improve the daily lives of older adults, but existing systems often fail to account for age-related changes in cognition, hearing, and speech. This paper presents a participatory design approach to creating accessible voice assistants tailored to the needs of older adults. We conducted co-design workshops with 15 older adults and identified key design recommendations, including simplified voice commands, personalized feedback mechanisms, and error correction strategies. We implemented these recommendations in a prototype voice assistant and evaluated its usability with 20 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion rates and user satisfaction.

title: Explainable Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Vehicle Control
paper_abstract: Autonomous vehicles rely heavily on reinforcement learning (RL) to navigate complex scenarios. However, the lack of interpretability in RL models hinders their widespread adoption. This paper proposes a novel framework, 'ExpRL', which incorporates explainability techniques into RL for autonomous vehicle control. We introduce a model-agnostic explanation method that generates visual explanations of the RL agent's decision-making process. Our experiments on a real-world autonomous driving dataset demonstrate that ExpRL improves the transparency and accountability of RL models, leading to safer and more efficient vehicle control.

title: Hierarchical Attention Network for Efficient Time-Series Forecasting
paper_abstract: Time-series forecasting is a crucial task in various domains, including finance, healthcare, and energy. However, existing models often struggle with long-range dependencies, seasonality, and variable importance. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) that tackles these challenges by incorporating multi-level attention mechanisms. HAN consists of a hierarchical encoder that captures local and global patterns, followed by a decoder that generates forecasts using attention-weighted representations. Experimental results on four benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of HAN, outperforming state-of-the-art models in terms of accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Agent Planning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent planning has become increasingly important in real-world applications, but the lack of interpretability in current models hinders their adoption. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework that integrates planning and explanation in a unified architecture. Our approach leverages attention mechanisms to model complex interactions between agents and objects, while generating interpretable explanations for the plans generated. We evaluate our approach on a series of benchmark scenarios, demonstrating improved planning performance and enhanced explainability compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Deep Neural Architecture Search for Efficient Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis
paper_abstract: Sentiment analysis is a crucial task in natural language processing, but existing approaches often rely on manually designed models that are computationally expensive and limited to specific modalities. This paper presents a novel deep neural architecture search framework, 'MultiModalNAS', which automatically discovers efficient and effective architectures for multi-modal sentiment analysis. Our method leverages a hierarchical search space and a novel multi-objective reward function to optimize both accuracy and inference time. Experimental results on a benchmark dataset demonstrate that MultiModalNAS achieves state-of-the-art performance on sentiment analysis tasks while reducing inference time by up to 3.5x compared to existing approaches.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Semantic Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval systems, but existing methods often rely on manual feature engineering or expensive annotation processes. This paper proposes a neural semantic embedding-based approach, 'NeuroExpand', which learns to capture nuanced relationships between query terms and documents. Our method leverages a multi-task learning framework to jointly optimize query expansion and retrieval performance. Experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuroExpand outperforms state-of-the-art techniques, achieving significant improvements in recall and precision while reducing the need for manual tuning.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Analytics on Distributed Column-Stores
paper_abstract: The increasing adoption of column-store databases for real-time analytics poses significant query optimization challenges. This paper presents 'CQN', a novel query optimization framework that leverages machine learning and graph-based methods to minimize query latency. CQN incorporates a cost-based optimization strategy that considers both data distribution and storage layouts, as well as a lightweight neural network to predict query execution times. Experimental evaluations on a 100-node cluster demonstrate that CQN outperforms state-of-the-art optimizers by up to 3.5x in query response times, while maintaining comparable resource utilization.

title: Decentralized Negotiation Protocols for Multi-Agent Systems with Incomplete Information
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, negotiation protocols enable agents to reach mutually beneficial agreements. However, existing protocols often assume complete information about the agents' preferences and utilities. This paper proposes a novel decentralized negotiation protocol, 'INCOP', which accommodates incomplete information and uncertainty. INCOP leverages Bayesian learning and iterative refinement to enable agents to update their beliefs and negotiate effectively. We evaluate INCOP through extensive simulations, demonstrating its robustness and efficacy in various scenarios, including those with heterogeneous agent populations and dynamic utility functions.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Personalization for Users with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous, but their interaction designs often neglect users with speech disabilities, such as dysarthria. This paper presents a user-centered design approach to create personalized voice assistants for individuals with dysarthria. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving 20 participants with dysarthria, identifying key challenges and preferences in voice interaction. Our proposed framework, 'VoiceAdapt', incorporates acoustic and linguistic adaptation, as well as user profiling, to improve recognition accuracy and interaction experience. A pilot study demonstrates significant improvements in user satisfaction and task completion rates compared to existing voice assistants.

title: Graph Attention Networks for Explainable Recommendation Systems
paper_abstract: Recommendation systems have become ubiquitous, but their opacity hinders user trust. This paper proposes a novel graph attention network (GAT) architecture, 'ExploRe', which generates personalized recommendations while providing interpretability. By incorporating attention mechanisms on user-item graphs, ExploRe identifies influential items and highlights relevant features, enabling users to understand the reasoning behind the suggested items. Our experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that ExploRe outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of recommendation accuracy and user satisfaction, while offering explainable insights into the recommendation process.

title: Query Optimization for Dynamic Graph Databases using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Graph databases have become increasingly popular for storing and querying complex relationships between data entities. However, optimizing queries in dynamic graph databases remains a challenging problem due to the constantly changing graph structure. This paper proposes a novel approach to query optimization using reinforcement learning (RL). We design an RL agent that learns to optimize queries by interacting with the graph database and receiving rewards based on query execution time. Experimental results on a real-world graph dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 30% in terms of query execution time.

title: Efficient Neural Ranking Models for Passage Retrieval in Dense Vector Spaces
paper_abstract: Traditional passage retrieval methods rely on sparse bag-of-words representations, which fail to capture nuanced semantic relationships. This paper presents a novel neural ranking model, 'DenseRank', that leverages dense vector spaces to improve retrieval accuracy. By incorporating a learned similarity metric and a hierarchical attention mechanism, DenseRank outperforms state-of-the-art methods on several benchmark datasets. We also propose an efficient indexing scheme that reduces computational overhead during inference, making DenseRank suitable for large-scale applications.

title: Adversarial Attack Detection in Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) have been shown to be vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their reliability and security. This paper proposes a novel approach to detect adversarial attacks in DNNs using Bayesian neural networks (BNNs). Our method, 'BayesDetect', leverages the uncertainty estimation capabilities of BNNs to identify input samples that are likely to be adversarial. We evaluate BayesDetect on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its effectiveness in detecting a wide range of attacks, including FGSM, PGD, and CW attacks. Our results show that BayesDetect outperforms existing detection methods, achieving an average detection accuracy of 95.2% across all datasets.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Embeddings for Sparse Queries in Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Sparse queries in Information Retrieval (IR) systems often lead to inadequate retrieval performance. Query expansion techniques can alleviate this issue, but existing methods rely on term co-occurrence statistics or manual thesauri, which may not capture semantic relationships between terms. This paper proposes a neural embedding-based query expansion approach, 'Neuxpand', which leverages pre-trained language models to learn dense vector representations of terms. Our method adapts to the query context by generating context-aware embeddings, allowing for more precise expansion. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval performance over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Efficient Neural Architecture Search with Evolutionary Multi-Objective Optimization
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising approach for automated machine learning model design. However, existing methods often rely on computationally expensive evaluation metrics or surrogate models. This paper proposes a novel evolutionary multi-objective optimization (EMO) framework for NAS, which simultaneously optimizes multiple conflicting objectives such as model accuracy, latency, and energy consumption. Our approach leverages a population-based search strategy with adaptive mutation and crossover operators, enabling efficient exploration of the vast architecture space. Experiments on benchmark image classification tasks demonstrate that our EMO-NAS method yields competitive performance to state-of-the-art NAS algorithms at a significantly reduced computational cost.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Deep Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Resource Allocation
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents for resource allocation tasks using deep hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL). We introduce a hierarchical framework, 'AgentCoord', which consists of a high-level coordinator that learns to allocate resources and a set of low-level agents that execute tasks. The coordinator uses a deep Q-network to learn a policy for resource allocation, while the agents employ deep deterministic policy gradients to optimize their task execution. Experimental results on a simulated grid-world environment demonstrate that AgentCoord outperforms traditional decentralized approaches in terms of resource utilization and task completion rate.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Cooperative Task Allocation in Autonomous Systems
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for cooperative task allocation in autonomous systems. Our approach, called MARL-TA, leverages deep Q-networks to learn decentralized policies for task assignment and scheduling. We introduce a new reward function that balances individual agent performance with global system efficiency, and demonstrate improved robustness to agent failures and environmental uncertainties. Experimental results on a simulated search-and-rescue scenario show that MARL-TA outperforms baseline methods in terms of task completion rate and overall system utility.

title: Hybrid Indexing for Efficient Retrieval of Multi-Modal Data
paper_abstract: The proliferation of multi-modal data has led to a surge in the demand for efficient retrieval systems. Existing indexing techniques, however, are often tailored to specific data types, resulting in suboptimal performance when applied to mixed-modal datasets. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing framework, 'MM-HI', which seamlessly integrates inverted indexing and hierarchical clustering to facilitate fast and accurate retrieval of multi-modal data. Our comprehensive evaluation on a large-scale dataset demonstrates that MM-HI outperforms state-of-the-art methods by up to 30% in terms of query latency while maintaining high retrieval accuracy.

title: Scalable Entity Disambiguation using Graph-Based Embeddings for Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs (KGs) have become a crucial component in various AI applications, but entity disambiguation remains a challenging task. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GEDIS', which leverages graph-based embeddings to disambiguate entities in large-scale KGs. By incorporating structural and semantic information from KGs, GEDIS learns to represent entities as dense vectors, enabling efficient disambiguation. Experimental results on popular KG benchmarks demonstrate that GEDIS outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of precision, recall, and F1-score, while scaling to large datasets.
