title: Gestural Interaction Design for Augmented Reality-based Cognitive Training
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel gestural interaction design for augmented reality (AR)-based cognitive training systems. We propose a taxonomy of gestures that leverages hand and finger movements to facilitate cognitive exercises, such as attention, memory, and executive function tasks. A user study with 30 participants demonstrates that our gestural interface improves engagement, enjoyment, and cognitive performance compared to traditional keyboard-mouse inputs. We also investigate the effects of gesture complexity and feedback on user experience and cognitive outcomes, providing insights for designing effective AR-based cognitive training systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Label Node Classification
paper_abstract: Graph-structured data has become ubiquitous in various domains, and node classification is a fundamental task in graph analysis. However, existing methods often struggle with multi-label node classification, where each node can belong to multiple classes. We propose a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) that leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture both local and global patterns in the graph. HGAT consists of a hierarchical encoder that aggregates node features at multiple scales, followed by a multi-label classifier. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of F1-score and AUC-PR, especially on datasets with diverse label distributions.

title: Enhanced Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval systems, as it enables more accurate matching between user queries and relevant documents. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages deep neural networks to learn semantic relationships between words and phrases. Our model uses a combination of word embeddings and convolutional neural networks to generate expanded queries that better capture the user's intent. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms existing query expansion techniques, improving retrieval effectiveness by up to 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Query Graph Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval systems often struggle to capture the nuances of user queries, leading to suboptimal retrieval performance. We propose a novel neural query graph embedding (NQGE) framework that learns to represent user queries as dense vectors in a semantic space. By incorporating query graph features, our approach effectively captures query relationships and contextual dependencies. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 dataset demonstrate that NQGE-based query expansion outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving a 15% increase in mean average precision. Our approach has significant implications for improving the effectiveness of ad-hoc retrieval systems.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Anomaly Detection in Multivariate Time Series
paper_abstract: Anomaly detection in multivariate time series (MTS) data is a crucial task in various applications, including finance, healthcare, and IoT. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture for MTS anomaly detection. HGAT leverages graph attention mechanisms to model complex relationships between variables and capture hierarchical patterns in MTS data. We evaluate HGAT on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods in terms of detection accuracy and efficiency. Our approach is particularly effective in identifying anomalies in high-dimensional MTS data with complex correlations.

title: Designing Adaptive Gesture Recognition Systems for Elderly Users
paper_abstract: Gesture recognition systems have the potential to improve the quality of life for elderly individuals by enabling intuitive interactions with digital devices. However, existing systems often struggle to accommodate the varying abilities and needs of this demographic. This paper presents a novel approach to adaptive gesture recognition that incorporates user modeling, gesture segmentation, and real-time feedback. We evaluate our system with a user study involving 30 elderly participants and demonstrate significant improvements in recognition accuracy and user satisfaction. Our findings inform the design of inclusive HCI systems that can support the diverse needs of aging populations.

title: Hybrid Multi-Agent Systems for Adaptive Traffic Signal Control
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel hybrid multi-agent system (HMAS) for adaptive traffic signal control. The HMAS integrates decentralized autonomous agents with a centralized optimization framework to optimize traffic signal timings in real-time. We develop a novel communication protocol that enables agents to share local traffic information and coordinate their actions to minimize congestion and reduce travel times. Simulation results on a real-world traffic network demonstrate that the HMAS outperforms traditional fixed-time and decentralized signal control methods, achieving an average reduction of 23.4% in travel times during peak hours.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Resource Allocation in Edge Computing Environments
paper_abstract: The proliferation of edge computing has introduced significant challenges in resource allocation, particularly in scenarios with dynamic workloads and heterogeneous devices. This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, 'EdgeOpt', which learns to optimize resource allocation in edge computing environments. EdgeOpt employs a hierarchical architecture that combines graph neural networks with deep Q-networks, enabling efficient allocation of computing resources, memory, and bandwidth. Experimental results on a real-world edge computing testbed demonstrate that EdgeOpt outperforms state-of-the-art heuristic-based approaches, achieving improved response times, reduced latency, and enhanced resource utilization.

title: Scalable Multi-Agent Task Allocation with Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent task allocation is a challenging problem in distributed systems, where agents must coordinate to complete tasks while minimizing communication overhead. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'DeepMARL', which leverages deep reinforcement learning to learn decentralized task allocation policies. Our algorithm combines graph attention networks with multi-agent Q-learning to efficiently allocate tasks to agents in large-scale systems. Experiments on a simulated logistics scenario demonstrate that DeepMARL outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of task completion time and communication efficiency, making it a promising solution for real-world applications.

title: Enhancing Deep Retrieval Models with Hierarchical Query Embeddings for Ad-hoc Search
paper_abstract: Deep retrieval models have improved ad-hoc search performance, but often struggle to capture the nuanced semantics of complex queries. This paper introduces Hierarchical Query Embeddings (HQE), a novel approach that represents queries as hierarchical graphs of word and phrase embeddings. We show that incorporating HQE into a state-of-the-art deep retrieval model significantly improves retrieval effectiveness, particularly for challenging queries with multiple entities and relationships. Our experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate the robustness and generalizability of HQE, outperforming existing query embedding methods in various evaluation settings.

title: Efficient Document Ranking with Neural Query Graph Attention
paper_abstract: This paper introduces Neural Query Graph Attention (NQGA), a novel ranking model that leverages graph attention mechanisms to capture complex query-document relationships. NQGA represents queries as graphs, where nodes correspond to query terms and edges encode semantic relationships. We propose a neural attention module that adaptively weights edge importance, enabling the model to focus on relevant query-document interactions. Experimental results on the TREC Robust04 and ClueWeb09 datasets demonstrate that NQGA outperforms state-of-the-art neural ranking models, achieving significant improvements in terms of NDCG and ERR metrics.

title: Investigating the Effects of Embodiment on Human-Robot Collaboration in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize human-robot collaboration (HRC) by providing a shared, immersive environment for humans and robots to interact. However, the role of embodiment in VR-based HRC remains largely unexplored. This study investigates how different levels of embodiment in VR affect human trust, communication, and task performance in HRC. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, who collaborated with a robot in a virtual furniture assembly task. Our results show that higher levels of embodiment lead to increased trust and more effective communication, resulting in improved task performance. These findings have implications for the design of VR-based HRC systems that can facilitate more effective human-robot collaboration.

title: Query Expansion via Graph-based Semantic Embeddings for Efficient Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, as it can significantly impact the precision and recall of search results. This paper proposes a novel graph-based approach to query expansion, leveraging semantic embeddings to capture nuanced relationships between terms. Our method, dubbed 'GraphExpan', represents the query and its expansion candidates as nodes in a graph, where edge weights are learned from a large corpus of text. We demonstrate that GraphExpan outperforms traditional query expansion techniques, such as Rocchio and relevance feedback, on several benchmark datasets, while requiring fewer computational resources.

title: Decentralized Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Cooperative multi-agent systems have applications in various domains, including robotics, autonomous vehicles, and smart cities. This paper proposes a decentralized task allocation framework for such systems, using reinforcement learning to optimize the allocation process. Our approach, called 'MACTOR', leverages a distributed, asynchronous Q-learning algorithm to enable agents to learn from their experiences and adapt to changing environments. Experimental results demonstrate that MACTOR outperforms traditional, centralized allocation methods in terms of task completion efficiency and system resilience, especially in scenarios with partial observability and uncertainty.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranking for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) systems rely on effective query expansion to retrieve relevant passages. We propose a novel neural re-ranking approach, QRex, which leverages BERT-based semantic representations to refine the query expansion process. QRex learns to identify and weight informative keywords, reducing the impact of noisy terms and improving the quality of the retrieved passages. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that QRex outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 12% increase in Top-1 accuracy and a 20% improvement in Mean Average Precision.

title: Decentralized Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In dynamic environments, task allocation among multiple agents is a challenging problem due to the uncertainty and volatility of task requirements. This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework that enables agents to learn optimal task allocation policies without explicit communication. We introduce a novel graph-based attention mechanism that captures task relationships and agent capabilities, facilitating efficient task allocation. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in adapting to changing task demands and improving overall system efficiency.

title: Decentralized Trust Management for Multi-Agent Systems using Blockchain-based Reputation Mechanisms
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, trust management is crucial for ensuring reliable interactions and decision-making. This paper proposes a decentralized trust management framework, 'BlockTrust', which leverages blockchain technology to establish a transparent and tamper-proof reputation mechanism. BlockTrust enables agents to rate and evaluate each other's behavior, and reputation scores are stored on a blockchain, allowing for secure and efficient trust computation. We evaluate the performance of BlockTrust in a simulated multi-agent environment, demonstrating its effectiveness in detecting and mitigating malicious behavior.

title: Hierarchical Bayesian Neural Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data, such as speech, text, and vision, is a challenging task due to the inherent complexity and heterogeneity of the data. This paper proposes a Hierarchical Bayesian Neural Network (H-BNN) framework that models the uncertainty in the data and the relationships between different modalities. Our approach leverages Bayesian deep learning to learn modality-specific and shared representations, and performs hierarchical inference to recognize emotions. Experimental results on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of H-BNN in achieving state-of-the-art performance in multi-modal emotion recognition tasks.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Data Warehouses using Hybrid Indexing Techniques
paper_abstract: Data warehousing has become an essential component of business intelligence, but query optimization remains a significant bottleneck. This paper proposes a novel hybrid indexing technique, 'HIQ', that combines the benefits of B+ trees and bitmap indexing. HIQ dynamically adjusts the indexing strategy based on query patterns, data distribution, and storage constraints. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that HIQ achieves an average query performance improvement of 35% compared to traditional indexing methods, while reducing storage overhead by 20%. We also provide theoretical bounds on the optimality of HIQ under various query workloads.

title: Meta-Learning with Graph Neural Networks for Few-Shot Image Classification
paper_abstract: Few-shot image classification remains a challenging problem in machine learning, particularly when faced with limited labeled data. This paper presents a novel meta-learning approach that leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn a task-agnostic representation for image classification. Our method, dubbed 'MetaGNN', adaptively constructs a graph structure from the support set and queries, enabling effective knowledge transfer across tasks. We demonstrate the efficacy of MetaGNN on several benchmark datasets, achieving state-of-the-art performance in few-shot classification scenarios.

title: Eye-Gaze Based Adaptive Gesture Recognition for Inclusive Interfaces
paper_abstract: This paper presents an innovative approach to gesture recognition that leverages eye-gaze information to improve the accuracy and accessibility of inclusive interfaces. Our system, called 'GazeGuide', uses a multimodal fusion of eye-tracking data and computer vision-based hand tracking to recognize gestures in real-time. We propose a novel adaptive framework that adjusts the recognition model based on the user's gaze patterns, enhancing the system's robustness to individual differences and variability in gesture execution. Experimental results with participants with and without motor impairments demonstrate the effectiveness of GazeGuide in facilitating more accurate and efficient gesture recognition.

title: Exploiting Graph Neural Networks for Efficient Query Optimization in Distributed Databases
paper_abstract: Modern distributed databases rely on query optimization to minimize latency and improve performance. However, existing optimization techniques often fail to capture complex relationships between data entities. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'GraphOpt', which leverages graph neural networks (GNNs) to learn query optimization strategies. By modeling database schema and query graphs, GraphOpt identifies efficient execution plans that reduce query latency by up to 40% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques. We evaluate GraphOpt on a real-world distributed database benchmark and demonstrate its effectiveness in handling complex queries.

title: Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Analytics in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Real-time data analytics has become a crucial aspect of modern applications, necessitating efficient query optimization techniques for distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel approach, 'QOpt', which leverages machine learning-based models to predict query execution times and optimize query plans accordingly. We propose a hierarchical clustering algorithm to group queries based on their execution patterns and develop a cost-based optimization framework that incorporates these predictions. Experimental results on a large-scale distributed database system demonstrate that QOpt achieves an average query response time reduction of 35% compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques.

title: Efficient Indexing of Hierarchical Neural Networks for Scalable Image Retrieval
paper_abstract: Hierarchical neural networks have shown remarkable performance in image retrieval tasks, but their computational complexity hinders large-scale deployment. This paper presents a novel indexing technique, 'HNN-Index', which enables efficient similarity search and retrieval of images in massive datasets. By exploiting the hierarchical structure of the neural network, HNN-Index reduces the search space and accelerates the computation of similarity metrics. Experimental results on the ImageNet dataset demonstrate that HNN-Index achieves a 5x speedup over existing indexing methods while maintaining comparable retrieval accuracy.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Neural Re-ranking for Information Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial step in information retrieval, which aims to enhance the retrieval performance by adding relevant terms to the original query. Traditional methods rely on statistical techniques, but they often suffer from noise and ambiguity. In this paper, we propose a neural re-ranking approach, which leverages a deep neural network to learn the semantic relationships between query terms and documents. Our method, called NeuralQE, first generates a set of expansion terms using a language model, and then re-ranks the candidate terms based on their semantic similarity to the original query. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that NeuralQE significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a relative improvement of 15% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Virtual Reality Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) systems often rely on manual controllers or simplistic gaze-based interfaces, limiting the sense of immersion. We propose a novel gaze-based interaction framework that leverages deep reinforcement learning to predict user intentions and generate intuitive control signals. Our approach combines a convolutional neural network (CNN) with a deep Q-network (DQN) to learn a policy that maps gaze patterns to precise actions in the VR environment. Experimental results demonstrate improved interaction accuracy and user satisfaction compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Decentralized Coalition Formation for Task Allocation in Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: Task allocation is a fundamental problem in multi-agent systems, where autonomous agents need to coordinate to achieve common goals. This paper presents a decentralized coalition formation algorithm, called CoFoTAS, which enables agents to dynamically form coalitions and allocate tasks based on their capabilities and availability. CoFoTAS leverages a distributed constraint optimization framework to ensure that the formed coalitions are feasible and efficient. Experimental results on a logistics transportation scenario demonstrate that CoFoTAS outperforms existing decentralized task allocation algorithms in terms of solution quality and scalability.

title: Enhancing Query Expansion with Deep Neural Embeddings for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion (QE) is a crucial step in ad-hoc retrieval, but traditional methods often rely on simplistic term weighting schemes. This paper explores the integration of deep neural embeddings with QE to improve retrieval effectiveness. We propose a novel framework, 'EmbExpan', which leverages pre-trained language models to generate contextualized term representations. These embeddings are then combined with a weighted term ranking algorithm to produce an expanded query. Experimental results on the TREC-8 and Robust04 datasets demonstrate significant improvements in mean average precision and normalized discounted cumulative gain over state-of-the-art QE methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion for Entity Retrieval in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Entity retrieval in knowledge graphs (KGs) is a crucial task in various applications, including question answering and recommendation systems. However, the performance of KG-based entity retrieval models is often hindered by the limited scope of user queries. This paper presents a novel query expansion approach, 'KG-Expand', which leverages the semantics and structure of KGs to generate relevant expansion terms. KG-Expand combines a graph attention mechanism with a mutual information-based ranking function to select the most informative expansion terms. Our experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that KG-Expand significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a relative improvement of up to 23% in terms of mean average precision.

title: Designing Inclusive Voice Assistants: A Study on Spoken Language Understanding for Individuals with Dysarthria
paper_abstract: Voice assistants have become ubiquitous in modern life, but their effectiveness for individuals with speech and language disorders remains limited. This paper presents a comprehensive study on spoken language understanding for individuals with dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by impaired articulation and intelligibility. We develop a novel acoustic model that leverages transfer learning and attention mechanisms to improve speech recognition accuracy for individuals with dysarthria. Our user study with 30 participants demonstrates significant improvements in voice assistant interaction quality and user satisfaction, thereby enhancing the accessibility of these systems for individuals with dysarthria.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Neuroimaging Analysis
paper_abstract: Recent advances in neuroimaging have generated large-scale, multi-modal datasets that require effective analysis techniques. This paper introduces a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture for integrating functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), structural MRI, and electroencephalography (EEG) data. HGAT leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant graph structures and modalities, enabling the discovery of complex brain connectivity patterns. We evaluate our approach on a large-scale neuroimaging dataset and demonstrate improved performance in predicting cognitive task outcomes compared to existing multi-modal fusion methods.

title: Hybrid Attention Network for Explainable Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition
paper_abstract: Emotion recognition from multi-modal data (e.g., speech, text, vision) is a challenging task due to the complexity of emotional expressions. Existing approaches often rely on deep neural networks, which lack interpretability. We propose a hybrid attention network (HAN) that integrates neural and symbolic representations to recognize emotions from multi-modal input. HAN leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant modalities and features, enabling explainable emotion recognition. Our experiments on the CMU-MOSEI dataset demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy and provides transparent insights into the emotional cues used for recognition.

title: EyeGazeType: A Gaze-Based Typing System for Users with Motor Impairments
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments often face significant challenges when interacting with computers. This paper presents EyeGazeType, a novel gaze-based typing system that enables users to type efficiently and accurately using only their eye movements. Our approach leverages a combination of machine learning and computer vision techniques to detect and recognize gaze patterns, allowing users to select characters and compose sentences. We evaluate EyeGazeType through a user study with 15 participants, demonstrating an average typing speed of 15 words per minute with an error rate of less than 5%. The results show promising applications for EyeGazeType in facilitating communication and enhancing quality of life for individuals with motor impairments.

title: Optimizing Query Performance for Distributed Database Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly popular for handling large-scale data storage and querying. However, optimizing query performance in DDS remains a challenging task due to the complexity of distributed query planning and execution. This paper proposes a novel approach that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to optimize query performance in DDS. We design an RL agent that learns to select the optimal query plan based on the system's state and query workload. Experimental results on a real-world DDS benchmark show that our approach outperforms traditional query optimization techniques by up to 40% in terms of query execution time.

title: Co-Tuning Neural Architecture Search with Hyperparameter Optimization for Efficient Deep Learning Models
paper_abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a promising technique for automating the design of deep neural networks. However, existing NAS methods often neglect the crucial role of hyperparameter optimization (HPO), leading to suboptimal performance and computational inefficiencies. This paper introduces CoTune, a novel framework that jointly optimizes neural architectures and hyperparameters using a differentiable search space. We demonstrate that CoTune achieves state-of-the-art performance on various image classification benchmarks while reducing the computational overhead of NAS by up to 75%. Furthermore, we provide insights into the interplay between architecture and hyperparameter search, highlighting the importance of co-tuning for efficient deep learning model development.

title: Designing and Evaluating Accessible Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to improve the quality of life for older adults, but existing VR interfaces often neglect accessibility considerations. This paper presents the design, development, and evaluation of an accessible VR interface tailored to the needs of older adults. Our interface incorporates several novel features, including voice-controlled navigation, high-contrast visual cues, and personalized font sizes. We conducted a usability study with 20 older adults, demonstrating significant improvements in task completion time and user satisfaction compared to commercial VR systems. Our findings provide actionable insights for designing inclusive VR experiences that cater to the diverse needs of older adults.

title: Auction-Based Task Allocation for Cooperative Multi-Agent Systems
paper_abstract: This paper addresses the task allocation problem in cooperative multi-agent systems, where agents with varying capabilities and resource constraints need to collectively accomplish complex tasks. We propose a novel auction-based framework, 'CoopAuction', which enables agents to bid for tasks based on their expected utilities. Our approach incorporates a probabilistic task model, allowing agents to reason about uncertainty and risk in task execution. Experimental results on a realistic autonomous vehicle scenario demonstrate that CoopAuction outperforms existing allocation methods in terms of system-wide efficiency, fairness, and adaptability to changing environments.

title: Efficient Indexing for Multi-Dimensional Range Queries on Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed database systems (DDS) are increasingly used to store and manage large-scale datasets. Efficient processing of multi-dimensional range queries is critical in various applications. This paper proposes a novel indexing technique, 'DRIQUE', which leverages a combination of bit-sliced indexing and hierarchical clustering to accelerate query processing on DDS. Our experiments on a real-world climate dataset demonstrate that DRIQUE outperforms existing indexing methods by up to 3x in terms of query response time, while maintaining a competitive storage overhead.

title: Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation in Smart Grids
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for dynamic task allocation in smart grids. We consider a scenario where multiple agents, each representing a microgrid, must allocate tasks (e.g., energy storage, generation, and consumption) to optimize overall grid efficiency. Our approach leverages a novel graph-based representation of the grid topology and a hierarchical deep reinforcement learning architecture to learn optimal task allocation policies. Experimental results on a simulated smart grid environment demonstrate improved efficiency, scalability, and adaptability compared to traditional centralized optimization methods.

title: Hierarchical Clustering of Time Series Data using Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Time series data is ubiquitous in many applications, including finance, healthcare, and climate science. However, clustering time series data remains a challenging task due to its high dimensionality and complex patterns. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical clustering approach that leverages the representational power of deep neural networks. Our method, called HierTS, uses a combination of convolutional neural networks and recurrent neural networks to extract robust features from time series data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that HierTS outperforms state-of-the-art clustering algorithms in terms of clustering quality and scalability.

title: Neural Query Expansion for Ad-hoc Retrieval using Cross-Modal Attention
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval suffers from the vocabulary mismatch problem, where the query and document terms do not align. We propose a neural query expansion approach, 'CrossQA', that leverages cross-modal attention to incorporate visual features from images and videos into the query representation. Our model consists of a multimodal encoder that generates a joint query-document embedding space, and a query expansion module that predicts relevant terms based on the attention weights. Experimental results on the TREC-CAR dataset show that CrossQA significantly outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods, achieving a 15% improvement in mean average precision.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multidimensional Arrays in Distributed Database Systems
paper_abstract: The increasing popularity of multidimensional arrays in various domains demands efficient query optimization techniques for distributed database systems. This paper presents a novel query optimization framework, 'ArrayOpt', that leverages a combination of array restructuring, data partitioning, and parallel query execution to minimize query response times. We introduce a cost model that accurately estimates the optimization benefits and demonstrate the effectiveness of ArrayOpt using a real-world climate dataset. Experimental results show that ArrayOpt achieves up to 3x speedup compared to state-of-the-art query optimization techniques for multidimensional arrays.

title: Efficient Document Ranking using Deep Learning-based Query Expansion
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in information retrieval systems, as it aims to reformulate the original query to better capture user intent. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'DeepQE', which leverages a combination of convolutional and recurrent neural networks to learn semantic query representations. DeepQE is designed to adapt to varying query lengths and complexities, and can effectively handle out-of-vocabulary terms and synonyms. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of both precision and recall.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning for Urban Traffic Management
paper_abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to coordinating autonomous agents for urban traffic management using hierarchical reinforcement learning. We propose a two-level framework, where high-level agents learn to optimize traffic signal control policies, while low-level agents adapt to real-time traffic conditions using deep Q-networks. Our approach leverages graph neural networks to model traffic dynamics and incorporates domain knowledge to improve the coordination of agents. Experimental results on a simulated urban traffic network demonstrate a significant reduction in travel times and increased traffic flow compared to traditional control methods.

title: Deep Query Expansion for Improving Passage Retrieval in Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) models rely on passage retrieval to gather relevant information for answering user queries. However, the retrieval stage often suffers from vocabulary mismatch and semantic ambiguity, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a deep query expansion (DQE) framework that leverages a combination of semantic and syntactic analysis to generate high-quality, context-aware query expansions. Our experiments on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that DQE improves passage retrieval accuracy by 12.3% and boosts overall ODQA performance by 7.5% compared to state-of-the-art baselines.

title: Efficient Query Expansion via Semantic Similarity Graphs for Ad-hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Query expansion is a crucial component in ad-hoc retrieval, aiming to augment the original query with relevant terms to improve retrieval effectiveness. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'SemExpan', which leverages semantic similarity graphs to identify related terms. By modeling the query and document terms as nodes in a graph, we compute their semantic similarities using graph convolutional networks. Experimental results on the TREC benchmarks demonstrate that SemExpan outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion methods in terms of precision and recall, while reducing the computational overhead.

title: Hierarchical Semantic Indexing for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed document retrieval systems face significant scalability challenges in indexing and querying large document collections. This paper presents a novel hierarchical semantic indexing approach, 'HSI-DR', which leverages semantic embeddings to organize documents into a hierarchical structure. HSI-DR reduces the indexing time by 30% and query latency by 25% compared to state-of-the-art distributed indexing methods, while maintaining retrieval accuracy. We evaluate HSI-DR on a real-world dataset of 100 million documents and demonstrate its effectiveness in supporting complex queries and faceted search.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Real-Time Data Warehouses using Column-Store Indexing
paper_abstract: Real-time data warehouses require efficient query optimization to support fast and accurate decision-making. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'COIX', which leverages column-store indexing to reduce query latency. We introduce a cost-based optimization algorithm that considers both data compression and storage layout to minimize I/O operations. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that COIX achieves an average query performance improvement of 3.5x compared to traditional row-store indexing, while maintaining comparable storage efficiency.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Multi-Modal Emotion Recognition in Conversational Agents
paper_abstract: Conversational agents require accurate emotion recognition to respond empathetically. We propose a novel Hierarchical Attention Network (HAN) architecture that integrates multimodal features from speech, text, and facial expressions to recognize emotions in human-agent conversations. Our HAN model captures both local and global dependencies across modalities, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the IEMOCAP dataset. We also introduce a new metric, Emotion Recognition F1-score (ERF1), to evaluate the model's ability to recognize subtle emotions. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach in improving conversational agents' emotional intelligence.

title: Adversarial Training for Robustness in Transfer Learning of Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Transfer learning has become a de facto standard for deploying deep neural networks in various applications. However, recent studies have shown that these models are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can compromise their performance and reliability. This paper proposes a novel adversarial training framework for transfer learning, dubbed 'AdvTune', which leverages the concept of meta-learning to adapt to different attack scenarios. Experimental results on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdvTune significantly improves the robustness of pre-trained models against various types of adversarial attacks, without sacrificing their original performance.

title: Efficient Hierarchical Clustering for High-Dimensional Data using Deep Embedded Forests
paper_abstract: Hierarchical clustering is a fundamental task in data analysis, but its application to high-dimensional data is hindered by scalability issues. This paper proposes a novel approach, Deep Embedded Forests (DEF), which leverages the strength of deep learning and random forests to efficiently cluster high-dimensional data. DEF uses a deep autoencoder to learn a low-dimensional representation of the data, followed by a random forest-based clustering algorithm that exploits the hierarchical structure of the data. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that DEF outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of clustering quality and computational efficiency.

title: Quantifying Relevance Feedback in Neural Retrieval Models for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Neural retrieval models have revolutionized open-domain question answering by leveraging large-scale datasets and deep learning architectures. However, their performance is often hindered by the lack of explicit relevance feedback from users. This paper proposes a novel approach to incorporating relevance feedback into neural retrieval models, using a multi-task learning framework that jointly optimizes retrieval and relevance prediction. We develop a large-scale dataset of annotated relevance labels and demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval accuracy and efficiency on several benchmark datasets. Our approach enables more effective and efficient question answering systems that can adapt to user preferences and feedback.

title: Efficient Online Learning with Adaptive Gradient Clipping for Robust Deep Neural Networks
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to exploding gradients, which can lead to unstable training and poor generalization. This paper proposes an online learning algorithm, 'AdaClip', that adaptively clips gradients based on the local curvature of the loss landscape. We introduce a novel metric, 'gradient fragility', to quantify the sensitivity of gradients to parameter updates. Experimental results on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets demonstrate that AdaClip converges faster and achieves improved robustness to adversarial attacks compared to state-of-the-art gradient clipping methods.

title: Hierarchical Attention Networks for Explainable Multi-Task Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-task learning has been widely adopted in various applications, but the lack of interpretability limits its usage in high-stakes domains. This paper proposes a hierarchical attention network (HAN) framework that learns task-specific and shared representations simultaneously, enabling explainable multi-task learning. Our approach incorporates a novel attention mechanism that dynamically weights task relationships, allowing the model to focus on relevant tasks and features. Experimental results on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HAN outperforms state-of-the-art models while providing insightful feature importance scores and task correlation analysis.

title: Hybrid Ranking Model for Efficient Document Retrieval in Distributed Search Systems
paper_abstract: Distributed search systems pose significant challenges in terms of scalability, efficiency, and accuracy. This paper presents a novel hybrid ranking model, 'Hydra', which combines the strengths of both neural and traditional ranking methods. Hydra leverages a neural network-based approach for document representation and a probabilistic ranking model for efficient scoring. Our experiments on a large-scale web corpus demonstrate that Hydra outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of mean average precision and query latency, while reducing computational overhead by up to 30%.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi--relational Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) aims to represent entities and relations in a low-dimensional vector space. However, existing methods struggle to capture complex relationships between entities. We propose HierGA, a novel hierarchical graph attention network that learnspatterns at multiple scales. Our approach leverages both entity and relation attention mechanisms to capture multi-relational dependencies. Experimental results on benchmark datasets show that HierGA outperforms state-of-the-art KGE methods, achieving significant improvements in link prediction and triple classification tasks.

title: Efficient Multi-Agent Pathfinding using Graph Neural Networks and Hierarchical Planning
paper_abstract: Multi-agent pathfinding is a challenging problem in AI research, particularly in domains with complex spatial constraints. This paper proposes a novel approach that combines graph neural networks (GNNs) with hierarchical planning to efficiently compute collision-free paths for multiple agents. Our method, 'HGN-Path', leverages GNNs to learn a hierarchical representation of the environment, which is then used to guide a hierarchical planning algorithm. Experimental results on various multi-agent scenarios demonstrate that HGN-Path outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of solution quality and computational efficiency.

title: Adversarial Robustness in Deep Reinforcement Learning via Multi-Agent Exploration
paper_abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) has achieved remarkable success in complex decision-making tasks, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains a significant concern. This paper proposes a novel approach to improve the robustness of DRL agents by leveraging multi-agent exploration. We introduce a framework, 'ROAM', which encourages agents to explore diverse trajectories and learn from each other's experiences. Our method effectively increases the model's robustness to adversarial perturbations while maintaining its performance in the nominal environment. Experimental results on various Atari games demonstrate the effectiveness of ROAM in enhancing the robustness of DRL agents.

title: Robust Image Classification with Adaptive Ensemble Learning and Noisy Label Handling
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks are prone to overfitting when trained on noisy or mislabeled datasets. This paper presents a novel ensemble learning framework, 'AdaNoisy', which adaptively combines the predictions of multiple base models to improve robustness against noisy labels. Our approach utilizes a confidence-based weighting scheme, where the weights are learned dynamically during training. We also introduce a noisy label detection module that identifies and corrects mislabeled instances. Experimental results on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that AdaNoisy achieves state-of-the-art performance on image classification tasks, even in the presence of high label noise ratios.

title: Designing Intelligible Embodied Conversational Agents for Healthcare Communication
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to improve healthcare communication, but their lack of transparency and explainability hinders trust and adoption. This paper presents a human-centered design approach to create intelligible ECAs that facilitate collaborative decision-making between patients and healthcare providers. We propose a framework that integrates cognitive architectures, natural language processing, and multimodal interaction to enable ECAs to provide clear explanations of their decision-making processes. A user study with 30 participants shows that our approach increases user trust and satisfaction with ECA-mediated healthcare communication.

title: Deep Query Reformulation for Efficient Document Retrieval in Knowledge Graphs
paper_abstract: Knowledge graphs have become a vital component in modern information retrieval systems, enabling the incorporation of semantic relationships between entities. However, the complexity of query formulation and the sheer scale of these graphs hinder efficient document retrieval. This paper proposes a novel deep learning-based approach, 'QueryRefine', which leverages attention mechanisms and graph convolutional networks to reformulate user queries. We demonstrate that QueryRefine significantly improves retrieval efficiency and accuracy by reducing the search space and identifying relevant entities. Experiments on a large-scale knowledge graph dataset show that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving a 23% increase in mean average precision.

title: Autonomous Task Allocation in Dynamic Multi-Agent Systems using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel approach to autonomous task allocation in dynamic multi-agent systems using reinforcement learning. We present a decentralized framework, 'RL-Allocator', that enables agents to learn optimal task assignments in real-time, adapting to changing environmental conditions and agent availability. Our approach leverages a multi-agent Q-learning algorithm, which incorporates local and global state information to minimize task completion times and maximize overall system efficiency. Experimental results on a simulated disaster response scenario demonstrate the effectiveness of RL-Allocator in reducing task completion times by up to 30% compared to traditional auction-based allocation methods.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Deep Neural Networks for Ad-Hoc Retrieval
paper_abstract: Ad-hoc retrieval remains a challenging task in Information Retrieval (IR) due to the inherent ambiguity of user queries. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach leveraging deep neural networks to capture semantic relationships between query terms and relevant documents. Our model, 'DeepQE', incorporates a transformer-based architecture to learn context-aware term representations, which are then used to generate an expanded query set. Experimental results on the TREC-8 Ad-Hoc Retrieval dataset demonstrate that DeepQE outperforms state-of-the-art query expansion techniques, achieving a significant improvement in mean average precision.

title: EyeTrackingLens: Enhancing Web Accessibility through Real-time Gaze-based Interaction
paper_abstract: Individuals with motor impairments face significant challenges when interacting with web applications. This paper presents EyeTrackingLens, a novel web browser extension that leverages real-time gaze tracking to enable intuitive, hands-free interaction. Our approach utilizes a machine learning-based gaze estimation model, which is fine-tuned on a large dataset of eye movement patterns. We evaluate EyeTrackingLens on a range of web tasks, demonstrating improved accessibility and usability for users with motor impairments. Our results show that EyeTrackingLens reduces interaction time by 35% and error rate by 45% compared to traditional assistive technologies.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Multi-Relational Knowledge Graph Embedding
paper_abstract: Knowledge graph embedding (KGE) has gained significant attention in recent years due to its ability to capture complex relationships between entities. However, existing KGE methods struggle to effectively model multi-relational graphs, leading to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAN) for KGE, which leverages attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant relational patterns. We evaluate HGAN on several benchmark datasets and demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art KGE methods, achieving significant improvements in link prediction and entity classification tasks.

title: Task-Oriented Dialogue Systems with Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks
paper_abstract: Task-oriented dialogue systems have revolutionized human-computer interaction, but existing models struggle to capture complex relationships between user goals, dialogue history, and external knowledge. This paper proposes a novel Hierarchical Graph Attention Network (HGAT) architecture, which models dialogue as a hierarchical graph and incorporates attention mechanisms to selectively focus on relevant nodes. We demonstrate that HGAT outperforms state-of-the-art models on three benchmark datasets, achieving significant improvements in task success rate and response quality. Additionally, we provide an in-depth analysis of HGAT's ability to generalize to unseen domains and tasks.

title: Efficient Query Expansion using Hierarchical Document Embeddings for Patent Retrieval
paper_abstract: Patent retrieval is a challenging task due to the complexities of patent documents and the need for precise query matching. This paper proposes a novel query expansion approach, HierPat, which leverages hierarchical document embeddings to capture the semantic relationships between patent documents. Our method represents documents as hierarchical graph structures, allowing for more effective capture of context and subtleties in patent language. Experimental results on a large patent corpus demonstrate significant improvements in retrieval precision and recall compared to state-of-the-art baseline methods.

title: Hierarchical Graph Attention Networks for Scalable Zero-Shot Learning
paper_abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) has gained significant attention in recent years, but existing methods often struggle to scale to large datasets and complex tasks. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical graph attention network (HGAT) architecture, which leverages graph-based attention mechanisms to model relationships between seen and unseen classes. HGAT learns to selectively focus on relevant semantic features and adaptively transfer knowledge from seen classes to unseen ones. Experimental results on four benchmark datasets demonstrate that HGAT achieves state-of-the-art performance in ZSL tasks, outperforming existing methods by a significant margin.

title: Efficient Query Optimization for Multi-Tenant Database Systems Using Reinforcement Learning
paper_abstract: Multi-tenant database systems have become increasingly popular in cloud computing, but query optimization remains a significant challenge. Existing approaches often rely on rule-based or cost-based optimization, which can lead to suboptimal performance. This paper proposes a novel query optimization framework, 'RL-Opt', that leverages reinforcement learning to adaptively select the most efficient execution plans. We design a Markov decision process to model the query optimization problem and develop a deep Q-network to learn the optimal policy. Experimental results on a real-world dataset demonstrate that RL-Opt outperforms state-of-the-art query optimizers by up to 30% in terms of execution time and resource utilization.

title: Efficient Passage Retrieval with Hierarchical Dense Retrieval for Open-Domain Question Answering
paper_abstract: Open-domain question answering (ODQA) relies on effective passage retrieval to provide accurate answers. This paper proposes a novel hierarchical dense retrieval (HDR) framework, which leverages a two-stage approach to efficiently retrieve relevant passages from a large corpus. Our method first uses a coarse-grained dense retriever to select top-k passages, followed by a fine-grained retriever that re-ranks the passages using a hierarchical interaction mechanism. Experimental results on the Natural Questions dataset demonstrate that HDR achieves significant improvements in terms of retrieval accuracy and efficiency, while reducing the computational overhead compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Gaze-Based Interaction for Augmented Reality: A Study on User Experience and Performance
paper_abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology has the potential to revolutionize the way we interact with digital information. However, existing input methods, such as touch-based interfaces, can be limiting and cumbersome. This paper explores the use of gaze-based interaction as a novel input modality for AR applications. We designed and evaluated a gaze-based interface using a wearable AR device and conducted a user study to assess its usability, performance, and user experience. Our results show that gaze-based interaction can significantly reduce task completion time and improve user satisfaction compared to traditional input methods, highlighting its potential for future AR applications.

title: Distributed Cooperative Search in Multi-Agent Systems using Conflict-Based Search
paper_abstract: This paper proposes a novel distributed cooperative search algorithm for multi-agent systems. Our approach, called DistriCBS, is based on Conflict-Based Search (CBS) and enables multiple agents to search for a common goal while avoiding conflicts. We introduce a decentralized conflict detection mechanism that allows agents to dynamically adjust their search strategies. Experimental results on various benchmark problems demonstrate the efficiency and scalability of DistriCBS, outperforming existing distributed search algorithms in terms of solution quality and computation time.

title: Evaluating the Impact of Haptic Feedback on Gesture Recognition in Virtual Reality
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has become increasingly popular, but gesture recognition remains a challenging task. This paper investigates the effect of haptic feedback on gesture recognition in VR environments. We designed a user study with 30 participants, where they performed a set of pre-defined gestures with and without haptic feedback. Our results show that haptic feedback significantly improves gesture recognition accuracy, reducing errors by 23.4%. We also found that participants reported higher satisfaction and engagement levels when haptic feedback was provided. Our findings have implications for the design of more immersive and interactive VR experiences.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults with Visual Impairments
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to revolutionize healthcare, education, and entertainment for older adults. However, existing VR interfaces often exclude individuals with visual impairments, limiting accessibility and usability. This paper presents an inclusive VR interface design framework, 'VR4All', tailored to the needs of older adults with visual impairments. We conducted a mixed-methods study involving participatory design workshops and usability testing with 20 participants. Our results show that VR4All significantly improves task completion rates and user satisfaction compared to commercial VR interfaces. We also identify key design recommendations for VR interfaces that cater to the diverse needs of older adults.

title: Embodied Conversational Agents for Inclusive Healthcare: A Study on Multimodal Interaction
paper_abstract: Embodied conversational agents (ECAs) have the potential to revolutionize healthcare by providing personalized support and therapy. However, existing ECAs often neglect the needs of individuals with disabilities. This paper presents a novel ECA framework, 'IncluBot', which integrates multimodal interaction capabilities to facilitate inclusive healthcare. We conducted a user study with 30 participants, including individuals with visual and hearing impairments, to evaluate the effectiveness of IncluBot in promoting engagement and trust. Our results show that IncluBot outperforms traditional text-based agents in terms of user satisfaction and perceived empathy.

title: Designing Inclusive Virtual Reality Interfaces for Older Adults: A Participatory Approach
paper_abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has the potential to improve the lives of older adults, but existing interfaces often exclude this demographic due to physical and cognitive limitations. This paper presents a participatory design approach to create inclusive VR interfaces for older adults. We conducted a series of co-design workshops with older adults to identify design requirements and preferences. Our results show that older adults prefer intuitive, voice-based interactions and clear, high-contrast visual cues. We developed and evaluated a VR prototype incorporating these design principles, achieving significant improvements in user engagement and task performance compared to existing VR interfaces.

title: Efficient Detection of Adversarial Attacks on Deep Neural Networks using Bayesian Uncertainty
paper_abstract: Deep neural networks (DNNs) are vulnerable to adversarial attacks, which can be detrimental in safety-critical applications. This paper presents a novel approach for detecting such attacks by leveraging Bayesian uncertainty estimates. We propose a probabilistic framework, 'BayesDefend', that models the uncertainty of DNN predictions and identifies abnormal input samples. Our method achieves state-of-the-art detection performance on several benchmark datasets, outperforming existing methods by up to 15% in terms of area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC-ROC). We also demonstrate the effectiveness of BayesDefend in real-world scenarios, including image classification and natural language processing tasks.

title: Coordinating Autonomous Agents with Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Task Allocation
paper_abstract: In multi-agent systems, efficient task allocation is crucial for achieving collective goals. This paper proposes a novel approach, 'AdaTask', which leverages reinforcement learning to coordinate autonomous agents in dynamic environments. AdaTask uses a decentralized, actor-critic architecture to learn optimal task assignments based on individual agent capabilities, task priorities, and environmental constraints. We evaluate AdaTask in a simulated disaster response scenario, demonstrating improved task completion rates and reduced communication overhead compared to traditional, manually-programmed allocation strategies.
